It wasn't the typical BYOB environment, it was quite small and we felt like our group was the only participating in the BYOB and having fun (a.k.a. being loud and obnoxious).  If you are looking for good food, everyone loved their pizza but all were a little more on the well done side (burn marks from the woodfire I assume?).If you are looking for a big group BYOB I wouldn't say this is the place since we felt quite out of place but I think it is the perfect spot for a date and a quiet bottle of wine.
Fantastic pizza, fresh ingredients in a more intimate atmosphere. Highly recommended!

This was our first time to this Pizzeria based in the heart of Lincoln Park. My wife and I were searching for a great, truly authentic Italian pizza. La Crosta delivers. We had the Mushroom and Truffle White pizza and the Sausage and Pepperoni Red pizza. Both tasty, great flavor and light crust. Delicious. We also had there specialty dessert. Again, delicious. We had a chance to meet and talk with Dino. Solid guy with a great deal of passion for his business which shows in his food. We drove 45 minutes for the experience and it was well worth it. We'll be back.Highly recommend.

We had the burrata as an appetizer which was amazing. Creamy and fresh. We then had the spicy coppa red pizza and mushroom white pizza. The crust was crispy on the edge with the perfect ratio of dough and toppings. The meat was delicious- you could tell it was authentic. Dino, the owner, confirmed that all the ingredients are from Italy. Yum! The ambience is cozy and welcoming as are the staff. I will definitely be back next time I'm in town.
Great crust. I always like it more well done but it was so tasty.Nice space, friendly service. Good location if you are going to theaters nearby.
Top notch.   Really enjoyed the good food and atmosphere.    Very nice place to have a Sunday dinner with the family.
The pizza is consistently amazing and the service is exceptional. Love the margherita and calabrese sopressata. Not much else to say really.

My friend recommended La Crosta to me and I am so glad she did!! We stopped in on Sunday night and I thought the place was just adorable!! Super cozy, great date spot or a place to go with some friends. BYOB. The arugula salad was amazing and good to share for two people. We ordered a pizza and it came out fast which was really nice, and we also finished it so fast that we had to order another one!! The food is light, fresh, and delicious. I highly recommend stopping by and having dinner!!

We were in the area Saturday night looking for a place to eat and watch Hawk game.  We walked by La Crosta, it was exactly what we were looking for.  We sat down ordered a drink only to find it was BYOB.  No problem, a patron poured my wife a glass of prosecco as I walked across the street to buy beer.  We ordered the bruschetta and caesar salad to start. Bruschetta had perfect balance plus drizzle of balsamic.  Caesar was not shy on garlic.We tried the truffle burrata and margherita pizza's, both exceptional flavor, the crust was nice and crispy. The owner Dino, was very engaging.  Looking forward to coming back with friends and family.

Tried a cheese & sausage pizza here earlier this week.  Very nice flaky, bubbling crust, excellent sauce - just a hint of tanginess.  Atmosphere had a warm vibe.  Earth tones with slight rustic feel made it seem like a nice place to go on a cold day.  Good date night place.

Went here on a Sunday night for a quiet dinner and it was delicious! This is the closest to Italian pizza I've had since leaving Italy. The atmosphere was nice and it being a BYOB restaurant doesn't hurt either. Would definitely recommend - really yummy pizza!

The five star rating on this place is baffling. The service was decent, but the food was terrible. My husband and I ordered bruschetta as an appetizer and it was plated beautifully, but it was incredibly salty. We also ordered a margharita pizza with sausage. It had so much olive oil on top that the crust was sopping wet. Each time we went to grab a piece of pizza, all of the toppings slid off because it was slathered in oil. Needless to say we left feeling hungry because we didn't finish either of the items that we ordered. Utterly disappointing.
The staff were delightful and the pizza was a treat. I highly recommend the Calabrese.
Incredible!  I will return again and again and again...  Authentic - fresh - delicious!

My friend and I just went to this great little BYOB pizzeria in Lincoln Park- La Crosta Woodfire. It was absolutely delicious and felt so cozy inside. We ordered the House Salad which was a great starter, especially because it wasn't drenched with dressing. Then, Dino- the owner- suggested we taste the Margherita and Portabella pizzas. I usually prefer a protein on my pizza, but no need...these were filling, hearty, and hit the spot!And to add a cherry on top, Dino was kind enough to surprise us with a new dessert- Bomba- 3 flavors of ice cream, covered in chocolate.Very personable staff, great food- easily one of my fave pizzas now...glad they deliver, and can't wait to try Due Carni next time!!

We are frequent regulars to this great new LP spot for this style pizza.  Service always consistent and the product is always tasty.  Must try the dessert pizza as well. The owner, Dino will accommodate your request and BYOB makes it all perfect!

Delicious food in a nice atmosphere. The ingredients are fresh and of the highest quality. Terrific brushetta appetizer and excellent pizza were highlights. The Nutella dessert was a  amazingly tasty treat!
Charming, quaint atmosphere. Perfectly fired thin crust pizza with delicious toppings. Lovely staff. I wish I lived closer - I'd be here all the time!

Great BYOB pizza place. They were very accommodating for our group of 12 on a Friday night. Food is great. We all enjoyed the burrata and bruschetta appetizers. We pretty much ordered a pizza each as they are Neapolitan style and very thin, but you could probably get away with two pizzas for every three people. My personal favorite was the pepperoni and sausage pizza, the Due Carne. I will definitely be back.

The red sauce is the best I have ever had. I asked where they get the tomatoes and they are imported from Napoli. The spicy soppresatta is incredible and the crust is perfect Neapolitan style. I have had 50+ different pizzas in Chicago and worked in the industry for  four years so I like to consider myself qualified. The only comparable pizza is Spaccia Napoli. If La Crosta can stand the test of time, I think they have the product to earn the reputation as the best.
Great atmosphere and delicious food - we had the Truffle Burrata and an order of Bruschetta.
We always have yummy fresh food, and the owner is very nice and attentive. It is a nice little neighborhood place.

Delicious food, great family atmosphere. Owner was very welcoming and provided solid recommendations for our order. Quality of the ingredients was excellent. Our party of four shared two appetizers, two pizzas, and a dessert. The mozzarella and sauce used on the pizzas was so flavorful. Will definitely be returning!

Great Pizza.  Very accommodating of folks with diet limitations.  The artichoke appetizer was to die for.  Dino, the owner/chef came to our table and chatted.  He really seems to know what he's doing and what he wants this Pizzeria to become.  Bravo!

100% authentic wood-fired Italian pizza.  We generally go to Spacca Napoli and having lived in Italy for a few years we have opinions about real Italian pizza being served in the US.  Spacca Napoli were booked and we live around the corner from La Crosta - so we thought that we would give it a try.  WOW - really great pizza and crust (the most important part).  The owner has thought through all the ingredients and processes for making a true pizza.  A pizza expert might not like the decisions that he has made, but the pizzas are the real deal and very, very, very good.  We think this place is in the top 2 - now Spacca Napoli and La Crosta.

Awesome pizza!  Tastes just like some we had in Italy.  The calabrese soppressata is delicious and I love their fresh tomato sauce and how the pizzas aren't loaded with sauce or cheese.  I love that its BYOB and heard they are getting their liquor license...I wish it would stay byob :)

La Crosta is pleasing the minute you walk through the door. It was a Saturday night around 6:00 pm when my boyfriend and I walked into La Crosta for the first time. We were greeted by a friendly hostess and quickly seated. The menu is one page which tells me that everything on it is done with great care and pride. We ordered two pizzas as we were unable to decide on one. My favorite was the artichoke pizza. Dino, the owner, came to our table to check on us and helped us with some suggestions. The atmosphere in La Crosta is so cozy we stayed for chocolate cake and espressos. Great work Dino, Kristen and staff!
Ive been waiting for a good neopolitan pizza place to show up ever since sapori di napoli closed like 5 years ago. This is it. BYOB FTW.
Literally amazing. The pizza. The service. Everything. Especially the truffle pizza with mushrooms- wow
Only tried the Margherita and Sopprasetta but both of them were superb. BYOB and nice atmosphere.

Seriously, this place! It's killing me. I attempted to visit Bang Bang in Logan, but to my dismay it was closed when I went. Now, I have had Bang Bang's biscuits....at Honey Butter Fried Chicken. It was for a collaboration they did and it was frucking delicious. I have also had Bang Bang pie....at Parson's. Hmmmm. I am just now seeing the pattern myself. Anyhow....So you see, I was familiar with Bang Bang's delicious offerings. I've just never enjoyed them at their actual brick & mortar....until today. This location opened not too long ago. It's a lot closer to me than Logan Square so SCORE!I met my pal for lunch and I have to say, this could be new favorite lunch spot. They had some acoustic guitar action going on, which was quite nice. I like the mix of cafe tables, casual couch seating and communal picnic table seating.But the biscuit specials! Whoa. They all sounded wonderful. I woofed down my biscuit sandwich which consisted of candied bacon, collard green, poached egg and hot sauce. I'm also declaring the best hash browns ever. A slice of butterscotch meringue pie to-go rounded out my order.Clearly, it was carb day today. But everyday is carb day at Bang Bang and I will be back to represent!

I have made the trek out to the Logan Square shop twice; it was worth the wait, but one helluva of a ride on public transit - 65 minutes! When I found out they opened a second location closer to me, I was through the moon. Now it only takes me a brief walk and a bus ride - a trip totaling 25-30 minutes - to get my hands on those delectable biscuits. Plus, the lines at the Logan Square shop can get ridiculously long, while the Ravenswood shop has the perfect balance of busy, but a shorter wait time.Since white carbs are my favorite food group, it's no surprise that Bang Bang's infamous biscuits have landed on my list of top eats in Chicago. They are soft, buttery and melt-in-your-mouth levels of deliciousness! Plus, I love the rotating selection of flavored butters and seasonal jams that accompany the biscuits.Bang Bang does offer a quality pie selection, but I admit that nothing I have had so far has jumped out at me or caught my attention the way their biscuits have. I think First Slice and Mama Hoosier's are equally as good - if not better in some areas - hence why I cannot give Bang Bang the full five stars.But the real star at Bang Bang are those biscuits. Dare I say the best in Chicago?
Really good biscuits and pies, paired with the worst coffee known to man.Will come back. But will bring my own café.

Love this place! A little out the way for us but so glad we made the trip.What we ordered:Harvest Grits - The best way I can describe this is "fall in a dish". Anything and everything that reminds you of fall you can experience with this.  highly recommend.Avocado biscuit - meh! skip this. I actually enjoyed eating these separately.  I ended up separating the avocado and had the biscuits after asking for some jam and butter on the side.brisket biscuit - GET THIS! hubs' order.  very tasty and he was happy with it.  He also stated that the pickle that it came with is was one of the best he's had.Service was excellent here.  You basically order, take a seat and they bring the food for you.  They were still very attentive even though they didn't have to be!  One of the waiters even made a list of recommended restaurants for us with the few days we had left.

Just wow, the food here and the casual communal environment here is great.My favorites are the "Chicken Pot Pie" and the "Biscuits and Gravy". I highly recommend you try this place if you're in the neighborhood, I have never been to the original Pie and Biscuit location, but if this little shop is any reflection of it, then it must taste amazing.I would definitely come again for a casual meal with friends.

Small and cozy hipster-esque nook in Lincoln Square...What I did enjoy--Very friendly staff that made a point of greeting everyone that walked in the shop.  We were even greeted with free samples upon arrival.-Cute leather couch and fireplace in the middle of the café that gave it a "homey feel".-You do not have to bus your own table at the end.-Biscuits were delicious...imagine a McDonalds breakfast biscuit only on a gourmet level.  The jelly and butter that accompanied it were very tasty.Why I gave it only 3 stars--The menu was pretty small and I found the food to be pretty bland overall.-The grits had no seasoning.  I found myself adding quite a few shakes of salt.-I really cannot speak on the pie as I didn't try it.  There was no way for me to see the pies before ordering so I wasn't going to chance it.

*This is more like 4.5 and probably will be a 5 after one more visit.Being a bang bang aficionado there is no question I had to come to a place with "Bang Bang" in their name and boy oh boy am I glad that I did (for those unaware of the glory that is a bang bang, I recommend Googling "Louis CK bang bang" for further education on the subject). I was hoping to go to their original location first since I prefer trying the first spot to open for an establishment before checking out additional locations, but I was running out of time in Chi and was within walking distance from here so this location had to do. Man oh man, it was so freaking good!I walked in and was greeted by the smells of freshly baked biscuits and I already felt I was in store for something special. Their sausage biscuit with lavender blue berry jam, plus an added egg, was ridiculously good. You know those moments when you first taste something and it's just undeniably good. This was one of those moments. It brought smiles to my face with each bite. I would like to try their other biscuits which sound fantastic too, but I would have to get this one again first next time.Unfortunately, I was not the biggest fan of their chocolate pecan pie, which sounded great. It was very moist, but way too sweet and molasses-y for my liking. Aside from that and in addition to the stupendous sausage biscuit, the staff was really nice and the space had a warm, funky, and inviting feel to it. Can't wait to come back next time I'm in town!

I was so excited to see that they opened a bang bang in Ravenswood!The restaurant is bigger than the Logan Square location, but without the outdoor seating.There is one large communal table, a couch area that could fit about 4-5 and then a few small tables in the front.The restaurant is clean, but I don't think they have a/c, it was pretty hot in there. I wish they had longer hours, they close so early!

This place was amazing. We came in just before closing time and they let us stay. We asked for them to guide us through the menu and make recommendations since it was our first time.We had the avocado and ham biscuit sandwiches, fancy grits, pecan pie, honey pie, and peach pie.All of it was amazing. Come hungry, add egg, add bacon, enjoy.

Yum!  Came here with 2 friends for a late lunch on a Saturday.  We had the brisket biscuit, ham biscuit, and the chicken pot pie as our meals.  Their biscuits are so good, I didn't even really need the sandwich fillings.  My brisket biscuit had a lot of meat...like...maybe too much.  And I like meat...but hey, too much is better than too little, so I'll just stop there.  Then, we shared 2 slices of pie - the butterscotch meringue, and the special which was a chocolate vanilla malt pie.  OMG.  Both were so good!  I took a slice of the chocolate vanilla malt home to my husband and shared it with him.  I like this location - no wait, more inside seating, and much more comfortable than the Logan Square spot.

This place is located right next to a popular breakfast and brunch spot called Over Easy. We stopped by this place as the wait for Over Easy was approximately an hour. This place was cute and the ingredients in their food was fresh.We ordered the candy bacon and gravy. The gravy came in tin to-go container consisting of two biscuits with their gravy smothered in top and sausage sprinkled all around the biscuits. The candy bacon was good. Not too sweet either and it made the flavor of the bacon pop! The gravy was delicious as well combined with the biscuit and sausage. It was hard to keep that all food on the fork. We washed it down with strawberry lemonade. It was tart but still good. You can add sugar to it as well if it is too tart for you.

My friend lives close by so we decided to come by for brunch. Several biscuit varieties available. The sausage biscuit is ok. Biscuit itself is nice consistency and soft. Sausage patty was a little hard. The maple bourbon pecan pie was phenomenal. Such a great balance of flavors, with a nice crunch!

I commend Bang Bang's service team this a.m.I already knew the food was going to be excellent, having purchased a to-go pie a few months ago. My boyfriend and I came in this a.m. hoping for a quick, in and out breakfast. As anticipated it was busy, but the lack of seating was due to customers lingering and socializing. The staff members kept track of our position in "cue" to be seated, and rather than rushing loitering custumers, they secured us get priority seating, then awarded our patience with a slice of their excellent pie.My boyfriend isn't a fan of restaurants whose procedures call for customer purchase, then seating, but due to this service team's dilligence and consideration, this was pleasant experience and we will be guaranteed regulars.Thanks again for the wonderful experience, staff!

What an adorable place to get a slice of good 'ol pie.First of all the decor is adorbs. Secondly the people who work there are also adorbs (hellooo hipsters). Most importantly their pie is delish, although on the sweet side. My friend and I shared a slice of the lemon chess pie with pistachio and the passion fruit. Passion fruit is BOMB guys, gotta get it! Definitely wanna go back and try their biscuits.I have a few complaints though: why am I paying $5 to $6 for a sliver of pie? I mean it's good for my waste line but how can you deny people the joy of pie? Also, why are you closed at 4pm on the weekends? I want dessert after dinner, damn it!Oh well, guess I can't complain because their pies are pretty damn good :P

What can I say that hasn't already been said about the bang bang pie franchise? It's just plain delicious.Went in after a trip on the brown line (never realized there was one closer to us) and couldn't wait to get everything...Problem is, you can order a lot not realizing your eyes are too big for your stomach.  We fell victim of this circumstance during this run unfortunately.Ordered the "Smokin Chix" and the "fancy grits". Never realized blueberries could complement the cheesy concoction, but it was a nice marriage of salty and sweet. Add some hot sauce, and you have nirvana.Chicken was cooked perfectly. Super juicy with a crispy skin.

Went on a beautiful weekday morning. Plenty of seating and a friendly face at the counter who walked us through some recommendations.  $35 later we received our food. That's when I understood the divided yelp comments on this place.We had the biscuit w/ sausage and egg. It was easily enough for two regular appetites. The biscuit was very good and very dense. The sharp cheese on the sausage was a nice flavor hit, but all together it was surprisingly bland. Ditto on the "not so fancy cheddar cheese grits". Even with a dousing of the supplied hot sauce, they were just okay.Then we bussed our table.Overall impression: solid, but not stand-out, food. And about 25% too pricey for what you receive. Nice neighborly ambiance.

DAMN that is some GOOD BISCUITS-n-PIE!  You can get just a biscuit with the regular stuff like jam/butter/honey or get one with more interesting toppings. The Hubs & I each tried a different biscuit topping and loved them both.  Their biscuits are often described as being like pound-cake but not as sweet and I'd say that is a good description but I'd just go with HEAVENLY PERFECTION in biscuit form.  We also planned on sharing a piece of pie, and did, but lucky us we got a slice for free which was nice.  The lady who brought it over said it was because it was our first time there but I think it was a combo of that & the fact that we had just walked many blocks in an absolute downpour thunderstorm to try them for breakfast.  Whatever the reason it was a much appreciated and promptly devoured slice of Key Lime Pie.The only thing holding me back from giving them 5 stars is the communal seating.  Sorry, not a fan of that type of seating, especially when it's a place that is popular and often busy/crowded.  Yes, you can cram a few more bodies in with the communal seating but my misanthrope self doesn't want to get chummy with the other diners or listen in on whatever gossip/drama the gals next to us are discussing.  Oh well.  The deliciousness of the food temporarily distracted me from the sardine seating. ;)

Day 271: Bang Bang Pie and Biscuits: I like pie. I like biscuits. So it should not be a surprise that when a place that emphasized both in its title opened within walking distance, I would eventually find my way there.The decor of the establishment is eclectic, almost aggressively so. It was relatively calm when we came in, so we had our choice of the communal tables, the barstools, the tiny bistro tables, and the giant leather chairs in front of the low coffee table that, frankly, I never quite understood how people were able to eat from. I ordered the Sausage Biscuit with an egg on top, got our table number and settled down to wait. The food came out pretty quickly, though, since my hot-chicken ordering table-mate got hers about five minutes before I did, they comped us a slice of Key Lime Pie, which, y'know, I'll take it!As expected, the biscuits were great and the pie was great. The sausage on the sausage biscuit, however, was a little flavorless and dry which was disappointing, but the poached egg on top and home-made jam on the side can and did make up for a lot. It might not be a place for a daily stop, but if the outdoor patio gets approved, I could definitely see it being a large part of this summer.

Bang bang, delicious.Small, cozy spot dishing out mad biscuits. Try a daily special to spice things up. There's not much more to say about this spot that hasn't already been said. Tasty, filling (this is a 'special treat' kinda place for me), decently priced. Maybe a little more ventilation would do them good, cause I walked out smelling like bacon biscuits?Great staff, to boot.
In for breakfast this morning  and the Gravy and sausage biscuit with everything was delicious. Had a bite if the cheezy grits as well, yum.

All of it. Amazing. Fantastic. Have never eaten (since the first time at the original bang bang) such amazing and delicious biscuits. We had the amazing BLT with candied bacon and fresh tomatoes. We had a pie flight of every kind of pie they were serving that day.  We had the grits of the day.  Oh my gosh I've never eaten pickled blueberries which were on top of the grits! Along with corn fresh off the cob and some feta cheese. Oh my gosh so delicious. And the staff from the manager to the chef who was busy teaching his next assistant they all rock. Love this location. Bigger. Love the decor. Love the food. Love the people who work there. Loved our experience. Can't wait to go again.

Disappointed since this is really a cute hipster stop in Lincoln Square and I love pie & biscuits.Service was fine but the pie and biscuits were just not that great for the price.  There is so much hype surrounding BBP that I guess I had higher expectations.  Biscuits had a nice texture and size but they were way to salty and accompanied by a less than stellar runny flavorless jam.  Pie was good but not great especially with a $5 price per slice.I've just had much better pie at a lower cost elsewhere in the city.

Let me get this out of the way: FIRST FIRST FIRST FIRST FIRSTImagine that goes on for awhile, also that I'm chanting it triumphantly on my couch. Couch is long and blue. I'm wearing some new jeans that have really energized me.7:50 a.m. In bathtub. Boyfriend is creaking around, up earlier than usual. He pokes his head in. He says he has an idea. Me: Bang Bang Pie? Him: Well...Me: yes!Actually, he wants ME to go to Bang Bang, collect savory breakfast items ("one savory AND one sweet."), and return. I get dressed.8 a.m. Small unrelated fight. I refuse to get breakfast out of principle.8:10 a.m. We hug it out.8:30 a.m. Not unreasonable line at Bang Bang. Many baby carriages. The wind is colder than normal, colder than May. I relax outside, unconcerned by the line. Various neighborhood residents shuffle the strollers around, snap them closed.8:35 a.m. Inside Bang Bang. Unlike Over Easy, the atmosphere is surprisingly relaxed. Since Dolce closed, I missed the tin ceiling here and the subway tile to the ceiling. Even though there is a line, it is moving quickly and efficiently. This is not their first rodeo (or location.) Their staff is trained, friendly and efficient. The neighborhood has missed this café. We are happy to have a new coffee shop, excited it also has food, cautious it might all be taken away at any moment. Credit cards are being swiped with no complaints.8:40 a.m. Taking in the menu, the food is a lot less portable then I had hoped. Other than the chicken pot pie, I don't see any vegetarian savory pies. I hope for more portable savory options in the future. But I'm happy to see carry-out packing is on point: paper bags with handles, they have made it what seems to not be portable food very convenient and easy to transport.8:45 a.m. Already ordering! the owner (or manager) is super friendly and relaxed, makes a point of introducing himself and asking if I live in the hood. I scooped a yogurt and granola from the fridge, don't miss this bonus material. Otherwise you'll notice the food is leaning on the heavier side, appropriate for the concept ...Got the fancy grits and chicken and biscuit to go. They have cleared out the space in an intelligent way to make room for waiting and foot traffic. One long farm table mostly occupied by families with many small children, addition to some traditional two tops and the fireplace lounge area. So glad they kept that. The only design decision I don't really agree with is building a wood facade up to the ceiling around the fireplace. A lot of money for no good reason, covering up the beautiful brick chimney.8:47 a.m. Self-serve coffee? Is this heaven? Also love that they have one huge thing of whole milk. They even have a little carafe of almond milk, acknowledging whatever that means for you.9 a.m. Eating at home, the grits are great - substantial in portion size, I would get some extra hot sauce to go next time, it's delicious! the collard greens are lovely but I could've used a few more veggies. I love poached eggs so I'm glad that is the standard option here. I didn't try the chicken and biscuits so I can't speak to that, but I love pimento cheese.9:25 a.m. Excited to try bang bang again, next time I'm just going to go for the classic biscuit and jam, only three dollars, and maybe supplement with an egg.Welcome to Ravenswood, Bang Bang, the most polite neighborhood in Chicago.

"Please sir I want some more." (Charles Dickens, 1837) This is what you will be saying after a visit to BBP&B shop.There is more than a whiff of the deep South here. Biscuits and gravy are delicious. The gravy is the creamy kind you find on chicken fried steak and is said to be vegetarian. It has a peppery kick and is served over a soft biscuit, with a hard biscuit on the side. Cheesy grits are delicious. The grits have bite and substance and the cheese smooths the dish out. Rhubarb pie has icing, something I haven't seen before, but when it comes to desserts, pile it on. The crust is crispy and there is some tartness left in the pie from the rhubarb (but not a lot; it's very very sweet, almost too sweet).Service is very friendly, the kind that calls you by name. The shop is small but has a number of nice features, like a sofa, fireplace, communal table, and a chandelier. It will be extremely cozy during the long Chicago winter. In the meantime, I am sure Bang Bang will make a splash, in Ravenswood or wherever it chooses to open a new location.

Overpriced. Their chicken sandwich was way too much for the size it was- it wouldn't even fill a toddler up. Grits were ok but again overpriced. I will say their pie is tasty and their service is good- but definitely not a bang for your buck.

I heard so many great things about the Logan Square location, so when this location opened up down the street from my place I HAD to check it out. It definitely lives up to the hype.I got the avocado buiscut - amazing! The buiscut is so fluffy and buttery, the avocado is smooth and the bites of pepper really add a freshness to it. I was worried the cheese would overpower it, but it really blends nicely. Absolutely recommend this. Can't wait to go back and try everything else on the menu!

i am soooo happy that Bang Bang opened up another location AND it's not too far from my place.We arrived on a sunday morning, it was a bit nerve wracking seeing all the people outside but it is next to a breakfast place and everyone outside was waiting for that place.We waited in line for a few minutes and settled on the bacon biscuit sandwich and i got chicken pot pie.Both were so delicious!! I usually don't like chicken pot pie but you can tell that their pie is made with quality ingredients and love.I can't wait to come back and try everything else!

Brought my daughter here, and we liked everything about it.  We ordered Avocado Biscuits and they were delicious, and shared a slice of Chocolate Chess Pie for desert.  The staff is very friendly, and the place lends itself to being social with family style seating, and the Velvet Underground softly playing in the background.  Can't wait to go back.

So so good. If you live anywhere close, or not even if you live close go here. Today I had the Wedge Biscuit and holy cow. The combination of flavors made this the best thing I've eaten in a long while.Also, don't skip an order without the hashbrown. It's a bit of goodness that everyone should try.

Absolutely amazing. First time here, and the breakfast was something to die for. We split the farmers and the avocado, with added candies bacon. So different, and so good. Topped it off with a key lime pie.... also, the staff is ridiculously nice. Really attentive and made sure we felt at home. you have to come here!!!

A very cool find! I've lived in Chicago for two years, but had never heard of Bang Bang Pie & Biscuits. My sister (visiting from NC) and I came in after reading about this place's s'mores pie on Buzzfeed. Go figure! We had a great experience.When we came in, we got a good look at the super simple menu, were greeted and bantered with by the fun cashier, and we got to set up our own little table and chairs area near the self-serve water/silverware station.Food was awesome. Biscuits were heavy and big, like a buttery, melty pound cake consistency but less sweet. Strawberry jam (my favorite!) was in season. I had the candied bacon too which was pretty great. I would've liked it crispier, but it was my first time having candied bacon, so I'm not sure if it's ever served that way.The pie was every bit as good as Buzzfeed said it would be. My sister, a known chocoholic, got the s'mores, and I got the tart, creamy key lime. Both were smash hits for us.Can't wait to visit this place again in the fall and winter to try out the rotating flavors... I'm hoping for a pumpkin pie or an apple pie. Too cool! Will definitely recommend to locals and tourists.
Try the honey pie and fancy grits. You will NOT be disappointed. Excellent and welcoming staff. Top restaurant in Chicago.

So this review is based on the food, service and overall experience at this place of business. The service staff seems knowledgeable and very friendly.  The food that was ordered. Which consisted of a wedge and biscuit and a gravy and biscuit we're good. Although the amount of lettuce could not be considered a wedge. It was more like a one by 4 inch section of a head of lettuce. It did taste good. Just didn't feel like the value for the money. My dining companion ordered the biscuits and gravy. Which was tasty, although a little bit over spiced with the pepper and I'm guessing the worlds smallest egg on top.The orange juice was fresh. The black flavored iced tea was good although a tad bitter.As for the space. It's a very charming and very hipster farm concept. The large communal table although very cute. Honestly does not utilize the amount of space they have to offer for people to sit down and enjoy their product . People with laptops , papers. People saving spaces. Another problem with the lack of seating is no fault of the restaurant , but , with the way you order and then go sit down to have your food brought to you. The problem that was happening was that one person would arrive early from their party. Order a drink. Then go sit down at an open seat. And hold the table space until their friends got there to get in line and order what they wanted. The only problem with this is people that were ahead of them in line their food was coming out and they had nowhere to sit. I only noticed it happen twice. And both parties seemed only slightly miffed.So overall. For me three stars. If I lived in the neighborhood. Didn't have to wait 25 minutes just to order. And I could find a seat when I came in. I probably wouldn't give it a higher rating.  The food was good. Nothing to write up in a paper about. Just honest good foodI may give it another shot during the week. When the weekend brunch crowd is not overwhelming the restaurant

I've been here twice now and love their pies! I've had the chocolate chess, chocolate pecan and Boston banana cream. All were delicious. My son loves the snicker doodle cookies. Service is great as well as the layout and decor.

9:30am Sunday Morning... Line 30 deep out the door! Coincidence it's right next to Over Easy or MKTG Genius? Do the math.. I'm back to good with the joint for sure after seeing that vintage icebox and the other aspects of the build out. Can't believe how busy it is; I think eventually you'll see these all over the country? Franchised? Hope not but makes me wonder if I'm in the wrong line of business.. I know I am!! Try everything.. take pie home/ take pot pies home..they keep for like a week..trust me. Try the GRANOLA! Talk later.. PS- Leave a tip!

The biscuit plain is amazing. The biscuit with gravy was wholy black pepper. It was overwhelming peppery which was a turn off for me but if you love black pepper this is the biscuit for you. Now I do like the bacon. The not fancy grit were ok. The ice coffee  was really good and the cinnamon roll was really good, it was moist, and the cream cheese was light and went with the whole fluffiness of the roll.

This place was delicious!  You have to wait in line outside to order at the counter, but they bring the food to your table. Lots of options of different biscuits with toppings and pies. I have lots of food allergies, so I went the simple route of a biscuit and a piece of the milk chocolate pie. Both were delicious and well worth the wait. I had wanted scrambled eggs with mine, but they only have one type of egg (can't remember offhand, sorry)!  I'd say that was the biggest downfall. You can eat inside or outside. The outdoors area is much nicer and has a ton of space...as long as you don't mind eating in benches. But it's rustic and fun and definitely worth it to try. They also just opened one in ravenswood.

I never got around trying out their Logan square location, but this one is better because within footsteps of home. Their biscuits is soft and moist unlike any other biscuit I've ever had. Almost like a cake but much more body to it.I had the hot chix biscuit sandwich- spicy full of mexican spice flare. Pickles added a nice balance with acidity sweetness, and mouthy lubrication to the biscuit and chicken.For dessert I got a slice of their rhubarb pie. Delicate flakey pie crust with a rhubarb filling that had a preserve consistency to it. If it got served to me without knowing what it was I would have said that this was the best peach cobbler I've ever eaten.Definitely worth stopping in for a quick bite.

Great little space but no outdoor seating.The Logan Square location is much closer to me but I traveled to try some items they don't have in Logan Square.Hot Chix Biscuit - Hard to hold as a chicken sandwich but still very good!Pie a la mode - So good!  I've been waiting for them to serve pie a la mode and it's even better than imagined with Black Dog Gelato!!!I hope they have these additions soon at the Logan Square location!

I think the reason it's named Bang Bang Pie Shop is because it's the bomb!  Though I'd heard great things about the original location, I never made the trip to Logan Square.  As a dedicated pie fiend, I couldn't wait to check out the Damen location.One evening, getting off the bus with two bags of Trader Joe's provisions, I couldn't wait to get home, but then I saw Bang Bang was open.  Of course, I trotted right over.  It happened to be the opening day, and the owner graciously greeted me.On this glorious morning, I ventured across the park to finally try their famous biscuits.  Though the place was bustling, the service was off the charts.  Though there were two people ahead of me, the line moved quickly, yet without feeling rushed.  The owner was at the register, and I was stunned that he remembered my name.  I placed my order - two slices of pie, biscuit, coffee - and my order was ready before i'd finished filling my coffee.  The biscuit was even better than reported.  I particularly appreciated the little cups of butter and fresh seasonal jam - not little pats like at a diner, but more than enough for my large biscuit.  The coffee is the best in the neighborhood.  I could easily head to Bang Bang just for a java fix.  In fact, I see a new weekend morning routine!

I've known that this place was coming for a few months and was excited to have another spot in the neighborhood to have in the mix whenever I need a bite. Sadly after coming here I know this isn't going to be one of my regular spots.The thing that killed it for me is how little value you get for what they charge.I ordered their hot chix sandwich and gladly paid nearly $10 for it because I've paid as much for other awesome chicken sandwiches before (the roost & honey butter fried chicken) and have been satisfied. I was expecting the same here, but when my sandwich came out I was seriously shocked at how small it was. The piece of chicken was the size of two chicken nuggets put together. Yeah the ingredients are high quality and it had flavor but I finished the chicken in two bites and was pretty much left with half the biscuit.I also had the grits and you would have to be crazy to think that's worth $8.The pie is great, I'll give them that, and I may come back for that even at $5 a slice but you couldn't force me to $10 on a sandwich that small again.

I went here for lunch with friends yesterday and loved it! I had the Bacon Biscuit with an egg on top. Absolutely delicious and their homemade biscuit was one of the best I've had. For dessert, I had strawberry rhubarb pie which was just tart enough and the crust was delicious. My friends shared a chicken pot pie and said it was really good. One had key lime pie and said it was perfect. The place probably can't hold more than 25 people or so, so I would imagine it's a bit hard to find seating on weekends. You might want to carry out your order at those times.

Amazing pie, biscuits and grits, just like the Logan Square location.The new location in Ravenswood is next door to Over Easy. They have more interior space than the Logan Square location, but I don't think that they have the cute garden set up. However, there are some two tops at the front looking out onto Damen, a cozy couch and chairs in front of a fireplace, a communal table and then bar style seating towards the back.I was there at 11:30 am on a Saturday, there was a line to the door (6 people in front of me), but I got through the line and left with pie in hand in under 10 minutes. Their menu of pies is slightly different than the Logan Square location, but that's not a bad thing, check the website and see what kind of pie you want and go to the location that soothes your pie craving.Since I live in Uptown, I am thrilled that there is a location much closer to me so I don't have to deal with California traffic to get my pie on.

Come on. I don't get the hype. This is just a review for the pie, nothing else.I just came back from European trip and saw this opened across the street. I like desserts and decide to give a try. After paying almost 6 dollar after tax for a pie of key lime pie, my first bite makes me wanna spit it out. It's very very very sweet. But I guess that's just how American desserts are.I don't want to be mean but after having all kinds of desserts in Asia and Europe. Nowhere else makes desserts as sweet as in America and this pie is even at the top of American dessert sweetness level.Price. This is definitely overpriced. People are just overpaying for the hipster atmosphere. 5-6 dollar a piece? This is what I pay for world class pastries. In Paris, a piece from top pastry shops is about 5-6 euros, which given exchange right now, it almost the same as 5-6 dollars. If you don't know Pierre Herme and Sadaharu Aoki, google them. That's how I want exchange  my 6 dollar for.

I had heard bang bang had opened up a second location close to me but I couldn't figure out exactly where it was.We were waiting for a table at over easy cafe next door and saw this long line outside so we decided to check it out. Soooo glad we did because I've been wanting to try bang bang forever!!We got a slice of their key lime pie  to go for later in the day and all I have to say is WOW! I'm not a huge fan of key lime pie so I usually only take a bite of my boyfriends, but this time I was upset I didn't get my own slice. It was REALLY good. He loves key lime pie and orders it from anywhere that has it and he couldn't believe how good it was from bang bang.My friend ordered the chocolate pecan pie  for later and she texted me later that evening with a million exclamation points, haha! She's a baker herself so when she says it's good, it's REALLY good.

I am a huge pie fan, so I was eagerly awaiting the opening of this place.  I would say this place has the best pie I have had south of the Nook in Osseo.   I have gone twice for takeout.  The key lime and the rhubarb were both excellent.   I was especially pleased with the crusts.  I am just sad we will have to wait a whole year for more of that rhubarb.
The biscuits here and at the other locations are the best in town.  Pies are good too but prefer hoosier mama...

Good pies and delicious chicken pot pie. Best I've had in the city so far. Seems to be a little hot inside too often, especially on hot summer days. Might be a bit difficult for more than a few people as well. Overall a nice place to stop in every once and awhile.

This is a place to come for pie, biscuits or grits. The cashier and other staff were really nice and helpful.I liked the plain biscuit with the phenomenal strawberry jam best. The lemonade was very refreshing on a humid day.The fancy grits were not quite worth the price. I liked the sausage on the biscuit, but thought it was better just simply eaten with the homemade jam.The seating with a giant table in the middle and high bar stools are a little odd. Try to snag one of the little tables in the front if you can.It was buzzing at an early lunch hour. Overall, I thought it was a little pricey for what it was. The decor was charming and the staff were pleasant. I'll still go back to try the sweet and savory pie.

The place is really pretty. The service was great. Happy to have them in the hood. Food is good, not great. But really all of that would be fine if they didn't service the WORST coffee I have ever had in a breakfast leaning establishment. I understand they're not a coffee shop, so I'll forgive the lack of espresso. But Chicago has some of the finest coffee roasters and this local business is servicing watered down diner coffee. I talk myself out of going back all the time because what's the point of breakfast or a slice of pie with a nice warm delicious cup of joe?

Two wedge biscuits, two coffees, and one slice of pie was nearly $40 with tip.  My biscuit was undercooked and doughy, but tasted fine, although I expected a little more egg for a $10 biscuit.  The pie was very good...I didn't order it, so I don't know the name, but it was fluffy and chocolatey.  Iced coffee was just the drip poured over ice, which was totally watered down.  The seating is weird, and I noticed water glasses are put rim down in a reclaimed wood crate...yuck...hope there's not lead paint in there.

My husband and I visited for the first time today. We wish the food had been as good as the warm, friendly welcome we received from the lovely young woman at the counter. Since we don't eat meat we were happy to discover the non-meat options. We were very disappointed with the biscuits and veg gravy, both overly salted and gravy extremely spicy. I was so looking forward to a light, fluffy biscuit. It was dense, almost gummy, overly rich and fatty and very salty! We also shared a yogurt parfait which was very good with their homemade vegan granola, but it was just glopped into a bowl so I'm not sure how it qualified as a parfait. My husband liked his coffee and my iced tea with lavender lemonade was delicious but I was disappointed that it was served in a plastic cup.Another thing that really bothered me was the lack of good ventilation! The whole place smelled of bacon and sausage fat. (I guess some people wouldn't have a problem with this.) I will have to return at another time to sample their pie. Hopefully it will be better than the biscuits! I may be a snob, but biscuits should be tender, just like a pie crust or why bother consuming the calories!I will say that everyone around us seemed happy to be there and pleased with their food.

I'll start off by saying that I miss the Dolce Casa Cafe, but was very pleasantly surprised with the food and atmosphere @ the newest Bang Bang Pie.  I will add that the menu is somewhat limited --- maybe adding a few choice appetizers would be a nice addition. We will be back!!!

Bang Bang makes the best biscuits I've ever had. That's right: ever. And I'm talking anywhere around the country, including Southern restaurants famous for their biscuits. Bang Bang's biscuits are moist but not heavy or dense, buttery but not greasy, and they hit just the right balance of savory with a hint of sweet. I have no idea how they do it. But I do know that at $3 each, including delicious housemade jam, their biscuits are also the best culinary deal in town.The new shop in Lincoln Square is downright adorable, and the hipster staff is very nice, efficient and chill. The pies are also exceptional, especially the wonderfully flaky crusts, but it's the biscuits that have made me a Bang Bang devotee. Goodbye, waistline!
Wonderful biscuit sandwiches in a cozy setting. Take time to study the chalkboard because the surprises are endless.
A friendly, southern and amazing place. We tried biscuits and gravy, passion fruit pie and French grits. Everything was so tasty. The grits deserves a special mention. It's the best...

I love the other location of this restaurant and was happy to see they opened a location closer to me. However, after trying it, I would not come back. I ordered a sausage biscuit and a side of cheddar grits. The grits were over salted and tasteless, and the sausage biscuit was supposed to come with jam but I was barely given any. Save your time and go to the location in Logan sq instead.

I wanted to like this place more, but I found myself disappointed. I ordered the avocado biscuit, and it was so-so. The biscuit was good, but it was overpowered by way too much avocado (and this is coming from someone who loves avocado). The whole thing was too buttery and heavy without any balance. The avocado could have benefited from some more seasoning to brighten it up (such as lime juice). The sandwich was disappointing, especially for the price. I would definitely go back and try something else, but overall I didn't feel like Bang Bang lived up to the hype.

Biscuits are delicious, ambience is great! Only thing is (and this is coming from a student who doesn't have very much money), I found it to be overpriced. A piece of pecan pie--just a slice, and a pretty small one at that!--was $6! That's kinda outrageous to me...especially when another establishment not too far away sells delicious pie slices for $3 (and they're a lot bigger). While the food is good, it's nothing that I felt I couldn't make at home. Except for the biscuits. Those are pretty delish!

This place is for foodies. Super good tasting food made from local organic food and a friendly staff.The menu changes weekly, but everything I've had was delicious.Very relaxed vibe, but the food outdoes most 5 star restaurants.Don't be afraid to lick the plate clean.

I had followed them on IG for months and of course saw the yelp reviews, so I was really excited to try this place, especially the kougin ammans. Well, they were working on the recipe so no kougin ammans anytime soon. Ok. Ordered a canelle for my sweet treat and asked some questions about the menu as it isn't the simplest. Cashier had no idea on any. Owner (?) right behind was able to answer. Was the cashier incompetent or just not trained properly? Either way...My guest and I were served our drinks right away. I was a bit disappointed my apple cider wasn't warm...I'm sure I could have asked, but I figured that's how they meant it. I wish menu would have included that detail though.After waiting a while and seeing other guests order and get their pastries right away, I figured mine had been forgotten so I went back up to the counter to request it. Another employee I hadn't yet spoken with gave it to me (without proof of purchase so I guess I could have requested more?). No one ever checked up so glad I asked.Our meals finally came out (15-20 min later?). The bean pancakes were quite good. The quiche was very jiggly, and I was not a fan of the texture. I love pie crust as well so more would have been great especially to balance the soft texture of the eggs. It was much fancier (and expensive) than I expected.Small place with one big table. Atmosphere was decent.  Service can be worked on as expressed above. Parking was pretty easy for us on a busy road. Nowhere to put purses when eating. Hope that the big table is empty and you can use another chair.

Best quiche I've ever had.  I've only ever ordered something else on the menu when they've been out of the quiche. If it ain't broke, ya know?Also love the space. I love to come here and do some writing.  Great, open format with beautiful light.One of my favorites.
My only complaint is that they aren't open every day!  Cellar Door consistently has the most unique, flavorful, tasty dishes.  This place is a true gem.

I found out about this bakery from a Chicago tribune article. Not being from Chicago I wanted to try out the fantastic sounding pastries before we headed back home.When I walked in, the pastry selection was limited because items were still coming out of the oven. I do not mind waiting for food so I got bread and butter while the kouign-amanns came out of the oven. With that being said, when I was baking for a living, we had at least the first round of all pastries ready to go before we opened our doors for the day.The bread and butter was very good. Homemade butter is a real treat. The bread was chewy and full of flavor.Where the train derailed was with the kouign-amanns. I got back to where we were staying and my husbands first comment was they looked burnt. There is supposed to be a crackly crunch of caramelized sugar so I held my breath while taking my first bite. Burnt sugar. So I peeled off the layer of burnt sugar but then I didn't get the crackly buttery sugar goodness that makes a kouign-amann a kouign-amann. And I ended up throwing mine away. Such a shame. A certain bakery in Salt Lake City still holds the title of best kouign-amann I've ever had.The nettle quiche was rich and decadent and the quiche was the richest example of a savory custard I've ever eaten. The canele was also very good along with the cats tongue strawberry filled sandwich cookie.Overall I'm glad we tried it but this won't be making the return list when we come back to Chicago.

Wow! This place is amazing. I walked over on a Sunday morning with a friend for some breakfast. We arrived around 9 and the restaurant was filled! I really enjoyed the environment. One long shared table with a few individual tables. I would say it's a 20 seater. Proceeded to the counter and ordered our coffee, kougin-amann, croissant, a scone, bread and butter and a quiche. There was one party in front of us and we were told the wait would not be long. We were given our coffees and pastries to enjoy while we waited.All of the pastries were absolutely delicious. Kougin-amann was so so flakey and buttery. The caramelized sugar at  the bottom added a perfect crunch as it should. The scone was my all time favorite though. It was nice and airy. You can tell the dough wasn't overworked. It had a really nutty flavor that I throughly enjoyed. The croissants were solid, flakey and baked to a golden perfection.Aside from the pastries, we ordered bread and butter and the quiche. The bread was nice and chewy and had a nice crust on its exterior. The house made salted butter was rich and decadent. All I can say about the quiche is that it tasted like a light airy custard that had been lightly steamed and set. I've never had quiche prepared this way, but it was unique and tasty.I've went back 4 more times now and have found myself really enjoying the changing menus and pastries they offer.

Today's pastry was a plum flavored square shape w/ top center protruding spherically. Again, unbelievably good. Not overly sweet, so moist.This place is just totally in contrast to my conservatively dressed, officious, control-freak attitude. No clear posting of the name or price. I just ask what it is, they give the formal name (European bakery term above me) and flavor, then I order, pay & enjoy! A match made in contrasting heaven!

Hubby discovered this place on a "Best Croissants in Chicago" list which was enough for a trek out in the middle of winter to see what the fuss was all about.  It's a small space with a large communal table and 2-3 small tables that are first come first serve after you place your orders up front.  You can see them cooking and baking behind the register and preparing the pastries for display.  The display case had a lot of turnover with various items offered with each switch of the trays.  The daily menu is displayed on a continuous roll of butcher paper on the right wall.  The guy taking our order was very welcoming and helpful in explaining what items were in the display case since there where no labels.  We were able to snag a small table and place our stroller on the side.Hubby tried the Staff Meal, which came with two thick slices of fresh bread, a soft boiled egg, and salad.  The egg was cooked perfectly.  I've only had quiche once or twice in my life, so I tried their Quiche and was pleasantly surprised with how flavorful but light and airy it was.  It had the texture of a light custard but didn't feel heavy at all, even after I ate the entire thing in one sitting.  The salad ingredients were fresh, but a tad salty.  We each split a croissant (nice and crispy outside and chewy inside) as well as another pastry that looked like an ear, which was way better than the croissant in terms of buttery crunchy exterior with the right balance of sweet interior.We were miffed they were closed over the Christmas holiday since we wanted to take our visiting family there for breakfast.  Will definitely be back!

This place is so beautiful and eating here made me feel majorly posh.There's a bit of a breakfast and lunch rush, so stop in some time in the middle if you don't like waiting. The portions aren't going to be huge, but your food will taste fantastic.I'd say that this is one of those places for the "live to eat" rather than the "eat to live" types. It's obvious that a lot of care and respect for all the ingredients used. Like you're not eating a cabbage dish because you feel bad for not eating vegetables; you're eating it because they made those vegetables the star of the plate. And the pastries! They're basically too pretty to eat but please do because they taste amazing.Also get some bread and apple cider. And lick your plate clean.

Delicious brunch in a bright setting. I think it would be impossible to be in a bad mood while eating here. Came in around 11 on a Sunday and the place was full. Cellar Door is made up of a couple individual tables and a very large communal one. You place your order at the counter, but they don't start making your food until you've gotten a seat. Our wait for 2 people was probably around 15 minutes.The good news is that they have some pretty amazing baked goods so while you wait, you can have a pastry as an appetizer. Even if there isn't a wait for a table, you should have a pastry as an appetizer or dessert because if they're anything like the pear tart we had, then you're in for a treat! So flaky and flavorful, you'll forget how much butter is probably in that dough.Ordered the brown butter and sage quiche and the fig yogurt bowl to split with my husband. The quiche was incredibly light and came with a green side salad. It's a pretty good sized portion. The yogurt bowl came with figs and pecans as well as a slice of cornbread and honey butter.Staff was friendly and I really enjoyed the atmosphere. Looking forward to coming back again. Took away a star because the hot tea is $5 for a cup and that just seems a little ridiculous. Everything else was priced well.
I had the marrow roasted figs and savory mung bean pancakes and they both looked and tasted great. The chocolate croissant was also the best looking croissant I've ever seen.

Love the Spartan nature of the place. It's about the food. Prob not the best value but great food overall.My favorite breakfast is the " staff breakfast" which simply is one egg, greens and bread. It's simple and delicious.  The coffee is very good as well.Communal tables, and great staff and very knowledgeable and helpful.

Yum this place is good!A friend moved to the hood so we ended up here for 'brunch.'  Its not your typical brunch place.  They have a brown paper hand written list of the menu for the day in Sharpie marker.Order at the counter and they bring it out to you.  Everything kind of just came out when it was ready...there was no order to it.All of the food was delicious.  The portions were perfect, juuussst right...just like Goldilocks...It was all fantastically fresh.  It was pretty reasonably priced.

Lovely, quaint, and cozy breakfast spot.  The items are so simple yet super flavorful.  My favorite is the quiche - I've had a few different versions of it here and it's always cooked to perfection with a crispy flaky crust.  The side salad is surprisingly delicious - just a small bed of microgreens with a vinaigrette - so tasty. I also recommend the staff meal of bread, butter, and soft boiled egg. You have to try to the pastries too - I had a tapioca tart that was so unique and divine, and a citrus olive oil cake also delicious.  Perfect place for a satisfying breakfast that won't weigh you down.

This place is really, really good.The seating can be hit or miss- there are communal tables and a couple of small tables, and when I have been at lunch it's quite busy. But the food is so delicious it's worth it to take a risk and wait for a seat.Small menu but plenty of veg options (which I love). Portion size is on the small side (I have thought this with every entree)- but that being said, everything tastes so damn good, and the execution is so flawless, that I really don't mind not having a huge heavy meal.Today I tried the white beans with kale and goat cheese- I don't know what I was expecting but it was DELICIOUS. I mean, so simple really, but so, so well done. I was very impressed.I don't come often (I'm not really sure why!) but if you're looking for something really delicious in this area, don't miss it.PS the bread is amazing. Make sure to try it. And the pastries are good too.

tl;dr: I paid $10 for a half a turnip and left hungry.I want to love Cellar Door. The name alone makes me happy - as it is the most beautiful phrase. The pastries are wonderful and unique. The quiche is unlike any other I have eaten. The place itself is beautiful with plenty of light and friendly staff.I had been here once before and had the quiche - which, as I said, delicious. This time I decided to try something different. I ordered pastries to share and decided I would try the "Turnip" from the lunch menu. My friend received her dish, and I waited a little longer for mine to come. When it did, it was the saddest and most disappointing "meal" I have ever seen. I realize they do it light here, but the size of my dish was ridiculous for the $10 it cost.The turnip was shaved thin, with some grilled ramps, a sauce on the bottom and supposedly a chili oil on top. But it was no more than a serving spoonful of food in total. You can see from the picture I posted how silly it looks on the giant dinner plate. I don't even think I got a whole turnip in the dish...The runner took my plate away after he set it down (and I gave the plate a look of horror), and said he had forgotten something. All I could think was: "Yeah, THE FOOD." He came back and said, "They forgot the chili oil." Again, I stared at this massive dinner plate with a side dish of food on it. Now with a light drizzle of chili oil. For $10.I left hungry, bewildered, and disappointed, which no one is looking for in a brunch. I will probably not be back, because there are other brunch places out there that will actually feed me. Do you know how many full sized turnips I can get for $10? Sorry, Cellar. It was fun while it lasted, but a girl likes to eat.
Hands down the best Quiche I've ever had, amazing bread, and comfortable space.Highly recommend to anyone looking for a clean, modern breakfast/ lunch.

Hipster Haven... Heaven?... Haven?... Both.Whatever, just shut up and get your best lumbersexual flannel or flowy artist shirt and ride your 1980s road bike here.Brunch here is like going to an edible art gallery.  The offerings not only provide an amazing visual, but they taste great, too.  The only downside is you end up paying for the craft and NOT the portions- so coming crazy hungry is not recommended.::LENTILS::The mixture of lentils, spinach, beets, and soft-boiled egg has a nice balance in mellow, delicate flavors.  It's almost as if Kenny G reincarnated to a meal. You like it, but you don't want to admit it.There is also a good progression of texture from firm to soft - lentils:beets:egg.  The texture along with the visual plating keeps the dish appealing throughout the meal.::MUSHROOM TART::All I could think while eating this is "Deez Shrooms On Point."  Not only would it succeed as a sick rap album, but I'd definitely eat it again.The medley of sauteed mushrooms has a pronounced saltiness that complements the foundation of crusty, flaky, tart.  The lump of cream and small side of greens adds more visually than to the actual flavor.  But those shrooms... YUP.EXTRA CREDIT:For those of you that need a review for the Hipster Establishment Test (HET), here is the 4-step cheat sheet:1. The signage out front refuses to write the entire name of the place.(It will use either some abstract art, initials, a clever nickname, or no sign at all.)2. The decor has some eclectic flavor.(Like putting new bike chain and handle grips on your aforementioned road bike.)3. Menus or receipts explore different vehicles.(Whether they deliver the receipt via handwritten parchment in a mason jar... or the menu is on a ceiling mounted chalkboard.  Your standard laminated menu won't make it here.)4. Sketchbooks will appear out of nowhere... nowhere.

Cellar Door Provisions is like eating at a friend's place if your friend had an amazing farm in their backyard and your friend is like the most talented French baker ever. There's a large communal table and then a couple of two-tops, seating around a total of 20 people. A limited breakfast menu is served starting at 8am and then a lunch menu at 11am. If you want your prime pick of pastries though, come early -- by 10am they were out of kouign amanns on a Saturday. Also, no caneles temporarily so they can focus on their laminated pastries, which seem to vary daily. I remember having a delicious sticky brioche roll with pecans and homemade strawberry jam.I've been here for brunch a couple times. Besides the pastries, the dishes I've had have been really beautifully presented and take advantage of what's in season but I can't say I loved everything. I like simple flavors, but the flavors in some of the dishes are almost too simple. What I did love was their quiche - it is so perfectly baked and still slightly jiggly. And those pastries. You know they take their baking seriously when literally everyone in the kitchen is doing something baking-related.

The quiche here is as good as it gets. The egg is just so fluffy I don't understand how they can do it. You gotta try the quiche here.The pastries here are also amazing. Personally, I was quite a big fan of their chocolate croissants. I will definitely be coming back to try more pastries. Make sure you come early-ish, because they stop making and start running out of pastries in the early afternoon.

Wow. Everything I ate was awesome. You know why it was awesome...because it's done right and I know that they care. I mean "on fleek". My boyfriend and I shared the quiche, chocolate croissant, cherry-vanilla tart, bread and butter and a cup of coffee.  The croissant was crusty outside and soft inside...not chewy. Tart had the right amount of sweetness. Bread and butter were soft. Coffee was great. Yeah...my meal sounds simple but I got full. I like that you can see people baking in the kitchen. I like the minimalistic decor. If I want a light breakfast or lunch and don't want to risk wasting my money on bad cup of coffee nor a chewy croissant....I'm coming back.

Located about 5 minutes from 90/94 Diversey exit. There's no sign on the store and can be easily overlooked. Th pastry menu is quite limited, but that should provide more quality food right? It's a open kitchen/bakery and everything seems to be fresh made in house. I came here at 1pm on a very cold Thursday and scored the last 2 morning bun and got one crossiant. Unfortunately the Kourig Amann were all sold out. I was told that the kourig is usually sold out by 12pm... BOO! My very first kourig Amann was from Dominique Ansel Bakery in NY and was known as the DKA. I'm very excited to find a place in Chicago that serves this.Crossaint - Flaky and not all buttered up. I can eat without guilt and it was really good!Morning Bun - It's made from the leftover batter of the crossaint. It's soft and flaky on the inside with bit of cinnamon and sweetness.Overall, i will definitely return for the morning bun and hopefully can score the kourig amann!! This place reminds me of the famous Tartine bakery in San Fran. Good Job!!

Amazing brunch and pastry options. I love the casual, minimalistic feel of the place.Sticky brioche roll: Perfectly sweetened and light. I could probably inhale twenty of these in one sitting.Plum tea cake: Well executed, but I personally wasn't a fan of the flavors. I was expecting more of a sweet plum rather than the slightly vinegar-y taste of japanese plums. I liked how moist and dense the cake was, and the brown sugar coating on top brought a nice touch of sweet.Blueberry danish: Another amazing pastry--the pastry itself was buttery and flaky without being overwhelming so. I wish there was a tad more blueberry flavor in the cream cheese, but overall this was delicious.Pistachio beignet: I thought this was a little disappointing, to be honest. I tasted little, if any, pistachio in here despite it being in the name. I did like the textues of the beignet with the peach and the yogurt, however.Quiche: I can't get over how good this quiche was. There was no fluff--no spinach, no vegetables, no extra ingredients. Just the wonderfully light texture of well beaten eggs complemented by a buttery, flaky crust. I loved how the richness of the quiche itself was balanced out with the shiso salad and edible flowers. Absolutely delicious and probably the best quiche I've ever had.Overall, the pastries were solid, but the quiche was out of this world. I'd come back time and time again for that quiche.

The pastries are the big win here; between a croissant, the pound cake and a decent chocolate brownie, I didn't mind overpaying for these small delicacies.  (Special kudos to the staff here; like some of the pictures I'm seeing by other users, the presentation at Cellar Door is excellent, bordering on artistic.)But the breakfast, and the overall value proposition, is where Cellar Door missed for me.  The Staff Meal ($11 for a soft-boiled egg, greens and an oversized piece of bread with butter) was not nearly enough to feed anyone in my party nor the staff that was actually working last weekend.  Like, for this price, I expect a bit more substance.  Strangely, an order of the bread and butter on its own is only $3...so, for $8, I'm getting an egg and a f*&^ing small pile of greens???The quiche was savory as promised, but for its price (I believe this was $10) and the side of greens, I was looking for more.  The taste of the quiche was actually a better fit for a smaller serving, if that makes sense, so while I might get it again I'd almost want to split it with someone rather than savory it up with that much quiche at the same time.I had my a la card discount to use for this meal, so the $24 hit for all of this food was easier to stomach than if I had to pay full price ($34).  But the value prop is way off here, so I'm not sure I would come back.

This place is so cute! So clean and simple but elegantly done. We had the quiche and sweet potato bake and it was delicious! The scone was yum too, a combo of hearty with a little sweet. They have a bookshelf with foodie books and it's so relaxing yet also hip and fun. My only request would be to have almond or soy milk for coffee. So good!

The food looks stunning...work of art, and tastes delicious. Two visits and great food both times. Portions are definitely on the small side. Our first vist we ordered three dishes for two of us, the next time we ordered the bread and butter as we were still hungry after we ate our delicious entrees. Croissants and bread are spectacular. Also loved the microgreen salad that comes with the " custard like" quiche. The dumplings surprised us because they tasted exactly like tamales! (Corn based)Definitely reccomend but not if you are very hungry.Love the design and the open kitchen visible to all.

Tastes as beautiful as it looks!I stumbled upon this spot mistaking it for a coffee shop.  It is a new, small, and simple place with amazing artisan food!  I had the quiche with marjoram and sumac, and a cup of coffee.  The quiche was creamy, smooth and a delicious blend of flavors.  The presentation, and the watercress salad with edible flowers, was beautiful.I was sitting at a long shared table. As food was delivered to various people at the table heads would turn to get a glimpse of the dish and then to compare it to the short daily menu on the wall. There is a breakfast menu and a lunch menu, each with five items on it.  The two men sitting next to me ordered the braised radish and the fermented cabbage dishes (this was more appetizing than it sounds).  From their conversation regarding the food they seemed to be in the industry, they were very likely were chefs themselves.  They complimented the chef. They even took pictures of the food.Good luck to Cellar Door Provisions - it's a gem.

Cellar Door Provisions feels like it belongs in a Portlandia episode. From the menus written on long sheets of brown paper that hang on the walls to the communal tables in the middle of the shop, CDP doesn't approach its restaurant the way others do. But I like that.I wouldn't hesitate for a moment to order bread and butter here. We dined for brunch and ordered the day's quiche and Staff Meal - greens, a soft-cooked egg and, of course, bread and butter. The quiche was silky, almost like a custard pie.  But the bread and butter was the standout: two generous pieces of perfectly chewy bread are topped with a heaping scoop of butter and just a sprinkle of salt. When you dunk it in the yolky eggs, it tastes even better.Seating is limited and fills quickly. If you can't land a seat, though, at least you can still grab a perfectly flaky kouign amann, croissant or morning bun to take away. Bread, butter and pastries are the bread and butter of CDP.

Good casual brunch option.  They have a large shared table and a couple other tables all with full view of the option kitchen.  Everything we had for brunch here was good and I would come back.  I had a quiche infused with lavender flavor that was the bounciest egg dish I have ever seen.  I also tried the berry tartine which is a couple of thick pieces of tasty toast with berries, greens, and some other stuff.  Never had something like that before and it was good.From their bakery, we tried the chocolate Madeleine which I thought was a bit dry.  I initially came here to try the Kouign-amann.  It was good, but a bit denser than I prefer.

Came in here for a Saturday brunch with the Mrs. Had an assortment of pastries, which are amazing, something with lemon and peach. Had the quiche and sunchokes, and we apologize because it seems we had someone else's quiche before ours. That was embarrassing and made the other person wait. But the quiche was amazing and the service recovery was great.We loved the ambience and vibe here. The setup, music and confidence for an open kitchen is something the team here should be proud of. Keep up the good work.

I'd come back for the pastries but not the breakfast entree items.I had the "Staff Meal": 2 thick slices of bread, butter, a soft-boiled egg, and a small salad of greens.  My partner had a slice of potato quiche which also came with some greens.  Both were good but not remarkable.  I thought the custard in the quiche was spot-on, but the crust wasn't flaky enough (well short of the quiche at Floriole).  The bread in my meal was very good, but nothing in this small meal seemed worth the $10 price tag.But the pastries were worth the visit: we had a kouign-amann, cannelé, and a caraway pound cake.  First time trying a kouign-amann or a cannelé, but we were impressed by the texture combinations and subtle sweetness of each (although slightly distracted by the orange blossom water in the kouign-amann).  The caraway pound cake had an great sweet-savory profile and tender texture.The space is also very airy and bright, which I appreciate in a breakfast spot.

To begin I have to say that the quiche is probably one of the best I've ever had. It delivers in being particularly light and fluffy eggs. It almost tasted as though you were biting into little individual clouds.  This eggy masterpiece is one that cannot be matched in any reasonable sense.  All of the dishes I tried were quite tasty.  Everything had a  bit of a light and healthy feel to it.  Though the dishes feel a bit minimalistic they capitalize on expert use of a limited number of ingredients in order to delivier great flavor.If you're looking for a meal that will keep you light on your feet and won't weigh you down for a busy day you have found it here.   I would also be remiss to not reccomend getting a delicous cup of local cider.  This place is truely a gem.

Delicious food - I had the quiche, never had a quiche like that before. The salad was terrific, too. Both were simple & tasted fancy. Great vibe. Calm, easy, & bright. Service was lovely. Felt like I was in New Orleans or abroad.

My favorite place in Chicago, definitely worth the trip. Wonderful people who are willing to stop and chat for insightful conversation and a very thoughtful approach to food. Beautiful all the way through. Try the bread!!

Cellar Door Provisions holds a special place in my heart. Why? Because their pastry/bakery case if filled with extorinary selections. And the one consistant place I have found my buckwheat goodie craze!

Could not be better. Leaves you with the impression that all the other good restaurants are just faking it. Very genuine eating experience. Don't expect a giant portion. If that is what you want go somewhere else.

Ok, my husband dubbed this place "the best breakfast that he has had in years".  YEARS!We are brunch people.  We go out at least once a weekend for it, so that's an impactfull statement.    We actually ordered the staff meal and quiche for that experience, the simplest thing on the menu - so that would be my recommendation for any first timers.We've since been back and have already tasted about 6 different pastries, which are all delicious, especially straight out of the oven.  You just can't miss with this place!   Can't wait to try them for lunch.My only gripe - I wanted to purchase a loaf of bread from them, since they are magically lined up almost within reach from the register.... But, you are supposed to order them at least 1 day in advance.   Of course, will have to do it the next weekend.  I will overlook the inconvenience for good food.

Food made with passion. Delicious pastries. Strong coffee. Food comes pretty fast. Small homey place with good music playing. Unique menu changes often. Yeah you may not get stuffed here but it is possible if you're willing to spend some dough

I paid $10 for one croissant and a buttermilk tart, and both were underwhelming.
