The croissant wasn't as flaky in the center as I would've liked, and it definitely didn't blow me away at the price I paid. The buttermilk tart was simply mediocre. While the buttermilk topping was nice and light, it was also completely tasteless.Overall: doesn't warrant another trip to Avondale. There are better options at more reasonable prices in the city.

I try to refrain from bread, but the kouig amann, though... Fluffy buttery delishness that you can pull apart layer by layer. Then the quiche - my knifesliced through ever so quickly. So light and moist, i could've eaten it with a spoon.Could've done w/o the yogurt dish. It was an odd combo of swt/savory. And the canelle was too dense for my liking.

Came here for the first time 2 weeks ago and i've been thinking about it ever since. Everything tasted so fresh and cooked with intention, and yet so simple.We had:The bread: Delicious, the crumb is a perfect texture and the butter a simple accompaniment to it. A part of me wished i had honey butter or an herbed butter to try with the bread, but maybe that would have ruined the pureness of itQuiche - Oh my goodness. This quiche has such a simple elegance to it. It was more on the custard side, and it was so silky with no fillings (not that it needed it). Decadent without going over the top. Nice, flaky crust. For how large the piece is, the cook was consistent all the way through. Excellent dish.Smoked trout with sweet potatoes, tagarashi, seeded danish bread, soft boiled egg, and hollandaise - this was delicious as well, the trout had a beautiful flavor that paired well with everything else. The sweet potato brought a subtle autumn flavor. Each bite was fantastic.there is limited seating, so may be hard to get a spot to sit.  i didn't love how there was one long table to seat multiple parties because i felt strange looking straight ahead of me to see another party. i felt like i was prying into their conversation, but i wasn't trying to and i just didn't know where else to look! would prefer that broken out to several smaller tables that could be combined or separated when needed.Wanted to also try the canele, but they were out of it at 11 am on a Saturday. Next time...next time...

Adorable cafe with big table for communal seating and a few two tops. The staff was very knowledgeable. I asked a lot of questions, and he gave some helpful recommendations. The menu is changed daily, very small. All fresh and homemade. I ordered the ravioli, and it was one of the prettiest presentations ever.The pastries are some of the best that I've had in the city. Flaky and buttery, exactly the way they should be. I had the Kouign. I highly recommend!

Adorable cafe that you might not realize was cafe when driving past. They have the best quiche in Chicago. It is literally like eating silk in egg form. And with traditional french pastries done perfectly and great coffee I hope it will remain a gem here in Logan.

Best quiche and pastries you will ever eat seriously. The quiche is so smooth and buttery and delightful. The kouign amanns are my favorites of the pastries but really none of their pastries have ever disappointed me. Go there! Even if it looks busy usually it doesn't take long to get a seat :)

Quaint little brunch spot that despite having a fairly pretentious hand-written menu, manages to avoid the pretentious vibe.  More earth friendly tones with a hint of hipster.  Ambiance aside, you can bank on each menu item consisting of truly the most fresh and organic ingredients, albeit this kind of harvest comes at a rather steep price in my view.The register staff has always been very friendly, but the real magic occurs in the kitchen. Though minimalist throughout, the seating is extremely comfortable, even for lengthy sittings over pastries, tea and good-hearted conversation.The bread & butter pairing is a nice way to start for those not scared of a few extra carbs - well worth it. The delectable quiche with side arugula salad is typically my go-to selection, but virtually every menu item is sure to peak the interest of certified foodies. Having said that, keep in mind the menu is routinely adjusted based on ingredient inventory. In other words, the menu at 2pm will likely differ from that of 9am.Seating is mainly communal and often a tight squeeze during peak brunch hours, so it's a gamble for larger parties.All & all, a nice change of pace from typical diner grease - leave those spots for epic hangover days. Your sober pallet will truly appreciate CDP.

Omg! This place is outta this world. We come here pretty much every weekend - no joke. Their menu changes every day (or week). They make everything in house. This place resembles something out of California!  Just light and healthy fare; even their pastries are fluffy and fresh and just breezy! :))MUSTS: the quiche - trust me u will never regret getting it. It sells out often so get there early to get ur quiche on! ;) the staff's meal - so simple yet so delicious - suggestion: if ordering for two to share order an extra poached egg with this fish. Trust me ull need it. Also get the pastries - they are so good doesn't matter what - all their pastries rock! We've also had tons of other dishes there but their menu changes so much that I don't know if they're worth mentioning...I'll just post the pics ;) the quiche and staffs meal are the only constants of the menu - they never go away :)There is plenty of parking around there and there is a bench outside so u can eat outside (but no tables). I highly recommend this establishment!!!

It's really hard for me to separate the pretentiousness and clientele of this place with the actual restaurant and food.I agree with the reviewer who said this place is out of Portlandia. And the people who were there when I visited were insufferable (parents who act like their toddler is God's gift to humanity, hipster girls on a lady date, middle-aged "I'm still cool" people who want to talk knowingly about artisan bread). But the food is real good. The quiche I had was custard-y deliciousness, and the bread and butter is great.It's a great place for a pastry or light lunch. It was crowded just before noon, and we had to wait for some space at the table. I wouldn't come here if I was super hungry--hard to get really full on some bread and dressed greens. There was also no meat on the menu--is this place vegetarian?It's no wonder this place draws a crowd in Logan.
Absolutely stellar food. Gorgeous presentation and flavor profiles. So unique and creative.

Well,My wife came in. She had the beet salad.Roughly $1.5 worth of boring beets. Very boring and very small. She wanted to make a scene.I had the buckwheat pancakes. They were dry. The sauce they gave was very little so all in all it tasted 80% dry. There were 3 .5inch size strawberries and a few berries.I gave them one star since I got a pastry there that tasted very good.All in all, I won't be going back. I can cook better blindfolded.

Ha, this place. Ordered the yogurt & buckwheat breakfast item. It was essentially a piece of thick bread with a dollop of yogurt and a sprinkle of greens. Small and not filling. Hubs got the quiche (I'm not a quiche person so although I tried it, I can't rate it), which he said was good.Yes, $5 for tea is INSANE and even $3 for a small mug of coffee (although it's refillable, come on, people, it's coffee!).I'm thankful I had an A La Card because paying the regular price for what we had would have been highway robbery.The ambience is full-blown hipster with an attempt at minimalist decor (read: tables and chairs). Some people like the open kitchen thing but I'd prefer if I didn't see staff PUTTING FOOD AND DRINK INTO THEIR MOUTHS in the prep/cooking area. That's a health hazard (I've worked in food service) and utterly disgusting, especially given they didn't wear gloves.

Lovely little restaurant. Their bread is delicious and their ingredients are extremely fresh. Limited seating and the word is out that the food is great, so go at on off time or you will be waiting. It's worth it, though.

The food is divine. I have not been this happy with a series of meals in a very long time.I am a vegetarian and I had the tomato consomme which was perfect for a warm day. Chocolate pastries were delightful. Bread & butter is great. There has not been anything I tried here that left me with a grain of disappointment. Overall excellent.

My favorite place for breakfast/ brunch. I like that rustic atmosphere of the place and the quality of their simple food is outstanding. Just their crusty bread with cultured butter makes a trip there worthwhile. I talked to employees of the place and their dedication to quality of their product warmed my heart.

The ambiance at Cellar Door is pleasant. The storefront is very unobtrusive, but not excessively so, if that makes sense. Inside is one long communal table and two or three tables for two, the interior of the kitchen is visible from the dining area. They definitely do a good job creating a nice communal vibe without pretension.The food is solid, but overpriced, at least what I had was. A breakfast crepe with a few sauteed vegetables that did not come close to filling me up, it wasn't bad at all but 12$ was too much for it.I went back and forth on whether this should be a three or four star rating because the place is pleasant and the food is nice but ultimately I think it is a little overpriced.I mean, a La Croix sparkling water costs 2$.... C'mon man, its 3.99$ for a twelve pack at the supermarket and I assume it is even less when you buy it in bulk.Definitely a place worth checking out but they need to either increase portion sizes slightly or reduce the prices slightly for me to be a regular customer.

Lots of half-shaven guys who think it's cool to keep their knit hats on while eating. And another one who is drawing in his sketch book while a copy of HG Wells' Invisible Man sits on the table. Gypsy women and purple puff-sleeved mod 25-year olds sipping $5 Voltaire tea.The communal seating area is a little smaller than the kitchen. They don't rush to clear tables. That's okay, I don't mind busing dishes in order to get a chance to sit down.  Don't bother getting off your phone to clean the surface, ask what we'd like to eat, or compliment the knitting wife has pulled out to bide the (extended) waiting time.Menu is pretty limited, but the croissants are good.  Very hearty bread with creamy butter. Of course, that was most of the entire entree, along with some salad greens, so don't come too hungry!

Its nice to have a new breakfast joint pop up in the neighborhood and a good one at that.  Cellar Door is easy to miss, as you wouldn't think it was a restaurant just walking by at night.  Inside its very bare bones in decor and the only signage they have is "CDP" stamped on the window.I can see why their decor is bare bones, as the main focus here is on the food, especially their wonderful breads and pastries.  I've had a fantastic Multi-grain Scone and Financier.  Just delicious.They have their menu written out on butcher paper by the counter, which varies each day.  You'll find dishes such as quiches, soups, salads, and sausages.  I'll definitely be back for some more delicious pastries and coffee.

What a great new addition to Logan Square! The food was so artfully presented and everything we ate was super fresh and tasty.  The ingredients were allowed to speak for themselves without being overpowered. And even the delicious pastries weren't dripping in grease or butter.  To put it simply, everything tasted very clean. The decor also matches the food perfectly... Tasteful, artful, creative, and clean.CDP is also owned and run by a few people who seem to genuinely care about the community and where their food comes from.  Aside from nearly everything coming from local farms and sources, these guys make their own butter, yogurt, cheese, and of course bread/baked goods in-house.  And they make their baked goods throughout the day, so they're always coming out fresh instead of everything being baked first thing in the morning.The guy working the register (Tony) seemed like a really nice/genuine person when I placed my order and helped talk me through the options. Turns out he's one of the owners.  He came over and chatted with my wife and I for awhile after we finished eating and was super cool.  We could really tell from speaking with him how much these guys care about what they're doing and about having a positive impact on the neighborhood (and planet for that matter).  They all met while working at a local food co op and it seems like that same philosophy has carried over into this new venture.I definitely recommend checking this place out... I don't think you'll be disappointed!
Great experience.1. Extremely nice,  no pressure,  professional  staff,2. Decent coffee,3. Quiche- amazing.  I suggest to try to know what I'm talking about.  Delicate and creamy.  Just Great.

Its very easy to miss this place this place.  Its on an unassuming corner and its not close to much.  And when you walk in, it has very minimalist feel.  They also have a very limited menu.  But what they do have is quite outstanding.  Their croissant is probably the best croissant in the city.  It is buttery, light, flaky and amazing.  I would travel miles for it.Their prices aren't cheap, and the portions aren't large, but you get what you pay for, and I will go back.Great addition to the neighborhood.

Cellar Door has some delicious baked goods. My favorite are the croissants...they're not always available but you can call ahead and ask to see if they have them. The only downside is that they are only open Wednesday-Sunday and only until 3pm. If you're still in doubt follow them on Instagram to see some of the great things they make.

This place has fantastic food.  The croissants and pastries are everything everyone else has raved about.  Good coffee, and I love the sane portions, flavor combinations, and delicate plating with attention to color, composition, proportion, and flavors.  It's a bougie gem in my less-than-glamorous neighborhood.I'd love to give them a better review, but there was one serious flaw in my visit: the person who handled the money was bare-handed grabbing the pastries to serve them.  I had to stop her, and ask her to use the tongs that were right there, hanging from a peg in the display case.  She looked incredulously at me, as if I'd just peed on her grandma.But, seriously, the croissants are almost worth getting hepatitis for.
Super great tasting food. So glad we found this place. Quiche is absolutely amazing. Tastes like nothing else I've had before.

Definitely a win for Logan Square. The menu changes every day so the couple of items off the menu I was able to taste might not be available. I ordered the omelet. There had white miso, kombu, wilted kale and smoked maitake in it. The combination of all these flavors made is incredibly tasty.The omelette also came with a side of toast, which was phenomenal - definitely homemade and definitely worth the 2$ for a side of it.Service was great, even though is was busy staff had the patience to take us through our several questions about the various items on the menu.Two minor downsides I'll star with are the seating area is a bit small, in fact we waited for about ten minute(after ordering our food) before we got a seat. This seemed to be pretty typical but everyone was able to sit down before they got their food.

This place is ridiculous. We have never had a bad meal and come once a week to see what new creations they have. It's also the prettiest food you've ever seen! The staff is super friendly and awesome. See you in a few days!

Items Selected:Kouign AmannRicotta Peach MuffinCaneleLocated in Logan Square, with a wall mounted menu that is rewritten daily, Cellar Door Provisions can best be described as a labor of love; a collaboration of three friends who've honed their skills in kitchens near and far focused on making great food "worth gathering around."  Locally sourced and open five-days a week for breakfast and lunch it was just after the small store's 8:00am opening that our party of three arrived and with items still emerging slowly from the ovens our sampling was somewhat limited, the friendly servers quickly procuring a pair of each warm item and delivering them tableside as a light soundtrack played overhead.  Clearly attuned to recent trends in regional French pastry with the oft-praised croissants still thirty minutes from ready it was instead in the creamy canele beneath a golden-brown shell that our tasting began and although a bit sweeter than I've come to expect the texture was spot-on, a similar bit of praise befitting a Kouign Amann whose still-molten core of butter ran down my wrist as laminated layers shattered and showered the table.  Appropriately impressed though slightly short of 'wowed' to this point it was last-but-certainly-not-least that we turned to the cheesecake textured muffin and featuring a deft balance of juicy ripe peaches juxtaposing pockets of creamy ricotta each bite provided a beautiful balance of sweet and savory, a touch of streusel topping tilting the balance ever so slightly towards the former and placing it amongst the best muffins I've experienced in recent memory.

Stopped by on a Saturday morning for the canele and decided to try a number of the pastries.I haven't had many croissants in my time but the one I got was a gummy in the middle. Not bad aside from that issue.The kouign aman was good, but the bottom was a little too burned. So much in fact that I peeled off the bottom layer in order to enjoy the rest of the pastry.The canele was great it's just as good as the rest in the city but smaller and more expensive.I spotted some of the food items. They looked very well plated, but the portions look like they were made for toddlers. Embarrassingly small. I would be funny as a business owner serving these portions at these prices.The quality of the products warrants another visit but the prices hinder that idea.

I love croissants.You know, *real* croissants, not some weird donut-croissant hybrid, or some gummy Pillsbury crescent roll masquerading as pastry.This croissant was fluffy, flaky and buttery. Simply perfect!

Not that they need another great yelp review but I just have to contribute. Everything about Cellar Door Provisions, from the large communal table, to the friendly chefs that come out to chat with you, to the ridiculously reasonable prices, or the peculiarly large kitchen-to-dining area ratio, screams out how much these people care more about food and community than about anything else. The staff are all super friendly and easy to talk to. You can tell every one of them is passionate about food.GO THERE AND EAT THINGS.

Top notch coffee. Incredible pastries. Awesome interior. Great staff.Great establishment, everything very carefully considered and executed. Haven't had a chance to sit and eat yet but frequently stop in for a morning coffee (and usually a pastry) to go. Im a tough judge on coffee and they never disappoint. The baked goods are great too. Everything made with great attention to detail, you can tell everyone working there is really happy to be there. I love the craft paper menus that hang on the wall. Menus change weekly.

Shared the Quiche and Morning Bun.  Both were phenomenal.  The quiche was rich and creamy and I absolutely loved the chunks of seasonal veggies.  The morning bun was super buttery and flaky with a slight hint of sweetness - perfect pastry to accompany the quiche.The space is adorable and the staff is friendly.  Need to check out their lunch menu next time.

So... I have been on the fence about writing this review. I know one of the people who run this place and I was afraid I couldn't write it objectively. But I can: a few months have passed since its opening and I keep coming back, in fact I take trips from downtown/west loop just to eat here).I come here for:- locally sourced vegetable-centric but not necessarily vegetarian food. Their style is a nod to California cuisine that it's not easy to find in Chicago- out-of-this-world sourdough bread (when possible I buy a loaf to take away as well).- great pastriesI like that there is plenty of street parking and that I always end up surprised I spent less money than I expected.

My wife would return for the quiche, but I would not for the pancake.  It was large, fluffy and a bit tasteless.  The hot apple cider is supposed to be a favorite, but I think I do it better.  So although the place is friendly and very cozy, I can't give it more than 3 stars.
Best canneles in Chicago, and believe me I have trying them all. In addition to their magnificent treats, we tried their salads and the staff meal, delicious!.Worth the drive for sure!

um, YUM!!!I definitely had a dramatic single tear shedding moment as I took a bite into a kouign amman and had a sip of their coffee. It took me back to the delicious bakeries in San Francisco and Portland. Then, I gathered myself and saw that they served food too and a group of us ordered a few different items (the staff meal, omelette, beets, and pork confit) which were all super flavorful and delicious.They even sell you whole loaves of bread (but they do tend to run out), and I love that their menu changes everyday and sometimes the same day if they run out of certain ingredients.I even ordered a pastry to go to share more Cellar Door Provisions love with a friend!I can't wait to go back, and I'm so excited that I finally go to check this place out.
Love this place.  Excellent food.  Excellent casual dining experience.  Kid friendly.

Just ate there on Sunday for a fun dinner - 6 course pre-fixe dinner $65. The restaurant will be open February 5th Wednesday - Saturday 9am - 4pm.The dinner last night was amazing. If this gives you a glimpse of what they will be serving for breakfast and lunch it will be amazing.The pre-fixe 6 course menu consisted of the following:A custard of dried  chanterelles, leeksCeleriac, cladonia lichens, sprouted rye berries, kefirCountry rye bread with Breslin whole wheatSmoked beets with lavender oil, pickled shallots, malabar blossomsSunchokes, reconstituted figs, anise seed, brown butterBraised breast of pork, shaved turnips, garlic confit, mustard seedApplewood smoked cheese, whole roasted appleBuckwheat tart, honey and acacia flower cream, salad of snapdragons and candied buckwheat groats.It was a great space with some fun items from the rebuilding exchange as decor.The smoked beets were so good and different because of the smoky taste.The pork was like butter, it melted in your mouth.I've never had snapdragons - they were a little bitter but overall an interesting desert.I can't wait for them to open for breakfast and lunch!Here's their menu for their opening:riends,We are so close to the finish! Here is our opening menu for next Wednesday February 5th:PastriesCroissant-$4Morning Bun-$5Canale-$3Multi-grain apple Scone-$3.50Buckwheat tart-$4Beet Tea Cake-$3Oat and Mulberry cookie-$1.50Morning- 9-11amQuiche-black garlic, leeks with winter greens and pickled shallot-$7Bread Plate- 2 slices with house butter, ricotta, and lavender honey-$7Lunch- 11am-4pmTartine-elderflower kiefer, charred onion, and shaved carrot-$8Salads--Smoked beets, shaved red onion, sprouted rye, and crispy kale-$9-Werp farm greens and house pickles-$5-Roasted sunchokes, sunflower sprouts and seeds, brown butter, and flowers-$9-Bread and house butter -$2Soup--Lamb leg and Breslin bean-$8-Carrot, turmeric, and fromage-$6Main-$14-House sausage, malted mustard, barley, and shaved turnip-Farmers cheese dumplings, bluefoot oyster mushrooms, shaved celery root, and malabar blossoms

Absolutely beautiful food -- a great place to go for a loaf of bread, coffee and pastries, or a proper breakfast or lunch. And if you can make it to one of their monthly dinners you are in for a real treat.The best bread in Chicago. Really. Try it. Buy a loaf, if one is available. I'm serious about bread, having tried all of the main places in Chicago and making it myself.The vegetables are not just local and fresh -- which is important -- but the dishes are designed to highlights the vegetables themselves. The dishes taste fresh and feels healthy and delicious. This style of cooking is not common in Chicago and is incredibly refreshing.The coffee is good on its own and pairs well with the pastries, which are fantastic and seem to be improving just week after week.The proprietors couldn't be friendlier.

What to say? Loved! Casual, unpretentious but utterly delightful and thoughtful. We enjoyed a late Saturday brunch at the communal table and ordered 3 very different plates. Each one offering a surprisingly simple but intricate array of seasonal flavors. Fab, local coffee and, last but not least, spot-on sweet and savory last courses. Everything to-die-for but my ultimate fave was the "super seeded" cookie. Completely unique with a browned butter complexity that made you want another one immediately after you finished the first. Great gem. Definitely could, and should, stay around for a very, very long time.

I love this place. Wonderful pastries, great fresh food and great energy. Tony and the guys are so warm and welcoming to everyone that comes through the doors. The fare is a nice change of pace from all the whiskey and meat places in Chicago. Very lucky to have them in our neighborhood.

First time to eat at Cellar Door Provisions. The staff is extremely pleasant. Opened with the Chocolate Croissant and great coffee. Then had the Shallot and garlic quiche. The macaroons are amazing. Took home some of their signature morning buns to go for our house guest. The morning buns are sweet rolls made with croissant dough. They make their own kefir, sourdough starter and Kombucha.
The bread and butter was delicious and my quiche was to die for. It's a very small space so I wouldn't recommend coming during the weekend or bringing a large party. Definitely worth trying though.
This place is legit.  It's like Tartine bakery in SF picked up shop and moved it to Chicago.   The morning bun and croissants are best you will find anywhere in Chicago.

There are about 15 pastry items on the menu, including the morning bun which has received rave reviews. The restaurant opens at 8. I arrived at 8:10 specifically to get a morning bun. Not only were morning buns "at least 30 minutes" from being ready -- they were not even in the oven yet -- but only two of the 15 pastry items were available. There was no apology for this from the otherwise friendly staff. I got a scone and a muffin which were good. I don't know why a place would open at 8am if 87% of its breakfast menu won't be ready until 8:45am.

I had high hopes for Cellar Door's breakfast based on early buzz. And there were some things about our meal that were very good -- the croissants and whole wheat sourdough (??) type bread that was served with the ham and eggs were delicious, and I enjoyed my sunchoke soup. The coffee was quite good, and the overall vibe of the place is refreshing. Some things, however, definitely need to be rethought as they get their legs. Our party of 5 ordered a scone, croissant, and brioche to share at the table, and each was served on a plate, bare. No offer of butter or jam on the menu or on the table, and when I asked for butter was given a tiny scrape of butter in a jar for a significant portion of baked goods. The croissant was delicious on its own. The brioche was good, but eaten plain was just not interesting enough. The scone was very tasty but parts were undercooked to the point of tasting like dough.And the "ham and eggs", which my father and husband both ordered, seemed like a joke. We were told the ham was actually going to be pork belly, which, yum, but what arrived at the table was a huge portion of bread, a lovely poached egg with accoutrement, and maybe 3, 3-inch long, shaved-thin slices of limp fat with a tiny bit of pork attached. Smaller than bacon slices and half as thin. For $12, an egg, 3 big hunks of bread, some greens, and perhaps a half oz portion of pork belly. This was a silly presentation and I strongly recommend they rethink serving a dish called ham and eggs when the "ham" looks like garnish on the plate. There are plenty of other places in town that source from local farms and can actually feed you (not just load you up on bread) a significant amount of protein for $12.

Some earlier reviews have mentioned their lack of preparedness or product and another took issue with the amount of condiments provided. I, too, had a problem with product availability, but I chalked it up to "opening day jitters".  I gave them another chance today. There's still an issue with product availability but I got my hands on a croissant. It was worth the wait!!! I've gone around the city trying croissants and they rank with my all-time favorites; past and present.  Hope they get the product availability issue worked out.
Amazing croissants!! I had the morning bun croissant and some sour dough bread and both were unbelievable. Not in my neighborhood, but planning on going back as soon as possible!

Each and everyone one of the team at Cellar Door are so very friendly and knowledgeable about their food. It's great to see the excitement in their eyes when they answer questions or tell you about new menu possibilities. The prices are very reasonable and the food is just great. Simple and great. If you don't have Justin's bread, you're doing yourself a disservice. Remember to get their early to enjoy their amazing pastries, they sell out quick!

Shared the quiche (creamy and delicious) and the house made sausage with poached egg and THE BREAD. Everything was delicious. Also- the coffee is very good - strong and not bitter. Eyed the pastries but was too full. Will return for those, as well as to test the lunch menu.

The food here is just delicious. I've been here about 5 times and am always impressed by the quality and simplicity of the meals. The bread and pastries are the best I have had in the city with the perfect flakiness. I've never had a wait for a table and the staff are always quite friendly. This is truly a gem!
Stopped by for brunch and it was great.  Clean tasting, fresh food that's very pretty to look at.  Coffee was great too.
$12 for a small bowl of parsnip soup. 12 for a small beet salad. No kidding. Food was good but nothing special and way overpriced.

The presentation and aesthetic is great. The baked goods are second to none. And the people working there are great.It's a low-key place where you get gourmet food without the pretension. For all the foodies out there, put it on your list.My dad said: "I've never had quiche like this in my whole life. It's simply amazing. Do they sell whole ones to take home?"

Very excited about the new place a block from my house! My wife and I love to spend our Saturday mornings at CDP enjoying the wonderful food and atmosphere.I have tried several variations of the quiche and it has always been great. The Morning buns are a must.The friendly staff and communal table set up have already led to new friends!
I never got to try anything because I left after standing in line listening to the cashier flirt with 2 girls for several minutes while ignoring me. How rude!

Wow, I'm glad I finally stopped in after gazing in the window at this inviting, sunlit, hip new space on my way home from work. The food is something else! Not only do they offer unique dishes that you'd be hard pressed to find elsewhere but they're all damn good! It will be hard to choose what to get when I return because I want everything on the menu...Not only this but sourcing came up in conversation with the staff and all the ingredients are sourced as locally as possible and with extreme quality in mind. Even the tea!

They have a beautifully decorated space! All of the tones are beige and light green with lots of natural touches like bamboo and twigs. I felt like it was a nice touch amidst the madness of downtown. Our party of 3 was seated immediately in the middle of lunch rush hour. Outside seats were already taken up, so if you're picky, get there early!We started by sharing the Kale and Artichoke Dip. We all looked at each when it arrived because the artichoke chunks were HUGE and they had raw kale on top, but it was superb. Between the three of us, we barely made it through half and already started to feel full. So good!I ordered the Turkey Press and I was not disappointed. I will say it was a little different than the description suggests. It's definitely more of a buttered bread that's toasted (think grilled cheese) as opposed to a panini, but still delicious! Huge slices of turkey, thick cuts of avocado and lots of garlic aioli. I didn't care for the bacon (and there wasn't much of it anyway!) because it wasn't crispy, but to each their own.My aunt ordered the Havana Club and my sister ordered the Chicken and Guac. Everyone was so happy, and as I sampled bites of everyone's I started to wonder whose I liked best! All of the sandwiches come with fries, tater tots or garlic mashed potatoes without an extra charge. Their were also options for a $1.50 upcharge, including sweet potato fries and a side salad.Of course, being in downtown, sandwiches ran around $14 a person, which wasn't terrible given location. Service was slow, but it wasn't because our waitress didn't care. I honestly think she was given way too many tables, which impacted her ability to wait on each of them in a timely manner.We enjoyed it, and will definitely try out some of the other restaurants in their chain!

I had two different cocktails, but I was really impressed with the porch flavored Jack Daniels. On a hot night, this one really hit the spot. I ordered the salmon BLT with sweet potato fries. The roll wasn't great as I recall, but the salmon was moist, the thick cut bacon was ciao and juicy, and the jalapeno aioli rounded out all the flavors together.Great location, great atmosphere, great food and drinks, friendly service. The only downer is the over the top prices.

Been back a couple more times (again, location location location) - drinks are not too sweet (Spa, Sinners & Saints, French 100, London Mule) and decently mixed -  not Aviary perfect of course but MUCH better than a well G&T at a dive bar. The whole rosemary frond in the London Mule is a nice touch, and the Sinners and Saints is appropriately strong.Do NOT get the steak sandwich - one of the worst pieces of meat I've ever had the displeasure of experiencing.  The brie and jam on it is tasty, but the steak was fatty, not charred, chewy and just downright awful.  Try something else - the tilapia looked very good.
One of my favorite lunchtime spots in the loop. I especially love it in the summer, their outdoor patio is amazing and right on the river. Plenty of space, but certainly make a reservation!

Nice place for a quick bite and drinks. It's busy and people are in and out. A lot of people go there to hold meetings and to chill after work. The food is OK, I ordered a sandwich and it was alright. Beautiful views, just a good location in general.

This is a good spot for work meetings and after work drinks, especially since it's located in the heart of the loop. I went here for a work lunch with a reservation for 7 people on a Wednesday afternoon, and we were sat promptly.For appetizers, we got the guacamole, tuna tartare, and bang bang shrimp. The shrimp was on the smaller side but very tasty. The guacamole was different in a good way; I would definitely recommend it. The tuna tartare was meh. Kinda flavorless and the chips were not good.For lunch, I ordered the Havana Club with fries. The sandwich was very flavorful, and the pork was very tender. The fries were good, but nothing special. With the addition of the appetizers, I was able to take half of the sandwich home and enjoy it as a second meal later.Overall, service was really great, and I'd recommend it if you're in the area and looking for a place to grab lunch.

Stopped for an early dinner and a drink (needed one after the Ledge experience at the Willy's Tower observation deck across the street!) We sat at the bar so there was no waiting time for us. Seemed like all the Milleninals who work in the adjacent offices were here! Great atmosphere, nice view of the river and loud music to block the noise of the tourist boats. Service was almost good and the food was OK, nothing to get too excited about. As a tourist I would stay away, they have enough locals they can count on.

Nice higher end grille with a great view right on the river, I've been here just for drinks, and after I did the ALA stair climb at the presidential towers, we went here afterwards, solid appetizer spread of veggies, pitas, hummus, tater tots, cheese curds and buffalo egg rolls. I got the south branch burger with asparagus, which was very good. And decent craft beer list as well. Granted my stair team foot the bill so I don't know the full cost of everything :p but it didn't seem too unreasonable

This place is in my work neighborhood, so I've been there several times. It gets crowded and a little too noisy at lunch time, especially if you're trying to have a work meeting over lunch, but the service is good and the food is even better.Their salads are really tasty, but today I treated myself to the bacon and Swiss cheeseburger piled high with avocado and served on a pretzel bun with tater tots on the side. If your mouth isn't watering yet, check your pulse.Best of all, they have ample outdoor seating that we took advantage of today, which eliminated the noise problem of eating in the restaurant. Whenever I leave work, I always see tons of people enjoying an outdoor happy hour, so that's on my after-work bucket list now.Overall, good lunch spot with above average food that isn't overly pricey. Try to sit outside.

I'm kind of over this place. The food is expensive, and just not that good. I had the Lobster Mac n' Cheese last night, and there were mayyyybe two pinkie-nail size shreds of Lobster meat. Just a big plate of noodles.The appetizers are spendy for a small amount of relatively mediocre food.The drinks are seem overly sweet, sweeter than before. And I hate, hate the pint glasses they're served in. I get that they are easy to shake with a cocktail shaker, but that type of glass is so utilitarian and inelegant.For the price, I've had a lot better.

Dropped in for lunch today with some coworkers and everything was fabulous! The place was busy but we were seated immediately at a table outside. Drinks came out quickly as well. I had a hard time deciding on what to get because everything sounded so good! All four of us ordered salads and loved them. I got the waldorf and Was impressed that all of my favorite toppings werent just on top where they usually sit, but were also in a layer underneath the lettuce. Next time I will get the seared tuna salad-looked amazing- and will hopefully be able to enjoy some cocktails as well

Shared the bang bang shrimp and had a few beers. Nice beer menu, drink menu and food selection looked appealing. Shrimp were fantastic. Establishment is a bit pricey so wouldn't be a regular stop for me but it was good. Staff is friendly and extremely helpful. Fantastic atmosphere.

The food here is reliably good and the service is always friendly.  I have been here for lunch about 50 times. The service is always friendly and non-judgmental, if, hypothetically, one drinks a few beers at lunch on a Monday.I ordered the fish tacos, which are always good.  My friend said that she liked the buffalo chicken wrap.I also recommend the chicken tortilla soup.

My experiences with South Branch have consisted of happy hour gatherings.  So, take that for what it's worth.  That said, I'm fine with it.  The patio that borders the river is a perfect place to be on a nice afternoon.  They've got a nice setup that is understandably packed given their prime location.  There's seating inside and out.  But, if it's a sunny day you'd best get your butt outdoors if you can stand the heat.  Tons of tables, some with umbrellas and a few hightops and a large bar with TVs in the middle.  South Branch has a decent craft beer selection though you'll have to get drafts from the inside bar as it's only cans and bottles outside.  It's definitely beer with the suits outside and if you listen closely you'll hear Patrick Bateman discussing murders and executions like you're at the Hitler youth RNC convention.  I prefer a quiet pub, but this is an alright choices for a few rounds at HH.

I personally love South Branch. I was taken here by my manager on my first day and left so satisfied. The service was decent, even though it was pretty busy.I had a bacon and avocado sandwich with sweet potato fries and this was more than enough. I had great leftovers once I got home.All in all, great experience at South Branch. Just looking forward to it warming up and being able to sit outside and enjoy wonderful dishes :)

We stopped over here with a decent sized group and had a very enjoyable time. They stuck us in the private room, which was sweet, and gave us our own waitress (who did a great job). We had drinks (wine, beer, cocktails, shots...) and even some apps (Bang Bang Shrimp, Buffalo Rolls, Cheese Curds, and Baked Spinach Dip) and they were all AMAZING. If I had to pick my two favorites I'd go w/ the shrimp and the rolls... both were out of this world!It's a good spot that wasn't too over-crowded while we were there. Definitely a nicer place at which you might feel underdressed in just jeans and a t-shirt.It's a good spot, we'll be back!
Best loop lunch spot. Probably wouldn't come outside working hours. Good working crowd for lunch and happy hour. *hot guys in suits* cowboy salad is the best salad there.

The five stars are based on one thing - fried cheese curds, everything else is immaterial.PS - I had never eaten cheese curds ever before this glorious evening happened to me, but I am going to dedicate the rest of my life towards finding cheese curds and eating them. Also, cheese curds should get their own emoji.

Very busy for lunch.  20 min wait.  I recommend making a reservation.  A spot opened up at bar.  Attentive bartender.  Wine glass had old imprint of lipstick, but besides that I ordered the salmon, which was perfectly cooked and moist. Tomato "coulis"  sauce could be from a gourmet jar, so it was lacking fresh flavor.  Nice pecan crusted on the outside with a generous portion of arugula salad.  Overall, a good experience.

For a Loop haunt and if looking for a venue with ambiance and location, this place is it. For outside dining or dining at a booth with a window, the view of the Chicago River is spectacular. Service is nonchalant, but not in a bad way. You get what you need, the servers stop by, just don't expect great service. It's just not the place for it...The Parmesan crusted talapia with spinach and garlic mashed potatoes is a delicious entree well worth the $15. The cobb salad, while my friend thought it was very good, wasn't anything special. Everything is plated well and is tempting. If you don't know what to order, I suppose looking at what is showing up at other tables is helpful, as I sincerely doubt the staff is going to give out any opinions.

After moving to an office downtown, this has been my go-to happy hour and lunch spot.  They have in my opinion, the BEST happy hour for anyone in the loop.  This is a place to see and be seen.  It gets very packed at Friday at 5pm, but if you don't mind standing up with your group by the bar, it can be a lot of fun to be in that atmosphere.  They have quite a few beers on tap and they make a great Moscow Mule.  There are a total of 3 bars at this restaurant.  One at the front inside, back inside, and one outside.  The appetizers are very tasty and usually don't take too long to come out once you put the order in.  I've had the calamari and the sliders, both were fantastic.Also they have an amazing outside section right by the river.  The location here is gold.  My friend and I have came here for lunch a couple of times sitting outside on a nice day enjoying the boats going by.  The food is actually pretty great too, I'm a big fan of the burgers and the chicken avocado wrap.  Also they have SWEET POTATO FRIES, that gives them +1 star in my book.  Keep doing what you're doing South Branch.

My new favorite downtown bar! Drinks & cocktails - prompt & perfect, service - excellent & friendly, food - flavorful & fun, plus outdoor seating, what's not to love?It's really a credit to Tim, the manager. His attention to detail will keep this place full every day of the week.The first time we came, we were only 2 people expanding to 4, and our food order was wrong, but we weren't sure. Tim came with the right item, and took care of the item in error.Needless to say, we came back with 16 people on a Monday, taking care of the staff as well as they took care of us.I think this is the start of a wonderful after work involving Happy Hour relationship...

Service is always great here, but my meal at this last lunch outing was not good at all. So the two stars are strictly based on the FOOD ONLY. Do not do not do not order the Veggie Burger... I know when SB first opened they had an amazing homemade black bean burger that I loved getting even though i like my meats. Then they took it off the menu for a long time and so when I saw it back on the menu yesterday I got all excited.  I have no idea what this current veggie abomination was, but it was basically a bland breaded brick of lord knows what, but all not good. When i left 3/4 of my burger still on the plate I think my co-workers almost had heart attacks since I always eat everything. Also, the sweet potato fries tasted like they were re-fried, so just added to the bad meal. I should've stuck to the salads or Turkey burgers like I usually have recently, but nostalgia got the best of me and it definitely was not the veggie burger of the "good ole days."

Took a long time to get seated and then no waiter showed up.  It was crowded so maybe that was the issue.  After 10 min I got up and left.  Nobody would've noticed except I sought out the host on the way out.

Had a quick lunch here and I had the buffalo chicken wrap, which was too much of everything for me, too much sauce, too much cheese and things were falling apart. I guess I am not a big fan of their wraps, but the place is nice so I will give 3 stars.

South Branch Tavern has a really great patio by the river and nicely decorated restaurant inside. That being said I probably will only return for happy hour drinks/appetizers after work rather than lunch. The menu was okay, but my fish tacos were rather bland and you can find a better lunch meal for less money other places in the loop.

Nice place to hangout, good food & drinks, but Service is not that great.I have been here once when I was in downtown and flying back to Minneapolis.   It is pretty good place to sit out, watch the people going towards the union station, office goers enjoying their evening.   I mean this place is full of energy and never a dull moment.  And when the weather is nice - the outdoor bar is really awesome.First - it is expensive - $25 for a drink and a burger.   I had a veggie burger - it was pretty good and it was really filling.Service - Not so great.   Most of the waiters have a cold look as if they are asking - hey why are you here !   Working in downtown with that kind of business and decent customers, I would have expected them to be full of energy.

This place has a great atmosphere with a sleek interior and a nice outdoor section right on the river. It is conveniently located right near the business district which makes it ideal for drinks after work. However they claim to have happy hour deals but I have not ever seen them.
Slower service during a busy Friday night. Wonderful atmosphere, fantastic food, and river view. This a wonderful place to enjoy your meal!

Always great service. Very crowded as they are not many bars in the main financial district of the Chicago Loop, however this place had been a fav since it opened several years ago.Their array of beers, GREAT sweet potatoe fries and fish tacos are amazing. Definitely, the place to go for happy hour. It's the ultimate, higher-end happy hour spot.

South Branch is your typical business lunch stop. Food is pretty good but nothing to write home about. The atmosphere is nice and they have patio seating right on the river which is perfect on warm days. Food is a little pricey for what you actually get but when work us footing the bill its as good a spot as any.

I opted to sit here with a cocktail while waiting to board a train rather than sitting down in Union Station.  Good move on the outdoor seating along the river.  Bad move for the food and drink.I ordered a French 100, one of their featured cocktails (and much like a French 75), but the champagne that came in it was flat.  Don't feature a cocktail on your list if you can't keep the ingredients for them fresh!  I ordered cheese curds to soak up the cocktail, but they tasted like they were fried in old oil.  Tasted like other people's stale dinners.  I couldn't eat more than a few, and I can *always* otherwise eat fried cheese.I mean, it was still kind of better than sitting down in the train station.  But if you've been down there, you know that's not saying much.
great chopped salad. Very busy, no lunch reservations for small groups. Convenient location- service was good.
Delicious salad, friendly staff, generous portions and no tv's. Perfect for a lunch meeting or lunch with colleagues.

I don't really know where to begin but I'll start by saying this was my second and LAST time at this establishment.To begin, the place is in the perfect location. The food is pretty decent, not much to complain about.However, my service tonight was deplorable.  A group of my friends had decided that this would be a nice place to meet for our annual girls night dinner/ drinks. We did it once before and the experience was decent. We came back tonight and were rushed, to say the least. We had a group of of six and were seated around 7pm. We ordered meals and drinks but after an hour were told the kitchen was closing, then, about 20 minutes later we told it was last call. I had barely touched my meal and was planning to have a few drinks. Anyway, within minutes we were asked to box everything up and were given the checks. We paid but continued to finish our drinks and were then kicked out! The man who kicked us out was soo rude! The place wasn't supposed to close until 10 and we were asked to leave before 9pm.Never in my life have I been treated in such a rude fashion. I was forced to stand outside in 20 degree weather to wait for my ride because they would not allow us to wait inside at 9pm! I understand wanting to close early on a slow night, but you do not do that when you have PAYING customers who intended to have a nice night out.Needless to say we will never be back. How rude, south branch.

This is for the bar only. Incredibly slow service. I'm done with it. You'll wait forever between drinks, I guess they keep it short staffed to maximize the bartender's tips. Drinks are average strength. Too many other bars in the Loop for overpriced drinks.

We were very sadly underwhelmed at this restaurant. It has a beautiful location, fantastic decor, and a large outdoor seating area. Sadly, the food and service fell short of expectations.The service was very slow. The waitress took our food after we were done and didn't offer it to go. We assumed it was... but it wasn't. We sat forever with an empty glass of beer before the waitress returned.Maybe if you sat at the bar it would be better, but as a sitdown it won't be good enough to bring us back

We had an event here in the private room, after cocktails on the patio. The patio is beautiful and overlooks the river.  Very crowded on this night with people enjoying the great weather. Quick service and the server was able to transfer our drink tab to the private room bill.The private room was very nice - comfy chairs, a tv if needed, one wall was all glass so we didn't feel trapped. Service was great. We were able to prop the glass door open and the restaurant quieted down fairly early (9pm on a Wednesday).Food was good and not overly fancy.
It's a wonderful place for happy hour and a the food is very solid. The next time I need a place to meet a client, I will be back!

It's a decent place to grab lunch. I love the interior decoration -- it has a slightly casual, upscale, yet elegant vibe. I just don't like the green river but that's not their fault. ;-)As far as the food, it's where you can find your over-priced yet still tasty business lunch. It's nothing that's extraordinary. I really enjoyed their Bang Bang shrimp as an appetizer. It has an Asian twist to it with just enough crunch. Their hummus platter was decent. I liked the texture that more resembles peanut butter than Sabras or what you can get at a grocery store.I also ordered the Mahi Mahi salad. Although the dressing was good, the napa cabbage seemed wilted. The portions are ginormous though! Even after one hour of digging in, I still had what could pass as a complete portion in front of me. The salad is about $17 so ... be aware. The mahi mahi wasn't super fresh though, which is disappointing.Overall, it's a great place for a business lunch. If you're trying to impress a client, I think the location rather than the quality of the food itself is more important, but hey, what do I know as a yuppie?

Over. Rated.Like everywhere else in Chicago the drinks are expensive. I've only had a bite to eat once and it was decent. Don't ask what it was I don't remember, I just know I didn't hate it.Don't get me wrong this place isn't bad at all. I just don't  get the appeal except during the non-winter months when the outdoor section is open. Only problem with that is it's nuts to butts full of people and if you have even the mildest bit of claustrophobia, you will bail fast.The service has always been good but I just don't race over there for happy hour and when my coworker peeps do I bounce when it gets crowded. So check it out grab a drink, who knows you may love it.

Came here last night for dinner& drinks....First, it's a hidden spot on Wacker dr. As I walked in there wasn't anything too special about the place.As for food.. It was good but just your average restaurant food. They had a nice wine selection. The service was excellent. No complaints there!Honestly.. It just an average restaurant. I am sure the summer is awesome to come here because I noticed they have a nice patio.If your looking for somewhere close to the metra to grab dinner this place may be your option.

Definitely make a reservation. Nice atmosphere. Delicious garlic hummus 'app' with herbed pita and veggies. My friends and I had burgers. I had the veggie burger which was actually more grains and beans than veggie. It was tasty!  Plus a side of tator tots!  Yum. The burger was a little dry and crumbled apart. I had it without the aioli.  Felt like we were eating at a European restaurant since we shared a long table, and salt/pepper shakers, with 4 other people. I would go back. Would be nice to have gotten a booth overlooking the river. Close to the train stations.

Usually I have a great experience when I don't sit at the bar.  Got here at 5:00pm, was very busy.  As it died down, could hear the bartenders complaining together about everything.  My drink was empty and they were all standing around, had to constantly flag them down.  Will not return unless I'm sitting outside.

I am giving this slightly higher than average reviews for one reason- location.South Branch does attract a certain douchy "too cool for my own good" clientele on the average sunny afternoon- but once you swallow that pill its a great little place.  The food and drinks are good- the prices are fair.  The location in the heart of the financial area makes it perfect for anyone looking for a business lunch, lunch date, or end of quarter drink-fest.I have been many, many times and will keep going back.  I get buffalo chicken wrap often (and tots) because I know exactly what I am getting every time.  Its good stuff, and worth the price.Good service too.

Food is usually really good (for lunch), especially the Cowboy Salad or Black & Blue Burger. My only gripe is not with the food or service, but the fact that they block reservations on OpenTable from 11:30am to 1pm so you have to CALL for a reservation (grrr). We come here 2-3 times a month.

I have visited South Branch on many occasions for lunch, happy hour, and work events. They already gain a star for having outdoor seating along the river. If you go during lunch time though you're going to want to go on the earlier side because they do not take reservations. If your into sports this is a great place to go to watch the game. Many TVs and great atmosphere. When I lived in the burbs I also like it's close to the metra train station, so you can eat and have plenty of time to make your train.My favorite item on the menu has got to be the buffalo rolls. Must get appetizer when you go. I also enjoy the Santa FE wrap and I go back and forth between getting the fries or being my child like self and getting the tater tots as my side. They were very accommodating when hosting myself and coworkers for events. We had everything from the veggie platter,  to the hummus, to the mini sliders and everything was good. There is something for everyone on the menu.

I'm sad to say I had an extremely disappointing experience with South Branch two weeks ago, after my winter coat was stolen from the coat rack. After closing out my tab, my friends and I went to grab our coats, and mine was no longer hanging on the rack. The employees told me they had seen a girl walk out with two winter coats - one tied around her waist over the one she was wearing. My keys and work badge were in the pockets of my coat.The following day, I called to see if my belongings had been returned. South Branch called me back later that day to inform me that the finance of the girl who took my coat had dropped my keys and work badge off, but not my coat, and he would *likely* drop my coat off in a few days.When I went to pick up my keys and my badge and found that my coat had not yet been returned, I asked that management contact the person who had dropped my keys and badge off, and they told me that they had not taken down any contact information for him, which is extremely disappointing. I, and a number of my colleagues, work right across the street and have loved grabbing drinks at South Branch after work. Unfortunately, after this experience, I will not be returning. I really wish the situation had been handled differently.

they only thing going for this place is its location which is probably why you they have such a snotty attitude, The food is marginal at best, which makes you wonder why they make you wait so long to get a table. Try Rivers in the CME building across the street, they typically seat  you within 5 minutes and food is great, sans the attitude!

South Branch does lunch rightFriendly and fast service compliments of Jessica, tasty food and an excellent beer and drink menu.  I'll vouch for the Cuban sandwich, if you're lucky you'll get a few sweet potato tater tots in your side selection :)

South Branch has potential to be one of the few great spots in the Loop. However, they rest on their location and skimp entirely on service. I ordered a salad and it took half an hour to prepare, then requested a box since I had to leave (due to not having time to eat) and that took another 15 minutes. I left having had a couple sips of beer and nothing else.

Classic American food and perfect place for a business lunch.  You can be as casual or formal as you want.  Make a reservation as it's extremely packed during lunch hours.  Food is what you'd expect:  sandwiches, wraps, salads, etc.  It's the perfect place to not be adventurous.

I wanted to try this place for a while. It is always crowded over the lunch hours when I walk by on the river side. Finally get a chance to try this out with my coworker. We arrived a bit early than our reservation. But they didn't have the table till almost our reservation time. Still quite a few people were still waiting. Quite a popular choice.The lobby is huge with very modern decorations. It would be very nice to sit outside during the summer. I chose the tomato basil soup and Cowboy salad. The tomato soup was a disaster. It tasted like they dumped the half cup of salt in there. I stopped after one spoonful. The waiter took that out my bill in  the end.I loved my salad which has a big portion with all ingredients I like and very fresh. I truly tried my best to finish it but could only ate half of it. My coworker liked her fish Taco.The price was a bit high for lunch. I also got a sense that this place is too popular to care for you. From the hostess to the waiters, they are busy and professional but they were more like " this is our way so you could leave if you don't like it.". I might give this another try for the after work drink.

I came here on a Friday evening with a big group of friends to celebrate two birthdays. We didn't make a reservation beforehand, which was a bad idea since it was poppin' with people (It was 5pm on a Friday, after all. TGIF amirite?) Anyways, when we got there, the waiter spent about ten minutes trying to find a table that would accommodate us. Fortunately, he found us one, and guess where it was?! In a private room! The room was absolutely beautiful, and it included a huuuuge round table so that we were all facing each other. We got really lucky for not having made a reservation. Anyways, I ordered the fish tacos. When served, they looked absolutely amazing and vibrant. Props to the chef for having good plating skillz. The taste, however, was pretty average. I don't know if it's because I'm Pakistani and I NEED tons of spices/flavor for a food to taste really good to me, but their fish tacos were just lackin'. I was so ecstatic when I ordered them because I love fish tacos more than I love my cat (actually, not really), but the taste was honestly a 6/10. My friend ordered lobster mac 'n' cheese, which was around $20 for a bowl, and after one bite, she pushed it away. She didn't like the taste at all, so she resorted to eating my side of sweet potato fries. Tragic.All in all, the food was pretty average. I probably won't go again because I don't think the food was worth what I paid for. However, the views from the restaurant are amazing, so don't hesitate to have a photo-shoot with your girlfriends next to the river afterwards!

South Branch is one of the nicest happy hour/lunch venues in my area of the Loop, and I am very grateful to have a reliable spot for after work drinks or a long, relaxing lunch.  Of course, nice decorations and ambiance mean higher menu prices, but sometimes that is a sacrifice I'm willing to make to sit in a roomy booth and drink out of an actual glass.The food and drinks here are pretty good.  For lunch, I like the burgers and the buffalo wrap, as well as the buffalo egg rolls (fried heaven).  There is a decent selection of beer here, and while I'm not a huge liquor person my Jack and diet seemed fine to me :).Be warned though-- this place has weird hours as most places in the loop do! Happy hours will be cut short to 10 or 11ish (so you'll have to move locations to get really weird with your co-workers...).

I made a reservation for my friend and me to meet here for lunch. Unfortunately, I can't comment on the food...because I never made it to a table. My friend did. She checked in with the hostess manning the computer (there were three hosts at the desk) and was seated. I, on the other hand, stood by the host table waiting for her. I'm not completely blaming the hosts for our Keystone Kopness of not meeting...but my name is unique and they had just heard it five minutes ago and if they have a bad memory they could have used their computer system thing to note that one guest checked in. Use technology to improve service and efficiency, people. Unimpressed by service makes me unsure about returning.

Two co-workers and I stopped in for lunch. It was fine. I just got a bowl of vegetarian chili, which was good and filling. The lunch atmosphere seemed more geared toward business people who wanted to seem classy during a business lunch.I would like to go back for dinner, though. A coworker got a mac and cheese dish which looked good and it seemed like a good place to get beer.

I've been planning a private event and I can't thank the wonderful team at South Branch enough for their efforts in making sure everything today ran smoothly from beginning to end. The people in my networking group noticed and were impressed by this as well. The orders were taken in a timely manner, food brought out right away and they were terrific with helping me out in making sure my presentation ran well on their TV screen. They also worked closely with me to develop a menu with my group's logo on it, which looked sharp.South Branch has a very nice room that worked out great for my luncheon group of 22. When you're hosting an event, it's some real peace of mind to be this well taken care of so you can focus primarily on your event agenda. It's why I'm looking forward to our group returning next month for another luncheon and more to come.If you're looking for a great place to hold a private luncheon or evening event, talk to Jennifer, Christina and the team at SB. They'll be incredibly helpful and detailed to ensure your event is a success like mine. Thank you South Branch!
Salmon and Mahi Mahi were amazing!  Service was great as well.  Great decor and atmosphere.

Came here for lunch today with my coworker since it is such a gorgeous day out and we wanted to sit outside. When we first went in the hostess said it'd be about 20 minutes if we wanted a spot outside, but when we went up to the hostess for outside they sat us right away..don't know what that was all about, but whatever.We were taken to a high top table in the crowded outside area that surrounds a full bar. We were promptly greeted by our waitress who took our drink orders and we decided to get the buffalo rolls appetizer. These were awesome! They're like egg rolls..but with buffalo chicken in them, and they come with carrots, celery, homemade blue cheese, and extra buffalo sauce.For my entree I ordered the waldorf salad. It was pretty good, but the beets were a little overpowering for me. I loved the candied walnuts, cranberries, and the sliced apples with apple vinaigrette. I saw them bring someone some kind of salmon salad that looked pretty good..I'll have to try that next time. Coworker got some kind of cuban club sandwich with avocado and bacon. and picked the side of mashed potatoes. This portion of mashed potatoes was insane, like as big as my head. He really liked the sandwich, but could hardly put a dent in the mashed potatoes.Prices here are a bit steep for lunch but what do you expect for the loop.

It's been the same since it opened.  I do like the place for after work as it's conveniently located.When it originally, in 2011, rated it high as it was new and fresh. Today, and perhaps rightfully sow, they know they have a lock on the market and they definitely take customers for granted in the delays in food/drink and the challenges of getting a table on some days.Wait staff is exceptional.  Hostess, at least on the North end, was poor recently.  Just lacked common sense on customer service.  So I do feel this establishment takes customers for granted as the "host/hostess" is really supposed to set the overall tone of the experience.

I love their food already but when I needed a great place near the Lyric for a pre-show dinner, they accommodated my reservation request even though the timeslot wasn't available online (mostly likely due to packed happy hour). Very appreciative!

It's getting warm. So grab your shades and join me for a drink at one of my favorite patios in Chicago - South Branch. Located off the Chicago River and around the corner from Union Station the restaurant and bar attracts the after work crowd and visitors. It is easy to see why. The large patio overlooking the Chicago River is elegant and modern and the patrons imbue it with fun energy. The interior is well decorated, incorporating woodsy forest elements ("South Branch"...get it? Like the south branch of the river or a tree!).The appletini is good, if pricey. The food and appetizers are decent. It's pretty crowded here and so reservations for tables are encouraged. Or face the crush of the bars. It's not open late or weekends. Glad the weather is cooperating for relaxing on the river with pals. I'll save you a seat!

I work right across from here, and could not resist a leisurely lunch on the first really warm, sunny patio day in spring.  Definitely make a reservation the day before if the weather looks good - this place gets busy during lunch and at happy hour.  Their patio is really big and has its own bar.  Easy to forget you're just in Chicago and it almost feels like you're on vacation - it's just a really nice atmosphere.Drinks are a little expensive but that's too be expected.  My friend and I split the garlic hummus (tasty, but I'd say overpriced at $10) that comes with nice herbed pita and crisp fresh veggies (which they refill if you finish).  I got the Asian salad which was really refreshing and cool on a hot day.  The sesame tuna was fresh and seared perfectly, the wontons added great crisp, and the dressing had great flavor.  Again, expensive at $15 but it was a big salad and I couldn't quite finish it.Basically a great place for a sit-down loop lunch or a happy hour.  You pay the "loop tax" for the atmosphere and the crowd (trendy Loopers in their twenties and thirties).  Probably a good place to meet someone if that's what you're after!  Just try to get that reservation if you can or be prepared to wait!

The draw of this place HAS to be the outdoor seating on the river, right? Because everything else is just wrong.We had 5 p.m. indoor reservations (pre-theater dinner) for 12 on a Wednesday. It was 95 degrees that day so we opted for a cooler indoor setting rather than sweat our balls off outside.The place was packed. From front to back to outside - every inch of space was taken up by after-work patrons, which wasn't the downfall of South Branch.... it was the service and food, both lacking of attention.Our server, though nice and semi-engaging, wasso.so.soslow. We'd order drinks and it would take her 10 minutes to get back to the table. She would constantly forget to ask the entire table if they wanted another round - or a first round for one person. We didn't get requested water until almost halfway through our meal. And.... our meal. Ugh.I got the Asian salad. I never knew tuna could be so disgusting; unable to be cut through and downright inedible. I think it had gristle in it like steak. It probably wasn't even tuna.... My coworkers' food pretty much stacked up in the same fashion.... over-cooked and processed burgers, dry salmon, tasteless entrees. Yuck.Even if the patio is the draw, I definitely won't patronize South Branch again. Rivers down the way at least has decent food.
Great place to go after work. It's relaxed, professional, and tasty. How? I'm not sure, but plain good and plenty.

My review is for drinks and atmosphere only - none of us ate food.Stopped after work for a few drinks with some coworkers.   It was decent out, so we grabbed a couch-like booth outside.   We got there early, like 4:15.....and by 5:00, I don't think you'd would have found a seat.Waitress was nice - seemed to be around when you needed her.    Prices weren't too bad, and they had a decent selection of wine and beer.It sucked having to fight the crowd inside to use the bathroom - which is tucked away in the back.Great location and nice outdoor seating - I'd come back for drinks for sure!

My husband and I popped in last night for a bite to eat and a glass of wine. Unfortunately they had already started to shut down the kitchen. After a long day at work, the manager, Tim, could see that I was bummed and immediately went to the kitchen to see what they could whip up. Ten minutes later we were feasting on some delicious appetizers and sipping wine. The staff was friendly and our bartender, Kelli, was adorable and hilarious! What a great way to end the day! Highly recommend!
Great food and drinks! The place has a good ambiance with great views. Nice place for either lunch or happy hour after work. Service is sub-par

Arrived here for a lunch at about 12:30pm and that was a mistake.  There was a waiting list and we headed to the bar.  We were able to find two spots and our whole group moved in there.  Now this would have been great if it was dinner but this was lunch and we were not getting alcohol.  Yummy ice tea, soda and water.  I so needed a splash of vodka in my kid drink.We finally got a table at around 1pm.  Waitress came by and took our order.  I ordered the Cobb Salad which consisted of grilled chicken, romaine, bacon, egg, pepperjack, tomatoes, and avocado.  I also went with blue cheese dressing on the side.  The salad was really good.  There was a lot of avocado in there too.  I also needed something bad and was going to get a side of tater tots.  I asked my buddy if I could have a couple of his and he said yes.  He was really generous and gave me a small plate full  And yes I ate them all and they were cooked perfectly.If I was in the area and needed a nice place to eat, then I would come here for food.  Hopefully it will be way past the lunch crowd but before the after work force.  I read that they have an outdoor patio on the river too.  I did not see it but I am sure it starts rocking in the warmer weather.

I had dinner and drinks here recently with a few friends for a happy hour event. South Branch was very accommodating regarding reservations and flexible with fluctuating numbers/moving tables around. Additionally, the waitress was great about splitting checks up for our group which I'm sure is a pain to deal with.I had the seared tuna salad, which was good but not amazing (someone pointed out that it could use some acidity like lemon which I agree with and think this would be a great addition). Everyone else's food looked great (I'm definitely trying the turkey burger next time) and folks enjoyed what they had. Food service was very quick.The one downside was that the red wine I ordered was VERY warm. I would expect this in a dive bar/pub, but South Branch is not a dive bar and has a decent wine list so I expected better. To me, warm red wine is pretty unpalatable. That being said, I would certainly go back as there was a great atmosphere on a Friday after work, plenty of space and a good menu. I know they have a great outdoor patio area so maybe I'll wait until winter is over!

I went here quite often because it is close to my office.  It is usually packed by 1140a so get there early.  I tried fish taco and you can get a larger portion of fish from a fish fillet sandwich in the union station.  It is only Tilapia, not sea bass, I wondered why are they so cheap?  I had to stuff my face with their cole slaw and chips to make me 'feel' full.The other time I tried their salmon.  The fish was warm, not hot like from the pan.  I guessed the fish was pre-cooked and sitting in the oven during lunch hours.For the money I am paying, I would rather go to Rivers.

Pretty solid lunch spot in the West Loop (have also heard good things about their happy hour, but I cannot attest personally)... Stopped by for a quick one with a buddy, and two seats came available at the bar, otherwise there appeared to be a 5-10 min wait. Menu looked great, but on a Friday during Lent I was "forced" to go with the Ahi Tuna Wrap. Quotes used because while I was bummed to not have the other stuff, it was short lived since the wrap was very, very good. Came with tater tots as well, which is always a favorite. Price was a bit high, but kind of what I had expected for such a nice venue. Will definitely be back!

I pride myself on being a connoisseur of Tequila and when I asked for a patron margarita, the waitress said we don't serve patron, which is my favorite.  At this point, I can't even remember what Tequila she said they had BUT when I was served the Margarita there was absolutely no Tequila in the drink.  The drink didn't even look like a Margarita more like a bottle of lemon juice from the counter at the store and umm that's what it taste like.The appetizers were not all that.  I was really disappointed after having expectations of indulging in delicious food and cocktails after a long day of work.  And of course I was the only one asked out of the group for ID.  LOL! I am over 40 and have children, honestly I don't think I look that darn young.Will not be returning to this spot.  Too many other fabulous restaurants in Chicago that serve AWEsome margaritas and appetizers.

The patio here is money; food is average, but there's no incentive to be great when you are in the Loop and serving $12-$14 cheeseburgers anyway!  I will say, a bit of a surprise--my colleagues enjoyed their ahi tuna salad and the veggie version of the Santa Fe wrap, so I'm sure we'll be back since our new office opened just a 10-minute walk from here.  Warm weather in Chicago!
Fun and lively lunch spot. Food was great. I had an Asian-influenced salad. Drinks are great.I'm in!

Love this place for lunch with the girls, birthday celebrations with the boss, or drinks after work with friends. Its cozy, sexy, and has the best summer patio in the area. The food is great as well, stop in, you won't be mad you did. The decor is stunning with a stone wall, private wine dining room, and branches (the name is south branch) that are really pretty and well done.I love it for the work week.

First of all, hats off to the staff.  They are absolutely great.  When some friends and I stumbled in a little tipsy and louder than needed, they didn't blink an eye and sat us right away.  They laughed at our silly jokes, but more importantly knew their stuff.  Knew their beers, wines, and bourbons.    The food being great was bonus.

Located near Union Station, it was the perfect spot for dinner after I rode the train into the city. Even though it looked pretty packed from the after-work crowd, my boyfriend and I were seated right away.I ordered one of the weekly specials: smoked brisket grilled cheese, which came with this sweet potato "soup" that was supposed to be used as a dipping sauce. I got tater tots as my side, which weren't anything special, but the smoked brisket grilled cheese and sweet potato soup/sauce were delicious. For my drink, I ordered a Magners Cider - yummy.Service was pretty good too - waitress was attentive, water glass was always filled, and food came out in a timely manner.I definitely want to come back when the weather is nice enough to sit outside.

I am a great fan of South Branch.  Yet again today, another fabulous lunch!
