The food here is not your typical Thai fare you get from most places in the city (although mad love to some pad Thai on a HO'd Sunday) and that is what makes it great.I can't really repeat verbatim all I've had there as I can't pronounce a darn thing but basically anything in lettuce wraps, satay, grilled octopus (wow!), beef curry, any soup...and last night I had the Cornish hen which was much bigger than expected and the seasonings were AMAZING. BYOB always always on point too.
So good!!! The tiger cry and the papaya salad are outstanding. Will come back just for those!!!

Ordered via Uber Eats and had the chicken basil stir fry with egg.  I guess i missed the part on how spicy it was and ground chicken.....egg a little over cooked. Favor was goodBut willing to try in the future

Amazing Thai food.  I myself am Thai and this reminds me of my mom's cooking.  The khao ka moo is like what you would get on the street in Thailand, and the khao mun gai is really good (the sauce is amazing).  Too bad we don't live in Chicago or else we would come here often.
Service was awesome! The ladies were super friendly. Love the food... I'm no expert on Thai food, but my fav was the soup and grilled beef salad with the sticky rice.

Maybe I came on an off day, sadly I didn't like anything here! We started with the chicken sausage balls, crying tiger, tom yum soup, and crispy chicken wings,.  The chicken sausage had a rubbery consistency and odd flavor.  The crying tiger beef was tender but it was bland and seemed like it wasn't marinated long enough in the sauce.  It came with sauce on the side so were thankful for that but the same sauce was served with every appetizer so it lost its luster.  The tom yum soup didn't have much flavor and tasted watery. I did enjoy the chicken wings, they were perfectly crispy and flavorful.  The beef curry entrée was decent but just one note and didn't excite me. I was excited to try this place but, honestly, I've had much better Thai food in the city.

This place is great. Having lived in Bangkok and tried Thai restaurants all over the city,  I can say this is one of the most authentic places I've been. The menu is very original with a lot of items you won't find on a usual Thai menu - on the flipside if you are looking for a pad thai joint, this probably won't be your favorite.Staff is also very friendly and JJ is also good for carryout.

I may have just found my new favorite authentic Thai place! Don't come here if you want greasy, heavy pad thai or fried crab Rangoon.  It's authentic, fresh and full of flavor.  I had the Basil Seafood and was blow away with the first bite!  The flavor of the basil, seafoods and sauce was balanced really well. My boyfriend got the Braised Pork Noodle and was equally impressed.  The pork was very tender and flavorful. We will be coming back soon to try out the rest of the menu!

We love this place. The pork salad and tiger cry were delicious with the sticky rice. Those sauces are so addictive. We also got the chicken wings to start. They were juicy and crispy. We had the taro and coconut dessert which I love, but for $5, it seems the portion is even tinier than it was before. That's the only disappointing thing. Everything else is amazing!

I've been here one other time, and we also had a carry-out order from here.  Last night, we landed here because we had just come back from our honeymoon in the Caribbean and needed some good Asian food after eating jerk chicken and lots of grilled seafood all week.  I wanted soup, my husband wanted low-carb (he's preparing for an upcoming jiu jitsu tournament).  This time, we ordered tom yum soup, the beef salad, and a Thai iced coffee.  The soup hit the spot, and the beef salad was so flavorful and amazing.  Like, I NEED to figure out how to make this at home.  If there's a salad I'll eat, it's one filled with meat.  Thai iced coffee was huge and very good.  This place is also SUPER close to home!  My memory is failing me on the other items we've tried, but one that I do remember is the fried chicken wings!  Delicious.  Glad this moved into the old Yuzu spot.
This is the best Thai restaurant in Chicago, and is a notch up from Opart (also worth a visit). The Basil Chicken here is crave worthy, and the daily specials are authentic and outstanding.
Excellent Thai food. Great place to enjoy friends and or family with traditional Thai food. I have Thai friends that love to come here as well, and give the stamp of approval!

A few years ago, I spent two weeks travelling all over Thailand. I fell in love with everything Thailand and vowed I will live there one day. There are hundreds of Thai restaurants in Chicago, but JJ Thai is the first I've found that pretty much transported me right back to Thailand! The food is amazing and is closer to what you'll find in the far-flung areas of Thailand than most other Thai places in Chicago. If you've decided that you're not a fan of Thai food, you should seriously consider giving JJ Thai a shot. If you love Thai food, you should give JJ Thai a shot. If you eat food, you should give JJ Thai a shot!! Outstanding place (and it's BYOB!!)

Opening night diner there was great. Limited menu tonight, totally understandable. Huge addition to the neighborhood. We had the chicken meatball appetizer to start. Very tasty, great sweet and sour sauce. Nice and spicy. Then we had the Khao Mun Gai (chicken over rice with spicy sauce).  Awesome ginger sauce. Super spicy with great flavor. Get extra sauce! Also had the Guay Tiew Moo Thoon (rice noodle in pork broth with pork meatball). This reminded me of Vietnamese pho. Pork broth with great cinnamon sort of flavor. Delicious.  Plus all the staff was super nice and very attentive. The bomb Thai iced tea and addictive banana chips sealed the deal. Can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu.
The Food is deliciosa Quite authentic. Highly recomiendes! Basil seafood is fantastic. Sticky rice also perfect On top that blob and pleasant staff
After many visits, my respect for this place has only increased.  Almost everything on the menu is worth trying.

So if your restricted on your food choices due to allergies or food restrictions this is not the place to go. I only do vegetarian or seafood when I eat outside. So, my choices were severally limited at this place. I had about two things I could really order at this place.The food was ok but not as authentic as I expected. I got the seafood rice which was ok and the shrimp hot and sour soup which was actually good. The staff was friendly and helpful in helping me decide on what to order. I'm not sure if I'd come back to this place. It's really small and dark lighting. This place is nothing out of the ordinary. I had higher expectations.

We chose to go here because of all the great Yelp reviews. I ordered the Curry Beef n Noodles. I dont know how else to describe it but the beef looked absolutely disgusting. It was so bad I couldn't eat it. I did not complain nor did I return the plate but I don't think I'll be coming back here. Additionally, there was a really foul oder as we walked in that took me a minute to get used to. Unfortunately I cannot recommend this place, however, to give a little credit, the Chicken Satay was very good!

After seeing the amazing reviews for this place, we were super excited to try the new Thai place that just opened up in our neighborhood.The first slight con is that on Yelp, it said the place offered delivery. This was not entirely accurate. On this cold, snowy day, delivery would have been money, but I guess they have not yet started this service. We finally bit the bullet and went with pick-up.Overall, it was good, but definitely not OMG mind-blowing good. We ordered the fried chicken wing appetizer to start. The wings were slightly dry and the sauce that accompanied the wings was alright. For the entree, we ordered the Khao Lard Ka Praw Gai (ground chicken basil) with fried egg. Now this dish, was pretty darn tasty and I would highly recommend it. The yolk of the egg mixed with the chicken really elevated the flavor. Plus, we asked for it spicy and the heat was spot on. The other entree we ordered was the Guay Tiew Kaeng Neua (rice noodle with beef curry). This dish was also tasty. The curry had a nice balance of spicy and sweet. The only negative is that there was very little beef (4 or 5 pieces) and the quality of the steak was poor. One piece was mostly fat and not really edible. I do also wish the menu was a little more descriptive as I am not the biggest boiled egg fan and the curry came with boiled egg. But that's just a personal preference thing.I will definitely order from here again, especially when they offer delivery. Even though they don't have dishes that we typically associate with Thai, this place is definitely worth visiting!

I have been here twice in the last month. The food has wonderful flavor and is nicely presented. My husband and I have tried a new dishes each time and have enjoyed them all. There are many meat dishes but nice vegetarian options as well. You will not find the Thai dishes typically found in Thai restaurants such as Pad Thai - which made me try some delicious new dishes. The atmosphere is also fun and comfortable. A wonderful new addition to the neighborhood!

Pros: Had the Guay Tiew Moo Thoon (rice noodle in pork broth with pork meatball). Tasty, flavorful, fresh tasting, quality ingredients.  I could go on and on...  This is not your typical Thai restaurant, they don't serve pad Thai, pot stickers, etc., this has more of an authentic feel to it, like eating at someone's house.  Be sure and experiment with the lazy Susan containers of chili they bring to your table.  I chose the mildest (red) one which surprisingly added an extra kick to my already full-bodied soup.  It was so good I kept adding more, more and more !!Tip: Thai iced coffee was more than generous.... just request easy on the ice.Attentive and caring service. They really, I mean really appreciate your business!Cons:  Seating. One word, uncomfortable.  They have those baby stools you see everywhere now, with no backing.  I was fortunate to grab a (1) table with stiff-backed industrial chairs, still uncomfortable though.  What happened to cushions???Sorry I like my drinks stiff, just NOT my chair!
The other reviews are spot-on when referencing the "authenticity" of this place. Hidden gem for sure. Love the music. I'll be back.

There are several Thai restaurants nearby to JJ, but this might become my favorite! I tried the chicken wonton appetizer, and the noodles with BBQ pork. Both were delicious. The inside is pretty small, so coming with more than 4 people might be a little difficult during peak hours. I liked the relaxed atmosphere and how the restaurant is decorated. Service was prompt and polite, what more can you ask for? Will definitely be back!
The braised pork rice was great!nicely braised,soft and savory. In contrast, i think the braised chicken over ginger rice was less outstanding. Love the tom yam soup though!

Very flavorful! Very cozy Very casual! Very yummy! Very affordable!! Lots of good things.Will be going back for sure. Water was given to us as soon as we sat down. We ordered off the menu and then decided to change our minds as we, noncreepily, watched our neighbors receive their bounty, and wanted what they had. I ordered the chicken and ginger rice (great portion, spices were on point, and chicken was tender and moist), grilled squid (just crispy and tender enough without being chewy, larger portion of squid i've ever seen), and I forgot the other entree but it was good. Will be going back for sure, I've already said that, but I really mean it.I wonder if they will have an outdoor patio for warmer weather? I only am wondering b/c I want to make sure they have enough space for me. All the time.Also, I think it's BYOB....but really don't quote me on that. It may have been some deep, dark desire of mine.

This amazingly authentic restaurant just opened in my neighborhood and I couldn't be happier about it!  Everything is amazing, the people that work here are lovely, and now that they offer delivery it could be dangerous!  If you're looking for the real deal, this is it!

Go here. You won't regret it. Everything I've had here smells amazing and is incredibly flavorful, and I like that it's not your run-of-the-mill pad Thai joint - you won't find that or pad se ew here - instead you'll find a streamlined menu of street food dishes. Their fried chicken with ginger rice, JJ tiger cry (charbroiled sliced steak with chili sauce), basil chicken with egg, and taro in steamed coconut milk dessert (oh god the taro, so good) are my favorites. The portions are generous and reasonably priced, the staff are friendly, it's BYOB, and the ambiance is cozy and casual. Everyone I've recommended this place to also loves it, so I hope it becomes a fixture in our neighborhood!

I live in Humboldt Park and this is one of few good Thai restaurants in the city without having to drive to Uptown or brave Lincoln Park/Lake View traffic. We've tried most of the menu and everything has been good. Particularly like the chicken meatballs and squid apps. The som tom was good but not spicy enough even though we asked for Thai style spicy. And khao man gai (not fried) is delicious and hard to find in the city. Will definitely be back.

My girlfriend and I closed the place out last night, and it was great. Didn't feel rushed or hurried. We got the Gai Yan with a side of sticky rice, the Tom Yum Kung Nam Khon, and the Guay Tiew Moo Thoon. The music, the room, and the menu names really make it an authentic experience. Also it's BYOB, so we brought in a bottle of wine for a really affordable date night. Awesome place, can't wait to go back and try more dishes!

Incredible.  Hot if you want.  Delicious and a fun atmosphere.  I enjoyed every dish.  Apps and entrées are on point.  Try it now! The sausage balls and tiger cry were on point.  Small and quaint.  Bring your own booze is always a plus.
Quick friendly service. Chicken meatballs are small but delicious. Skip the soup and get the delicious Miang Kham self-roll coconut peanut roll.
Ate dinner here with my wife. We both thought the food was fantastic. Service was super friendly and they answered all my stupid questions about sticky rice. Will def be going back.

If you're not eating here, you know nothing about what's good for you, nothing about amazing Thai food, and you don't what you're missing. Eaten here several times. Only thing I didn't love was the chicken meatball app. Most recently had chx wing app, marinated beef salad, ka pow (basil chx), tofu noodle dish, and dear lord I needed taken away from me to stop eating. All I have to say is, Yum. I hope you expand but dont leave west town, please.
Extremely satisfied.  No better place for true authentic Thai street food!

Excellent authentic thai street food! We got the chicken rice (kaomungai), grilled chicken (gai yaang), numtok pork, guaytiew mhoo toon, and somtum. All were excellent! Love the grilled chicken - authentic like the ones in thailand.
This place is amazing, period. Food is on point and its BYOB. I come here a few times a month.

Attended soft opening last night.  Terrific ambiance, fast service (very hospitable) and authentic thai food with rich flavors and very nice presentation.  Had #6, Grilled chicken balls on skewers with homemade spicy sauce, #7, Chicken-stuffed fried wonton, #23, Rice noodle with stewed pork soup and meat ball and #18, Chicken over ginger garlic rice.  Everything was EXCELLENT!  Our favorite was #23.  Reasonable prices, great food and BYOB.  Who could ask for more? We will be back to try more dishes and will recommend to friends!!

After seeing that the line for Yuzu was an hour long my lady friend and I decided to pop into JJs. I got the E-Saan pork shoulder with sticky rice and it was fucking amazing. It was a bit spicy (in a good way) and super flavorful. Was decently priced and just so good! I definitely recommend this place and will stop in a again guaranteed.

I was looking to try a new Thai restaurant, and JJ's seemed like the perfect place to try. JJ's did not dissapoint! My family and I ordered the grilled squid, tom yum soup, basil chicken, panaeng beef, and braised pork noodle. The squid was great, with a nice charred flavor.  The soup was alright, but we agreed it wasn't the best we'd ever ordered. The basil chicken and panaeng beef were savory, spicy, and delicious! But the true star of the meal was the braised pork noodle. It was heavenly. The broth was rich, and the pork was tender and sooo good. I will definitely return!

Fantastic food and service all around. First time experiencing E-Saan style eating, where you grab super-duper sticky rice and pick up delicious meats with it. It was fun and mighty tasty. The Grilled Pork Salad was stunningly good - tender and popping with fish sauce and fresh lime flavors.

This place is amazing.  The food is good and authentic.  I love Thai and have never had Thai food this good.  Like everyone else says in their reviews it seems more authentic like truly what you would get on the street in Thailand.  The place is cute but not fancy the service was good but not great but seriously after we left my group could not stop talking about all the amazing dishes we ate that we had never tried before.  This place rules.  I did not want to write a review for fear or this place getting crowded but I owed it to them since it was so darn good.

This place has awesome thai food. The service is consistently good, trendy/cute atmosphere and its a byob. I'm a vegetarian and consistently get the Nam Tok Tao Hoo.  Great and welcome addition to the neighborhood!!

Food is fresh, very tasty and leaves a great feeling in your stomach after you eat it.  Almost a food buzz.  You won't find the giant corporate conglomerate restaurant food delivery truck here.  Mamas in the kitchen cooking traditional style, 20 somethings doing all the wait service which they did very well.  Could have lived without the blairing 20 somethings Thai rock music with non stop electric guitar solos from the speakers which are right above the tables.  Kind of took away from my food experience a little.  Traditional music with the traditional food, no?

Love this place.  We have been several times and everyone we have taken with us has loved the food.  Its definitely different than most Thai places.  You won't find Pad Thai on the menu here. Its BYOB which is great, pretty cheap and everything I've tried has been really good.  My favorites are: the Pla Muk Yang (grilled squid app) which is really good, super tender and not chewy, the Gai Yang (grilled marinated chicken), the sauce with this is amazing and you have to get the sticky rice with it, and then the Guay Tiew Moo Thoon (braised pork noodle), its like a ramen with excellent flavor and pretty spicy.

What makes this place stand out from other Thai restaurants in Chicago is its menu - it strays from the standard fare of Pad Thai and Pad See Ew, and instead offers Thai street food. Beyond that, the flavours and quality are just alright.I've ordered carryout from this place twice. The first time, the food was nothing outstanding but not terrible either. The sticky rice was a nice accompaniment to the Khao Lard Ka Praw Gai (basil chicken). There's just something about the combination of those flavours and textures that made it extra tasty.The second time, I ordered Khao Mun Gai (braised chicken over ginger rice) - it was quite disappointing. As soon as I opened the carryout container, the smell reminded me of day old chicken that was reheated in a microwave. The chicken was a little tough and dry for being braised. It really made me wonder if the chicken was indeed reheated in a microwave. Also, I understand that the bulk of the flavour of the chicken should come from the side of sauce; despite that, the chicken itself was pretty tasteless.The distinctive menu selection doesn't compensate for the so-so flavours. Two tries is enough to give it a fair chance; I won't be back.

Do you remember the first time you had really good wine and realized you'd been drinking puckery cold garbage up until that point in your life?  Apparently, so many Thai restaurants I've been to in this city are doing it all wrong.  The dishes here have tons of fresh flavors.  They are complex, balanced, and the $$ value is extremely high.  I've heard repeatedly that Thai cuisine is one of the most amazing cuisines in the world.  This is one of the only restaurants in this city that delivers on that promise.

It was good. I went with friends and they were more impressed than I.I did like that it is BYOB.The noodles were good.The fried chicken was good.Overall the food was good.The service was very attentive.

This place is dope. I went for lunch and I was surprised I was the only person there. This place serves a lot of delicious Thai dishes I haven't seen in other restaurants. I chose one basically at random and I got an enormous portion of beef and curry noodle soup. Some of the dishes cost a couple bucks more than they might at other Thai spots but the portion size was insane. Definitely an awesome spot.

Was super excited that an authentic Thai restaurant opened up so close to my place. I eat here at least once a week. The Basil Chicken is so good, next best to my moms and that says a lot. They're all super nice and friendly, and I love the authentic Thai music playing in the background. The peek gai tod is also delish, and to find kow mon gai anywhere but Thailand and my moms was such a delight! Definitely check it out! It's not your typical "Thai" place in terms of menu but it's a must visit!

I went  for afternoon tea and it was an amazing.I had a reservation which they kept sweetly even though  I was 30 mins late..I am not a desert  person but I like afternoon tea tradition so I chose to come here..It was definitely  worth the experience.. I got the simple menu for 29 usd..I told them that I am allergic to sea food and they gave me the option to add other finger sandwich I like..I must say they dont have lot of variety on the finger food but reallly it did not matter. I loved the scone, fresh cream and finger sandwiches they presented. I could not finish it and brought them home.They have nice selection of tea. I asked for  extra cream which I received happily.. The service was really good, one of the best in chicago..It was nice to have so many happy  people around..

This review is only for the tea service. I love going out for tea, so when my mom suggested we try out the Allis, I was game. I wasn't sure what to expect given that tea isn't their specialty, but I was pleasantly surprised.The ambience was nice and relaxing. My mom and I were seated in two big cozy chairs (comfy seating is a key part of the tea experience) right by the windows, which was a great set up. The only downside is that you're basically in the middle of the lobby of Soho House, which to me isn't quite the ideal location for tea given all the activity.The food was on point as well. A classic tea includes finger sandwiches, desserts, and scones, and the Allis delivered on all fronts. I'm kind of a scone snob (biscuits are not scones!!), but the Allis nailed them and had real clotted cream, which is a major win in my book (unsweetened whipped cream isn't clotted cream!).The service was also good. Our server checked in a regularly and gave us tea refills when we were ready.I'll definitely be back for tea!

This is a lovely place to go for afternoon tea. I just love the deco and it's such a comfy spot. I am new in Chicago and I enjoy the Westloop.Now let's get to why I am giving this spot 3 stars. Well the waitresses were so careless and they really didn't  seem to care about the patrons. The were just chatting and never really came to refill our teapots, never really checked on us, they were catching up on their on things.The food itself was tasty but the service just put a damper on the whole experience. THE ONE THING THAT TURNED ME OFF ABOUT THE AFTERNOON TEA IS THE FACT THAT U HAVE TO PAY EXTRA MONEY TO GET MORE FOOD, AFTERNOON TEA IS SUPPOSE TO BE ENDLESS BISCUITS, SCONES, MACAROONS, SWEETS OR WHATEVER IT IS THAT THE PLACE IS OFFERING, I SHOULDN'T BE PAYING EXTRA WHEN I AM ALREADY PAYING A FIXED PRICE FOR HIGH TEA. THEY NEED TO GO BACK TO THE DRAWING BOARD ON THIS ONE. I have been to a lot of high tea spots London, Europe, Africa and this was the 1st for me. So as a result I would rather go to the Drake and other places that offer afternoon tea in Chicago.
The food is consistently excellent, and the wait staff are pleasant and responsive. It's always a treat to go to the Allis for breakfast.The coffee isn't great, but Sawada is across the street.

This was recommended to me by a friend.  There is valet parking available and we took advantage of it.    We called ahead for Sunday brunch and we were told there was no wait- which was great and we were seated right away.  FYI the hostess stand is at the top of the stairs.  The service was a little slow- it took a while to noticed, but everyone was still friendly.  The Mimosas here are delicious and made with fresh OJ- we had a couple rounds. I had the chopped salad and it was good- I've had better dressing but nevertheless still a very good salad.  If your looking for a light, not too heavy breakfast, this is a great spot.

I'm glad I found a Gilt City coupon for afternoon tea for two or else I would've been really upset that I spent $90+.To be honest, I've been dying to come to the Allis for over 2 years now when I missed out on a calligraphy shop held here. And what a better way to enjoy this place by having tea time. Or so I thought....My friend and I came to The Allis on a Sunday afternoon for a girl's day with afternoon tea. Upon first impression, I was stunned by the interior design. The abundance of light and vintage furniture won me over. Unfortunately, I ended up spending ~5-10 minutes trying to figure out where in the world the host stand was. Even though I enjoyed wandering around the Allis, which I soon learned was basically the lobby of the SoHo House. I checked in with the hotel receptionist - whom I thought was the host - only to find out that the host was just a regular server. How are we supposed to know who the host was?Once my friend and I were both seated, it probably took ~15 minutes a waiter to actually acknowledge us and take our order. Once we were served our tea, the only time our waiter came by was to take our empty plates away. We actually had to wave them down every time we needed them. My friend actually asked to have more water for her tea, and they took the tea pot without coming back. By the time, I was done drinking my tea, she didn't even want any more tea.When I first made the reservation, I was informed that we would only be allowed 1.5 hours for tea time. We probably spent ~45 minutes enjoying our afternoon tea and over 1 hour waiting around for our servers. I'm glad that they didn't ask us to leave because I would've been furious. It's unbelievable how it seemed like there were a good amount of servers, yet none of them providing good service.If you can tolerate poor service and want to enjoy afternoon tea, this is actually a  great place to go. You can loiter around with your girlfriends as much as possible and enjoy the scenery. I don't know if I'll ever be coming back.P.S. You MUST get the almond tea! It's probably the best tea I've ever had in my life!

I came here with a friend to celebrate her birthday with high tea. The offerings are good, and the variety of teas they have are interesting. Be prepared for over cuteness and pinterest worthiness in terms of ambience, and yes, there are a lot of women  here, I literally saw only 2 male diners. All the wait staff seemed to be men though, with one woman.You place your order and your three tiers come out- chocolate cake, passionfruit macaroons, scones with jam and butter, red velvet cupcakes were a few of the contenders. to me, it was relatively inexpensive with 25$ without prosecco and $30 with.Come for the ambience, fill up on sugar.

There cannot be enough said about the Allis at the SOHO. The dark wooden cabinetry, Violet velvet chairs, blue floral porcelain chinaware and chandelier light fixtures are my definition of class. Allis is a great lounge for enjoying artisan tea over finger treats. The basic afternoon tea consists of three trays of bit sized egg salad, cucumber+cream cheese, salmon sandwiches, banana cake, macaron, lemon tart, scone, chocolate layered cake and more!You can't go wrong with their loose leaf tea selection. All are a great selection. We enjoyed the hot chocolate pu'er and almond green tea very much. Will be coming back for more.

We were hunting for a rooftop bar but couldn't find any that were open in our part of town, so we swung by The Allis after scoping our options on Yelp. What a gem! The first floor bar is long and open with high ceilings. We seated ourselves and our server explained our cocktail options. Lots of strong, creative drinks can be found here.The environment is dark and rather quiet and drinks were fantastic. Would be perfect for an intimate drink after dinner. Be sure and swing by the bathroom. You have to walk through the restaurant upstairs and it looks so fantastic. I was sad I wouldn't be back for dinner, but I placed it on my list for next time.The Allis is a winner if you're in this neck of the woods.

It is absolutely baffling to me that this place is 4 stars. Maybe because of the ambiance?Service is the worst. It takes 20 minutes in itself to have a waiter come to greet/acknowledge you. Food, drink and tea list are good.I came today and had the same waiter ask 4 times if we wanted to put in food. I told him we had placed it with the other waiter, but that I would like to order tea. With that he came back 3 more times (I'm not kidding) to ask what tea I wanted. OK, if this guy has a medical issue causing memory loss I feel bad, but if not- what the heck is wrong with you?!?This place was the spot a year ago, but with so many other swanky/trendy/Instagram-worthy places popping up rapidly, no need to come here again.

Sat upstairs which is newly done, very cute.  Had the olive and almond app, it was great.  I could eat that all day.  Also had an amazing salad.  Had bacon and beets on it.  It was all chopped up super fine, so delicious.  I am going to make all my salads like that for now on.

Loved my experience here!!! First of all, we arrived at 11am and we were informed that last call for breakfast was already had. But without us even asking, the waiter said he would ask if we could order breakfast if we wanted, and thus, we were able to order off the breakfast menu! How kind :)I ordered the croissant sandwich, which was nice and flaky and delish! The bacon was particularly perfect. I also got the jasmine green tea, which was so goooood. And they give you a LOT. I couldn't even finish the whole pot.The atmosphere of the place makes you feel cozy and important. Is that weird to say? But it just does. There is tons of open lighting, which I am a sucker for. I loved dining here for breakfast.And lastly, the staff was so wonderful. Well, I kind of already mentioned this. But towards the end of our meal, the waiters gave us ideas on what to do and where to go during our visit in chitown. They gave great and genuine suggestions. Also, together they looked like they could form their own one direction band ;)Everything was wonderful about this place!!!

I could have given it a 5 star but the wait was way too long - about 45 mins to he precise and the waitress forgot one of the items on the order and did not seem to care about it even if she apologized.I loved the interior of this place - nice couches, different kinds of tables - something for every body except kids. I went here with my team. We ordered a chopped salad with a poached egg, devilled eggs (never came), tomato-mozz sandwich, steak sandwich and pulledpork samdwich. The food was pretty tasty - my poached egg was a bit over cooked but thats okay. We also ordered iced tea and cold brew which came in a fancy bottle that looked like some bottled beer from the 90's.The staff is friendly and service is good but slow. Food was good too. Overall a nice experience. Will go again!!

I came here for afternoon tea with 4 other girls and had to wait about 30 mins before my friends and I were seated.We were very excited for the pastries and sweets and tea but were disappointed by the freshness of the food. The bread on the sandwiches were dry and the macarons were hard. The only dessert that I enjoyed was the scone and the chocolate great (which was great). Other than that, the tea was just all right. Not super aromatic, but decent.The ambiance of this place, though, is beautiful. The chandeliers, couches, tables, and decor are all spot on. I love how the colors of the furniture complemented the decor and the walls of this place. The plates are also gorgeous. I love the simple, yet classic design of the plates and tea pot.Come here for the aesthetics, but definitely not for the afternoon tea. I might come back and try their brunch, since I've heard great things about that.

Acting as the lobby and first floor of Soho House, the Allis feels like something of a country club dining room-lobby-library hybrid. The entire place is incredibly photogenic and let's in lots of light. I love the crystal chandeliers, the vintage-mismatched feel of the furniture, and the casual ambience. During the day you can enjoy brunch and tea, while the evening brings the bar scene.Their cocktails are really nice. My favorite by far is the Soho Mule. If you like ginger, you will love this. Till 6:30 they sometimes have $1.50 happy hour oyster specials. The soft pretzel bites with honey mustard and warm beer cheese will make you very happy.Bonus, heads upstairs to Chicken & Farm Shop for dinner.

Nice venue! We came at night. High ceilings, great ambience overall and good drinks. Standard prices. Food was decent. And not packed for a Sat night Which was actually really great.No reservations. Great place for a date and group if you can snag it.

This place is so cute! I love the marble countertop on the bar and the fact they can keep it clean without defect (ever had white marble? NEVER again).With fresh vegetables, fruits and herbs you can't go wrong with any drink. They care about presentation. The bartender is cool as hell and the vibe is chill. The cocktail list is limited and the liquor choice isn't the average super cheap stuff. I appreciate it. Almost makes me want to move to Chicago and make this a regular place.I ordered the Eastern Standard with Gin. In one word to describe it: Yes. That is all.Dropping the Mic.

I visited the Allis with my family for afternoon tea and it was great! A bit pricey, but some of the best scone and pastries you'll ever have. My favorite was the scone, pumpkin loaf, and.. Well, everything! Service was friendly and polite, albeit a bit slow. Great atmosphere and nice experience overall.Only weird thing is that the bathroom is upstairs, inside another restaurant (chicken restaurant). Awkward, but okay.

I love visiting The Allis for their tea service!  This is the perfect setting to catch up with girlfriends while surrounded by beautiful food and furniture.  Get their tea set or sparkling tea set - the sparkling version comes with rose prosecco.The tea tower comes with a variety of savory tea sandwiches and tiny cakes/sweets.  Sometimes the cakes can be a bit dry, but they are beautiful and seeing all of the treats together in a tea tower is worth it!  Afternoon tea is $34 and it fills you up.

I went to the Allis for lunch and was delighted by how charming the space was and how delicious the food was. The Allis is located in the Soho House right off the lobby. They have different menus throughout the day from breakfast til dinner.I had the soup and salad combo with the bean soup of the day and the chopped salad. The presentation was cute and the food was light but filling.They have a fancy afternoon tea that they suggest making a reservation for that I would love to go back and try.The reason I gave the Allis 4 stars instead of 5 was the service. The waiter took forever to come back and take the order after giving us the menus, never came to check how the food was and took an unnecessary amount of time to get us the check. It wasn't busy when I went so I don't see any reason for the slow service.

Perfect for the person that (if you're considering breakfast):-Wants a quiet morning with a friend-Wants a light and healthy breakfast that includes in house fresh croissants, smoked salmon, bread, and flavorful teas-Wants to get work done alone on their laptop-Enjoys large chandeliers, appreciates china, and the SOHO environment-Wants to spend fairlyThey have high tea available everyday from 3-5 and they recommend you make reservations- can't wait to come back for that. The service is slow- they just a laid back and casual service.The Allis is beautiful- a great place to come by in the West Loop.

I was here for a Girl's Day/celebrating a birthday around 4pm in the evening, and got the high-tea for the four of us.This was my first experience with high tea and I really liked it (although my bank account probably did not!)First: the teas. We shared African amber, Jade green and Verbena mint. I loved the African Amber with notes of mango, hibiscus and vanilla. Jade green needed more steeping time for full flavor and verbena mint was pretty good as well.The food: We had the 29$ package that came with cream puffs, chocolate cake, fruit tart, macaroons red velvet cupcakes, salmon and ham finger sandwiches, and my favorite = scone with clotted cream. I was introduced to the goodness of clotted cream at this place and it seems like I can eat a tub-full of it by itself! It was this rich, delicious cream that went perfectly with the scone.The service was good. The food was a bit overpriced, and quite forgettable (besides the clotted cream and scone!). I would go for another tea with my girls, but not sure if I'll get the package again.The ambiance is very laid back. On a side note, I was introduced to the Pizza East and Chicken Shop right upstairs. And filled out the form where if you install the app after they send you invites, you get 50% off the bill on Mondays (for chicken) and Tues. (for pizza!) Looking forward to those visits!

I've been here twice for brunch. The first time here, I ordered eggs in a pot with a side of fruit bowl and hot tea. I wasn't expecting the eggs to be really good. I thought it was going to be decent, but nope, they were savory, with right amount of salt, and delicious runny yolk.Second time, I had lox, blueberry muffin, and hot tea. The smoked salmon for the lox was very fresh. I even enjoyed the muffin because they tasted like they were home baked.The interior design of this place is eye opening, with elegant and vintage vibes - also comfty chairs & sofas. This place never fails to impress me, and it is my go-to brunch spot. There's not a lot in their menus, but I hope that they can expand them.

My best friend and I started a tradition of trying a new afternoon tea place this past holiday season. To kick it off, we tried The Allis, which did not disappoint! The weather was horrendous that day--it was one of those days you wonder why you even left the apartment. Tea was the perfect pick-me-up. I would recommend making a reservation. They weren't booked, but I'm pretty sure the weather played a role, plus it was a Monday. For $24 each, we got a selection of tea, finger sandwiches, and sweet and savory pastries.My favorite treat on the tower was chocolate cake, which I usually think is just meh. The biscuit and jam/cream were also PHENOMENAL. Like literally an explosion of flavor in your mouth. My only complaint about the tower is that there were a few too many sweet offerings. I wish there had been more savory offerings.Service was great from everyone, and I highly recommend. Can't go wrong with SoHo House!

Every time i walk inside The Allis, I fall in love all over again. It's a designers dream- eclectic, and dressed with all kinds of beautiful elements like chandeliers, velvet tufted couches, and a modern library setting.I'm most often found here enjoying a glass of champagne while waiting for a member to arrive. They also have a small but lux menu filled with light munchies- lox toast, brisket grilled cheese, Marcona almonds and olives, etc. Everything I've had is delightful.They also have a great full brunch menu, and they serve tea on the weekend! I'm a sucker for a good tea service, so I'm looking forward to trying that out with a group of girlfriends.

I came here for brunch and was fairly disappointed.  Their brunch menu is limited.  After having to ask, I found out that "they do not have the facilities to cook eggs."  All of the eggs are hard boiled.  They might break them down somehow, but they all start hard boiled.  When that was revealed to me, I canceled my order and went elsewhere for brunch.  This place should be purely considered a bar.

Fun and fancy place to have Afternoon Tea.  For $34 per person, you will get bottomless tea (choose from one of 8 varieties) and a piece of 10 different pastries served on a 3-tiered platter.  The Mallorca Melon tea was my favorite, very fragrant and perfect as is (no sugar needed).  There was also a Peach Rooibos, which was unfortunately not as fragrant as I hoped.  The pastries were not too sweat, and included 3 finger sandwiches (salmon, egg salad, and cucumber).  The scone with jam was a favorite (also whipped butter), and banana bread was a big hit.  The Blackcurrant Macaroon was unusual, like a mixed berry flavor.  My impression of the price is that you are paying for the ambiance, and for a chance to feel fancy while you spend time with friends in the afternoon.

I adore this place!  Me and my daughter had their fabulous afternoon tea service before she heads down south for college.  Wow, Proseco and sweets and savory sandwiches served on lovely chintz plates.  The vibe is cool, elegant but funky.  The food was tasty and service was impeccable.  Do this people!  Take your mom, daughter or best friend here for tea.  You will not be disappointed.  It's a bit pricey at well over $50 pp with tip but trust me, it is lovely and will provide you and your loved one with a wonderful memory.I've been to afternoon teas at the Drake, Four Seasons, Ritz others and I have to say this is my favorite by far.  What  sets it apart are the little attention to details.  If you go and you need to you will see what I mean.  I only wish my Mom was still with me to enjoy this little piece of heaven on an afternoon.

Located in the Soho House hotel, The Allis is one cool spot.  The space is simply amazing; the high ceilings, large crystal chandeliers, floor to ceiling windows add an air of sophistication. The modern art on the exposed brick walls helps to balance things out to create an environment like no other.The ambiance is perfect for sipping tea, a cup of coffee, pressed juices or even a craft cocktail or two.  You decide, as it's all available here. In addition to an array of beverages there are light meals and pastries on the menu. On my visit I went with the craft cocktails (of course I did) and was not disappointed.  The Soho Mule was quite tasty; made with 42 Below Vodka, house made ginger syrup, soda and ginger candy. The ginger candy adds a nice twist to the drink. I also tried the Eastern Standard (Grey Goose, lime, sugar, cucumber, mint) which was refreshing. Service is just what one would expect of place like this; friendly and attentive.I look forward to my next visit to The Allis.
Nice cozy environment. We ordered avocado sandwich and smoked salmon bagel. Both are good and fresh. The serving size is small, but is enough.I will try the high tea next time.

I went to the Allis the first time this past Saturday and was impressed right off the bat. I was looking for a place to study in west loop and decided to drop by. When you first walk in, you notice almost immediately that it's not your run of the mill study space (and to be quite honest, I don't think the Allis is REALLY meant to be a study area, definitely more like a bar/ restaurant/ place to catch up with friends and family). There are beautiful chandeliers hanging from the high ceilings, comfy sofas and chairs everywhere, and lots of tables to sit and read the newspaper. Being a hotel lobby (Soho house), there are people coming and going, which means good people watching! If anything, just come by to enjoy the beautiful space.Upon sitting down at a long wooden table, a waiter came up and took my friend and my coffee orders (I got the mocha and my friend, an americano). We waited about 10 minutes before being brought our drinks. The mocha was really good- I've never had blue bottle coffee before and thought it was delicious.I came here at around 11 am and there was plenty of seating. Once it hit around 1 pm, the place definitely filled up and larger groups started coming in. I'd say, come here early and enjoy the nice ambiance and great decor and leave before the afternoon rush. The servers were exceptionally nice and patient. Overall, a great experience. I'm looking forward to coming back for afternoon tea or brunch sometime soon.

I've been inside the Allis before, but this time I was here at night for drinks. I like how the lobby transforms from a cozy lounge during the day to a bar at night. I don't know if it was the rainstorm, but the lobby was kind of empty. My group snagged one of the long tables. I wanted to order food, but it was too late and the kitchen was closed. I ordered a  Soho Mule - 42 Below Vodka, Ginger, Lime, Soda served with candied ginger. It was really good, probably one of the best mules I've had. You could really taste the quality ingredients. The ginger flavor was very strong, but I liked it. I also loved the decor - especially the chandeliers, furniture and artwork. I definitely want to go back and try their tea service.

Wondering if you should try this place out? Well you better! There is no place like this in Chicago...it's beautiful with a line of gorgeous chandeliers across the whole restaurant! There's an open bar to the right when you enter and to your left are the couches/tables that you sit onOn the right and left side of The Allis are two other restaurants, one's a chicken shop place and the other is a pizza place!Anyways, this place is beautiful and so well put together and elegant and just plain cute! My cousin, two sisters, a friend, and I went on Valentine's Day, and reserved for the Afternoon tea which was great with savory and sweet finger foods!So the tea platter special was so cute and actually kept me full without giving me that bloaty feeling!There were three finger sandwiches - egg/cucumber/salmon, there were also a bunch of two-bite desserts that were all fantastic and scrumptious!I swear this place makes you feel like your British and that you are a part of the royal family just having a casual lunchThe service was great and was very glad to share more information about our platter and explain anything we needed to know! Everything came out in timely fashion. It was a bit pricey, for all of us, we paid $230 in total. With 5 tea platters and a couple more items! Hope you try it...God Bless :)

I wish I could give two different ratings,One for service one for food. Food is great! We really like everything we've ordered from them but oh man they are SLOW! And confused. You have to be very patient and have no immediate plans if you go there cause it takes them about 20 mins before they even bring you coffee! And forget to bring you what you ask for...but they are very nice and polite.The egg white sandwich is good, light, and delicious. Their On Toast is pretty good! We have also tried The Allice and Bagel or Bialy (we got bagel). All are very good and fresh. We haven't tried any of their drinks but they look tasty and refreshing! The orange juice is freshly squeezed. We love their outdoor seating area and they get a whole star for letting you bring your dog!

Favorite meal=Afternoon Tea! While I try to find any excuse to inject caffeine into my body, I think I may like the actual sandwiches and sweets at tea better than  tea itself. The Peninsula is usually my go to for afternoon tea, but I recently decided to switch it up for tea at The Allis.The Allis is located within the Soho House and the only dining area that non members can enjoy. Their Afternoon Tea may be the best deal in town at $24/person ($32 if you include a glass of prosecco). In comparison High Tea at the Peninsula is $55/person ($68 with prosecco).The sandwiches, sweets, tea and prosecco were all very tasty. My only complaint was the stomach ache I had later that evening for eating way too much. The atmosphere is a bit more casual than some other High Tea hotel experiences, but still great.Unfortunately, they aren't able to do a table for more than 15 people with the way they were set up, but did their best to accommodate my party of 18.Looking forward to trying other meals (and of course more tea time) at The Allis. Based on tea here and food in the members only restaurant at the Soho House I'm sure it won't disappoint.

This is one of the best places for afternoon tea, First, the tables, chairs, and decoration made it an unique, vintage environment. Second, the afternoon tea tasted really good, and the waitess was very friendly. Third, the desserts were incredible. With so many options, this place is perfect.The only that didnt work as well was parking. It took me 20 minutes.

I love this place. Ambience is cozy yet sophisticated. Intimate and classy. Came on a Friday night and it was full but not packed. Was able to get a table easily.Drinks are amazing too! Affordable and delicious. Cocktails are all around $11. Definitely a nice change from the $15-$20 cocktails in LA.I highly recommend the allis soho mule. It's a very spicy (in a ginger spicy way) drink. It wasn't syrupy ginger at all.I also recommend the eastern standard. For those that have been to Spago in Beverly Hills, there's this $30 drink called peppino's revenge that I absolutely loved but couldn't afford to drink again. Eastern standard is very close to pepino's revenge but half the price!!! Ding ding ding!!!Loved the server and everything about this place!

The tea sets and plates are absolutely stunning. I made a reservation for 5 on a Sunday afternoon and we got the huge round table in the middle of the floor.The mint tea had a really subtle flavor. When I got a hot water refill, it almost lost its flavor.The tower of food was gorgeous!! I thought everything was delicious except for the lemon tart. It tasted like metal..  They also have a vegetarian set!

This place was only able to earn a 3-star review from me because of the decor and charm. It has a very old world feel that is like an immediate hug when you enter. You feel like you've gone back in time to when men were gentlemen and women were ladies.And then my friend and I sat at the bar and were promptly ignored for 20 minutes. At the bar. Where there were like six people working behind the bar. Almost intentionally avoiding all eye contact with us.Eventually one of them accidentally looked over and we were able to order a drink. We each got a glass of champagne. The glassware was beautiful and once again gave me that happy going-back-in-time feeling.After drinking our drinks, we decided not to stay. It felt very pretentious and the wait staff couldn't have made us feel any less welcome. Unfortunately, we once again couldn't get anyone to even acknowledge our presence at the bar. All we wanted to do was pay and leave. It took us another solid 20 or more minutes of actively trying to get a bill before someone finally paid us any attention.It's definitely a unique spot. But, make a reservation and sit at a table. The bar is a wasteland of rude waitstaff.

If I lived in Chicago, I would probably live at The Allis.I've only been here for brunch but I love everything about this place...* The interior design is elegantly eclectic, but still really warm and cozy* Ambiance is casual, relaxed, not at all pretentious* Staff has always been exceptionally warm and friendly* Brunch options are great and really delicious* Love the coffee (Intelligensia)Can't wait to try this place for high tea or cocktails some day. :)

Overall this was a good experience. Their tea was delish and they let each person order their own preference of tea, which is a major plus! However, their tea sandwiches were disappointing flavorless. Some of their pastries were good, but not all. For the price, we found the eats accompanying the tea to be disappointing. The ambience of quite nice and it was a fun outing.
Went here for breakfast, I spent 15 including tax and tip for toast with avocado, chilli flakes, and an egg - I was starving after. Breakfast fail

This place has been on my list for a few months now, and I'm glad I came!  I love breakfast and brunch and this place is a place I would definitely tell friends and family about!I went with my girlfriend around noon; even though parking was terrible, we were seated within 20 minutes (which was honestly super fast!).  I had the toast with avocado and it was delicious!  I realize it sounds like a simple dish, but it is worth getting.  My girlfriend got the eggs Benedict, which were also very good!We also got some tea (Bourbon something...) and not only was the presentation of the tea very nice, the tea tasted delicious!I can't wait to go back and try something else! If anyone ever comes here, be ready to spend a couple of hours here (you won't even feel it, its just nice to be in there).

The interior design of this place is absolutely stunning!! It has a perfect balance of urbanism and old time feels. The ambiance was even better when my afternoon tea set came out. I felt super fancy drinking tea and eating small snacks with my friends on couches and with chandeliers hanging from the ceiling. Although the experience was great, I thought their teas were not very strong. It was difficult to tell the difference between the two different teas we ordered. The treats that also come with the tea were also nothing special (excluding the scones... EVERYBODY MUST TRY THE SCONES)Overall, it was nice to cross it off the bucket list of restaurants to try, but probably will not be visiting again anytime soon.

The Allis is a beautiful place - lots of natural lighting, chandeliers hanging from the high ceilings, wood tables contrasted with brick walls, couch chairs, and an overall vintage feel. LOVE it..such a cozy atmosphere. Would highly recommend this place for afternoon tea with your girlfriends - it's about $29 per person and includes an assortment of finger sandwiches and desserts as well as a pot of tea. Keep in mind that afternoon tea is VERY popular here so you will need to make reservations ahead of time. I made mine for 5 people about 2 weeks in advance and even then, they only had 2 times available for the Saturday that I wanted.

Came here with my wife and daughter for afternoon tea. Was definitely impressed by the warm eclectic interior and causal seating arrangements. High tea consists of your standard finger sandwiches, scones, pastries, and desserts. Tea was good and service was excellent. Would definitely come back when we are in the area.

I had afternoon tea here with an alumnae group I belong to, and it left a lot to be desired. A holiday pop-up market was just finishing up when we arrived, so the first half hour of our gathering was accompanied by blaring music from a DJ, followed by an hour of constant door opening right by our table as workers broke down the setup, making several of us wear jackets during the tea.The tea sets were cute, but several ladies had various cracked/chipped cups and pots. At least four of us had lukewarm tea arrive, and it was a good 45 minutes before anyone who ordered a glass of champagne got any. The desserts were ok - the chocolate cake was too sugary and rich for my taste; the cream puff was bland and soggy, and the macarons kind of stale. The lemon tart wasn't bad, or the thumb-sized slice of ham and cheese finger sandwich I had.One member of our group informed our server she had a nut allergy; our server in return asked how much of a concern cross-contamination was. Seriously? "I have an epi-pen but I'd rather not use it," my colleague replied. Apparently they've never had to accommodate anyone with a nut allergy, as this then required sending staff down the street to Whole Foods, causing a longer wait for the tea snacks, only to have what arrived be several chocolate chip cookies, several frosted sugar cookies, and some sliced pineapple with raspberries. Don't trouble yourselves, really. For a fancy-schmancy place, I am not impressed with the quality, creativity, or service we had. For having paid about $30 per person, I'd be happy to pay an extra 10 bucks for a better experience elsewhere next time.

You walk in and you're definitely hit with a beautiful interior space which I can definitely appreciate! I came in with a friend and we stood in the front not knowing if we could seat ourselves, but after around 3 minutes we decided that it was okay to do so. I still don't know if it's a place that you seat yourself so it didn't lose any points there.We sat down and admired the area for quite a bit of time before a server came to help us, but he was very nice and took our order.I think the food is what made the place get two stars. I ordered the Lean Sandwich and my friend ordered the Mean Sandwich (both ten dollars). Honestly, I felt like it's just what I make for myself before I leave my apartment in the morning. If you want to go for coffee, the coffee was splendid and a perfect location to chill and read a book/edit some photos/ do some writing!

Came for afternoon tea, which I found pretty expensive for what was basically 2 sandwiches cut into smaller pieces, and a handful of too-sugary sweet treats.  They do have a "vegetarian option" which basically involves removal of the smoked salmon, but no creative difference otherwise.I had called and made a reservation, intending only to make sure there was space for us, but when we actually sat down, they insisted that because I had reserved afternoon tea for X number of people, we HAD to order X number of tea sets.  Personally, I think that's kind of ridiculous.  The waiter went to "ask the manager" if we could share a set, and came back with the compromise that we had to order at least Y full sets.  Gee, thanks.  I didn't realize there was essentially a minimum charge per person for afternoon tea.  Maybe that should be made more clear on the website or on the menu.Overall, I would not come back, although the space itself is very bright and welcoming.

A HUGE fan of getting afternoon tea at this place. Everything is so classy, from the giant chandeliers to the tea sets made in England (yes I actually checked out the bottom of my cup haha) to the nice plush armchairs we sit in.The best part? Afternoon tea with a whole tower of goodies is only $24, which was easily $40+ at a fancy hotel like the Drake. And you essentially get the exact same thing (probably a little more actually, I was so full afterwards!).In this giant three tier tower of goodies we got a total of 7 pastries and 3 finger sandwiches, and they are all decently sized. My favorites were the cream puffs, which were incredibly soft with very aromatic but not overly sweet filling. My least favorites were the macarons which were a little too sweet and a little too sticky... and I'm also just spoiled from having lived in Paris.... Then the chocolate cake was just nothing too special and wayyyy too much sugar. Of course, I'm just nitpicking at this point, overall everything was awesome!

Stopped in for breakfast before work on Saturday...A very chill atmosphere. Sat at the bar in a very uncomfortable stool and I was only there for a short time. Ordered the Mean Sandwhich got the Lean Sandwich... I guess they thought I didn't need the extra calories... For a low cal option it was pretty good thanks to the jalapeños. Also had the Yogurt and berries w/ granola which was the thickest yogurt I ever had. Good and filling but really odd, somewhat hard to eat. Berries were great! The coffee there is some of the best I've had.

If you're #basic: Russian Tea TimeIf you're with your fancy granny: The DrakeIf you're a lady who lunches: The LobbyForget the harpists, fountains, hovering waiters and just the overall pretention.Afternoon Tea at The Allis has all the style and elegance without sacrificing the hospitality and comfort. It's like settling down in someone's chic resalvaged home!They have since up'd their full experience to $24 (from $18), but even so, it is still well worth it for their great selection of teas and their generous three tiered offerings. From their fresh finger sandwiches, dainty macarons, large chocolate cake slices to the obligatory clotted cream scones... be prepared to box up the leftovers.I've since been twice to their Afternoon Teas and I've never felt rushed. Our servers were always on point about refilling our teapots with hot water.It has been the perfect place to arrange a catch up session with some girlfriends.Available everyday from 3-5pm. Reservations highly encouraged!
We wee're looking for a place to grab a drink and came across this gem inside SoHo House. Drinks were good, very artisinal and chic.  A little on the price side but good service and great lounge.

Chicago's most affordable Afternoon Tea ($24) with excellent quality ingredients and portion.  I also love the flexibility -- a la carte or full afternoon tea service.  The best scone in Chicago!TEA ($3 per pot) -- all tea selections are great with balanced flavors.  Reasonable pricing makes me sample the tea per pot.  Increase steep time for free refilled pot.FINGER SANDWICHES ($6) -- ham and cheese, egg, and salmon.  Like the first 2.  I still find the salmon fishy.DESSERTS -- tea service comes with citrus poppyseed cake, scone, red velvet cupcake, chocolate cake, cream puff and lemon tart.  All are great and still delicious as leftovers.SERVICE -- still good, kind and informative.  A bit sparse maybe as you may need to hunt one down.VENUE -- plenty of seating.  Plenty of plugs (1-US, 1-EU) near the tables.  Relax.I shall be back for more teas!

Amazing experience at The Allis' afternoon tea! My friend and I were looking for a way to celebrate our college graduation and my birthday and were so glad we chose to do this. For the one hour we were there we felt like we were living in instagram - that was how pretty The Allis was. $34 got us a good amount of food - 3 finger sandwiches, an assortment of pastries and a scone. We came hungry on empty stomachs and felt the amount of food was just right - not too much to feel like we overate but enough to last us into the evening. It seems like they change up the menu every season along with the tea pairings. I had the spring menu (went in early June) and the melon tea was amazing! Servers were attentive without being intrusive. Would definitely come again! Didn't wear anything too fancy - but still fun to dress up a little bit to fit with the ambiance!

The Allis is an elegant lounge/bar with a relaxed and casual feel. Despite the easy going vibe, the setting is something to be amazed by. The high ceilings, concrete pillars, floor-to-ceiling windows, chandeliers, and vintage look all contribute in creating a look from a different era.What you'll find on the menu are light meals such as salads, pastries, pressed juices, coffee, and fine craft cocktails to pair with a small meal. I even heard they hold tea time, which anyone can reserve to partake in, and that includes an elaborate spread.The Allis was a great stop for day drinks. I had A Man About Town rye cocktail, and that was a smooth drink down to the last sip. My girlfriend had a regular Old Fashioned and that was just as perfectly crafted. We also shared an avocado toast, which was two slices of toast piled with chunky seasoned avocado and topped with a half boiled egg. It was very filling and so fresh, the ideal brunch meal in my opinion. The servers were all charming and attentive, so it was a pleasant experience overall.

We went around 4pm so they were between their afternoon tea and small plates menus. Because of this we kind of went backwards and had a chocolate croissant first which was heavenly. At 5 they gave us the small plates menu so I ordered the grilled cheese short rib sandwich which my friend had been raving about. The server didn't hear me correctly and brought me the truffle grilled cheese sandwich instead. When I told her about the error she quickly had it fixed. The sandwich is out of this world delicious! You have to try it.Aside from bringing the wrong sandwich, the service was pretty great. I was pretty happy with my visit and will probably return.

I ordered a lunch combo of a hearty tomato soup and a chopped salad with beets and a Meyer lemon dressing. The soup was fantastic- non dairy and slightly spicy. The salad was very nice as well.The setup is interesting- the bar is to your right when you enter the soho house, and the entire lobby makes up the seating. This gives it a very casual feel- you can order while lounging in the lobby if you choose. I decided to order lunch while I was waiting on my room- very convenient!In the evening there was a full crowd of mostly young professionals having dinner and drinks. Later on the crowd dimmed down. Not sure how busy it is on weekends.I appreciated the convenience of eating here as a guest of soho, and thought the menu was fresh and well prepared with healthy options. I would definitely recommend this restaurant and will return!

Love this place. The ambience and decor is just beautiful. The chandeliers, furniture and bar are mesmerizing. I love the mix between the old and new. The champagne flutes are so pretty and remind me of my grandmothers china cabinet. The brunch menu is small but has a variety of options. Coffee is a good quality and plentiful. The mimosas are made with fresh squeezed orange juice. I had the granola bowl which was filling and healthy. The pricing is very fair the quality and location. The waitstaff is fantastic and our waitress, Mary Ann?, was knowledgable enough to explain all the different areas of Soho House. When the patio is set up, I will be going back.
Super cool and super beautiful spot.

I came here for afternoon tea last week. I made a reservation the night before (I made it on a weekday).The Allis has a beautiful atmosphere and there was wonderful service. The staff was very attentive and everything we ordered came out in a timely fashion.The finger foods and desserts that came with our afternoon tea was delicious. The presentation was  also very cute.

The Allis has a spectacular theme and is filled with beautiful people--workers and guests. My girl friends and I came to have dessert, which was amazing! We ordered the banana bread, red velvet cupcakes, and the chocolate chip cookie. My favorite of these was the cookie! The service was fantastic and I will definitely be coming back!

SoHo house usually gets two extreme reactions - the phony, privileged yuppies brag about being on its exclusive membership like they do anything with it besides rub shoulders and judge other privileged, out-of-touch empty heads, while those who think its edgier to mock what's popular, scorn at the thought of joining such an establishment like they don't conform in their non-conformism. But that part of social commentary aside, I was happy that I went in myself to check this place out and see if it lives up to its hype.I wouldn't really encourage anybody paying such a hefty price for a membership unless you're born with a silver spoon in your mouth. However, I will highly recommend that people try out the Afternoon Tea at the Soho house café - The Allis. It is truly unbeatable in terms of the food and service you get and the price you pay for it. Some other famous hotels and restaurants also do the afternoon tea services in Chicago but no one delivers this well at a price point lower than most.For just $29, you get a great selection of finger sandwiches, scone, fancy cakes, and tea of your choice. I had the chamomile citron and it was divine!The food was perfectly sized to go with tea and there is enough of it that once done, you feel satisfied. The interior is quite lovely and there was an eclectic group of people. The light chatter in the background along with the soft music went quite well with the tea service.I definitely would recommend Chicagoans to try their tea service and bring all their visiting friends and family here for the same.

Ambiance: wildly throwback, fancy, and vintage place. Very interesting and snazzy decor from the floor to the ceiling - it's beautiful. Opens early and, like most places, gets busier and busier throughout the day.Service: quick and friendly. That's pretty much all that matters so that's great.Food: n/a.Drank: very tasty drinks. Even the simplest coffee could fool one into thinking they're drinking some sugar loaded junk from some coffee chain. The biggest con for this place is the price. It's pricey but you're paying for some high quality drinks and a fun atmosphere.

Came in after dinner down the street for a quick nightcap. The Missus and I aren't exactly what I thought this place would love to see walking in. We're in our 40s, not exactly style hounds, and aren't sceney types. But we like a nice drink now and then, and this place was welcoming, sans attitudes, and had extremely tasty libations. I had a hot toddy, and The Missus had a soho mule. Both were killer-particularly her mule, which had a very strong housemade ginger syrup. I imagine that on a weekend night this place is probably overfilled, but tonight was perfect. Great stuffed chairs and little nooks here and there to chat or just sit and read. Have to come back and grab a bite sometime. But great first experience here.

Such a gorgeous space. Natural light floods the beautifully decorated interior, as the space houses many creatives and young professionals working/chatting/drinking.One of my Top 5 places to go in the U.S.

It breaks my heart to leave such a bad review because this was by far my favorite spot in the West Loop and I come here pretty often with friends. But my most recent experience was pretty awful. I'd made a reservation for afternoon tea with my girlfriends. When we tried to order, our server said we need to order one full tea service for every person because "that's the requirement for making reservations". I double-checked their website, as of 2/15/16, there was no information about this. Nor was there any mention of this "requirement" when I made the reservation or called to confirm the reservation the day before our visit. Eventually he relented after checking with the manager, but cautioned we should "remember this requirement for our next visit". I find it insulting that we, the consumers, are being told off when they obviously have a lapse in their staff training. To make it worse, the dry scones we were served came without the usual array of butter/jams, and sadly it would have benefited from both. I visited the Allis when the afternoon tea service first started. Back then, though the food was nothing special, at least the service made up for it. The ~2.5x price jump is not justified by the quality of food and along the way, they lost their down-to-earth charm & friendliness. Skip the tea service and just get a drink.

I attended tea time one Sunday winter's evening. Our table was candle lit and the chandeliers glistened. I felt as if I was entering the realm of French Royalty, with an urban industrial twist. Three tiers of high quality pastries from cakes to crumpets to sandwiches and scones along with plentiful re-fills on your individual pot of tea (highly recommend Rooibos) all served on the cutest printed tea cups and dishes. I instantly felt like Marie Antoinette-Queen of Tea Time! By the end of snacking I was stuffed with my belly warm, full, and above all happy! Best $27 I have ever spent along with the best tea time experienced! I can not wait for another act of indulgence!
Great service and of course, an incredible venue with beautiful decor. Just came for dessert but everything was perfect.

It was my first time having afternoon tea. It was an amazing experience!The atmosphere is beautiful, from the elegant chandeliers, to the floral tea tableware, and comfortable velvet couches to sit and enjoy with friends. I did some research before choosing this location, and I chose this venue due to affordability, compared to many other tea services in Chicago, but does not compromise quality at all.The tea service itself was one of my favorite experiences. The food was delicious and provided a traditional afternoon tea service experience. There are three tier stands filled with finger sandwiches and a variety of desserts. The portions look deceptively small, but are quite filling. I went with three people, and all of the food items are served on one stand. Each person has one serving of each item. I really enjoyed the small cucumber sandwich, the small salmon sandwich, the scone with the strawberry jam, and the chocolate and peanut butter dessert.There are a good variety of hot tea choices. Each person gets their own teapot serving. I chose the African Amber tea. I prefer more sweet teas, and I was so happy with my choice.It is definitely a more formal environment, wear business casual. And the tea service is only available at certain times, be sure to schedule accordingly.

Am definitely making a return visit!  Love the ample selection of afternoon tea treats.  I ordered the Lapsang souchong tea which wasn't my cup of tea (no pun intended)....preferred my friend's selection - the African amber. Absolutely lovely ambiance as well and superb service.  I felt that the price was quite reasonable compared to other places I've visited for afternoon tea.

There are quite a few different places in Chicago that offer high tea, but this is a great spot, affordable, and the menu is just as good as the other ones offered on Michigan Avenue but at a better price! Great service and plenty of parking, my girlfriend and I were greeted promptly and given a great little seat where we shared a 3 tiered tray of cakes, sandwiches, cookies and other assortments. We chose the one that included a sparkling cocktail which was delightful! Service was very prompt and we loved the tea that was included. This is so great for little get togethers and I plan on taking my Mom here as well. The pricing was not bad at around $30 a person and I was absolutely stuffed! Parking is not terrible either, you just have to look. I highly recommend this place. The decor, the food, the service, the price - you can't go wrong here.

Came here on a Saturday night with 10 people around 9 pm for some drinks before heading out. We ended up staying for 4 hours. This place is an awesome lounge. It's the name of the bar inside soho fyi.There is music but it's not so loud you can't hear the person next to you. Seating is mainly on couches, lounges and random tables. It kinda looks like your grandma's furniture put into a swanky loft. But it works. It was busy but not so crowded you couldn't get a drink or sit down.The drinks are well made. They offer a small food menu, mainly bar bites. Since we had so many people I ordered one of everything on the menu. Granted we had all been drinking quite a bit but favorites were the guacamole,  truffle grilled cheese and short rib and cheese panini.Service is a little slow. Often drinks were "forgotten" by the waitress. But not a bad lounge option. I will definently be back.

Came here because I got off work early and wanted to treat myself! They had a small lunch menu with salads and sandwiches. I asked if i could get the avocado toast w the soft eggs (which wasn't on the menu) and they were able to accommodate me. I expected something small with few pieces of avocado but oh my goodness! It looked like two large avocados on my toast. Very delicious and exactly what I wanted. The inside is spectacular. Comfy and for the hippies :-) I hope to be back for tea time.

Best afternoon tea place by far. Very fancy, ambient setting, and decorative desserts. The finger sandwiches are delicious and in fact, I'm craving some right now. Their tea was delicious but it's really the atmosphere that you pay for. Gorgeous chandeliers and beautiful plating. It's about $30 for the afternoon tea but do it once every month or two and it's affordable.

Came here for afternoon tea on a Monday. We were able to call in in the morning and get reservations for 4:30. The Allis is located inside the Soho House, and offered two pretty affordable options for afternoon tea. Afternoon Tea set was $24, while the second option was Afternoon Tea with a glass of rose prosecco at $32.The sandwiches were a bit salty for our taste. The bread was also a bit hard (perhaps stale?).  The sweets were nothing special, and the teas were just okay as well. The best of the set was the scone, lemon pound cake, and red velvet cupcake.This was also the most casual afternoon tea place I've been to yet! We sat on sofas with the teas on coffee tables. Others around us were people in their 20s and 30s typing and working away with coffees.The decor was cute, but I'd go elsewhere if looking for afternoon tea!

Love this place! I have been here twice for far for afternoon tea. The service is wonderful! The tea and tea snacks are delicious. The chocolate cake slice is YUMMY. I wish they would give everybody at least 2 slices. The tea sandwiches are very good. I could do without the lemon poppy seed bread as it is on the dry side.Decor and atmosphere is fun! This place is great!If you plan on stopping by for tea, make sure to call ahead and make a reservation.

Walked in for breakfast with a friend.2 things struck me at once... I loved the old world deco it has for a breakfast place... Reminds me of Grandma's home and secondly the polite wait staff.Went in... Seated promptly. And served water within minutes... Smooth. She didn't frown when I knowingly chose tap over sparkling, that was an added plus.Food was served promptly and was above average but not amazing.Here is the rating -Food- 3.5/5 (eggs were nicely done but didn't like the cured salmon)Deco - 4.5/5 really liked the feel of the place... Relaxing with refined elegance to itStaff - 5/5 no complaints. Polite, smiling, minimal wait periods and checked intermittently on the table (added plus that it was unobtrusive)Price - 4.5/5 12usd + taxes for 1 persons breakfast and coffee.Overall - 4.5/5 above average food with great deco/staff for the price - sure I will take it.

The bf and I stopped in to Allis for a pre Valentines Day dinner drink this past Saturday. We came in at about 8:30 and were lucky enough to score a table for two. The table was perfect for the two of us and the chairs were super lux which added to the rich ambiance of Allis. The vibe here is very cool, chic, and Chicago-y (yes, I know not a word, but it works).We ordered two old fashioned's which I thought were delicious. My bf thought they were good but a bit lacking in flavor. They do offer a small plate menu of you were looking to grab a snack while drinking.
