Where to start? There was so much that we got to experience at this new BBQ joint in Logan! First our server appeared to be frazzled during every interaction at our table. It took around ten minutes for two drafts beers to arrive (during A slow Sunday evening), at which point the server had forgotten who had ordered what. Our friend attempted to order the whiskey strawberry lemonade, but apparently that was a "mistake" on the menu. His alternative cocktail was delivered fifteen minutes later (and no, the occupancy of the restaurant had not in fact increased). The rest of our party showed up to order more cocktails, that took another fifteen minutes to arrive. By this time we were all ready to order! Now, we get to discover that "we are out of the ribs and wings, and oh you wanted creamed corn - we are out of that too!"  This was followed by more more confusion over who ordered what drink and food. Needless to say we were MORE than ready to wash away our disappointment across the street, with a cocktail from Masa Azul, who offered everything on their menu that they said they would, with finesse! Son of a Butcher has some serious room for improvement if they intend to compete with the other hip restaurants of Logan Square.P.S. The reason i included an additional star: the Ron Swanson tots were legitimate.

This place is not what I expected! It's everything I've ever wanted and more in food. The Pambazo style burger is something to get, and OH MY GOD the ribs... SLOW ROASTED and dry rubbed. So delicious. The seasonal cocktails are on point;'There are some who call me tim,' the hibiscus and the orchard shrub cocktail, is probably my favorite, as it blends tangy and sweet AND the bartenders can make a great rye old fashioned.

Me and my roommate went here for brunch this morning. We live right down the street and saw this place driving a few times and had always wanted to try it. It's a small little spot, they had a DJ playing in there front, the music was good for brunch, mellower and hip hop style at a good volume so you have no problem talking to the people youre with. The décor is really cute, about 7-8 booths against the wall and a bar you can sit at, like I said it's relatively small. We sat at the bar and chatted with the bartender Stephen for a bit, turns out we walked in on the first day of their official brunch! What luck!Now on to the food, sooooo goooood!!! I got the Brunch and Turf, which is steak, 3 bacon wrapped shrimp smothered in BBQ sauce, potatoes, eggs and toast. It was so delicious! That is the only way I ever want my shrimp made again. My roomie got the Loan Star Benedict, also very very good! I highly recommend this place and we will definitely be returning for brunch and to check out their dinner/cocktails.

Have you ever had food that looked amazing, yet, didn't taste like it. Well, that was my experience at Son of a Butcher. I saw all the hype on Facebook. Read the reviews on Yelp, and it looked amazing. So I was convinced. Then, I saw there were two pages on Yelp for this spot. One had 4 stars and the other had 3 stars. Which had me confused and it didn't make sense. But, I'm adventurous, like to try new spots all the time, so I decided to go with my fiancé, her cousin and my mother.At first glance, the place is nicely set up. The bar overtakes the area when you walk in, which is good, because it is a tavern. We were seated promptly but I noticed that they were not too busy for a Saturday night at 7:00 pm. Anyways, it took a little while for us to get menus or service, approximately 15 mins before our waitress come by and asked us if we wanted anything off the menu. But, she was pleasant and it seemed like she was overwhelmed. So we proceeded to order. My mom had a Michelada and so did I. My fiancé had the "son of a  margarita" and her cousin had a regular beer. They were out of a lot of beers and the beer she ordered said was available, then we were informed it wasn't and we were still charged for ordering it.The Micheladas were less than average. Tasted like a little bit of Bloody Mary mix was thrown in with some ice and beer. Nothing to write home about. The "son of a margarita" was pleasant and had the hints of lime as the drink stated. Good drink. Although I've had better margaritas (i.e. Del Toro).We ordered some appetizers and had the Poblano Mac and Cheese and the Piggy Pops. The Piggy pops came in and they were pretty good. Only gripe was that they were a little cold. But otherwise the taste was great. Just wish they would have put more salsa on the platter. Seemed like they drizzled it on but there wasn't enough to go around. The Mac and cheese had decent taste to it but nothing great. The cheese sauce was watered down and it tasted more like pasta than anything else. I wish they would have roasted the peppers or done something more with them because the flavor was very mild. Anyways, more cheese is needed on a Mac and Cheese plate please.We then ordered our entrees and my mom had the "Straight out of DF". Her skirt steak was lackluster. I've had better skirt steak at your run of the mill Mexican restaurants. The skirt steak was chopped up and mixed in with the onions and peppers. The plate comes with tortillas and they were super soggy and seemed like they were heated in a microwave oven then thrown on the plate. For the sides she had guacamole and frijoles charros. The guacamole was good, nothing special. The frijoles charros had good taste but seemed like they had tomato sauce added to them. We're Mexican and we never add tomato sauce to out frijoles charros. Everyone else ordered burgers and I had the Pombazo-Style burger. I was so excited about having this burger. It looked amazing in the pics and the description of it made it seem like a stellar burger. From the price, (i.e. $15) one would assume you would get a great dish. But it was very disappointing. The bun was dipped in the guajillo sauce, which is cool, but after the first bite, I wasn't impressed with the taste, and my hands were now drenched in sauce. Something I didn't think about before I ordered. The beef was below average although it was cooked to my liking. I like my burgers medium. It had little flavor and seasoning to it. The burger came with a bunch of lettuce, although no where in the description does it say that the burger comes with lettuce. The carnitas were ok. Nothing great. I also had a hard time finding the grilled onions. I probably found two strings between all the lettuce. Overall I'd give it a 2/5 stars. Very disappointed. I don't think I'll ever go back to this place.

This place is a disappointment. We ordered 6 wings, which were good, but only received 5.The menu says that the carne asada entre with 2 side dishes is meant for two people so we ordered it. While the entre was good it was only about 2-3 tacos worth of meat with all of the additions. They must have literally used about 3-4 ounces of actual meat. The two sides were small enough for only one person per side. This was almost $20 for this fucking nonsense.WTF? The only thing we enjoyed here was the music. I do not recommend this place.

Still on the search for a good burger place in Chicago. It must really be difficult to cook a burger to medium because all I ever seem to find are too rare or too well done burgers. Tonight's was well done and honestly, 'twas a shame. It really wasn't so tasty and the best part was missing - the bacon. Also, I guess I'm just not a shoe string fry kinda gal. They are good for what they were if you like those. I'd say the best part of my meal was the goose island four star pils... Lol.Oh. And what the heck is this????

It's more like 2.5 stars...My friends and I ventured to this place after finding out about the hour long wait at Fat Rice. We got seated immediately and ordered our drinks and food. Sadly, they were out of the "piggie by the pound" so I got the spaghetti while my friends got their chicken sandwich and regular burger. We also shared the bone marrow between four people. The drinks came out quickly while the food, on the other hand, came out really slowly. I loved the moscow mule but you can never go wrong with a moscow mule.The bone marrow came out and there were three marrows. The portion is a lot and don't be afraid to ask for more bread. The bread was good but it was salted and it got too salty for me.My spaghetti was also really salty..I kept having to drink water to dilute my taste buds. I got to try the chicken sandwich and that was meh. The chicken sandwich at Popeyes is probably better than this. And the fries were mediocre.Another thing was they offered ketchup in spoonful size. We kept having to ask for more ketchup and that was a bit annoying.Service was amazing and I love the ambiance and decor but the food, not that great. And it was a bit on the pricey end..

The re-opening in late June completely changed the menu. Please consider all reviews past May 2016 as invalid. Check out their menu on their website for something up to date.I enjoyed the unique selection of the original venue but now it's basically another sports bar. Just what we need more of!

This place is awesome!!! small place on the corner.Love the atmosphere. A great chill bar. Spent all Sunday here! Owner is a great man he got us all a shot and he let me do a complimentary wine flight to try the different wines they had. Little bummed I could not try their bone marrow.. will have to come back! Bartender very cool and he charged my iphone for me. It was not busy which I liked

We came here for dinner on a recent Saturday night and had a really good time.  I was able to make a same day reservation on Open Table and we were seated right away upon arrival.  We had some questions about their cocktail menu and our server answered them and helped up decide which ones we would probably like based on our tastes.  For food we went with the spaghetti and the piggie by the pound.  Both dishes were really good, but the piggie by the pound was the clear winner.  It's a great little place on the corner and we will definitely return to try more of the menu or maybe just get the piggie again because it was that good.

Atmosphere is a little weird, but we did come here at 11 on a Monday morning. My husband and I decided to split the BBQ hash. It was pretty and tasty and enough food to share between us and our 2.5 year. It comes with a side of toast. GET THE RYE! I have never in my life recommended rye or would choose that kind, but they were waiting on their bakery delivery, so it was our only option. I'm so glad though. It was warm, soft, buttery perfection. I wish they sold it by the loaf.

Brunch used to be a foreign concept to me before I met Sam. I had simpler tastes and my idea of a nice dinner was going to Baker's Square. So brunch was one of those terms like aioli or molecular gastronomy that didn't really resonate with me at all. After Son of a Butcher's Cochon Brunch, I'm kinda glad I'm in the know.Sam and I decided to come in on a Saturday morning around noon. It was raining a bit outside so the outdoor seating along Richmond St. were empty. I can imagine it would be a pretty sweet spot to grab some food on a warm night though. On the inside the decor kinda reminded me of steampunk a little bit. I could be way off here but there were a lot of brass and wood finishings. Plus there were these chairs that almost looked like they had gears on the legs. You could tell some thought went into the style of this place. Plus, the murals they have going on outside are pretty neat too. I figure this shot has been taken a hundred times before but this greets you as you walk up.Being the cochon (pig) brunch, I kinda had to go with the Piggie by the pound. Sam went with the Beef Navel Eggs Benedict, classic brunch food. Sam said that her eggs Benedict were good, I tried a bit and the yolks and hollandaise running into the muffin made it a really rich bite. The star though was the Piggie by the pound. You get a serious pile of pulled pork with some corn tortillas and I decided to add-on some almond chimichurri for good measure. The pork was super tender but there was still some pieces with a bit of a crunch to them and then there were some fatty bits mixed in too. Wow is pretty much all I have to say. If you come here for brunch and you don't try this, you're doing it wrong. I will say that it can probably feed 2 people and it was only $11 when I went. That's an awesome deal. Since I was eating at a tavern I also snagged a Goose Island Green Line.There were just a few nits to pick though. Sam came in wanting to try the biscuits and gravy and the spuddies on the side but they weren't ready yet. That was kind of unfortunate since it was already an hour after they opened. Aside from that, I'd say Son of a Butcher was a solid 3.5 out of 5 for me. With Fat Rice across the street and Longman & Eagle a few blocks away, Son of a Butcher has some high profile neighbors, but I think it holds it's own. Sam and I would definitely recommend this place to someone on the hunt for a meal in Logan Square.

This place is amazing! The food is great, drinks are great, location isn't bad and the staff are friendly and really just the best! Can't beat this trendy Logan Square joint for a trendy, large-portioned dinner and drinks! Definitely try the mac & cheese and the Son of a Margarita. Cajun fries are also the bomb

I really wanted to like this place and I am super disappointed.  I love the location, design, and menu but the service really made me want to walk out without paying (which I would never do) not that anyone would have even noticed.  I left two stars because my boyfriends burger was really good, especially compared to my $13 eggs which were not as good as a similar dish I recently had at Ihop.  I would go back to try something else but the service was a joke.  I understand places get busy especially on Saturday afternoons but we barely got to place an order then were literally ignored for the entire time.  After desperation sat in, I had to get refills myself from the bartender (who was awesome and brought us a carafe of coke afterward, thank you awesome bartender dude!).  I saw who I assume was our waitress running around busily so I understand, HOWEVER, call in reinforcements, or lean over as you are ringing in a ticket to at least check on us once, or don't seat us at all until you catch up! I'd rather wait for a while than be completely ignored.

I came to Son of a Butcher on a Saturday night recently, and had a good experience. I made reservations on Open Table earlier that same day and was able to easily get a reservation. When I first arrived, our table wasn't ready, but one of the hosts made sure to keep us updated on how much longer it would be until we were seated. Probably waited around 15 minutes, but I made myself at home at the bar while I waited. Their drink menu includes plenty of beers, Around 5 or 6 cocktails, and a few wines. I had two cocktails that were whiskey based (I forget the names of them unfortunately), but they were well worth the $10 and potent.To eat I had the braised beef meat pie dish. This dish included 3 pastries stuffed with tender seasoned braised beef and a gouda cheese sauce on top. This dish was very flavorful and is ideal if you aren't too hungry. My boyfriend got the lamb meatloaf with a sweet potato puree. The meatloaf is a better fit if you are wanting a full meal. I tasted the lamb meatloaf, and it paired perfectly with the sweet potato puree.The service we received from the staff was mostly positive, but our waitress seemed to be kind of in a hurry to get us out of there. We had a 9pm reservation, and the place doesn't close until 3am, so it was a little weird.  Maybe she was tired or was almost done with her shift.  Since I had good experiences with the host, bartender, and other support staff, I wouldn't let my experience with her detour me from coming again though.

My friends and myself went to have brunch for 12 people. I can understand 1 or 2 maybe even 3 orders wrong but EVERYONE'S order.? Not to mention we sat for an hour and a half just waiting for our drinks. which were simple mimosa's. luckily we were all in good company with good conversation. The orders of food that did come had an outrageous amount of salt. A simple brunch turned into 3 hour hassle. Everything was wrong. The people who worked there all seemed to be confused . I was very upset because I live in the area and this place was a huge FAIL!

I've been here a handful of times so far and have loved it every time. I love the casual neighborhood bar vibe, and the drinks and food are always on point! On Sundays ("Industry Sundays"), the food menu is limited, but I felt like a bad ass when I ordered the entire menu. They no longer have the Butcher's Stash (off-menu) available on Sundays, but if you go any other day of the week, do yourself a favor and order it -- it includes about three pounds of meaty goodness, a smooth-as-butter liver pate, and various jams and pickles. Other highlights include the bone marrow, fries with chorizo gravy, goat cheese fritters, spaghetti (DEFINITELY get it with the egg), and the piggie by the pound.Bonus points for the amazing playlist! ;)

Went for brunch on opening day (of becoming the by WHISK restaurant that it is) with a friend, knowing its opening day...so everyone may be a little rocky. Overall, it was still a great experience! Didn't go for cocktails since still hungover, but I got the croissant sandwich, with a side of chipotle queso fundido sauce for dipping.Anyway, All the things that I loved:The bacon - supernaturalThe croissant - buttery goodnessThe potatoes - crispy, salty, with that thick brown crunch on the outside (I encourage you to order a side of that chipotle queso sauce that comes with one of the omelette a technically.Poblano Mac n' Cheese - melt in your mouthThe toast w/ house made preserves - legitThe service - there was a couple short glitches but it was their first brunch so I'm giving them a break and they even took something off the bill for coming out a couple minutes late.Go support this place, and for sure do brunch!
Good beers, good champagne gin cocktailNice appetizer special and the 1 lb. pork sliders were tastyService was good
Worst customer service I've experienced on Grubhub. I've been using Grubhub for over 3 years and never wrote a bad review. Don't order from here, there are soo many better, cheaper places.

I thought the place was great , not busy but not empty at all, staff was very prompt and friendly . The food was amazing ! Their queso pico app was bomb and I got the chicken Gouda sandwich , that melted in my mouth, so good! Also I got the Ron Swanson fries ...must try. The boyfriend got one of the burgers that came on French toast and had an egg inside and said it was  delicious . I would take the bad reviews on this place with a grain of salt . Very cool little tavern type place for a good meal.

Solid new neighborhood spot. We tried the classic burger and the snickers cheesecake, which were both on point. The porkbelly on the burger was perfectly cooked; we'll be returning to try the pork belly "piggy pops" appetizer. The beer list is also solid.  I would consider the prices to be fair and in-line with other similar establishments.The service was great and all of the staff members we encountered were extremely nice and attentive.We also look forward to the upcoming weekend brunch menu.Welcome to the neighborhood!

Went to have dinner with family... Sam was our waiter... Ted was our bartender..I was surprised that they came to our table and said hello.The foot has a bit of heat... And that is a good surprise to the event...  The place was not loud or rowdy...Good recommendations for the beer... The pumpkin was a great choice..I highly recommend if you like a little heat in your meal.If in the area, I will go again... Nice all in all...

Diggin' it. We have been three times since the Whisk take over. One visit was a little bumpy but the other two were fantastic. Great service at the bar and delicious food. Pambazo Burger?! Yes please. I'm looking forward to checking out brunch soon. See you all soon!

I want to start off by saying that the food is really good here, and I will come back to sit at the bar. I was here this past weekend, and I must say I was a little disappointed with the service. Upon arrival, we were seated right away, which is always nice considering this place has been getting really popular. We sat down at this booth/table which was super close to other people but oh well, it was fine. We waited about 10 minutes for our server to come and greet us, which again I understand, they get busy I'm not their only customer; however, I'm pretty sure one of the managers (girl with long hair to the side and a hat) saw us sitting down for a good while, I'm talking about she made eye contact with us and she didn't approach us and couldn't crack a smile. We were then approached by our server, a really nice guy, and he made it all better but it still sucked to have waited almost an hour for a decent service.Good cocktails and food, definitely sitting at the bar next time.
Incredible food and service.... but if you like wet butts this is the place! Wet outdoor chairs but you don't notice with that sweet sweet food
Good brunch, the piggie benidect was very yummy. Service was a bit slow. Definitely will be back.

We were so excited to try out SOB. Our excitement was quickly diminished by the lack of service and communication. Not only did we wait 20+ minutes for our drinks we ended up walking out when it hit the 1 hour mark for our food to arrive. While watching other tables walk out we still had a glimpse of hope that our food would arrive. When it did not arrive, we asked our server to cancel our food order and we would settle up our drink bill -- 10 minutes later without a drink bill we begrudgingly left a $20. As we walked to the door, other tables applauded our bravery for doing what they wish they would have done too.  I would leave zero stars but that's not an option.Expectations are the building blocks for disappointment.Get it together SOB. So much wasted potential.

Lately I'm into Instagram as a tool to find new tasty restaurants in the Chicago area.  I was excited about all I was seeing online for this spot, but I'm sad to report this wasn't a good experience.  We showed up on a Sunday afternoon and enjoyed getting an outside table.  It didn't take long to get a server and we placed our order.  A few minutes later she came back and said - sorry, we don't have anything you ordered.  No ribs, brisket, pork, wings, etc.  And no beer that you ordered either - please try again.  Okay, so we changed our orders - quite disappointed - but life goes on, right?  Again, a few minutes later she comes back - sorry, we don't have that beer either.  Um, let's hope the third time is a charm.  Not so much...but she mentioned the owner was inside and trying to find it for us.Zero for three -- not a good ratio.Anyways, we waited another 10 minutes and we see our food coming out.  It looked decent and then the waitress let us know they were still hunting for a beer option.  At that point, we told her that we'll just skip beers.  The tater tots were wrong - we wanted ranch ones.  So I asked for some ranch for the tots.  They brought me maybe a tablespoon - which is when I had to ask for more...don't skimp on the ranch!As far as the food - we had one of the house burgers.  No bueno.  It was just a big mess of meat piled up - hard to eat and not much flavor.  We also had tacos - they were below average.  Trying to give a compliment here - The best one was the pork belly with pickled onions...thankfully the pickled onions had some flavor.  Mac and cheese - skip it - it was dry and zero flavor.  Tator tots - how can you screw those up?  Well sadly...there were piled in a big bowl and the bottom of the bowl was coated in grease.  Seriously, the bottom two layers of tots were swimming in grease.  We ate the top layer and then discovered the grease and stopped.  Bummer - I love tator tots.I will say - the waitress was nice and felt bad about all the "we're out of this" items.  (As she was also telling the table next to us the same thing about many items from drinks, appetizers, etc.).  But, if the owner is on-site - how about coming out and apologizing and maybe comping one of our sides?  And I suggest better inventory management.With so many other amazing spots that we've found in the city - we will not return to this one.  Two stars was generous.
Ramen was very yum.Pulled pork also quite yum.Bangbang pie for dessert always yum.Everything yum.Nice people too.

I really enjoyed Son of a Butcher.  I didn't actually know it existed until we made a reservation, but I'm really glad I visited.The spot is very very cute - I think some of it may have been converted from an outdoor space as there seems to be an outdoor wall inside the restaurant.  Very charming.The atmosphere inside is cozy and there's a really cute outdoor space that's becoming out of season right now.  There are candles on the table and a combination of booths, bar area and tables.  It's not a huge spot, but larger than it looks upon first entry.Our server was friendly and let us peruse the menu.  They were out of quite a few items, so, considering that and the time (as it was a little later), we were given the late night menu.  I think the items could use an amp up in naming...for instance, I wasn't sure if two of the items were sandwiches (they were) because of how they were described.  Also a bit confusing if a few items were appetizers or meals.  I'm not sure how the larger menu looks, but I was a little confused.Anyway, we split the gyro and the burger and both were delicious.  The burger was juicy, cooked perfectly and the bun..wow...seemingly plain but but oh so good.  The gyro was also delicious - really meaty and juicy and had a great yogurt sauce.  The fries were pretty good - thin and crispy.I thought the drink list was interesting - not a lot of wines, but unique ones.  I didn't peruse the beer list, but seemed long, so I'm sure they had lots of good options.I was a little sad we couldn't order off of the real dinner menu and that the items weren't clearly explained, but the staff is happy to help.All in all, a good spot and I'll definitely return.
Great service amazing brisket! Great service!and unforgettable drinks! A must try ... trust me I know good when I taste it!

We were on our way to another spot in the neighborhood when we saw this place, stopped dead in our tracks and then bolted inside to see what Son of a Butcher had to offer. Disappointment was not an option.We were immediately welcomed by very friendly waitstaff and I instantly fell in love with the decor. Think Restoration Hardware meets Something. Basically, just a cool, open space.As with all dining experiences, libations come first. The wine/cocktail/beer selection was extensive so there are definitely plenty options. Without thought, I gravitated towards the Smokin' Rose: a fruity, blackberry smoky mezcal-y concoction that was pure liquid sunshine.After quite the dilemma as there were so many delicious options, we opted for the hummus. Probably the best I have ever had. It was so fresh that you could taste the cumin and coriander and perhaps a slight hint of orange zest. It was accompanied by warm, perfectly charred pita bread and every bite was delectable. The pickled onions were also a good addition to this dish and it was a beautiful presentation. I wish this moment lasted longer.Now for the meat option. I mean, Son of a Butcher has pretty high standards to live up to with a name like that. But no problem. They did it.Get the Lamb Merguez hot dog. It comes with grilled apples, sage and a spicy mustard. Amazing flavors and ingredients that married each other and I was there to witness it. After each bite, something was happening to my heart. It was becoming full, right with my tummy. That is always a good sign.Finally, the chef Frank, is amazing. He introduced himself to us and personally made it his mission to ensure that we were having a great experience. A modest man with an impressive résumé. He knows what he is doing and is passionate about it and is definitely taking food to another level. A great individual who cares about food, the restaurant and its patrons. What more could you want? And the best part, it shows.And when we left that night, it made me wish that I was the Daughter of a Butcher. Enough Said?

I'll keep this short and sweet... The two tables next to us both left before their food even came out. It was a disorganized sh!tshow and the food was by no means a standout in the neighborhood. They've got the location and decor nailed down, but unless they can get their food and service kicked up several notches, Son of a Butcher part II seems destined to meet a similar fate as its first act... Perhaps even faster though. Hopefully they can get it together and turn things around.

My wife and were pumped to hear the team from Whisk was taking over Son of a Butcher and WOW have they delivered.  Rick's team is pumping out incredible dishes like the "BBQ Brisket Hash"  which I honestly feel bad for anyone who hasn't experienced it yet. I've sampled burgers, sandwiches and beers and have yet to be let down. The neighborhood is fortunate to have such a great brunch/lunch/dinner spot!!

I am giving this place four stars even though I have only had cocktails and beer here.  That's right!  Four stars!  And I have only so much as looked at their food, which, from its smell, appearance, and description on the menu, seems like it would be amazing.  What are you gonna do about it, send me to Yelp! jail?  Sure, I'll go back and eat there someday.  But I have things to cross off my to-do list, so help me God, and today SoaB gets four stars for beer and cocktails.  I dare you to do anything about it.

Happy to see this neighborhood joint upgraded in food, vibes, and drinks. The previous location had something missing, and looks like whisk found it! Try the shrimp tacos!!!! Excited to try their brunch!

I probably should have read the reviews before I came, but I'm glad that I didn't. I had seen the pics, and wanted to try everything. I showed up on a Sunday for Brunch, but my friend went to the other location. So, I ordered two cocktails, and the poblano mac and cheese with brisket to go. It was amazing...I'll come back for the brisket. The drinks were light on alcohol for sure...but beyond that service was good and quick.

I think I'm in love with whoever this butcher is. If I wasn't in public, I think I would lick the plate. Drinks are great and their piggy by the pound is absolutely amazing. Definitely come here for Sunday brunch. Can't wait to come back here.

We came here for brunch on Easter Sunday (maybe a strange choice, but they take reservations and are not far from us!) and really enjoyed our meal. All of us got the veggie hash (potentially another strange choice in a meat forward restaurant!) and very much enjoyed the dish. It was a little over-salted, but the veggies were very fresh and the overall flavors of the dish blended well. The service was attentive, but non-intrusive....

Absolutely loved this place. Used my giftie here and got the eggs benedict. The service was unlike other places, I was dumb and ordered this 'to go' not realizing what a mess it would be to eat on the go. The server was so helpful and kind, got out plates and set up the whole dish for me to eat in the restaurant.

Full disclosure: I went to a preview event last night in which Son of a Butcher passed around free bites of their food items to neighbors. I have to say I think this was an EXCELLENT idea to get the residents of Avondale & Logan Square involved and excited about the opening of their restaurant. Really smart marketing on their part, so kudos! Plus the whole event went very smooth and was seamless from what I could see as a customer.I made a reservation through OpenTable and it appears they will continue taking reservations. They have a limited amount of tables so if you plan on going to eat, I would highly recommend making a reservation. Other than the few booths (which are super chic & comfy), it's standing room only at the bar. Interesting approach to not have stools or seating at the bar. Overall though, I loved the decor and atmosphere of SOB (is this okay to write in a review!? I feel dirty!!!)Service was excellent throughout our stay with multiple people checking in on us and making sure our glasses were filled and our bellies were full.I was quite happy with their draft list. Though not huge they had nearly 100% local breweries on tap - Solemn Oath, Off Color, Lagunitas, 5 Rabbit, Half Acre, Revolution, Pipeworks and Marz. I highly appreciate supporting our local breweries and loved that that's the approach they are taking. Not only that, but they don't have the standards from these breweries on tap. Sure we all know Anti Hero, 5 Lizard and Scurry are great...but awesome to be able to try some NEW brews. Beer prices aren't atrocious either ranging from $5-7 for the tap beers. On top of the draught beers, they have bottles of some of the standards plus some unique things like sours! You're after my heart, SOB. And don't worry hipsters, they have PBR, Old Style and Old Milwaukee.Short version of my beer gushing, I'm down with their liqs selection.Hey Sarah! That's all fine and good about drinks...but this place is called Son of a BUTCHER!!! What about the food?!?!Yea, yea, over eager beavers...I'm getting there!The bites I was able to preview last night:Coriander Crusted Goat Cheese Fritter, Apple Compote $8 - These little guys pack a punch and I don't recommend eating them on their own, the goat cheese will overwhelm you. Doused in the apple compote though, it makes for a fun and tasty bite.Rice Cracklings, Salsa Verde, Pickled Vegetables $6 - Not an overly exciting dish but if you need something clean and non-threatening to munch on while sipping suds, this starter may be calling your name. My friend loved all the pickled veggies that came with the dish.Lamb Merguez Hot Dog, Grilled Apples, Sage, Spicy Mustard $13 - Loved the lamb sausage! The chunk of apple was huge so they may need to cut them up a bit more in the future but the flavors went together very well in this dish and I could see myself ordering this on the regular.Chistorra and Fried Oyster Po'boy, Cucumber, Yuzu $13 - I had never had chistorra before and love trying new food items. That little sausage was probably my favorite meat of the entire evening!Hog Wellington, Oyster Mushroom Duxelle, Smoked Lemon Hollandaise $18 - I can see the potential in this and I definitely want to give this another try in the full dish form. The meat in this wellington seemed a bit dried out but I'd like to attribute that to the tiny portion.One thing I really am enjoying about the Son of a Butcher menu is the great balance of flavors. They use strong ingredients but offset them with something more calming paired in the dish. I also was seeing some flavor combinations I haven't before.Official opening is June 18th! Their Cochon brunch menu looks awesome & will be served Saturdays & Sundays from 11am-3pm. I can't wait to try the brunch and some other menu items. Being just a couple of blocks away from home for me, I'm hoping to make this a regular hit up spot.Welcome to the 'hood, Son of a Butcher! Bonus points for the company email (info@thatsobt.com) and the gratis shaved ice outside! That was some amazing lime ice!

I wanted to rate this place higher. I really, really did. However, that's not how the cookie crumbled this time around.Our waitress was very knowledgeable of the menu and very friendly. She had great suggestions and was checking in on us in good intervals.However, my issue comes with the food: both financially and where portions are concerned. The fritters are delicious, but for $8 I was expecting enough food for two people. My fiancé and I both ordered specials, which I really wish we would have known the price of before ordering. Each special came out to close to $35 dollars. Now, I've been to places with $35 dollar specials. I get it. Sometimes you gotta pay for something a little extra. But these specials were pretty standard, sloppily organized plates. They tasted fine. And I guess overall I'm not crazy disappointed with them, but I'm super salty that they didn't list prices for these items (like almost every other restaurant I've ever been to).Our bill came out to well over $100 for two people. To put that in perspective, Parachute (a Michelin star rated establishment-less than a mile away) was the exact same price for world class food.

I'm gonna chalk up how relatively empty it was to the fact we were there early while the Cubs were playing in Game 4 of the NLDS. But if a place like this can't make it, then the whole neighborhood deserves to drown in PBR.From the moment we got there, it was a great impression. Really fun and thoughtful decor with intimate little booths. This venue would be great for private events too.The drinks were big hits. I got the Smoking Rose, which puts mezcal front and center with just enough blackberry to balance the flavor without being too sweet. My partner got the Butcher's Mule, which opts for rye instead of vodka and has a strong minty punch to it. Also delicious.Foodwise, she got the Lamb Merguez meatloaf, which from the bite I had, was delicious and complex. I opted for the Ramen, which seems like a little bit of an oddball on this carnivorous menu, but then again, going for the oddball item is not a bad strategy: if the chef thinks it's worth breaking 'theme' for, it must be good. That rationale paid off, because this bowl of ramen, with a rich, meaty broth, perfectly cooked noodles, and the added goodies of hunk of pork belly and a soft boiled egg, goes toe to toe with any dedicated ramen house in the city. Yeah, I said it.We also got to chat with Dave, the manager, at some length about the Cubs, the neighborhood, and New York (where he grew up and we recently moved back from). Talking to him sealed this place for me. It's not all that hard to get a good meal in Chicago. But as the food scene here continues to grow, you want to support the places where hardworking people create a great experience in an authentic and earnest way. This is one of those places. Now go give them your business.

So I need to figure out a nice way to write a bad review. The experience for brunch yesterday was a bit awkward and something strange was happening behind the scenes. On our arrival, we were able to get a great spot outside for 10 people immediately (which could be taken as a "sign" by some). We had some jam that was on our table from the previous customers that we had requested multiple times to be wiped off because the bees were coming for it... it was under the table so the person that was sent out to clean it up didn't see any "spills". The servers we had were great and they were doing the very best that they could given that apparently there was something happening inside the restaurant that was causing them to close down an hour and a half early during Sunday Brunch. They ran out of champagne for our mimosas after we ordered one carafe. Some of the other items weren't available as well... I forget what they were off the top of my head. The food was just "ok" - I had the Texas Benedict. There wasn't much flavor to it at all so I had to add my own. Everyone at the table had the same opinion, the food was just OK at best. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great. Anyway - it seems that something needs to be sorted out because this place has really good potential.

I really wanted to rate it higher, I really did... I went there with my wife for dinner, and I was disappointed. We live close by and waited for this place to open. We hear a lot of good feed back about and I said to give it a try.The staff is good, even if you don't know much about the dishes they will help you out! A big problem is that for dinner they have a different menu than during the day with not much plate to choose and is over priced!!!For two people, in this neighborhood to pay $100 I think is overpriced.

I'm happy this place opened up. It's a nice addition to the neighborhood.It's a self proclaimed "old man bar" with gastropub-pub style food. Pretty good beer list, but no cocktail menu (differentiates this place from the rest of the hood and fits with the old man bar thing). They bring out a small plate of sliced meat as you sit down, which is a very nice touch.The food was good here. I'm interested to see how the menu evolves over time. I sampled the lamb tartare, which was different than I expected with a nice curry flavor and creamy texture. The bone marrow was good, as you would expect, but nothing unique. I wasn't a huge fan of the goat cheese fritters, not that they were bad but just not notable enough for me to order them again. The Hog Wellington was delicious, but it was served on a tiny plate which was very strange. I had a bite of the "no beef" mushroom Italian beef knock-off and thought that was really good, but I'm not a huge fan of the thin fried potatoes. I could see the sandwich menu being a go-to for me here. Typically I wouldn't be so specific in my review notes, but this place is new enough that maybe they can make slight adjustments and become a great spot.The service was super friendly, as I expected from a new place trying to win over their first customers. I love just down the street so I think I'll be coming back here soon.

I was so excited for check this place out. We sat at the bar and the bartenders were sweet. But service and quality were below par to say the least. Our breakfast took 1 hour to come out. I ordered the Green eggs and ham omelette. It did not have ham in it. Instead it was turkey meat. Instead of butter, our toast was served with a side of mayo. When we finally received the check the server charged for 2 cups of coffee. My husband ordered coffee but was not told at any point there was a charge for refills. It was a disappointing experience to stay the least. It's too bad because the dinner menu looked great. But I'll never get to check it out because I won't be going back. There are too many great restaurants in this city to give it a second chance.

They do everything right. Menu? Awesome options. Food execution? Spot on. Welcoming vibe? To the 100th degree. Funky but comfortable ambiance? Check. A total delight in the Logan/Avondale scene. If you want an awesome dinner in a place that makes you feel welcome and happy, look no further. This is what a restaurant should be.

This is a great addition to the food scene in Logan Square. My wife and I had dinner there shortly after it opened. The lamb tartare was fantastic, and so was the beef neck that I ordered. My wife is still talking about the mussel and meatball dish she had! Delicious!This past weekend we were looking for a place to eat on our way to the farmers market and popped in here. Service was good and friendly. She had the farm fresh eggs and I had the lamb sausage. Both excellent. We even had a chance to chat with Frank, the chef. Highly recommended.

Best brunch in the city hands down.  Similar interior as Longman and Eagle but MUCH BETTER food.  A mix of comfort and a little bit of Logan/Avondale flavor.  David - the manager is a true host.  I don't think I've gotten better treatment in this city ever.  Servers are solid and knowledgable and the chef is hands down amazing.  Chill beats are always playing - good drink menu as well.  Just love this place all the way around and taking advantage of the early days before I can't get a seat on the weekends.

I way pretty disappointed, after having high hopes for this place. The bone marrow app was barely enough for 4 people to even get a taste of. No one at my table wanted to finish their entree, which included the ramen and meatloaf. My steak & frites was fine, but certainly not worth charging $26 for. Seemed understaffed as well, plus we had to wait half an hour despite making reservations.

Had a great experience here, tried about 8 dishes.Really great preparation and presentation, the beef neck was the star of the show. Also excellent were the beef tongue and lamb merguez sandwiches, and vegetarian wise, the goat cheese fritters and rice cracklings, which were pretty much the most accurate representation of chicharron in vegetarian form I've ever seen, served with an earthy salsa verde speckled with an authentic escabeche. The food was exceptional.Service was kind of what you'd expect. Hipster whatever, who cares. Vibe was good, eclectic art and wallpaper, could use a cosmetic cover on the heating ducts. Good place to eat, check it out and ignore the inept reviews...and Mike Sula, he can be a dick with his reviews. A smart dick, but still a dick. ;)
Wow! And my people's owned! Congrats!  hats to the chef!  My new favorite place. The bathroom had hooks for my purse!  Love the decor, the music, the gm was great. Love love love it!
This place was AWESOME!  Went there for bunch, had great bloodies and great food.  I highly recommend it for a date, group or just to hang out and enjoy.

So ... No stars.  I assure you ... The food is great and the cocktails were wonderful BUT ... The service was rotten - absolutely terrible.  We visited 4 days after the grand opening.  Ten minutes after we placed our order we were informed they were out of ribs - at 4:30pm?  Why wouldn't the wait staff know this ahead of time.  Service was slow ... our appetizer didn't show up until after our dinner.  There wer 4 of us - two entrees came out ... Then mine.  I ordered tater tots but my sandwich was served with fries.  Instead of leaving my meal they removed it ... Nothing like a Luke warm pork sandwich to replace the fries.  My meal returned ... Then the appetizer (thank goodness) because my friend didn't have his entree yet.  Finally ... the final sandwich showed.  Our wait staff was apologetic but not attentive - came to the table only once to check our drinks and water.  No ownership of our issues and yes - we payed full price for crappy service.  Sorry Whisk.  You really didn't care or want our business.  We won't be back.

Nice atmosphere. Sat outside and it was great. Had the pork cheek sandwich and it was good and spicy! Fries are spectacular. Mixed drinks were tasty. Service was great, and I loved our waitress. Will be back!

I was really excited when this place opened.  Looks really neat and reminded me alot of one of my other favorite places, Longmen & Eagle.  Anyway - we came here for brunch so I can't comment on the dinner food.  The brunch menu had some cool unique options.  Problem is....very small portions.  The biscuits and gravy type option they had was so small that we actually walked home after and made breakfast.  Tiny food portions, at that price, doesn't seem like something that would fit in Logan Square....We did go on the morning of Fathers Day....which I expected overwhelmed them since they JUST opened a few days prior.  However - the service was not good.  I've worked in the industry for several years so its pretty hard for me to actually say a place has bad service but this was def not their best day.  My bf ordered coffee and didn't get it til the food came out.  They kept mentioning that they ran out and would have to "go downstairs" for more.  Also, they didn't have silverware or napkins and we had to ask twice for them even after we got our food.  Really couldn't tell if the bartender was just super bad at her job or she was just embarrassed she didn't have alot available behind the bar i.e. napkins, silverware, coffee, sugar etc.  She didn't really want to make eye contact with us or even wait on us.Although our experience was not the best I do realize the place has just opened.  I gave it three stars because it really does have potential.  It seemed to have a great drink menu which I liked and I bet will be an awesome happy hour place.  If I can drag my bf back there again (he was pretty pissed about the 1st time) then I will def re rate higher as I can see this place doing pretty well!
The drinks were pretty bad.  Pretty easy to just buy ingredients and make better drinks at home.Food was solid.

Was excited to see the fall menu. Live close and it's a great location but....ordered a chicken sandwich and it was all breading and hardly any chicken. With Honey butter nearby , way off the markSo much potential but not going back

My recent visit to Son of A Butcher has made me come out of review writing retirement.During our visit, I honestly think just about everyone who worked there (chef, manager, bartender and of course our server) stopped by our table at some point to say hello or help us. Service was excellent and the food even better. The vibe and decor immediately appealed to me. Good tunes in the background.Food:  Complimentary ham with a giardiniera right when we were seated. Very delicious and caused an intense craving to try out their brunch on my next visit. Summer squash to start, the beef tongue gyro, and the lamb shank. The only criticism I would give was the summer squash was a little salty. But we still ate all of it. We planned on sharing the two main dishes. We ate about half of the beef tongue gyro and barely made a dent in lamb shank. All the dishes were incredibly flavorful with unique spins on what you might traditionally expect.Although I insisted my friend take the leftovers home, I was pleasantly surprised to see that I 'forgot' (K - if you stumble across this review it really was an accident) to give them to her and I got to relive this delicious meal the next day.Disclaimer: Although the chef and manager may have brought us some free shots it is very minimally impacting my 5 star rating.I will definitely be back. Maybe to writing reviews. Definitely to SOB tavern.

Good place! New joint in Avondale.. inside it's a lot bigger than it looks, really nice bar.  Good beer list and many craft cocktails being made, it's new so they're pretty busy. The food was just outstanding flavor wise!  We tried the Goat Cheese Fritters: Great but you only get THREE!? Then two amazing sandwiches..The Chicken Confit: Flat out great & The Fried Oyster Po-Boy: May have been better than the Chicken! Def recommend this place & the staff was very good as well/ give 'em a shot!

Not understanding some of the low reviews. We've been here for lunch and dinner. Each time, the food was really good and drinks were reasonably priced. The staff are really friendly, and super sweet and accommodating to families with kids.

This morning, I went to Son of a Butcher to try their unforgettable brunch. My friend and I were seated right away, choosing to forego the patio in favor of air conditioning. The service was impeccable: warm and prompt. We split an order of pain perdu (French toast) and piggie by the pound. Apparently, they roast a pig here each weekend and serve a pound of whatever they can take from it for brunch until they run out.I used to be a vegetarian, so I was not looking forward to the piggie end of things, but it was delectable, salty, and served with surprising and tangy sauces and corn tortillas. The French toast with mascarpone was as delicious as any brunch I've had at Lula. This place, however, had space to spare. It's brand new, half empty, delicious, and so spacious that I witnessed a family comfortably navigate multiple strollers without causing any discomfort to the single people around them.In short, I look forward to leaving hourlong waits for amazing food in Logan Square in the past and coming here more often!

This was the worst food i have ever tasted.  It was so disappointing because it looked like it'd be good and the menu sounded awesome.  But everything was bad.  Service.  Food.  Drinks were ok.  It took 15 minutes after ordering drinks to get them and it wasn't even busy.  There were a total of 8 tables and 3 servers.... The bone marrow barely fit on one peice of bread.  I got the po boy which and i had 2 bites of and couldn't eat anymore it was that awful.  My boyfriend who eats anything even if it doesn't taste that great had the torta and he refused to eat it after a couple bites.   Then it took forever for our server to come back with our check even though she went to both tables next to us.Super disappointed with this place.

We tried this one on a whim one day, and we were pleased. It's got a trendy feel to it, and the staff was really nice (host, bartender, and waiter). I wanted everything on the menu and settled for the pig by the pound (I can't remember if that was its actual name!) The name scared me for a second, but then I felt like a boss ordering it. It was a little too salty, but I'd definitely go back and order it again. The vodka drinks were on point! Props to the bartenders for taking care of their customers!

From the moment I walked in I was rooting for Son of Butcher to be a winner. Great energy, ambience and food.....Piggy by the pound is a must....the fresh carved piggy was an unparalleled  treat. ....staff was totally engaged and completely dialed into everything on the menu....kudos to David and the Son of a Butcher crew

Went to their preview event last night and all of the items they passed were fantastic!Favorite dishes were the No Beef sandwich, Hog Wellington, Lamb Tar Tar and Menudo Ramen. Plus they had a great brew selection ( showing a lot of love to local brews).Loved the concept and decor. This is a great addition to the Avondale/ Logan Square neighborhood.

I wanted to like this place, but I didn't. It was pretty bad, actually...well...except for one tiny thing.We ordered the Roasted Bone Marrow. I mean, it's fat, and fat is delicious. That's what earns it the extra star. It's a bit overpriced to scrape out some fat, but it earned it the extra star. Take a slab of bread and soak it into that fatty goodness and although you're still left wanting, it is a wonderful heart attack. I wouldn't return for it as I can get the same tasty fatty flavor from my rib eye steak at home for cheaper.The beef tongue gyro was a dry ol' thing with not a ton of flavor, except the mayonnaise that it was swimming in or yogurt that tasted like mayo? Not sure...but noooot good at all.The Pork cheek, well, that was just a salt lick. If you like licking salt, you'll love it, and it was as if they tried to hide the salt lick in the spicy and the cheese, but it just wasn't working. I was really excited for this one and had high hopes that just failed sadly.The best part of both of those plates were the fries. I have never sat in a restaurant and ate all the fries off the plate, but I did because I couldn't eat the rest. We left everything, so I sat there very disappointed and dipped my thin cut curly deliciousness into the one tiny spoon scoop of ketchup that they provided me with and then left... still hungry and wanting a good meal.Unfortunately, we won't be back.

Had a fantastic meet and greet on opening night, great addition to the neighborhood.We had three different appetizers, goat cheese fritters, Lamb tar-tar and the pork-skin. All three where delicious with my favorite being the goat cheese fritters.They had a great local selection of beers and cider. We highly recommend.

3.5 stars.We picked this place while trying to organize a get-together where the annual tradition is centered around something meaty.  The restaurant had nice decor and the concept was intriguing, which made us want to try all the unusual offerings.  Overall, the entrees were excellent, but the appetizers and drinks were a bit pricey (bone marrow yield a tablespoon at most).  One person in our group sent her drink back, but the waitress charged for it anyway, so it came out of her tip.
This place was great.  Their burger (add pork belly) will rival any in the city.  Certainly a welcome new addition to Logan Square.

I am a big fan of Son Of A Butcher.  Its meat, beer and other libations served in a cosy environment.  The staff and management were all pleasant.  My friends and I will definately be back.  Love Love Love.

Came here for brunch a few weeks ago. I was there with my girlfriend and another couple.  I made the very tasty mistake of ordering the pound of pork. When they say pound of pork they actually mean a pound. It was probably a little than I could really finish, but it was DELICIOUS. They have a good drink selection and it wasn't overly crowded. There were people at each table, but the bar wasn't full. I'd definitely come back here.

food is great. service is awful, amateurish, and way too informal for this caliber place. hopefully they will step it up. get a hostess, get a bartender, have waitstaff that knows the menu and knows how to properly serve a meal.

The best part of this place is the management.  David is the general manager of Son of a Butcher.  I've been here twice, and the first time I came here, he instantly treated me as family.  He brought in a wonderful vibe and energy, and made you feel at home.  He's very welcoming, and a big reason why I want to keep coming back.  He's a great person to be running a neighborhood establishment.  I'd follow him to whatever restaurants he managed.

I like it. That burger and drinks are nice. I'm enjoying this spot. Only issue is I see they are doing evening with djs. They could use better speakers. Doesn't have to be loud just sound better. Then I believe that atmosphere for evenings will be on point.

Great atmosphere good food reasonable prices. We came here at about 9:45 pm and so we could only order from the late night menu but there were still some interesting choices and luckily the dishes we wanted were both on it. We started with cocktails and they were delicious but mine was very small for 10$. Then we got the fried chicken confit which was delicious and the fries that come with it are probably the best fries I've ever had no joke. We also got the ramen which is in a Mexican broth. Very interesting and different dish and a good hunk of pork belly in it too! Very interesting and nice place to eat, well definitely be back!

One word. Underwhelmed. Service was almost non existent. Not sure why our beer glasses seemed to have actually been dipped in the beer. Not only am I cleaning my own table. I  have to wash my hands because everything is covered in stout. Had they been busy. I could understand. There was barely anyone there.Now to the overpriced food. No I don't expect IHOP portions. I actually avoid that type of joint like the plague. But if I order, what turns out to be a tiny bowl of lamb sausage hash. I don't expect to be fishing for the microscopic portion of sausage. My girlfriend's vegetable hash was meh.......Bottom line, if you're gonna spend the money. Go to Longman down the street.

Truly enjoyed my time there.  I had the mussels with meatballs, Amazing suace and great dish overall!!!  Also tried the hog wellington, very good, the pork was flavored perfectly and it was not dry!  Both dishes got better and better with each bite.   Fantastic decor and great vibe.  I will be back there and I highly recommend it!

Had high hopes for this place.  They have a very good beer and drink selection but very limited menu. I had hoped this was a just trust the menu place where they do only a handful of menu items really well.  Ended up with great drinks and little disappointed in the food.4 of us went and started off with 2 salads, goat cheese balls, and the hummus.  All were fairly tasty but small portions that were difficult to split. Goat cheese balls were ok but little too goat cheese overload.  They needed something else to cut the richness.  The hummus was very good but didn't give you near enough bread (4-5 small triangles) so we needed to ask for more.For main I had the lamb which was good but little on fatty side.  Others had the burger and it was also a little on smaller side and slightly over cooked, tasty though.Ok spot, but needs a more expansive menu or at least expand the larger plates. This great bar/pub with strong drinks and beers needs to have better food.

OVERPRICED & OVERRATED!! I ordered the veggie hash, not filling and tasted....meh! The portions are very small for the price ($14). The service was slow for not being busy. I really don't know how they have 4 stars!!

Having been one time before, we thought of this place to take an out of town friend for dinner to kick-off our last hoorah Saturday night. Luckily they were able to accommodate our original six that turned into eight. Our hungry bunch devoured everything up and down the menu! We tried the crispy fritters, puff pastry, a pork schmear special, bone marrow, ceasar salad (enough for four to split as a starter), steak frites, chicken sandwich and two excellent specials of scallops (that came on some salted black bean goodness) and the juiciest stack of pork chops. While it is short menu, don't let that fool you into thinking it's not diverse. Each dish really has a lot to offer with many unique twists. I also quite enjoyed two of their rye with walnut bitters cocktails and they have a great selection of beers that do compliment the menu. Our waitress was adorable, attentive and took great care of our group! Overall, it made for a very enjoyable and hearty start to the night!

My guy and I had been looking for an impressive meal for a while, and we finally got one here! So many places lately have been so disappointing, but this one definitely impressed us with their food!My guy and I generally go for sports bars, relaxed kind of places with a mix of burgers, sandwiches, salads, etc. We were being treated to this meal and wanted something a little bit more upscale but not totally over the top or expensive. This was a perfect balance of all that. Most of the dishes were in the high teens and $20 range, and they had a good range of salad, sandwich and entree too.We came here on a Saturday around 530. It was almost totally empty inside, but 75% full on the outdoor patio area. We had made a reservation through yelp to be safe. We were given water right away and were on our merry way.We decided to go for a cocktail for starters ($12-13). I had the "in between flights" which was a blend of bourbon, honey and grapefruit. It was really well balanced and refreshing. My guy had the "calder", which is their version of a manhattan? or old fashioned... I always get those confused... anywho, it was a large and lovely drink too.For entrees, I went for the watermelon farro salad and added steak ($10). The portion on this wasn't massive, but definitely satisfying! It's NOT a lettuce salad topped with farro. It was strictly farro, watermelon, basil, feta and steak with a dressing. The flavors were really unique and kept my tongue on alert! It was really different but excellent! The steak was so tender and good on it too! My guy had The Director entree- roasted chicken, grilled zucchini and polenta. Holy cow was his good too! I sampled some chicken and the polenta and both were totally knocked out of the park. He was able to finish it all but was full by the end of it.This restaurant is so convenient to many blue line stops too. We loved coming here and would gladly return!

A good after work dinner spot.  Came with the ball and chain for a quick dinner and drink, and was impressed by the service and food.Drinks: IPA and Wine. Wine was a heavy pour, good selection.Food: Steak Tartare - wonderful flavor, but odd that it was served with potato crisps. Also ordered the poutine which was fatty and delicious.The manager came to our table to ask if we needed anything, and service was very friendly and reliable. While not the creme de la creme it definitely is a good fit for a happy hour, dinner or lunch.

Enjoyed lunch at this place last weekend. We were immediately seated outside and brought water. The food was great! I had the grilled chicken sandwich with a side salad, both delicious. My boyfriend had the burgers and fries, also very good especially since they make their own pickles.The beer selection was pretty vast and had a lot of local beers which I really liked! It was a quick lunch for us so we were in and out within 30 minutes, however I do think our waitress could've paid a little bit more attention to us, but since we are younger I know that we don't always get the best attention.Overall good place, I would recommend for lunch!

I had a delightful meal at The Marq this week! Service was attentive and friendly, fun atmosphere. I ordered the Nicoise salad and it was delicious.The salmon was some of the best restaurant salmon I've ever had. It was moist, flavorful. The egg was perfectly cooked. I also loved the purple potatoes.Would love to come back and try more!

I stopped by the Marq due to its proximity from my hotel, and it was raining, so I was too lazy to venture out farther.I started with a sazerac which is always a risky order at an unknown bar. Thankfully it was perfect- light on the absinthe with lemon peel. They have several interesting selections for drinks on their fall menu, including one a butterscotch pumpkin rum combination and a twist on an old fashioned with maple syrup, walnut bitters, and chocolate ganache dipped bacon.I was still recovering from a late lunch, so I ate several starters. The whipped ricotta with honey and balsamic glaze was unbelievable. I also picked at a house salad. It was unexpected with frisée, Peruvian potatoes, and green beans. I enjoyed the combination.The atmosphere is relaxed with a subtle industrial theme. The servers were laid back and knowledgable, particularly the bartenders.

We made a reservation for a group of five and we're promptly seated.  Great service, large menu selection and decent wine list.  I went for the cedar plank salmon.  Perfectly cooked - as I had ordered.  Everyone else had delicious meals.  No complaints.

We stopped in after an appointment in the city for a drink, seeing The Marq was well rated on Yelp and nearby. The atmosphere is just hip enough without being overstated. It was clear the patrons were comfortable there; many in jeans plus a mix of business travelers.The service was awesome- we had a hipster with a mustache and a rad personality- and definitely made it worth the visit. He was on point, funny, and helpful with everything we needed.Hubs and I ordered different craft beers and some fried pickles. All were great. The pickles were battered like fish or tempura, but sweet and tangy. Definitely interesting!Worth the stop, for sure.

great place to meet up with friends, eat and drink and catch a game.  Old fashioned has bacon in it!! The burger was top notch and seasoned well!  I will return here again.  The prices were very reasonable for the city.

I will say 3.5 stars. Somethings were disappointing, some where not. We were a large party of 13 and we had a reservation of course. When we arrived they tried to put us at a 10 top and then 3 others would have to sit in a lounge area. We asked if we could all be together (which you would assume would happen). They did accommodate but I feel like that should have been done beforehand.We ordered some apps for the table, the fried pickles were very good as well as the sauce that comes with it. The hummus was also pretty tasty, the pita chips were a bit hard, but ok. But overall pretty solid options.I ordered the burger, I asked for medium, but they have to cook it medium well because it's two 4 ounce patties. Whomp. This just truck me as the kinda place with a real burger. To be perfectly honest, I didn't like it at all, it had a weird flavor to it. Not enough to send back, because I generally hate doing that. I wouldn't order that in my opinion.Everyone else at the table seemed to enjoy their various salads, salmon, etc. Maybe I should have gone with something else, but i was very underwhelmed.Service was very good and she did a great job handling the large party but it took a really long time to get our tab and half our party left to go back to the hotel. Overall, A-OK and maybe if I were in town again I'd swing by and try something besides the burger.

I had walked by this place a week earlier and thought I should check it out. Then later that week a friend of mine wanted to go someplace in the area and suggested this place. I didn't realize it was the same place until I arrived there. If you read the reviews, they were on point about a couple of issues. The place is loud and noisy but no more then other places...I think the walls and ceilings lack enough insolation. The food is pretty good, especially the polenta and amish chicken and salmon and succotash. However, the salad we got beforehand was bad. They served us the hearts of the romaine as a salad!?!? The beer menu is also limited and I was surprised because they had a huge bar at the center of the restaurant. Overall good experience with those exceptions. Probably won't be coming back...other options in the area.

Beautiful views, great location. Great, accurate, friendly and knowledgeable service. Food that isn't intimidating but with delicious twists thrown in. LOVED everything! Brussels sprouts definitely worth a try, the ribs were my favorite!

Nice place with high prices and menu is geared toward profit.  Not conducive to larger groups.I was here twice in the past week.  Once for lunch with a coworker and once after work with coworkers.  The lunch was ok, but portion was small.  I frequent other restaurants in the immediate area and the Grillroom nearby has better portions with similar quality and ambiance.  After work, this place was slightly awkward because everyone paid their own way because prices for drinks were high and there were no appetizers that could be shared except for their meat and cheese tray.  We'll be going back to Ceres at the CBOT building in the future.The Marq appears to be bent on its own style.  It's nice if you want a more quiet or intimate setting, but this is conflict with the tv screens on the walls.  This place has yet to figure it out.  Adjust the prices and menu selections.  I'll stop by in a few months to try again.

I just had an overall great experience when I went in for lunch the other day. It's really fresh looking, the service was excellent and the food was amazing. It was my first time being there as I'm not from Chicago, but when I'm in town again I would 100 percent go back.

Nice dining area! We came for a late lunch/early dinner. It was pleasant. The place was quiet, but comfortable. Our server was friendly and professional. The drink menu was good and so was the food.I had the ribs, which were alright. I've honestly had better at 'hole in the wall' places, but the presentation was good, the price was fair, and it was tender and tasty. I wouldn't mind eating here again.We also came once just for drinks, killing time. We sat in a lounge section and it was comfortable and fun. They have couches where you can sit and the ambiance is nice. They also have an outdoor seating area and large screen TVs indoors. I don't know what it's like at night or during "game day," but our daytime experience was pleasant. They are located near the financial district and it's close to transportation and hotels. It's a cool place!

You are well taken care of here although it's packed after work. No less than two busy bartenders were on the spot as soon as I sat down at the bar. The first asked me about my drink while pouring beers and making cocktails for others. He delivered a great martini while a second bartender asked about food. They seem not to have fixed locations but help whoever needs help. What a great idea.Dinner was salmon with polenta and hit the spot. Then a manager comes over and asks if he can clear the plates and bring my check which he does. Now I'm wondering is this good service or are they rushing me out to make way for another tab? My verdict--it's good service. The people here seem nice and they are efficient. Most people are hurrying somewhere after work. So if you're 30-something and good-looking, come here after work to see and be seen; and if you're like me, NOT 30-something, you can still come here and have a nice time.

Hey great service... Good wine list... And interesting food.I had the deck which is an interesting come nation of sweet and savory with the hot kimchi and the berry sauce. My friends had tortellini and salmon and there was three people in the clean plate club at the end of dinner

My Marq dinner ordered burger and Belgium white wheat beer. The front desk girl Kathryn was quite friendly and sweet. She gave a lots of tips of visiting surrounding at actives. I was able to sit on the sidewalk seat and enjoyed the weather. The food is good as a standard American style dinner.  The whole corner area smelled like alcohols spilled in street, lovely. My burger came faster than the bartender can fill my beer.It is closed on Sunday.

Let me start off by saying the atmosphere and decor of the place is really nice.  The dim lighting and arrangement of tables and bars gives off a very casual vibe that anyone whether coming for an after work drink or evening to watch the games can enjoy.  They have a descent amount of TVs (some larger then others) that makes for whichever location you choose to sit an enjoyable one.Of course after reading the reviews I knew I had to order The Marq Burger along with the Mac and Cheese.  What I liked best about the burger was how juicy it was and that was probably it.  The burger came with the usual toppings and I added on some caramelized onions ($1 extra).  I found the entire burger to be tasteless and that was with all of those toppings including my additional onions.  This was disappointing because I love a good tasting burger and I really didn't get the WOW factor after biting into it.  The other meal we ordered was the Mac and Cheese.  Not a fan of this either I'm afraid.  There wasn't anything special about the cheese and once again I found it lacking in flavor.  Compared to other dishes similar to these I have tried these particular ones didn't have anything specific that stood out.The servers were friendly although they forgot to bring us our drinks two separate times.  I was really looking forward to this place giving me a good quality burger but I'm afraid it didn't fulfill my taste buds.
Love this location for lunch and after-work cocktails. Great spot in the loop. I highly recommend the "The Intern" and the burger. Both are delicious.
Great place. The food was really good and the wine was excellent. Great space for having large parties. Our server was awsome. Can't wait to go back.

We were able to stop by for lunch today on our way to the Art Institute. The Marq was a lot more crowded since my previous weekend evening visit but we were lucky get a table right away. Same great service as last time even with the crowd.Food: we ordered Mac 'n Cheese and the Marq Burger with a fried egg. The Mac 'n Cheese was very tasty..nice and cheesy topped with panko bread crumbs for a little texture. The burger was was very good with the pickled onions and pickles adding a nice acidity to the flavor. The egg was good..but be warned..it can get messy! We ended up using a fork and knife on the burger to avoid getting yolk all over our hands and mouths!Service: Superb service again even with a pretty full house. Our server (Kat?) was great, checking up on our table, making sure we had everything we needed. The management also came by a couple times to make sure our meal was to our liking.Atmosphere: Great place, in the day time it changed to a bustling lunch spot for business people grabbing lunch. Although bustling and crowded, it still felt comfortable.Value: Good value for the lunch menu in the area. Burger came in at $14 plus $1 for the egg, Mac 'n Cheese full order was $13. Might seem a bit high for some people but the execution and quality of ingredients (plus the service) warrant the price.Overall: Second visit on this trip and enjoyed it again!

Located across the Federal Plaza (walking distance from the Willis Tower), the Marq was pretty busy with office people on a cold Friday afternoon. Nevertheless, the service was friendly and fast. I was dying to get the recommended Salmon BLT, but unfortunately they were out of it (it was around 1 pm). So I ordered The Intern (sirloin on wheat bread with roasted peppers and mushrooms, caramelized onions, and chimichurri with fries) and pea soup instead. The Intern was very tasty and filling, but the fries were too salty for my taste. The pea soup was meh, it was good to warm me up on a cold day but not good enough for me to reorder. Since I was on vacation, I also ordered a drink - From Rio to Goa - boy was it strong! It wasn't bad, just a lot stronger than I anticipated. My server, Migee, was super awesome and adjusted my total even though I returned the drink.The Marq has a modern comfortable look to it and I absolutely loved the credit card holders (pictured).I would definitely come back to try it out for a happy hour whenever I'm in Chicago again!

Went here on my last day of the trimester at DePaul as a gift to myself. Once you walk up they do have seating outside but I chose to sit inside cause it was hot outside.I said at a table and was greeted by a wonderful, sweet woman named Shannon. I ordered lagunitas and the Executive to start off. The manager came over and talked to me about different kinds of IPAs beer they carry and he recommended one for me so I figured I would give it a try. Muncipal IPA. (Very similar to Lagunitas but a less bitter)The Executive sirloin steak was cooked to a perfect medium and had this very distinct chimichurri sauce. Wonderful. I tried different soups after this the Chef's Soup and the Green Pea Soup. The Chef's Soup I can't remember the name was boiled in pork and bones and had all different kinds of vegetables.Overall 5 out of 5 stars. Excellent food and service.

My fiancee's cousin from Hong Kong was here for a conference, and we wanted to take her out to dinner somewhere in the loop. We really enjoyed the Marq, it has a pretty casual vibe but the food was pretty high quality. We liked the honey ricotta appetizer, and the pumpkin risotto was amazing, not too heavy and very flavorful. The service was efficient and polite. I will definitely be back if I need a place to bring someone from out of town.

Loved my Salmon Poke! Sooooo tasty and fresh!  Marinated Faroe island salmon, cucumbers, jalapenos, avocado, fish sauce, mint, cilantro, toasted sesame seeds, served with crisps.Staff was friendly, will definitely come back to take advantage of the patio area on a day that I am not busy at work!

It was pretty quiet for a Friday night, but the service was great and so was the food. I had the Marq burger with bacon and a fried egg. It's a little messy, but delicious! My husband had the pasta dish and thought it was good. For appetizers we had the fried pickles and chilaquiles. Both had good flavor and the sauce for the fried pickles was great.Nice decor and close proximity to downtown hotels. Servers were attentive and food did not take long to come to the table. I'd recommend the Marq if you're looking for a place that will have a little something for everyone, is reasonably priced (about $15-$20 per entree), and has a casual (but not chain casual) atmosphere.

We found this awesome place on Yelp after looking through 30 or so restaurants to meet and satisfy 5 friends with different tastes, budgets and hunger levels.Upon walking in (had reservations) we were seated quickly.
