And then I got stuffed. So if you are still hungry after two tacos, maybe get another taco instead of downing a whole thing of mac and cheese. But I would eat it again! Ha.Now here's the thing: our server was super friendly. But when we ask to get some recs or if we haven't been to the restaurant, I don't think it's necessary to explain literally every single thing on the menu, including all the different cocktails. And that's what happened. Took a while. And I do appreciate the passion. But it was overboard and long. The kicker? When we said we didn't want drinks, she brought out the draft list because she forgot and "just in case." That was unnecessary. We also hadn't even finished dinner and she started telling us all about dessert. It sounded great, but we hadn't finished our meals! Eh, not a fan of that.I enjoyed the vibe and the decor and it's in a great part of Logan Square, my hood. I know I will be back. I will try some other stuff on the menu when I do. And I will buy a drink next time too. And dessert. :)

Great nachos, tacos - a fusion of Mexican and southern flavored - and desserts.  We had to try each flavor of pie: lemon, oatmeal pecan, and chocolate mousse.  All three were good, the lemon and mousse especially so.  Enjoyed the cocktails as well.Very friendly and helpful staff.  A nice vibe all the way around.

Went here last weekend in a group of six. We made a reservation on OpenTable, which was easy and convenient, for 7:30 on a Saturday. The cocktails were pretty good and probably the best part of The General. We started with the chips and guac and it was pretty ok. Nothing special but decent. The chips were light and crunchy, which was nice. When the tacos came out we were excited but biting into them was quite a disappointment. No flavor, soggy texture (catfish), not worth the calories in my book. Since I didn't want to waste my cals on the tacos, I asked for more chips for the guac (large portion of guac, which was nice) and they sadly never came. The group also had orders of mac n' cheese and jalapeno corn bread. The mac n' cheese tasted similar to water noodles, extremely lacking in flavor. The cornbread was meh, maybe the best food item I ate though. It could have definitely used something else.On the plus side, the ambiance of the place was nice and welcoming, the servers were nice and relatively attentive (besides the chips).I'm sad that it was so blah for me as I was really looking forward to loving it.
Seriously just about perfect. Great tacos. Especially the brisket. Guac, chips and Mac and cheese all delicious. And the cocktails divine. Price is perfect and pie delicious. Nothing we didn't love

Amazing food and experience!  We kept driving by, and finally decided to stop in for dinner.  Our server, Lauren M., was incredible!  She walked us through the menu which is full of unique tacos and a huge craft beer selection.  Everything we ate was phenomenal!  We got guacamole and chips (I swear it felt like the bucket was never-ending), a Mac & Cheese with brisket (SO good), and 4 tacos that my husband and I split.  Each one was better than the next!  We'll definitely be back!
nice vibe, laid back,  amazing cornbread and super cool employees!! im not a bar person but if i was a younger logan square-ite, i could see this being one my hangs. check it out...

This place is trying to be too many things and doesn't seems to have done one thing particularly well. I have lived in Logan Square for many years and so I have been waiting to try this place. The general store doesn't work at all. It is not obvious that any of the wine or supposed produce is for sale. If you see an empty carton of eggs and want to buy some you have to ask staff and they will run downstairs to get it for you which is not convenient. Does anyone remember Service Merchandise?? Exactly, obsolete!Also, the farm to table taqueria is somewhat unique but farm to table is now Everywhere. We arrived and the restaurant was only a quarter filled so plenty of space and definitely a fun space for drinks. However, you can sit anywhere but the tables were not assigned to the waitstaff so it took like 5 minutes or so for them to determine who would serve our table. I have waited on tables in larger venues and you need to be assigned a section or you will have tables everywhere and Running all night which provides poor service! The waitress was very nice and understood the menu but it took the two bartenders and bar back/bartender at least 10 minutes or more to poor one specialty drink and one glass of wine. Not sure I want to find out how long it will take three people to  serve drinks on a busy night.Of course, we ordered the guac and chips and it too well over 15 minutes to receive. In fact people that arrived after we did were served more complicated plates sooner than our guacamole and chips. Come on! I can't imagine they would be soooo inefficient with guac and chips.Tacos were okay although the order was mixed up and it was the same at the table next to ours. I ordered fried chicken which if it's a taco I should be able to eat it as such. Otherwise call it an overcooked chicken tender with a gravy that doesn't add any flavor on top of a tortilla which is merely a garnish. The pork shoulder taco was very tasty but was the only one of the bunch. The brisket taco ordered by my friend was not as flavorful as described. Lastly, please don't say this is a taqueria if you don't serve even a small side of beans!! Seriously?! I am Latina and a mixed green salad or Mac and cheese are great but definitely not taqueria worthy. And throwing Jalapeños in everything doesn't change itchy fact.

I came here with the wifey for an afternoon snack and to scope out the  new spot in the Square.  I remember back in the day when we only had a few to check out, now there's a ton of great options; which is great, just not for my wallet!  I tried to order a few beers, but they seemed out of each one I tried to order.  I'll chalk it up to it being the first week.  The beer list was solid and the cocktail list looked interesting.  The wife ordered the Mexican War and enjoyed it.  We sat in the small patio area behind the restaurant.  There seemed to be a lot of employee traffic from the kitchen to the back garbage area.  We shared a few tacos, the catfish, chicken, and pulled pork tacos.  I liked the chicken taco the most, and found the pulled pork taco to have a little too much fat chunks for my liking.  Overall, they were very tasty.  We then followed up the tacos with some chips and the poblano salsa.  The salsa was fresh and delicious, but wasn't as hot as we would like.  The service was super friendly, and attentive.  I think they did a great job with the space, and look forward to giving them more business.

This place needs more work to be part of the Chicago taco craze. The tacos are pricey and lack flavor. They incorporate southern food but this also didn't have the right amount of spices. The "pablana" salsa could've used some salt. The service was okay. Perhaps it will get better as they establish themselves. Until then, two stars it is.

The decor and atmosphere at The General are pleasant. It is a nicely put together quaint dark wood interior that really does well to continue the "general store" theme. The food is just okay though and the prices are too high. For 4.25$ you get one taco that is somewhere between small and medium sized with a side of cabbage. Between me and my friends I tried all the tacos they offered and most were decent but the meat was all very wet, every bite sent a splattering of water all over my plate, overall not a good value. The guacamole we had was pretty good, but be careful, about 1/4 of the guacamole was left but all of our chips were gone, if we wanted to finish it we would have had to pay 3$ extra for more chips.... Most of the beers are probably .50 cents to a dollar more expensive than they should be but they do have a rotating $4 beer in a boot glass that was a very good deal. All in all it is a decent place, cool theme but the tacos are simply not good enough to have me in as a regular customer.

The tequila, lime and aloe vera cocktail is fantastic and I loved the tacos. I thought the helpings were generous and they were more interesting than big star tacos, albeit slightly more expensive. The fried chicken one was especially outstanding. Plenty of seating, good music and friendly staff.
Delicious food at reasonable prices. Service started strong but really went down hill towards the end. Overall I would go again and ask for the check about 20 minutes earlier.
Um I went back and had the chess pie for dessert and it was amazing. I really could have eaten the whole pie. I love chess pie and this was the best one I've ever had!!

Wonderful new Logan Square spot! Farm to table tacos at incredibly affordable prices. They have an awesome deal of a taco of your choice, a shot of bourbon, and a beer (in a boot!) for $8. (The Mudcat taco is my favorite!) They sell beer to go. They have pie. They have beautiful wooden tables and fun chalkboard signs. They have great service. Can't recommend it enough!

I came in tonight for a quick bar experience and found so much more. Johnny at the bar had his hands full, but I didn't feel anything but appreciated. Great skills. Great food. Perfect neighborhood spot for those of us who want more. Thanks Johnny.

Fried. Chicken. Taco. Fantastic! The guacamole is addictive. I also recommend the cocktails which are super refreshing. I had the Mexican War and the Abolitionist. Liked both but the War was more my taste. The scene is chill; great tunes playing in the background but not too loud. Beautiful, rustic decor is charming. Go there. Now.

Was just walking by, but the giant windows opening onto the patio and people sitting at eye level inside seemed inviting--a gentle neighborhood hangout. The place was calling to us so we went in, and the atmosphere was lovely (no blasting music), tables full of friends having conversation. BEST OF ALL, the food! Many veggie sides, smokey black eyed peas and greens. And amazing brisket... A late evening treat.

Not a whole lot to like here...Food:Firstly, tacos are so played out in Chicago.  $4-$5 per taco?  No thanks.  Not when L'Patron is BYOB and the tacos are like $2.50.Drinks:largest beer pour is 12 oz.  and out of the 5-6 times I've been there, the printed menu has never been correct.Let's get one thing perfectly clear--this is not a cocktail bar.  That said, the cocktail menu looks good, but the staff is clueless on cocktail construction and is overall very poorly trained.Atmosphere:I like it, though if you're trying to catch a game, there's one awkwardly placed TV, that's it.  The staff is overall very nice, though one gentleman was pretty rude to me, I tend not to let that get to me too much.Overall:Not sure what they were going for here.  It's like they tried to be several different things and missed the mark on all counts.  If you're a genuine cocktail, beer and taco lover, stay away--The General is a total charlatan.

I really wanted to like The General. When I saw it was opening I was hoping it would help me get over losing the former tenants, Provenance. Sadly, the General came up short.The space is really well done and evokes a sort of Disneyland version of an old timey general store. The cocktails we tried were pretty good, and they have a nice craft beer list. The waitress and staff all seem super nice. Unfortunately it's all downhill from there.The food ranged from OK to mediocre. The chips were thin and crispy but, the guac was a little bland. The salad was nice and fresh, but also a little bland. The chimichanga with shrimp and grits was good, but tiny and cost $8 for one piece cut in half. The tacos were all meh. The catfish taco was salty. The fried chicken taco was bland and dry. The vegan taco tasted like something I've made at home when I was hungover. My bother in law tried the pork and brisket and liked the former. Nothing was offensive or bad, but all of us agreed it wasn't worth having again.What's really egregious is the pricing. The tacos were $4-5 each and small. The three of us paid about $100 with tip for a drink per person, a few shared apps, and two tacos each. That's ridiculous, especially in Logan Square were there are dozens of great mom and pop places that make way better Mexican food.  I get that that organic and "farm-to-table" ingredients are not cheap, but again, there are so many of those places in Logan Square as well. And if you get the itch for fancy, organic, farm to table artisanal tacos, just go to Wicker Park.

My boyfriend and I stopped by a few days ago for drinks. We loved the ambience - they did a really nice job with the interior and had great music playing (Johnny Cash). I had the Abolitionist followed by the Mexican War. My boyfriend had the Blackjack (x 2). They were all very tasty. We also ordered some jalapeño cornbread to munch on. It was moist and rich but a small portion when split between the two of us. A little bit pricey overall but with such a great vibe and yummy drinks, we will be back!
Came here for brunch.  I liked the space and the service was great.  Good deal on bloody marys!  The food is not really on par with other brunch spots in the neighborhood, but not bad...

Great neighborhood "go to" when my significant other want to grab a quick bite to eat and don't want to break the bank.  The $8 taco, beer and shot of bourbon special can't be beat!  That with a mixed green salad and an order of guacamole, is enough for a decent meal for two. You get a very nice amount of guacamole, unlike most places where you get a ton of chips and a small amount of guac.  I've only tried a couple of the tacos, but what I've had are all very good.  My favorite is the no bones about it, veggie/vegan taco.  I've tried their BlackJack mixed cocktail and it is very nice.  A good mix of flavors and not too sweet.

The best word to describe this place is Cute.  The mini Das Boot is cute. The decor is cute. The waiters are cute (hey ;)). And unfortunately the food is cute. I don't want a cute taco. I want a delicious taco stuffed full of ingredients. Not a brisket taco with half a piece of brisket on it. I also don't want a cute plate of mac and cheese. This is bbq/mexican/soul food none of those food styles are cute! For the price ($18 for 2 tacos and a mac and cheese) this food leaves much to be desired. I plan to try this place again in the near future. Hopefully they will take heed to many of the awesome reviews below me and their helpful advice. If not, I will just go back for the cute atmosphere.... and waiter ;)
Food was delicious especially the pork belly mac and cheese.  Good beer list with a lot of local choices.  Staff was very attentive and friendly.  Will definitely return.

The beer can chicken taco and the fried chicken taco were fantastic! I love the bourbon and beer lists so I did not try one of the signature cocktails. The staff was friendly and professional and the place looks great. I am looking forward to trying more menu items and seeing what the will carry in the general store.

Went in to the General with a girlfriend for some food and drinks. Service was awesome - attentive, friendly, appropriate recommendations. We loved our food, namely the mac and cheese, fish taco, and greens. We found the spot comfortable and inviting. We were also impressed by the fact that there is a changing table in the bathroom :)

They only sell tacos and side dishes. The sides were good (Mac and cheese and cornbread), but the tacos were terrible. They were very bland and overpriced. The server was very good- knowledgeable, attentive, and kind.

With the passing of Provence, The General Restaurant & Mercantile took up residence  in the former.  Gone are the bottles and jars of fine delectables but happily replaced by high end tacos and cocktails.Logan Square and Chicago have been leading the way with the reawakenedMexican fusion food scene and The General spins the scene a little more.  Southern soul food mixed with traditional taco guidelines to create some innovative and tasty foods. Similar to Spanish tapas, The General's menu is meant to be sampled with sides causally amongst friends over a drinks.FoodThe Vegan Taco - is the hidden gem of the taco offerings.  It is flavorful and hearty without feeling like you have missed out on something.Shrimp and Grits Chimichanga with the Black Bean dipping sauce is delicious and the polenta like texture of the grits adds smoothness to offset the crunch.  The dipping sauce adds a little sweetness from the black beans.  Great little appetizer to start.DrinksThe beer list is manageable with the bar staff being attentive to questions.  The cocktails like the Abolitionist are strong but balanced, plus eating the edible flower is a fun twist.  The drink special is a boot of the day, which adds a little something extra to the traditional drink special.DecorThe decor is a throw back to the retro prohibition days and the tin ceiling and re-purposed tables add to the overall theme.  The TVs in each area are needed as Chicago is a sports crazed.OverallA nice addition to the taco scene in Logan Square with solid choices.  This is not the place for tex-mex or traditional Mexican foods.  Instead, the southern twist is new welcome addition to the scene.

My family loves the general.  The servers and bartenders are friendly, knowledgeable, and nice.  They are always friendly with our young children and even the dogs (out front).  I love that you can buy some grocery staples and booze from the general store area.  We eat here all the time and will continue to do so.

The service is great and the food is AMAZING! We came for the Bluegrass brunch and the live music was as good as the food! The cinnamon rolls are warm and delicious and the chicken mac and cheese is creamy and well seasoned. My new favorite Sunday brunch spot!

I stopped in here last week and I think it was their 1st day open. Room looks nice. I did not have any food but what I saw people eating look very good. We sat at the bar and the bartender was very nice but the cocktails where not good!! We tried 6 of them between 3 of us and all of them were way to sweet and the main spirit was no where to be found in any of them. For $10 for each of them I would expect better. We all left because our stomach hurt from all the sugar in the cocktails. We might go back and try the food but cocktail program has allot of work needed to make them appealing. Beers look like any other Logan Square bar...

The staff was very friendly but it took forever to get our first drink and a side of chips and guacamole! Come on, do they make the chips fresh for each order? Most likely not since ours tasted a bit stale. I had the bourbon beef taco and fried chicken taco. Absolutely no flavor in either expect for the spice gravy on chicken. A chicken tender with gravy in a tortilla is not a good combo. I eventually separated the two. On its own, the tortilla was good. Chicken was dry and I even choked on it. My friend had the pork shoulder taco. That was tasty. I'd recommend that one. The only reason I would return here would be if I were stop in for a drink.

This place is really excellent! I went by after a super long day at work and the vibe was really fun and energizing!! I love the BBQ/Mexican hybrid concept. Such a cool idea! Why has no one else thought of that?! Also I am a tortilla chip snob and theirs were delicious and clearly homemade. The mac & cheese was amazing and the beer can chicken taco was my fav. Definitely going back!! So glad to have this in the neighborhood!

Delicious food and great atmosphere, a super fun place to hang out! The handmade guac is to die for and I highly recommend the mac and cheese with pork belly added, as well as any of the tacos. Whether you're in the mood for a few drinks and apps or a big meal, the General is definitely worth checking out.
We popped in to see what the new spot was all about and was blown away by their tacos and curated beer list. I hear they have a great outdoor space too so I can't wait to go back and check that out.

Omg, so yummy! The guac was TDF (to die for) and the Mac and cheese will continue to make me crave it daily since I went.  They also nailed the beer list and the service was great. I love the old saloon feel of the place and it has the feel of being cozy for winter but airy for summer. I'll definitely be back! I look forward to their new menu items and their evolution as a business.

We were pretty unimpressed. Totally lackluster  service and very small portions (for the tacos), even considering the recent opening. I might try again for a drink but it seems better in theory than in practice. Also no hot sauce! At all! For a taco place!

Was so good! Ordered chips and guac was surprised at the portion- huge! Also loved the beer and taco special. Served the beer in a boot! Also sampled the salad. It was super fresh and yummy. We sat near the kitchen and watched them make and roll fresh tacos.

I'm trying to put my finger on why I like this place so much--a lot of it is the lack of pretension that others have noted. It seems like there are a lot of new places in this neighborhood that put an emphasis on looking cool with retro items that aren't really functional or in some cases comfortable, while others can't seem to contain a sense of moral superiority about their menus (I was once told I couldn't have decaf at Bang Bang Pie Shop because the owner didn't believe in selling inferior products--it only went downhill from there.) In most cases comfort seems to be afterthought. This place is such a refreshing change--especially the design of it--even little things, like that the way the front patio seats face the street so customers are integrated with it rather than being fenced off. Same with the inside. The tables are just far enough that you have privacy and the music is good but not oppressively loud. Maybe it's the Southern hospitality thing. Who knows. I'm just really glad they are here.

was so good. the tacos...they were all incredibly well balanced in terms of texture and flavors. i really couldn't pick a favorite but...veggie and fish are my thing. the tortilla chips are bubbly and have this texture where the surface feels a bit soft and grainy, yet they're all crunch. the cocktails are unique and delicious. get a couple of boot beers to boot!

Came by right before 6pm Tuesday evening #tacotuesdays. The patio with picnic tables was very inviting and there was a nice diverse crowd when we arrived. The staff was very friendly and helpful as my friend and I weren't sure on how things worked there. We ordered in line and then sat ourselves with a table number.We got chips and guacamole, shrimp tacos, ribeye tacos, and the chicken tacos. Some people are bothered by not being able to order the tacos as a single item as they come in two, but if you are going with others, then it should be no problem in swapping and sharing, so this wasn't a big deal for me, as I essentially got to try 3 different tacos.The guacamole was fresh and tasty. The slices of radish seasoned in tajin were a nice touch. I enjoyed all the tacos, but the shrimp one was best for me as the fried kale really elevated the taco. My friend also enjoyed her horchata, as it wasn't overly sweet.Overall, we only waited about 10 minutes for our food to arrive and our server was very nice. We snagged a bottle of hot sauce from a nearby table and this was tasty. Tacos weren't too small or too big and prices were maybe a touch steep, but not too bad, especially as the food was good. This is a great casual place for friends to catch up or for families or just somewhere to grab a bite. If you want authentic tacos, then go down the street, but I welcome something new and different in the neighborhood, and now I don't have to go all the way to WP!

I live right around the corner from this place and was happy to see something new come into town. So, when they finally opened me and my mom visited A.T. to see what they had to offer. We ordered the garlic shrimp taco and sweet & spicy chicken taco. While we waited we got some of their famous drinks. As one commenter stated, the drinks have way too much ice which seems to water them down and becomes a waste of money. The owners wife came over and I had a chance to chat with her about Antique Taco. She was very nice! However, I have to be honest about my review. I have come here and tried other things off the menu as well. Here is a list and my ratings:Garlic Shrimp Taco: Was the best thing on the menu until they changed the recipe! The first time I went I loved it, just went recently and it was ...Yuck! Especially if you're expecting to taste it the original way that you had it and you bite into something else. I was starving one day and had a taste for it and was thoroughly disappointed. Why in the hell did they change the recipe?..I will never know.Sweet & Spicy Chicken Taco: Greasy for some reason..not the best but not the worst either.Creamed Elote: Horrible! I've had authentic Elote from a street vendor which was delicioso this was a no, no! I didn't even finish it.Horchata: Eh ok.Guacamole & Chips: Good. If you messed up on this simple dish then you would need to go out of business.Fish Taco: It's ok but Definitely missing something like other people have stated. What? I don't know yet.Some other things that disspoints about this place is everytime I have a taco it's cold. After waiting so long your food is not fresh and hot. As much money as you spend in that place cold food should be the least of your worries. Lastly their system seems to be unorganized or something. I can not understand why people have to wait so long for their meal. Someone doesn't know what they are doing or they don't have enough manpower in place to produce the food faster.All in all, hopefully Antique Taco will take some of their Yelpers advice because it's nice to see a new spot off of 35th instead of all the way on 31st. We need more places over this way to frequent.

I placed a to go order for the fish tacos and the ribeye tacos along with the chili cheese curds and the horchata milkshake. I sipped on the shake will I waited. Let's start with the shake. What a genius idea to take two very delicious items and bring them together! Wow! It was rich and very tasty!I waited for about 10min for the order. The fish tacos were crispy and flavorful. The ribeye tacos were tender and full of flavor. The chili cheese curds were everything! Any one of these items on their own would surpass your expectations. I can't wait to come back!

Well.. Where do I start..1. 50 min wait to just order... Why? Because they had ONE register open.. Mind you, this was opening week.. And Friday night..2. They have a bar with just beer and pre-made margaritas ..with ONE "bartender" again... On opening week..3. 50 min for tacos to come out.. FIFTY MINUTES!4. Tacos come in twos.. And expensive ..$8? Really. It's TACOS!5. Decently tacos... Tasty.. The steak was a bit tough.. But well seasoned. Pork was tangy and delicious. Shrimp were good, but you only get 3 shrimp for. $4 taco.. COME ON!5. I'm Mexican and love tacos... They had NOT one Mexican cook. Bunch of young hipsters cookin up some meet and tossing it on a tortilla with a random ingredient and calling it "gourmet"Overall I give it a BIG FAT MEH!

This place is new in my neighborhood. I've been waiting for a few days to try it since its grand opening. The line out the door has deterred me from doing it any sooner, but it has also got me very curious.So, on a Sunday night after a late lunch, my husband and I decided to go at 9pm. Lo and behold, no line at all. The service was friendly, but our food came super slow, it took about 35 minutes.We ordered:$7 Crispy fish - very good$8 Grilled ribeye - very good$7 Carnitas- good$7 Guac and chips - average$7 Rum horchata - yummy but small$5 Pils draft beer - okayThe tacos come in twos, and we didn't know. At first, I was sticker shocked when I saw the menu, and I thought to myself, never again. However, when I found out there were two of each, the price was a little more acceptable, but how the heck were we going to finish 6 tacos?!?! We ended up taking two home.In all honesty, the tacos were pretty good, but for like $4 each, I'm not sure they will make it here in Bridgeport. The taco competition here is fierce, and with Pilsen down a few blocks serving $1.50~$2 authentic tacos, I don't know. Knowing that the owner is originally from Bridgeport, I hope he knows what he's up against.

This is more of a 3.5 than a 4 but I'm rounding up because I would actually come back for certain situations.We came here tonight around 9pm and there was hardly a wait. We ordered two super crunch tacos (he didn't like it. I liked the octopus. The meat inside was okay. Reminded me of my own taco nights. Weird surf and turf that doesn't work together.), fish tacos (wasn't a fan of the red onions but he liked the contrast of acidity), pork carnitas tacos (loaded with meat, best flavor, even better when you use the sour cream that comes with the cheese curds), and cheese curds (great sized portion for $8, never been a fan of chili but I actually liked this one).Service was meh. The guy who brought our cheese curds gave us one bowl and fork and left with the extra bowl and fork that he had in his hands. So two people equals one bowl? Then we got our first order of tacos and the girl was going to take away our number stand without asking if we had more food coming (we did). I understand they haven't been open for a while and these are little kinks so I'm willing to look over them.Since I live in the area, I would probably come back for the pork tacos or maybe the ribeye since I liked it when I was at the other location. Such a better "late night" spot. Plus I could see that the tortillas were being made by hand! Love that.

This place interior isn't that big, but the patio outside does add more seats making it decently spaced out. Considering it first open the line was long and the wait to get our food even longer.. stood in like maybe just 20 min and the wait for our food was nearly 50 mins.I'd say give it about 3 weeks if you want to try it but don't have a lot of time or patience. It'll probably doe down. The food is decently priced for what you get. I mainly enjoyed the enchiladas and the shrimp tacos. They were the best out of everything I got.But give it a couple of weeks for the place to settle I don't think it's worth it at the moment.
Finally stopped in and am glad that I did. Had two sweet and spicy chicken tacos and the chips and guacamole.Food is fantastic!

Horchata: A for taste, B- for portion sizeDelicious, but came in a small cup with WAAAY too much ice. Maybe ask for less ice so that your drink lasts you more than 5 minutes.Fish taco: A+Probably the best fish taco I've ever had. It's a piece of fried fish fillet, not grilled. The sauce on it has amazing flavor and there's a very nice range of textures in the taco.Pork carnitas: BIt's not bad, but I've had better. Could also be because I ate this after the AMAZING fish taco, so nothing could really compare.Rosemary margarita: A for taste, B for portion sizeAgain, so delicious but came in a teeny tiny cup. Hard to taste the rosemary, but overall a darn good marg.

Welcome to the south side, we've been waiting for you :) this place just opened up. Simple good quality tacos and extras, this place is rockin', behind the counter and on the dog friendly patio. Tonight's music was a varied selection of Motown tunes that had some people singing along.Not a huge menu, but it doesn't need one.  Fish, shrimp, rib eye, etc tacos. Great sides, my favorite is the elotes.Your food will  not come up fast, after all this ain't no Taco Bell. Good Motown tunes on tonight.Parking is a plus too!

I brought my boyfriend here because told him "I once had the best fish taco of my life at a street festival from Antique Taco so we should go to the restaurant".I ordered two of the fish tacos and one of the 'on special' pork jowl tacos.The fish was cooked very well on the taco but there was a cabbage slaw on top. The slaw was expected, but it tasted like someone had accidentally dropped a cup of liquid smoke into it when the recipe called for a drop. It prevented anything else from being tasted so I had to scrape it off to be able to eat these tacos. The smell was so strong that I was having liquid smoke burps up to 12 hrs later. This was nothing like the taco I had from the antique taco street vendor a few years ago.Fish taco issue was excusable. What came in the pork jowl taco was not. After taking a bite I noticed a weird texture in my mouth. I swallowed, set the taco down, inspected it for a second, and found a 1" by 2" piece of pork jowl WITH ABOUT 40 OF THE PIG'S SPIKEY BLACK CHIN HAIRS (~8mm/ea) STILL GROWING OUT OF THE PIECE OF JOWL. I almost vommed. Did they forget to shave/skin the pig before they butchered it?I told the waitstaff and she took the taco off the bill, thank sweet baby Jesus, but I was so grossed out that I don't think I can go there again. I would have expected the entire bill be comped for this grievous offense. The server gal said the manager was coming out but she never did, so we left.

Yeah, I'm not feeling it.  I'm very glad that there is a trendy restaurant on this formerly desolate corner, but this is easily the worst taco place in an area of the city with A LOT of very good taco places.  It didn't help that they charge $8 for 2 tacos, regardless of whether they're made with steak or potatoes (WTF?).  It didn't help that our chili cheese curds contained zero chili, just curds and garnish.  It certainly didn't help that it took them more than 15 minutes to prepare my order at a time when there was zero line, because the kitchen staff was standing around chit-chatting.  Finally, while I'm no slave to tradition, it is a pet peeve of mine when traditional names are used to describe an extremely inauthentic preparation.  Cook the dish any way you want, but call it something else.So good luck to Antique Taco.  I hope they continue to enjoy a steady stream of hipster customers willing to overpay for a sub-standard product, if only to keep this corner of Bridgeport lively and bustling.  You can find me a few blocks away at San Jose eating REAL al pastor etc. with twice the flavor for half the price.

We had been anxiously waiting for the opening of this place. We came by on Tuesday, but were too early.  It hadn't opened yet and once it did, the line was out the door. We were finally able to make it tonight after a softball game, and only waited about 10 minutes. The place was packed at 9pm but we were able to find a picnic table outside. The ribeye tacos, carnitas tacos, corn and guacamole were delicious! The order taker and servers were really nice and the prices were reasonable. They have a liquor license too, big plus!  I've found my new favorite place, and only a couple blocks from my home.

While $7/8 for two tacos may seem steep, I can at least say they're big and good. It's also a change of pace from the other Mexican restaurants in the area. The line was long yes, but then again it's new and there was a lot of anticipation, plus it was 7pm on a Friday so we knew to expect it. They have a bar too with some good beer, especially 5 Rabbits from the SW side. I had the pork carnitas tacos, plus chips n guac and mango orange juice. All very good. I would definitely like to come back at one point and try some more of the tacos and the horchata. Not an everyday place but good to have once in a while.

Wow. Delicious, beautiful food. The carnitas tacos were smoky, heavenly treats. And the poblano and potato tacos were even better. The quest on top of those tacos blew my mind. Chips & guacamole arecreamy, salty, limey, crunchy goodness.The coconut margarita was subtlety sweet, strong but simple. I am still dreaming of it. Get. It.Don't skimp, splurge! Love love... Coming back tomorrow.(I did ask for the house hot sauce that was on other tables, and it wasn't delivered to us at all during our meal, but I don't want that to detract from my review or experience- it's more about giving feedback to a great establishment to help make it even better! So well done!)

I came here with some friends for dinner on opening week and the line was long, as expected. We stood in line for about 45 minutes and then waited for our food on the patio for about 45 minutes. Luckily, the weather and music were good. I had the coconut margarita while we waited, which was alright. My bf and I shared the garlic shrimp, crispy fish, grilled ribeye and pork carnitas tacos (in the order of most to least favorite). Yes, we both had 4 tacos each. We ordered waaay too much food. I should have known better since I've been to the original spot a few times. I'd recommend 3 tacos per person or 2 tacos and a shared appetizer. Unfortunately, they were already sold out of the super crunchy taco, so I'll have to come back for that. I like the atmosphere and the food here, so hopefully the lines and wait are not as bad next time.

I've been to their north side location and preferred the atmosphere and set up there. While the food was excellent it doesn't have the same vibe as the other one. This location doesn't have a personality.  Really small parking lot.

Recently opened. Slow service, even for to-go. Team is friendly, young and local. Not much hustle going on here, team looks like they are still learning. Good food.Update: they had an issue with the ticket printer and my order got lost. Manager was really sweet and refunded most of our order. 5 stars for good response and honest answer.

Lived up to all the hype.  Be wary though - it get packed QUICK!  We got there at 5:15pmish and within another 15 minutes the inside was packed (it was raining out, so couldn't do the patio).Had the:- super crunchy taco- carnitas tacos- sweet & spicy chicken tacos- garlic shrimp tacosIf this wasn't my last night living in Chicago, I would become a regular at this place. At least it was a great last meal in Bridgeport!
Great food and atmosphere on the patio on a summer's eve.  Very excited they're open for lunch now too!  With alcohol things get real pricey quick, but the rosemary margarita might just be worth it.

The food was decent not worth the price service was ok we walked in & weren't greeted by anyone the cashier just looked at us the drinks are overpriced no utensils we have had much better definitely won't be back

Let's give a happy 4 star rating to Antique Taco because they are great neighborhood business in the Bridgeport community. We went to their " Shake, Rattle and Roll" free event to celebrate their arrival here in the Bridgeport area. They gave everybody a treat of ice-cream or a horchata milk shake and free smiley booth photos! We had a blast. Of course, we had to also order some tacos! Why not we were in there. I ordered their rib eye tacos for $8 you get two sizable tacos full of juicy rib eye beef topped with some micro-greens i think arugula and some onions and fresco. It was really good tacos I loved their freebies as well the Horchata milk shake is what dreams are made of! It had the delicious rice cinnamon sweetness with the thickness of a milk shake the combination is dreamy. Let me say I can't wait to walk down here to try some of their margarita's next time it looks like a great place to get a quick fun date night and it's just down the street from house, it's another bonus.We dined in their outdoor patio. It was a rainy day but it was warm out so we just stuck with outdoor dining.  It has a fabulous dining hipster vibe type of atmosphere. Totally welcoming to children of all ages and the staff is so sweet and kind. We hope this place works out brings a lot of people into the Bridgeport area and see what Bridgeport has to offer!

I'm a city worker that eats lunch at new restaurants all over the city all the time and this was definitely the most disappointing experience I've had in several years.The woman taking orders at the counter was cold, bordering on rude. They are incredibly unaccomodating, and wouldn't allow two people in my group to order their meals the way they wanted them.They also only allow you to order pairs of tacos, which is just needlessly stupid. Let me order two separate tacos, don't force me to order two of the same. I would have loved to have ordered three different tacos and tried them all, and perhaps if I had been allowed to order what I wanted I wouldn't have been so disappointed.I ended up getting the fish tacos and they were bad, definitely the worst I've had. The cabbage slaw had a pleasant smokiness but the fish itself was bland and slightly undercooked and the entire package was just underwhelming and disappointing. I was shocked that it was so bad.I ate with a group of four guys and only one of us was satisfied with their meal. I will never go back  -there are tons of great restaurants in the Bridgeport/McKinley area and this isn't one of them. It's all style and no substance.

1 star for drinks, omg none are good except for beer. House Rosemary Margarita sounds good but it's not(also disregard the Rosemary part because they just literally put a piece of rosemary in it and call it so), prickly pear margarita even worse, don't know where to start with the mango/orange Vodka so don't bother.  2 stars for food, grilled steak taco tastes super salty(my hubby likes salt and he even said its salty), Spicy shrimp and mushroom tacos, ok. 3rd star(4 stars) for service which is the only thing they got right. Mgmt of Antique Taco, pls change your $ to $$. 3 adults and a child, we paid $150 and not happy. :(
Great service, cool space, great food.The shrimp tacos are the best. Their house salad is so satisfying and delicious.Love the expanded menu and huge patio.

Artisan tacos made by hipsters. If I had to describe this place in one word. Antique Taco goes for quality over quantity for your price, which is what you should expect. Their menu is sparse, but still has variety. Every item is small but loaded with ingredients. Lastly, everything is delicious, but overpriced. With every good thing you find, there is something not as good. Like many people say, it's definitely not an every day kind of thing, and if it was cheaper I'd go there more, but it is definitely a once in a whole kind of place.

The only thing I wish you could do is order tacos separately. Otherwise dope spot in Bport! Love the mushroom tacos, potato and poblano tacos, horchata milk shake, and habenero hot sauce! Also love the huge outdoor patio with picnic tables! Great chill summer spot

Unacceptable wait time 1hr+ for order and food. Maybe give this place a few weeks and let the hype die down. The outdoor patio is spacious but the interior is small. Pricy 2 tacos for $8 and drinks are small $8.Fish and shrimp tacos are a must!!

Hipster  tacos made with fresh ingredients. Crispy fish taco and the shrimp taco are my favorite by far. So fresh and flavorful!! Everything is cooked just right. The crunchy octopus taco just tasted like a beef taco. I wished it was just octopus without the beef.I love the fun drink selections here all served in fun mason jars. This location has a big outdoor seating area good for a big group. My only reservation is that the food takes a very long time to prepare. We waited over an hour on s not so busy day. It's fine on a nice day with a group of friends to hang with but might not be an ideal place to eat if you're pressed for time.

I've been to Antique Taco at least half a dozen times since they opened in Bridgeport six weeks ago, it is that good!  All the tacos are outstanding as well as the Chorizo Chili, Smokey Chicken Enchiladas and the guacamole.  The drinks are refreshing, especially the house margaritas.  The prickly pear margarita is an adult version of a slushy and really hits the spot after a long week or on a hot day!The service is fast and the food gets to your table quickly.  Sometimes reorders can be a little slow but only for food not so much for drinks.They don't have a full dessert menu yet; which is a shame so we just usually have an extra margarita for dessert.  :)

Overall an underwhelming experience.  But I did go on their first night of being open.  Wait to order was long and even longer to get food.  Not surprising that the food came out like warm.  The wife and I tried 4 different tacos and the elote. The pork carnitas was ok nothing spectacular. The grilled rib eye I felt was under seasoned and overcooked. The sweet and spicy chicken was up next and did not disappoint.  This taco was full of vibrant flavors that meshed very well.  Next up was the potato and poblano. I felt this was by far the best taco of the four. The elote was a very interesting spin of what I've had on the street. Very rich and tasty.  I will be back when the fervor calms. The poor staff was definitely overwhelmed with the volume. I'm sure this contributed to a subpar experience.

I checked this place out last night.I got there at 7:30 and didn't get my food until 9:00... Maybe 9:10. And it wasn't overly crowded at all. To make matters worse, there's no compensatory chips and salsa... Or even water. You have to pay for that.Despite the agonizingly long wait, the tacos were amazing. I specifically recommend the garlic shrimp tacos.
Top shelf!     Really glad to have AT in the neighborhood.    Super fresh stuff and great flavors.    I'm here once or twice a week.
Order to go was wrong and when I called to complain, no apology or reciprocation. Price too high and meat was fatty. Won't be back.

I went with a friend on Saturday of opening weekend. The food line was long, but moved quickly. We ordered the garlic shrimp tacos and chili cheese curds. It took a while for the food to come, but likely due to opening weekend kinks. Both dishes were flavorful and portion sizes were fairly generous. Each taco had 3-4 shrimp and I had a hard time closing the tortilla. Drinks were ordered at a separate counter/outside window.  The lavender paloma was refreshing and the lavender flavor wasn't overpowering. My friend's coconut margarita was made with real coconut.The old radios and vintage signs contributed to the "antique" feel of the space. Oldies were playing over the speakers.
TASTY. The tacos are super good but I LOVE the kale salad. Everything is super fresh! I wish we had this place close to home, I would eat here all the time.
One of my faves.  Im so glad they opened a location in Bridgeport.   Best fish tacos in the city....in my opinion.

Not only did I have to wait an outrageous amount of time but the food was only average at best and way over priced. I had the horchata milkshake as well. I normally love horchata but I couldn't even finish this it just tasted like chalk and was incredibly small for the $5 price tag. I'm so sad. I love tacos and wanted this place to be good.

Had the Al Pastor Taco (had pineapple in it - was able to order single) along with the Rib Eye Tacos (had to order in pairs) and both were great! I wish they had better salsas though. They were just ok. I do look forward to heading back here vs Carbon any day! Great summer chill spot with huge outdoor benches!

July 6th, 2016:So I was going to stop by the antique taco that opened today.... Hour long waitJuly 13th, 2016:Hmm I'm going to hang at the house for a little bit longer, then head to antique taco, they open at 5FinnnnallyIt only took a 45 minute wait to get theseWtf, you're telling me I paid $18 including tip for tacos??I'm sitting at the bar, there's a couple with a toddler, the mother's face looks like she regrets having the child, the father is trying to entertain him so he doesn't start screamingI didn't realize it was $18, I wanted less tacos
Awesome potato and poblano taco. For appetizers the chili cheese curds are a must try. Outdoor patio is super cute and great for summer nights. I will definitely be back.

I'm really glad they're in the neighborhood, and I'll probably be back - the drinks were great, and pretty cheap compared to the competition ($8 for a craft cocktail isn't bad) but the tacos were just ok and too expensive ($7 for 2).Biggest pet peeve, for me, is that when you pay with a credit card, the pre-set tipping options start at 15%.  Which seems way too high for counter service and no wait staff. Yes, they bring your food to your table, but, that seemed mostly because there's nowhere to stand and wait for it.On a $100 bill - which doesn't take too long to achieve, given $3.50 tacos and $8 drinks - you're tipping $15 for the privilege of standing in line to order your food...also, there were no bike racks, which, really? in bridgeport, serving hipster tacos and you can't spring for a few bike racks?
I expected to wait in line but having only one register is a huge design flaw. In 45 minutes they had only checked out six people. Not acceptable.

The food was great. I got  the potato poblano tacos, which were really good--- I am not a vegetarian and didnt miss the meat and the guac was really good too, next time I know to ask for extra pickled radishes. The bar drinks were good too just pricey and tiny  but packed a punch. All in all great, the inside is pretty small but they have outdoor seating also. I gave 4 stars because the prices are a little high.

Love, love, love this place! It is their second location and they are continuing with their great food and atmosphere in Bridgeport! The food is made fresh when you order which is well worth the wait. It comes out fairly quickly, seasoned greatly, and perfectly portioned. I am the biggest fan of the chili cheese curds and the fish tacos. I actually tried the mushroom fajita today and I was not disappointed!Their choice of music is fantastic! I could sit there for hours sipping on their famous margaritas and listening to the golden oldies! If you are in the area you should definitely stop by. I know I will!

I arrived here last night on a Friday, at 10:17 to find they close at 10pm. In Bridgeport you don't close at 10pm, the White sox game was still going.There were other people arriving to find that they have closed. Other establishments are open but this is too early,especially on a beautiful summer night

First time here, my boyfriend and I arrived at 5:30 and there was already a decent amount of people there. We waited about 10 minutes to put are order in.. The music was a little too loud and it was hard to hear the young lady on the cashier. We ordered the creamy elote, agua fresca, grilled shrimp tacos, and grilled ribeye tacos. Food took about 10 minutes. The creamy elote was more of a soup consistency but it was delicious. The tacos were very flavorful however my tortillas were cold when they were served which was disappointing because I saw them making them fresh in the back. Overall great environment and flavor.

I've been to Antique Taco several times already since they opened! The wait time has been long at times but the food is worth it. I love the Chicken Enchiladas and my husband loves the Shrimp Tacos. We also love the oldies music in the background. Definitely worth a try.

No authentic Mexican food here. The pork carnitas tasted like pork in bbq sauce on a tortilla. The corn was so smothered in mac n cheese sauce you could barely see, let alone taste the corn. And expensive at about $4 per taco. I'm always thrilled to see a new business in the area and by the amount of people there others do like it but it's definitely not my cup of tea.
Lots of good choices here, and they're not afraid of spices. Get the super crunchy!

They must've ironed the kinks out because we had zero issues. The line was a little long, but once we ordered we had our drinks delivered in minutes and the food not too long after. The shrimp tacos were out of this world good. We also had the chili cheese curds and they were delicious. Great food, service and drinks. So glad this is a part of our hood now.

Not a good place to eat at. I had their smoked chicken enchiladas and their mole sauce taste like tobacco and the smell of it was gross. I rather go to 18th Street in Pilsen where there real mexican food. I wouldn't even give them a star cause the food suck that much.
This place is legit. It gives you the big star vibe and the tacos are much better than big star. The only downside is the only one cashier.. Too slow

The tacos are yummy (a little salty but still enjoyable) and the atmosphere is great. I absolutely love that they opened up in Bridgeport and the use of the space is fantastic. But the times that I have went, service is just always incredibly slow. Until service gets more efficient especially since the line is always so long there, I can't give a 5 star review.

Antique Taco was a revelation amongst the mediocrity that is the local taco joints that surround the Bridgeport neighborhood. If you are looking for your typical mexican taco served with bland rice and beans than do not come here. However if you are looking for something that is elevated and a menu that will provide your palate with new and exciting flavors than this is the place for you. The food here combines some traditional aspects of mexican cuisine with tastes from around the world. I was pretty hungry so I ordered 3 sets of tacos which more than enough. The tortillas are made fresh in house and the ingredients taste like they were just pulled from the farmers market. My favorite taco was the pork carnitas but the fish and ribeye were close seconds. I washed everything down with a rosemary margarita which was probably the best margarita I have had in my life. All in all the whole experience was great and I would defintely recommend going here for a night out.
So happy to see another AT location. Same great classics with some new goodies - SMOKED CHICKEN ENCHILADAS

Although pricier than other neighborhood places for tacos, they were very good.  I ordered the shrimp and my husband ordered the pork carnitas.  The portions were generous -- 3 good-sized shrimp on each taco, so I felt we got our money's worth.  The pork carnitas had too much barbecue sauce for my liking, but I suppose that is a matter of taste, my husband enjoyed them.  It has a fun, large outside seating area, and I'm just so glad to see a thriving business take over that space that has been vacant for so many years.  It will be a regular place for us.

This is one of those places that makes you jealous of the people who work downtown and can actually go here for lunch.  My biggest gripe about this place is that it is closed for dinner and on weekends.This place has a great take on Asian fusion.  I love the bacos here - I've tried the pork, beef, shrimp and tofu.  I particularly like the pineapple salsa that they put on the pork and beef baco - the pork one is my favorite (and it's cheaper than the beef one).  The banh mi sandwiches are pretty decent too.  The surprising star of this restaurant is the chorizo egg roll, which is packed with flavor and goes very well with the avocado aioli.

My husband and I were on vacation and I saw that Saucy Porka was one of the highest rated  places to eat in Chicago. We added this to our list and even though it was a little out of the way from the areas we spent most of our time, it was worth the trip!We headed here on a weekday for an early lunch and at the time we got there we were lucky not to wait very long. The place is pretty small so I could see it getting crowded a little later. The people working at the counter were friendly and explained several of the menu items to us. I decided to order two bacos (pork and steak) and the chorizo egg rolls. My husband ordered one of the rice bowls that included pork, shrimp and Chinese sausage. They had plenty of bottles of Sriracha lying around to increase the spice levels for those who wanted it.My personal favorite was the pork carnitas baco, and I personally loved them being served on a bun. The flavor was different but in a good way. I liked the pineapple with the pork. As people have noted, they are small, but two plus two of the egg rolls was enough for lunch for me. I also liked the egg rolls, but as my husband said they almost had too much meat and not enough of the other stuff (sweet potatoes and other veggies). I did love the avocado aioli that came on the side (I wanted to dip everything in it!). My husband enjoyed his rice bowl and it was a pretty large size for lunch.Saucy Porka is worth a trip for lunch, especially if you are in the mood to try something unique and different!

I was really looking forward to trying this place and it didn't quite live up to my expectations. The miso braised pork bao was too salty and had a barbeque-esque flavor. The asian style paella was pretty good. It had pork, sausage, and chinese sausage. I thought the chinese sausage added a nice flavor to the dish. Not something I would have thought to add but it worked great in this dish! The chorizo egg rolls were decent but it wasn't as flavorful as it sounded. The best dish in my opinion was the curry sweet potato fries. But honestly, it'd be pretty difficult to screw those up!Service was great though! We had a party of 6, and the place is pretty tiny. Right away, they tried to find a table that would fit us and our server was super attentive and informative.

Over the span of a few months, I've visited several times and even converted my parents. If baffles me that I still don't have a review for Saucy Porka.What have I tried? Curry sweet potato fries, chorizo egg roll, saucy pork sandwich, Ho Chi Minh sandwich, and short rib bao. I am not a big fan of the baos, but I almost always repeat the sweet potato fries, chorizo egg roll, and saucy pork sandwich.The sweet potato fries' crispiness is done in perfection. Every time I take a bite, I wonder to myself, "How did they get it to this texture without burning it?!" The spice and curry aioli sauce is also exceptional. The egg roll is packed with queso fresco cheese, sweet potato, red cabbage, onions, and chorizo. To its side is the avocado aioli for dipping. In no way to degrade this egg roll, it fondly reminds me of the chop suey egg rolls that I use to have in my childhood years. The execution and wrap is similar but the ingredients are the major difference. This chorizo egg roll and its queso fresco cheese has me hooked. Last but not least, the namesake saucy pork sandwich has tasty, tender pork carnitas topped with kimchi. Ever since having it, I haven't touched the other sandwiches at Saucy Porka again.

Looked great on YELP, so I decided to check it out.It's a latin and Asian fusion place.Just had 3 baos just to test out the flavors. Not very good value. They're pretty pricy for such small baos. I mean they try and stuff as much stuff in there, but it's so small that it fits as much as a taco.Took the subway there, so I didn't have to deal with parking. The seating area is small, but can handle groups; it's more of like a fast food place so you don't feel the need to stay very long.Ordered:Pork Carnitas topped with pineapple salsa and served on a steamed bao bun $2.75(nothing special than a carnita taco in Dallas.)Thai Chicken Curry topped with pickled Asian slaw served on a steamed bao bun $2.75(very dry and not strong curry flavor)Miso Braised Beef Short Rib topped with pineapple salsa served on a steamed bao bun  $3.50(My favorite one)My husband and I tried this with some fries from the Frite shop 2 stores down.

a coworker suggested I try this place in the future for lunch, I instantly understood after I glanced and the menu and photos. Two hours later, I was at Saucy Porka.Walking in, the restaurant is very small but has the ability to seat a lot of people at the inside tables. After studying the menu, I had a tough time choosing between the baos and the ramen. Thankfully, the ramen came in a half size so I could get both! (Honestly, I was probably going to get both of them even if it came in a regular size...but thankfully didn't have to) anyways, I ordered the Thai chicken curry, the miso braised short rib and the sofrito marinated shrimp, and of course, the 1/2 order of ramen.The Thai chicken curry bao is life changing. It was like biting in to a cloud and then that cloud explodes with flavors of curry and happiness all bouncing around your tongue. On a side note, I wish I could take a nap on one of those baos. They are so soft and addicting. Anyways back to the bao tacos. Next to try was the miso braised short rib. The sauce drizzled on the beef was thick and very sweet. While I liked this, I didn't love it nearly as much as the chicken curry. Finally the sofrito marinated shrimp. To me this had absolutely no flavor. I couldn't put my finger on what they were going for here, but either way I had one bite and was done. Not worth finishing it.Finally the ramen. It was both light and perfectly satisfying. Chucks of jalapeño may terrify you but the seeds create a delicate balance to the salty flavors and really balance the entire soup. The short rib melts in your mouth with each bite and makes you want to cry each time you have to swallow and end the amazing experience.Overall I would give the chicken curry a 10 (it honestly deserves a standing ovation from everyone inside the restaurant at the time with me), miso braised short rib a 6 and the shrimp a 3. The Ramen gets a solid 8.5 with a high snap of approval.Next time I would be interested in trying more of the baos or even a rice bowl. All looked great as I passed by others and stared down their food.:)

Overpriced and difficult to find parking ($6.50/hour around this area). The baos were small and I would need at least three to be full. I orderd two baos and the large sweet potato fries and the total came close to $12.The pork carnitas was bomb but the thai chicken tasted off to my taste buds. Fries were decent, meh, I've had better. But the thing that stood out was the sauce that it came with. That made things much more flavorful.One thing I didn't like about this store was one of the name of the sandwiches, dubbed "Ho Chi Minh". I don't want to make things political but it irks me since Ho Chi Minh was the leader of the communist party in North Vietnam and I don't support the store naming one of the sandwiches after him.Service was fast and friendly. If you get a sandwich or just two baos, they bring it out on this food basket and it makes things look very empty. It's probably not a big deal but if you're one of those social media people, just a heads up, it won't be Instagram worthy..

Great fusion flavors but for a price! If you are in the area and just really craving Latin and Asian flavors then definitely stop by here. They have a great selection of Bao tacos (Bacos), banh mi sandwiches, noodles, and Latin and Asian influenced appetizers and well as desserts and beverages. The prices are a bit high, but it is in the downtown business area. This concept of fusion can be tried elsewhere in Chicago for cheaper though.I ordered the Arroz Con Edamame, Curry Sweet Potato Fries, and the Thai Curry Chicken Baco. Everything was really delicious! For $9 the Arroz con Edamame was a bit pricey for the size, but they do give a fair amount of the braised pork. The flavoring in the rice and meat was very good. The Fries were perfectly seasoned as well and the aioli that accompanied it was so delicious! I couldn't help but use all of it. The Baco was just okay. Maybe I was just incredibly hungry and basically inhaled it so I could not really taste much of the curry flavor, but the bun was soft and the chicken itself was tender.Nonetheless, the experience was nice and the food is worth a try!

I work across the street and avoided this place just for their name!  being Vegetarian i assumed there isn't much for me!  and i was wrong, a co-worker suggested they have awesome soup and would make it without meat for me.  I decided to give them a try, and wow was i missing out!  I ordered their pozole soup without pork.At lunch time they are extremely busy and crowded; of course as their food is flavorful and tasty. I'll be back!

Such a great lunch place, when you go around 1pm it's not crowded at all. Bacos are tasty although  could use more sauce (compared to Spotted Monkey). Sweet potato fries are a must, it comes with fresh cheese on it and the dip that comes with it is incredible.Staff is nice and offered to refill my tea cup with hot water more times after they noticed I finished it.

When researching good eats in Chicago came across this place. It was.... very different. husband hated it. I thought it was...different. I'm used to a regular soft or hard taco shell but these Bacos taste like under cooked dough. Nice experience and very friendly staff

Stopped by for lunch one day and loved the experience, perhaps even a little more than sister restaurant Spotted Monkey. I got the miso braised short rib rice bowl, which had an extremely generous serving of short ribs and rice. The miso flavors were subtle--more subtle than that of Spotted Monkey-- but all the more delicious because of that, and the ribs were extremely tender. My one (very slight) issue would be the cook of the rice--I didn't taste the coconut flavors as stated on the menu, and the rice was a little overcooked to the point of being a large white blob.Despite this, I loved the meal and would definitely be back again, especially to try the adzuki beignets.  Being sister restaurants, Saucy Porka and Spotted Monkey have rather similar menus, and overall I'd prefer the rice bowls at Saucy Porka and the bacos at Spotted Monkey.

I was really disappointed visiting this Latin Asian fusion. I've never had a fail from yelp ratings, it was rated 4 1/2 stars!!!!First off, the price point for the amount and quality of food was not fitting. I wouldn't even say that the food was average, from taste to warmth and texture all was below average.We had the shrimp bao, braised short ribs bao, Asian style paella, sweet potato fries, and Vietnamese coffee.The short rib bao had pineapple but they were neither sweet nor sour which added no benefit to the taste. Checking the pineapple taste before adding them to these baos might be beneficial. The shrimp slaw was bland, probably need to recheck seasoning before serving these again.If you've had Vietnamese coffee before, don't try theirs. This was nothing compared to Vietnamese coffee, better off getting soda or water.Overall, expensive for below average food with good customer service.

Seems a bit overhyped, I'm afraid.I was so looking forward to some quality fusion in the financial district.Unfortunately, upon ordering the miso braised beef short rib bowl, I was met by a saucy, salty entity trying quite hard to masquerarde as "miso." Dry, salty, with not much texture differentiation. I would say, this entree was "miso-inspired" at best. My friends and I managed to beat a truly insane lunch rush line, but I wouldn't say the quality of the miso bowl was worth it. Granted, my portion was far larger than my friends who ordered the other " baco" items or appetizers. Did I mention the bowl was $11? This is not for those trying to scrimp on a budget.On top of all of this disappointment, patrons kept eyeing one of the seats at our table. One of my friends was 2-3 minutes late, and we were trying to keep the seat until she arrived. Even while she was ordering, people kept trying to move the seat. It's a dog eat dog world out there, I'm telling you. Especially, it seems, when it comes to Saucy Porka.I'll give this place another shot on a less busy day, but until then, there are plenty of other options to try.

a solid Asian-latin fusion restaurant. order at the counter. the cashier was super nice and friendly. for anyone from Houston, this restaurant is similar in concept to Fat Baobao tacos aka bacos are served in those white buns used to eat peking duck. I tried two:- Thai Chicken Curry topped with pickled Asian slaw served on a steamed bao bun $2.75- Miso Braised Beef Short Rib topped with pineapple salsa served on a steamed bao bun  $3.50.Both honestly exceeded my expectations. Very nice flavor profile on each. Between the two, I liked the short rib one more. Mostly because I'm more of a beef than chicken person.I also tried the Curry Sweet Potato Fries topped with queso fresco cheese served with curry aioli ($3 half/$5 full). This is honestly a must try imo, but I'm biased because I love sweet potato fries. The curry aioli is a game changer. It tastes rly unique and is delicious!

I came in here starving after getting off of a flight, and waited for them to open their doors so I could eat! lol but I came out with disappointment. sigh...I got what was recommended the most here on yelp: the short ribs tacos and the saucy porka banh mi sandwich. The tacos were not good to me at all, i dont know why everyone here is praising the mango slices that tops these because it did not compliment it at all! Moreover, it added a sour taste to the tacos and killed the savory goodness of it altogether. The sandwich was decent, not the best ive ever had (and ive had a lot of banh mi's in my life lol) I would get it again but not if I wasnt craving it. The meat was kind of dry, I thought the whole thing could have used some more sauce. But the saucy porka sandwich was the only thing I could finish.I've tried plenty of korean/asian infused mexican restaurants in the past. And saucy porka did not meet my expectations. Im giving the place 3 stars because the customer service was very sincere and the ladies working the back was super nice and friendly to me! Otherwise, I would not give it such a "high" rating.

If you work nearby, I think it is a great lunch option. However, need to be very careful about going around noon. I would definitely try to go later or around 11.30am.But food is good!!! greasy?!? yes, let's admit it! but it's lunch so your body has the rest of the day to digest ;-) because those onces of fat are worth!The rice plate is very good and the portions are super generous.

BLUF:  Must go if in the area. Long line goes away quick and worth it.I have tried all the tacos and that is about it but they are amazing.  You'll need 3 to be full and 4 to be uncomfortable and 5 to hate yourself.  Go with 5.  All are great.Long lines but it really does go quick so don't let it scare you off.  Get it to go, no reason to eat there unless you have to.

The chorizo egg rolls are so. freaking. good. here! I legitimately did a happy dance when I saw that I got 2 for $3.50. Granted, it's probably not the healthiest option, but it was super tasty.I also got the short rib bao taco--this was good but you'll need to get 3ish to feel like you had a full lunch.Definitely try to order ahead and pick up-there's not a ton of waiting area inside.

Good food and a good price for lunch.Location is more for those that work in the area as no parking unless you wanted to pay the expensive downtown parking or get lucky and find a place on the street.Can get busy at lunch so recommend getting there just before noon.

Saucy Porka is serving up some phenomenal Latin and Asian fusion food and I am so happy to have stumbled upon this gem on my way to Willis/Sears Tower. My boyfriend and I ordered a small sweet potato fries, one Thai chicken curry baco, one miso short rib baco, two sofrito shrimp bacos, and the Saucy Porka banh mi.Everything was SO good! Super well seasoned and flavored. The meat was incredibly juicy and tender. I don't normally like sweet potato fries, but I freaking loved these! They were so crispy and the mayo dipping sauce was delicious. Highly recommend the fries and just about everything else. I would eat basically everything Saucy Porka serves on their menu.

Amazing Asian fusion place! Must must try!!!!This neat little place is tucked away. We tried their Bao tacos in chicken, pork carnitas and shrimp - AND THEY BLEW OUR MIND!!! The flavors just burst in your mouth. The service was awesome and one of the servers actually shared her story - some of the pictures on the walls are of her and her mom! A definite repeat place!

Asian/Latin fusion!? Definitely my thing! The place was packed with people on a Friday afternoon! I guess it was lunch time, it was packed with both tourists and business people. For those not familiar, you order at the counter and then find yourself a seat. Their people will bring out your food by calling your name or asking for your number card.We ordered the asian pork paella and 4 different buns (pork, beef, shrimp, and curry chicken.) The presentation was great - made it look even more delicious. The paella dish was amazing. Definitely tasted the fusion flavors. I loved every bite! The rice was nice and crunchy and the pork sausage made it taste so much better! They also have sriracha sauce if you want to add some kick to your food. As for the buns, I was a fan of the shrimp (with a green sauce) and the beef one. The pork one was way too dry - we had to drench it with sriracha. The curry chicken tasted weird. The curry wasn't like any other curry that I've ever tasted - it was weird.Although not a sit in restaurant, their employees would still come around and ask if we're enjoying our food. The portions aren't too big though. I should open my own Asian/Latin fusion place in NY, maybe it'll be just as successful!

Good ramen, really good fried chorizo rolls. Bacos were ok. the tofu baco was boring; the short ribs baco was too sweet but better. In general the food was not spicy enough. Three stars because:  No Bathroom. That is just not okay.

5-star lunch spot in the loop!  The Bao tacos are little, filling bundles of deliciousness.  The carnitas were sooo tender and flavorful.  Can't go wrong with the curry sweet potato fries either.  We went a little before noon and found a seat within a few minutes.  The line started to grow after 12 but it moves quickly.

After visiting the Willis Tower (yes, I'm a tourist and I'm not ashamed to admit it! And yes, I did take some selfies out on the ledge), my boyfriend and I needed a place for a quick lunch. A Yelp search came up with Saucy Porka and everything on the menu sounded pretty good. It was an Asian/Latin fusion, so it seemed pretty interesting.You order at the counter, find a table (if you can - the place is really small), and they bring your food to you.I went with the Saucy Porka (pork carnitas served on French baguette topped with kimchi). I guess I've been eating really good banh mi sammies back in NYC, because I was expecting this one to be on par with the ones I'm used to. Unfortunately, it was nowhere near there. The pork was a tad try, and it was missing the pickled carrots and daikon, which are two of my favorite components!My boyfriend went with the Asian Style Paella (served with Chinese Lop Churng pork sausage, spicy sausage, pork carnitas, edamame, bean sprouts, scallions). He really like it but I thought this was just alright. It had the same pork carnitas from the sandwich that I wasn't a huge fan of.The portions here aren't that big. We weren't still hungry when we left, but we weren't really full either. Maybe we just didn't order the right dishes.

Went around 1pm on a Wednesday. Smaller space with 8-9 tables that were all taken. But didn't have to wait too long for one to open up. I wouldn't expect a seat during lunch hour if you have more than 2 in your party. But the hostess/cashier was super helpful and helped us put a couple of tables together, and even waited until we had a seat before preparing our food so it wasn't cold.Got the sweet potato fries and Tostones to start. The red curry coconut aioli really makes both of these apps worth it. I got the Pork Carnitas and Short Rib "Bacos". Both were simple and tasty. Wifey was happy with the Pork Ramen soup, especially on 40 degree "Spring" Chicago day.Parents got the Short Rib rice bowl and Arroz con Edemame with pork, which they both enjoyed. Both were substantial portions as well, so no worry about leaving hungry.Not in that area that often, but I'd go back.
A great lunch spot, I always get their Basil Chicken Salad, which is a very generous serving for $7.
So yummy!! Especially love the soy ginger tofu and miso short rib bacos.  Definitely get the sweet potato fries!!  Worth the wait, very limited seating in the location tho.

Excellent first impression!I had the Baco with short rib , which was delicious. Tender meat, sweet sauce with a bit of tang.I also had the large Pork Ramen;  nice cuts of pork, savory broth, and nice depth of flavor!The young lady proprietor is a delight; friendly and engaging.  I'll be back!

Great little place in the city to stop by for lunch. I tried the saucy porka sandwich and also ordered the chicken curry baos. I was with two other people and they tried some baos and other sandwiches too. We also all shared the chorizo egg rolls.The flavors of the food were great and the portions definitely fill you up! I didn't really like the cassava chips that came with the sandwich, though. The sweet potato fries were also a bit undercooked which was kinda disappointing. But the sandwiches, baos, and the egg rolls were fantastic!The restaurant itself is a bit small, but clean. Service was great. I appreciated them allowing my mother to sample some kimchi, as she had never really eaten it before and was afraid of the spice. Glad she tried it too, as it was too much spice for her. If I was ever in the area again I would totally stop by this little spot again.

We were looking for a brunch place near the Willis Tower and found Spicy Porka as one of the top places rated around the area. Not your usual sit down brunch restaurant, as this place looks packed with regulars working on the financial district and seating is a FCFS basis.I went for the Asian Style Paella, which was nothing special, but it was good. Service here is awesome - we went during peak time and a staff member came around 5 times and asked if everything was alright.

Phenomenal food and experience! Our group had the Asian paella, ramen, carnita bao, shrimp bao, and then the waitress brought out some curry sweet potato fries since it was our first visit. This fast casual restaurant really brought its A-game!

It was hard to find free parking so I had to pay to park..then I asked the cashier what she thought was the best dish and I tried it... I had the Asian paella and a can of coconut juice ( the juice was my idea and one of my favorites ).. It is almost like any paella I have tried so far.. Yellow and dry.. Which I did not really like.. The only vegetables was a little bit of edamame and green onion.. It had more meats I could not really identify and it was also a little over cooked with I think terayaki sauce.. So the dish was flavorful, but dry and overcooked.. So I was not impressed.. The can was 2 or more dollars, where you can get it for 1 dollar at other places.. The dish was 10 dollars, but it should have been cheaper.. They brought out the dish almost too quick, so nothing was really fresh.. To me, it was a little less than OK..To be fair, I did not try the other dishes and I probably should have read more reviews before trying the 4.5 star place..

The Bao and chorizo egg rolls were really good. I think the egg roll was our favorite. Baos are good, but don't compare to baohaus in nyc. The rice bowl was ok but the barn mi bread was too hearty for sandwich

I was just visiting the city and wanted to try something the locals appreciated, this little shop popped up on my search.
