Though you'd think there would be cheese in this dish due to the consistency, there isn't any surprisingly.- Slow roasted pork shoulder: This was also delicious and a nice-sized portion (granted it's $26). It was tasty, but it's not a dish I would absolutely order again necessarily.- "Deluxe" focaccia: I didn't eat this since it was made with primarily cheese, which wouldn't agree with my lactose intolerance. However, my friend said she absolutely loved it.The food was great, and I wouldn't mind revisiting. However, I felt that the food was a bit on the pricey side for what it was. Although the dishes I ordered were good, they weren't necessarily dishes that are a must-order.Our server was pretty attentive and friendly. She really took the effort to make me aware of which dishes I can order due to my food allergies (as in she crossed out dishes on the menu that I couldn't order and wrote down notes on the menu). + brownie point.

My father, brother, and I came here for lunch and had a great meal that I would give an easy 4 stars. Kelly, our server, was really nice as was everyone else we encountered here, but I'm adding the 5th star for Blake who was fantastic!The layout is simple, narrow, and cool. I like how, depending on where you're sitting, you can see the cooks and servers hard at work. For food, we went with: Chorizo-stuffed medjool dates, Charred beet tartine, Smoked Salmon tartine, and the Avec burger. All the sandwiches and tartines come with a choice of marinated lentil salad or spiced chips as a side. We got both.Everything was great. The bread that came with the dates was nice and crusty and perfect for sopping up the remaining piquillo pepper sauce. Each tartine had it's own unique flavor as did the burger and everything was made with quality ingredients, precision, and care. I did prefer the marinated lentil salad over the chips, but they weren't bad. A great spot for lunch, brunch, or dinner. I definitely intend on returning for all the above.

Let me tell you about my work team. We all love food a bit more than is probably healthy, we tend to overindulge while traveling, and we have a vegetarian in the group. We chose to have dinner at Avec when first getting in to Chicago and our only regret was that it was tough to find places for dinner the remainder of the week that lived up to our meal at Avec.We decided to just go veggie for the whole table to keep it simple and we ordered a trio of cheeses (say yes to the honey. do it.), olives, the foccacia, the kale salad, the tabbouleh, the burrata, an amazing bottle of wine, then dessert because you always need dessert, right? Everything was light, fresh, and just generally delicious.The space is on the small side, but very comfortable and it didn't get super loud despite being quite busy on a Sunday evening. Chicago has a ton of great restaurants but this will definitely be a repeat stop next time I'm in town.

First off, I love the atmosphere. Open, rustic, natural lighting, fresh air.Service was superb, beyond expectations.One of the most recommended items I hear around town is that you gotta try the "Bacon wrapped Chorizos stuffed dates" and I did.My god, I'm adding them to my "you must eat before you die" list.Just amazing.The mussels were a bit fishy and I can tell it's probably a more classic mussel broth dish with an interesting overly seasoned naan? Not my cup of tea.The broccoli dish although had very little broccoli was very refreshing and tasty.A hit.Lastly, I can remember the name of it but the bartender/server informed that it is a newer dish. All I know is it was a chicken entree and it was cooked to perfection.If I'm ever in Chicago again, I'll definitely hit up Avec. It's casual, it's friendly and it's simply delicious.

Been here for both lunch and dinner, and luckily didn't have to wait for either one (and the dinner was at 6PM on a Saturday night for 2).For lunch, I highly recommend the salmon tartine as it's a perfect combination of sweet, salty, and sour. Very resonably priced too! The roasted pork one is also great. Only complaint is they tend to be a little messy to eat (large chunks of meat that may or may not be semi falling as you bite into it) if you're the super dainty type.For dinner, I honestly feel like there are just way too many good choices:- Chorizo stuffed dates: a classic and many folks swear by it, but personally I think it's a little too saucy for me. The pepper-tomato sauce feels a bit blunt - I like my flavors "harmonized" with each other better if that makes sense?- Butcher's steak: beyond awesome in terms of how much the beef tastes like beef- Pork shoulder: Very soft and beyond substantial. We were both basically full after just finishing up this dishP.S. It's community sitting so make sure you don't mind being elbow to elbow with other people.

I was recommended to try Avec after talking with a colleague on how great my meal was at Publican.  He thought this would be another great restaurant that has a small plate approach with the focus on food tastes and not being pretentious!  He was absolutely right.  One of my favourite dishes came from here and I would happily come back to see if it's on the menu.We were told the menu rotates often and though they do have some standards (the dates!!)... it changes often so don't expect to see the same menu even a month later.  It is a small restaurant with the actual kitchen among the diners.  We sat along the bar instead of the communal tables and got a great view of the chefs at work.  We were given a nice introduction to their top dishes and we composed a VERY filling dinner.  Everyone working in the restaurant is in constant motion.. whether it be clearing plates, cooking, taking an order, or serving... it's a constant hustle.  It gives a great vibe to the place.We started off with the sprout salad (love the flavours and texture... crispy sweet apple slices with a hit of mustard, and crunch and nuttiness of peanuts), calamari (my fellow diner was really hesitant on calamari.. he thinks rubber bands. Turns out this was a great dish and now he's open to having it again.  They were tender and the lime citrus note was good), chorizo dates (very good... love the sweetness hits you first then the paprika and pork flavour comes afterwards.  LOVED the sauce... we used all the bread to sop it up), paella (WARNING this is a LARGE portion.  Like more than enough for 2 people... we're talking probably 4.  it came with 5 large head on shrimp and 3 chicken legs... plus a ton of crispy bottom rice.  Great dish but damn we were stuffed), and ended with kumquat flan (LOVE this... my dining partner thought this might be too eggy and it was more like creamy milky heaven... the caramel was so good).We did over order but wow, great flavours and execution.  I love the constant changing menu and how it does offer a variety of vegetables, seafood, and meats... not just a constant focus on red meats.  For those of us who like to eat more vegetables, Avec will be a constant on my list of places to eat in Chicago.

Their most famous dish, chorizo stuffed medjool dates wrapped in bacon (bottom right) is to DIE for. Every bite took me to heavenWe also tried the branzino fish - baked and fried to perfection with delicious crispy skin, and the chicken liver pate (not in pic). They were finger licking good!!If you are not a fan of lamb or goat cheese, skip the sausage.

Was in Chicago for a conference and decided to meet up with a friend here. I had a vodka tonic and we ordered:-Brandade-Kale salad- Dates wrapped with baconAll three were the shiznit let me tell you, especially the brandade. It was the first time I had it, and it blew my mind so much I had to look up recipes to make my own. Kale salad was good - well marinated without wilting/ soggy. Portion was generous - we were very full just with 3 dishes. It was a weekday and the place was already crowded, so I imagine you probably need a reservation for popular times.Avec just made me fall in love with Chicago a bit more. Thank you and keep up the good work!

The food was great, especially the salmon and brussels sprouts and pork shoulder! And negative was waiting for a half hour standing in a small cramped area by the door when we had reservations! If you're in a hurry don't go here. The place is loud, crowded but it's great food!

Several years ago when I went to Avec, it had a high-end, trendy, American feel to it. I never detected anything French or Basque about it. And there was a hint of Mediterranean. As of my most recent visit, it's still very high-end, trendy, American.The service is top. The food now is okay. Since my visit in 2008, the small plates have seemingly become entrée size. My advice would be to order linearly, not all at once if you think you may not get to enjoy a large plate because the small plates are larger than expected.I had a shaved brussel sprouts salad that had grapes, slices apples, crunchy peas, and some flavourful cheese in a tasty vinaigrette. This came in a large bowl. The other dish I had was a huge bowl of mussels. This also was supposedly a small plate. The mussels were a bit mushy, opposed to the al dente lima beans. Having had mussels at other restaurants in a sauce accented with saffron, the sauce on the mussels at Avec made for an okay dish. And instead of toast for better sopping of the sauce, there was something akin to doughy naan. The server paired both with wine, a white for the salad and a red blend for the mussels, and both pairings were spot on.Avec is a happening spot, so reservations are recommended. For the food, I give 3 stars. The service bumps my rating up because the servers are very good with offering suggestions. I got the opportunity for a return.

Over the years, Avec has become so inextricable from my memories and experiences in Chicago that a trip to the Windy City feels incomplete without a bite of those incomparable dates and a cold Atomium. Like most restaurants of its ilk, Avec doesn't take reservations and can handle around 30 people at capacity, so the wait for dinner is typically 1-2 hours during the dinner rush. This may be a blessing in disguise if it's a nice day, since it gives you the chance to enjoy an aforementioned Atomium (a crisp, flavorful Belgian ale) in the small standing area outdoors. Inside, you'll find that the long, narrow venue is constructed floor-to-ceiling from shimmery reclaimed wood. The seating is communal, so be warned: you might find yourself shoulder-to-shoulder with a couple on an awkward date.The Mediterranean-inspired menu is subject to change, but thankfully there are some standouts that seem to be permanently in rotation. The shared dishes vary in size, but are all both filling and surprisingly affordable. There are no wrong answers here, but I personally was not a fan of the whole roasted fish, and others have reported that the paella is subpar. My favorites:Medjool Dates - Avec's most popular dish and with good reason: it's a masterpiece. The savoriness of the bacon and chorizo are cut nicely by the sweet, fruity tones of the dates. The smooth sauce is tangy and satisfying -- soak it up with the firm Ciabatta.Pork Shoulder - One of the largest courses on the menu, the slow-roasted meat is tender and succulent. The broth is mild and the white beans give it a nice earthy consistency.Brandade - If you don't like seafood, you may want to avoid this one. But for the rest of us, this dish is a knock-out. It comes with a creamy, rich puree of white fish that you can spread on sliced toast. The fish is mouth-watering and warms you right to your core.Foccaccia - A large, thin serving of hot, perforated flatbread with taleggio and ricotta cheeses baked in. Not one of the more filling options, but definitely one of the tastiest. Ask for a side of honey to really make the flavors pop.The servers are always highly professional and don't try to insert themselves needlessly into your dining experience; I appreciate that. The venue is gorgeous and you can share some sensational food for $30-$45 each. Make plans to go this weekend and don't look back.

This place is amazing!  It's a tapas place, as it seems with everything else in Chicago, so everything is shareable.  The small plates are pricey (but still good!).  The large plates are all really good deals (because they are double the size, great portions but pretty much the same price).  The pork shoulder was cooked perfectly and is probably my favorite thing on the menu.  Also really liked the lamb tartare, and the mussels.  If you want to get something that is filling and delicious but won't break the bank, I would get the pizza.The wait is not that bad (barely any wait for 4 people on a weekday), and there's sort of a patio-like area where you can chill and order drinks while you wait.Oh, and it's a Pokestop.

I've been here a few times for both dinner and Sunday brunch and every experience has been very solid, although I have to say that my brunch experience probably edges out dinner by a little bit.The bacon wrapped dates are a little on the salty side but still delicious. I've also tried a couple of the fish tartines, all of which have been consistently good. My favorite was the the smoked salmon taramsalata--the flavors of the smoked salmon were light and came together very well with the frisee and tangerines. The brunch pizza was also amazing--the crust was thin, light, and crispy, and the runny egg was perfectly melted into the cheese. For dinner service, the foccacia and honey is always a solid bet. The one entree I've gotten that I wasn't a huge fan of was the pork shoulder, which I found a little overwhelming because of its rich and heavy flavors  (though it would be great to share with 3-4 people).Overall, avec's prices are very fair for the portion size and the quality of the food. The only complaint I have would be the setup of the restaurant--the communal seating forces you to sit elbow to elbow, and often times I find myself practically shouting at my friends in order for them to be able to hear. Other than that, though, avec is awesome and I will definitely continue to come back for the food.

Sunday Brunch ReviewTips:-They don't take reservations and you have to get there at 9:55- well, I strongly recommend that.-Don't complain about communal dining- if you don't want to do it, then don't come here. It's a laid back restaurant that stretches wide as other Yelp reviews have mentioned-Come with 2-4 people. If you're cool with sitting on the counter cause it's just two of ya- that's great!-Don't bring kids- not enough space-ORDER a PIZZA! Those flavors, that spice, that sunny side up egg, perfect to share. The crust is 'finishable' worthy. Probably the best breakfast pizza I have had in Chicago.-French toast has a strong lemon taste if you like that.-They have great tea- but I got an expresso and Bourbon for 8 bucks and that made my Sunday morning!Will I come again? Sure, if I'm up early and going with 1-2 people. But not rushing!

I'll admit, I've only been to dinner there once, but go often for lunch. It is always outstanding. The set up is small shared plates but I'm an eater and I always feel satisfied. It's loosely communal seating but I've never had that be of any issue. It can get very loud in there... lots of wood. So depending on the day or time, it's not exactly intimate. It's more celebratory and conversational. The staff and service have always been great. And the food is outstanding.

Jesus Christ! Avec is an easy to miss spot on Randolph, so PAY ATTENTION or you'll waste a lot of time. The food is phenomenal, though, and the pork shoulder dish has vaulted to the very top of my favorite dishes in not just Chicago but the entire world. Look, I'm not a guy prone to hyperbole, but it was that good.There's a solid selection of cheeses, too, if you want to make a plate, and the dates and fish were amazing as well. But they could have been fried cardboard, and I wouldn't have cared and would have still given Avec a coveted "Merlin Five" because the pork shoulder was just that good. If you want an example where one of the most tired "meat cliches" actually is true -- "so tender you could cut it with a butter knife" -- then go to Avec and order that.Our server was awesome and had cool tattoos. Warned us against ordering too much food, but little did she know how fast the metabolism on this lil' AZN is!

I came back to Avec for lunch in February and I have to bump up my rating from 3 (in December) to a 4. The things that mattered to me in December were no longer much relevant. I ended up ordering the seared trout for lunch - it laid on top of bread with a salad medley in between. It hit the spot and really gave me the push to update my review - yum!Here's my review for December:The place is a bit hard to find since the door is camouflaged with the wall. Once you find the door - push, don't pull.I was expecting the place to have a more formal or semi-formal ambiance based off of the info I read online (queue the dim lighting, semi dressy attire, and music with volume that is loud enough to cover eaves dropping but soft enough so that you won't lose your voice from screaming) - my expectations were let down. The lighting was faintly dim, workers wore jerseys, and I don't think music was playing at all.The restaurant menu is setup suggesting that people share plates family style. They recommended that 1 large dish or 2 small dishes be ordered for 1 person.Kale Salad (small) -Delish! The salad was light yet full with flavor. If you're looking for greens, I would highly recommend this option! --- 5/5Chorizo Stuffed Date (small) -The spice of the chorizo, saltiness of the bacon, and sweetness of the dates really made this an interesting dish! I enjoyed trying it after noticing the hype from Yelp; but a try was good enough for me. The dish comes with 4 stuffed dates; we had 1 each and had the rest for take away. --- 3/5Pork Shoulder (large) -The first thing I thought of when I took a bite is that this reminded me of a taco - in a good way! The pork was very flavorful and reminded me of flavored meat in tacos. I, as many, would recommend this dish. --- 4/5Steak (small) -Good. Nothing less or more than my expectations. This was the last dish we settled on for our dinner order. --- 3/5Apple Crostata with Ice Cream -I love it when warm breaded dishes meet cold ice cream! The apple pie wasn't as warm as I would have liked it so that was a bit of a let down. They don't mention it on the menu, but this dish has raisins! My bf is allergic to raisins so he wasn't able to try it which was unfortunate. --- 4/5 (with the caveat that it's not cool to leave out ingredients that people can be allergic to)Turkish Coffee Gelato (Special") -My bf ordered this since he recently came back from Turkey and has declared turkish coffee one of his favorite types of coffee. Unfortunately, he was let down from this ice cream rendition. --- 3/5There were three things that really caught my attention:1. The bathroom sink/dryer combo - I've never seen something like that before! Pretty nifty!2. The "kitchen"! Are the back 2 ovens behind the bar the main part of the "kitchen"? I noticed it on the way out so I didn't have a chance to ask, but it's such an interesting setup! It may be why the dessert took much longer than expected. I would say dessert took over 15 minutes to be served.3. About 5 minutes after we placed our dinner order we noticed a "specials" board and wanted to change one of our dishes for a special. We were told that they couldn't change it since they dish was already made - unfortunate since we really wanted to try to scallops, but fortunate since the kale was amazing!Maybe I'll come back in the summer time.

We had lunch here and was impressed with the quality of the food, service, and ambience. Also enjoyed the music here that they played as well. It is a very modern restaurant. Our server was excellent!!-Sausage with bacon wrap (flavoring was great)-Salmon sandwich (the salmon was fresh)

Of all my meals in Chicago, this one was my favorite. Perhaps it was just the welcomed solitude after constantly being around people for a week. (#introvertprobs) But aside from the occasional glances from the server or corporate guys drinking on their lunch break next to me, my attention was solely fixated on the food. That's what you would call an unbiased, unclouded experience!I dropped in during lunch and was happily seated at the bar. I overheard the host tell guests that the wait for even groups of two were at least 20 min for a table. (However, they do take reservations for lunch now!)I considered ordering the famous pork shoulder, but after consecutive meals at the Girl and the Goat and the Purple Pig, I was all pork-ed out haha. I ended up deciding on the kale and carrot salad with mint, dill, green harissa, and sunflower seed dukkah and the popular chorizo-stuffed medjool dates. The server was so kind to half the portion of the dates (from four to two) so it was more reasonable to finish -- and it was perfect! I loved how refreshing the salad was, with a hint of spice from the harissa. I've never had dukkah before, but I didn't mind it at all! I would have preferred smaller slices of the carrots though, much easier to eat! The half portion of chorizo-stuffed dates was just right with a good balance of sweetness from the dates and saltiness from the bacon and chorizo. But the pepper-tomato sauce was such a hit, I was devastated when I ran out of bread to dip into the sauce.Definitely would come by again, perhaps stop by its sister restaurant Blackbird next door next time!

There are so few times I've eaten at an establishment that just transcends the 1 - 5 Star Review system. As rare as this happens, it sometimes does - like tonight at Avec.Let me throw some adjectives out there; memorable, fantastic, complex, thoughtful, delicious, smart and a list of twenty more.Avec was a dining experience I've had only as many fingers (no toes) as I have or maybe less than that.So let's go through the dinner I just had:Tabbouleh Salad with so many things going on your palette was jumping like a frog.Chicken Liver on Crostini that was as smooth as silk and kicking with a lot of side flavors given by ingredients that I had no idea what they were.  Let's just say IT WORKED!Chorizo with Dates that was as thoughtful as a dish I've ever had.  This dish affected my mind more than my palette - Very Cool.A Pork Shoulder Casserole that made my Chef Wife's head buzz. She was blown away and I haven't seen that awed look on her face in years.Fideos with Squid and Ink - Wow - Unbelievable!Portokaloptia pudding with ice cream that was crazy good.Sure you have to wait an hour for your table at 9:00 on a Wednesday night, but let me say emphatically that it is totally worth it.The wine list is well constructed to fit the food.  The service was very good. The price is surprisingly not much compared to similar dinners as memorable.I apologize if this glowing review sounds like my son owns this restaurant (which he doesn't) but I will not forget this evening anytime soon, and I say those words so seldom.

This place had this chicken paella dish a while back that was single handedly one of the greatest dishes in the Chi.They got rid of it for some lame vegetarian version, and that since event has ruined my entire life.I love this place, I just can't go back there until this dish is back.

Wow. This place is absolutely amazing. I came here off a friend's recommendation and I am so glad I took her advice.The restaurant is a Mediterranean-style, wine bar kind of place and has a very cool, modern vibe. You can also eat outside at these wooden standing tables, which was also pretty cool.The service was great, and I got a salad which was very good. But the most amazing part was by far the dessert. I ordered a Turkish Float (lemon gelato + strawberry malt soda) and chocolate sesame truffles, and both changed my life!!!They also have a wide selection of international fine wines and cheeses, but I didn't order those (unfortunately). I would feel safe assuming they're just as awesome as the items I did order.I cannot wait to come back to Avec the next time I am in Chicago, it really was awesome.Highly, highly recommend.

I came here for lunch on my short trip.  What really got me is Anthony Bourdain saying this is a spot he liked in an interview i saw.  Kinda tricky to enter...either that or I'm just kinda dumb.  I tried to push the glass door open but it only opens from the inside.  The main entrance is actually to the side of the open doors.  Its kinda cramped in there.  Imagine one long space with Just bar seating on one side and community seating bench tables on the other side.  Cool decor though.Menu.  Their lunch menu is pretty limited.  Mainly consist of salads and sandwiches.  I wish there were more options since I'm from out of town, but I'm not their target market.  Lots of things i wanted to try, but prob are served during dinner.  They do have outside seating for nice days.Bacon wrapped dates stuffed with chorizo in a red sauce...DELICIOUS.  i really enjoyed this appetizer.  Comes with a ciabatta bread and dipping the bread in the sauce...it was really good.Steak Pita wrap sandwich.  The flavors were really good.  I love cilantro and red onions with that vinaigrette dressing.  came with a small lentil salad that paired really well with the dish.I did ask the waiter if i can get half salad and half chips for my side...never got my chips.Service was mediocre.  We sat at the bar and the our waiter was just whatever.  Just ad a whatever attitude.  Maybe it wasn't his day.

Oh man. There is so much hype around this place that I just don't understand. It's good, but it is definitely not exceptional.Chorizo-stuffed medjool dates (5/5):This was probably the highlight, then everything went downhill after this...It was creamy and flavorful and just brought me to another level.Focaccia (2/5):bro... it's a simple dish. But it does not stand out. There's an overpowering flavor of truffles which is not pleasant. The whole thing is basically just bread + cheese + truffles. not worth the money or the hype. I expected more from avec.slow roasted pork shoulder (4/5):solid pork shoulder. Besides the strong note of salt there is not much going on with the dish. It is homey in deed, but nothing creative or makes it stand out.Creme caramel (4/5):nothing to complaint about besides a little too sweet. nice balancing of flavor with the edible flowers and crunchy things

Went here awhile ago and most recently went back a few months ago. What can I say it's an amazing restaurant with delicious dishes that are great for sharing.  I went with my husband and the wait was about an hour on Friday night which wasn't too bad, so we decided to stick it out. We were sitter at the shared table which was a gift and a curse.  On one hand we got to see all the dishes everyone else was ordering which helped us pick our dishes. On the other hand we got to see all the dishes everyone else was ordering...Delicious place, definitely worth the wait and I hope to be back again soon.

I had no idea what I was walking into when I came here, I just knew a few friends mentioned Avec was awesome and yada yada yada. Coming in was a bit of a surprise, the place is squeeze tight small. You'll have some room to walk around, but there is bar seating (which has long waits) and communal seating which is a free-for-all. You can get more privacy at the bar, but the communal you will basically be seated at a table with open seats. You might be squished into the middle, or if you're lucky, you will get the end seats. It'll be difficult to get seated with more than 4 people in my opinion, but you can try your luck.Came here with my gf and we luckily got the end of the table. Ordered some drinks which were good, and got two small plates - the butcher's steak and the whipped brandade. The steak came around medium and I enjoyed it, but my gf likes steaks more well done (I know...). The whipped brandade didn't do much for us, I would recommend trying the dates. I didn't try them, but someone next to us got them and they looked fantastic... bacon chorizo and some sauce, just get it. I recommend one small plate for a couple.The large plates are pretty enormous. We got the wood oven paella and the slow roasted pork shoulder. Wood oven paella was amazing. I loved the slow roasted pork shoulder as well, the lemon yogurt was amazing with the pork shoulder. The serving sizes seem pretty large - we orderd two small plates, and our waitress recommended half-plate of the paella and we couldn't even finish the pork shoulder dish that much. Stick with one small plate to share between two people, and individual large plate per person.It gets pretty cluttered but its a very casual feel. If you get stuck in the middle of a table you might hate the experience. The food is really good though. As long as you aren't uptight and demand perfection, you should have a good experience here. It takes a while for the food to come out, so maybe order your large plate as your small plate comes to you. Still, I'd recommend Avec to anyone.

Avec is probably my local favorite restaurant, and I am always happy to be here. This is my go-to spot for taking guests who are visiting the city. The staples -- chorizo dates and focaccia -- are remarkably consistent in quality, and are always a pleasure.The other parts of the menu, which change seasonally, are nearly always worth trying. I fondly recall sumac salmon, squid ink spaghetti, poached eggs, and many other great seasonal dishes. That being said, I've also had ones that weren't so good (duck egg pizza this season, for instance), so there's some variance among the seasonal items.The gelato and sorbet selection, which changes daily, is also always worth going for. Not only is it usually very well done, but it's almost always an interesting and compelling flavor.That being said, the music and atmosphere are great too. Avec manages to be intimate and feel vibrant while maintaining a high level of polish.Service is usually great. I have only once ever had an unhelpful server.
A quarter liter of white burgundy for $12 in Chicago, count me inAmazinggggg liver mousse  bowlI walked by here a bunch but never came inWill return

Came here because I heard so many great reviews about this place... but was VERY underwhelmed.I came here for brunch on a Sunday and had to wait about 15 minutes before being seated. I ordered the chorizo stuffed bacon-wrapped dates, slow roasted pork shoulder, and the baked egg dish.Chorizo stuffed dates: (3/5) Although this is supposed to be avec's "signature dish", I was not impressed. I've had better bacon wrapped dates at other restaurants in Chicago.Slow roasted pork shoulder (3/5): The meat was tender, but it wasn't very flavorful. I could only taste the saltiness of the broth, but didn't have much flavor otherwise.Baked Egg (2/5): This dish was recommended to me by the waitress. She said it would compliment the other dishes that I ordered. However, the sauce, kale, cheese and the chickpeas just didn't work together in my opinion.Service was average as well. Perhaps it was because the restaurants was so busy Sunday morning. Overall, I feel like this place is over-hyped. Or perhaps due to the hype, I had higher expectations.

It breaks my heart to give Avec 3 stars (3.5 stars if possible) because it's been on my list for a while and it's so well rated on Yelp. But...Liked:-- Casual communal setting-- Hostesses were super friendly-- Roasted chicken was really good-- The "butcher's cut" small plate was also a hitDisliked:-- Everything was way too salty-- We ordered 4 small plates, 2 large plates, and only liked the two listed above. The rest were 'meh'-- The affogato with 'walnut nocino' was way too boozy... we mentioned it to our waitress and she kinda just shrugged-- $38 for a branzino that's neither large nor specialOverall we had a good time, mais nous pouvons le faire sans 'Avec.' (my husband made me say it)

The second Chicago tapas outing of the day - while superior by 1-star (compare to Purple Pig), not perfect. The 'woodsy' ambience remains constrained by the boxy dimensions of the restaurant. In no particular order: squash flower pizza (flavorful - garlic x 20, but where was the flowered squash?); octopus with charred watermelon (excellent, but why so acidic?); panzanella with grilled halloumi cheese (agreeable, but high on vinegar); chorizo stuffed dates (perfect); initiated with fantastic Greek rosé and in-house chamomile-beer. Nonetheless, we somehow don't feel a strong desire to return.

I mean what to say about this place that hasn't already been said. Came here on a Friday night right after work, and a group of 4 was easily able to slide into one of the communal tables and get right to it. Super extensive wine list (didn't even read it to be honest) and very short cocktail list. Ordered an old fashioned which wasn't on the menu but turned out very well. Girlfriend ordered a tea and gin inspired drink, which actually arrived after our first plate of food - the only downside to the meal.Food order included the dates (they are everything that other reviewers have mentioned and more. you need these in your life), mussels with fresh naan and flavorful lemony broth, greens with feta and fennel (needed something green.. right?), focaccia bread which was more like dry flatbread with creamy cheese in the center (wouldn't order again), lamb shank with calabria chili sauce and apricots (wow!), fresh yogurt and berries, and finished with olive oil chocolate cake. Dates were easily my favorite thing, followed by the lamb and mussels.The place is loud and busy (rightfully so) so expect that going in. You'll sit in close quarters and stare at the surrounding plates wondering - hm should we order that? Yes. Yes you should. Order as much as you can eat as the menu rotates a bit and make sure if you take guests they are comfortable with communal seating. Not as pricey as the neighboring blackbird makes Avec a great spot with high repeat potential.

My first dining experience in Chicago and one of my favorite dining experiences overall.  We came without a reservation around 8 on Tuesday night and were promptly seated, albeit right in between two parties on a long picnic bench style table.  This may or may not be your thing, but be prepared to share space and conversation ;).  It also makes it so that the person sitting in the middle, with his/her back to the wall has to ask everyone to the left or side to get out in order to get out.  I think this may probably be the only thing I did not enjoy about our dinner.Service at avec is great - our server knew her stuff and all of her recommendations were on point.  We had the chorizo-stuffed bacon dates (AMAZING - this is what they're known for so be sure to get it), the branzino (again, delicious - the sauce it sits above is out of this world; we drank it), the mussels (superb), and two desserts - the caramel custard and this deconstructed carrot cake (which was a special that night).Every bite I put into my mouth was delicious.  I would (and will) definitely come back!

This place is absolutely phenomenal, and the service is top notch! The hummus, dates, and pork shoulder are an absolute must. If you are lucky enough to have Sandra as your server, ask her for suggestions on wine pairings. She knows the list and menu inside and out, and anything she suggests will blow your mind. The next time I'm in Chicago, I will make it a requirement to return!

At the Chicago Best party, featuring more than a dozen best restaurants in Chicago of the year, Avec presented an incredibly AMAZING bacon wrapped burger with the works. It was probably the best bite at the event (who would've thought a burger would steal the show?)!One of my favorite burgers thus far; however, as I browse the menu online, it doesn't appear to be listed. Not sure how this particular burger fits into the "Mediterranean or French" menu, but it is worth keeping!I'll venture in for the burger, and for the eastern Mediterranean dishes!

I love Avec. The only bad thing about it is how good it is that I come back here all the time.Finding a reservation for this is as hard as finding a spot to park in downtown Chicago :) :)My suggestion is to go here by yourself so you could be seated at the bar. *What I did*Love the communal tables and the atmosphere here a lot a lot and a lot! Everyone there was very friendly and attentive. Was expected that from the hype and everything. The food... omg omg omg. Everything was amazing.

I have been to Avec several times. I don't want to claim that I tried all the menu, but I can say that I tried many many dishes on their menu.Everything these guys do is delicious! really, there was never once that i tried the food and I thought it was off!I think one of my favorite item on their menu is the chicken liver crostini. so so good! then, the brandade! and the notorious stuffed chorizo dates (and I don't like dates in general...)Overall, I think that the small plates are better than the large plates and, honestly, the portions size of the small plates is good enough to make you happy!Also, the drink list is quite large. They have wine from almost all the European countries and from several regions within Europe.I would definitely recommend this place to anybody who is craving for small twisted Southern European tapas! You will not get it wrong!

There is a simple reason that Avec has been here for more than 12 years.. it is Outstanding!Deserves all the accolades it gets - interesting menu, incredibly friendly service, great atmosphere & vibe.  Negatives.. ?? Zero, zip, none.

I can't wait to go back!  I just moved back to Chicago, so I was just riding my bike around and checking out all the changes. I stumbled upon Avec, and always wanted to go when I visited, but for whatever reasons i didn't. I was alone and only ordered the bacon wrapped dates and a couple drinks. OMG the dates were insanely good. The drinks were great too, but how were those dates so good?  The service was friendly and fast. I cannot recommend Avec highly enough.

Creative and super flavorful! Our favorites were the kale salad (spicy and rich) and the chorizo stuffed dates (seriously??). Also really liked the salmon tartine and lamb burger. The green hazelnut tea was also delightful. Community style tables added charm and our service was impeccable. I love being served by people who get as excited about food as we do :)

I always disliked communal seating, but now I really despise it.  This was my second time returning to Avec, and the food still didn't impress; no need to call out anything specific - everything was just mediocre.Why the 1 star?  Let me lay it out.  My husband and I were celebrating something and decided to come here for a date night.  We got seated at the end of the long table in the back of this narrow restaurant.  I sat with my back against the wall.  Later on, a party of 3 got seated at the end of the table adjacent to us, and 1 of the guys was told to sit in the aisle in between our two tables, so I was blocked if I tried to get out.  Then a large party arrived and occupied the opposite end of our table, leaving just two vacant seats left at our table next to my husband and me.  Near the end of our meal, a couple arrived, and the clueless hostess asked us me to move to let them in, but like I said - I was blocked by the guy.  What first bothered me was that she didn't notice the guy blocking me, so I had to ask him to move when I feel it should've been her.  I looked over at her, and she clearly had this "oops" face.  Additionally, I was very pregnant, and squeezing past diners wasn't very easy.  My husband and I decided to just ask for the check and forego dessert at that time so we found our waitress who rung up our bill.  I waited alongside the counter next to her.  Moments later, the hostess returned and asked me if I needed any assistance because I was in the way!  I'm like, "I'm trying to pay, and there's no where to go."  And she's like, oh!  My husband was already by the front door waiting for me, and he told me she approached him and told him he couldn't stand there to wait!  What the heck?  Where do ya want us to go then, lady?!  We're trying to get out of the way, and you're just being extra annoying making us feel unwanted and out of place in this restaurant!  She single-handedly ruined my night, and now Avec is officially on my shit list.

I LOVED this place and think it could be one of the best restaurants in Chicago. Small plates, big flavor! We ordered the chorizo stuffed dates (A MUST), the salmon with an amazing crispy skin like I've never had before, and finally the chicken. Also we got the truffle flatbread, which really wasn't that great -- it needed both salt and more truffle oil.Conspacked and sometimes over an hour waitno reservations
We loved everything that we ordered. And we ordered everything vegetarian. You can do half orders on some of the menu items so that you can try more menu items.

Came here for a birthday dinner on a Monday night. Showed up early, around 5.30 and got a table right away.Dinner was excellent, ordered Dates that were outstanding, muscles that were delicious and pork shoulder that literally melted in your mouth.Wonderful service, great atmosphere and one of the best restaurants I have been to in Chicago. Do not miss it!

This place is amazing. We were a party of 4 and ordered 3 small plates and 1 large. We left full. I suggest ordering less and then ordering more if you are hungry.Prices are more than reasonable for the quality of the food.People list not taking reservations as a con, but I like first come first serve as it allows out of towners to try new places without planning. Also, there are plenty of fine places to eat around Avec if they are full. We got there right at 5 and were seated immediately.
Highly recommend: chorizo in dates, hummus with pita, fideo (kinda like a paella). Do NOT get the baked egg with kale and green tomatoes, tasted like warm kale juice. Service was great tho!

Avec is pretty special.Once you figure how how to get inside (side door on the left, push really hard) it's a long narrow floor plan. Choose to sit at the bar or a table.Their are extensive wine choices not as reasonably priced (the one recommended to me  was $15 a glass) and some great beer options - I had the Satan Red Ale, 8 bucks & delicious!It was late and I wasn't starving, so I choose the Brussels sprout salad that had a light  dressing and the thinly shaved, raw Brussels  sprouts were ingenious as a salad! Very good & I would order that again if I find myself at Avec.I wanted one other dish, but small. The server mentioned a few items that they'd do half orders of - one of those the chorizo stuffed bacon wrapped dates. Done.These were nothing short of amazing. Much better with the chorizo than not, in my opinion, because the dates are so sweet - I'm all about adding more savory. And that piquillo pepper sauce - YES! It was so delicious that I would like to put it on more and more things.Yelpers didn't steer me wrong on this one. Thanks, you guys!

Went for lunch. Had an amazing salmon tartine. It was fresh, seared and delicious. My partner got the avec burger and his mind was blown. The menu is creative with lots of veggies thrown into the mix. Definitely want to try dinner here.

Delicious small plates that pack big flavor.// WAIT // Less than 5 minutes at 9 PM on a weeknight for a party of 2// AMBIANCE // Prepare to eat in an incredibly narrow restaurant with communal tables where you will sit shoulder to shoulder with other dining patrons.// FOOD //+ Chorizo stuffed dates: salty, sweet, and savory, all in a cute little package+ pork shoulder: Ridiculously tender hunk of savory meat. Will please the carnivore in you.Definitely worth a try if you are in Chicago

I stopped by Avec for a long work lunch and definitely wasn't disappointed. If you're doing lunch, I recommend getting there right when they open so can get a seat and put your food order in before the lunch rush hits.As I came during Chicago Restaurant Week, for only $22 I got the following items from the prix fixe menu: charred sweet potatoes, Avec burger and sesame cocoa crunchies. A lot of restaurants skimp back on portions for lunch menus, but the portions here were huge and I left completely full. By far, the highlight of the meal was the burger. It was packed with flavor due to all the sauces and I couldn't help but scarf it down.The service was also great. I was seated at the bar and although it got pretty busy, the bartender was constantly refilling my water and my food was brought out quickly. Overall I had a great experience and can't wait to go back to try their famous dates!

The food at Avec is awesome, service is okay, and ambiance is awful. The chorizo dates were my favorite dish: much spicier than I had anticipated, but I love spicy food so that was fine. Our server and the hostess were both kind of...gruff. I was also irritated because I made a point of telling our waitress that we needed to be out of the restaurant by a certain time to catch a show, and she totally blanked on that so I had to flag her down frantically after we'd finished our meal.My biggest issue with this place is the space. Yes, it's super cramped, and you dine at long tables smooshed up next to total strangers, which is not my thing at all, HOWEVER that is not my biggest issue. The tables/benches/chairs are AWFUL. The chairs are super tiny, basically little wooden squares with backs that are approximately one inch tall (that is not an exaggeration). I am a pretty small person and I could barely even cross my legs under the table, which was built for Smurfs. Also, my friend and I both had issues with the super mutant and pretentious wooden front door to the restaurant. What a terrible atmosphere. For this reason, I won't be back again, which is a shame because the food was very good and decently priced.

First look:I was honestly so nervous that my family and I wouldn't like it due to other yelper's negative review due to no reservation and small space. I was prepared for a long wait, so I wasn't surprised once we got in around 7 and was told there would be about a 45 minute- 1 hour wait. We used this time to go in for a drink a couple doors down and a western restaurant for the wait.Atmosphere:I really did love the atmosphere it even though it is indeed a slim fit restaurant that has apparently be open for 12 years, so they must be doing something right. The lighting was great, the embroidered napkins were a nice touch, and the plating dishes were perfect. Yes of course it was loud but for the conditions, I think anyone could handle it.Food:Hands down amazing, I can't complain about a single course. The char-grilled sweet potatoes was sweet with a tahini and grill taste, the Brussel sprouts salad was fresh, and the olives and bread was a nice starter but could've done without. Entree wise, my mom got the fresh fish which was good but was frightful of bones, and lastly my tangine was hearty for a vegetarian dish a  tang of the yogurt. I agree with others who said that two small plates or one large plate is standard as a filling meal. The proportions are perfect for any time of the day. Outstanding!Dessert:Two out of the three of us went for the special desserts of the day where my dad got the lemon ginger sorbet and my sister got the mint chip gelato. Each had special touches, the sorbet with a torched meringue, and the gelato with two small shortbread cookies atop it. finally, I had the greek yogurt cake which was moist and creamy with a crunch and the currants inside made for nice collected components.Conclusion:. Wouldn't regret this visit at all, Even Due to Lenten obligations, we had to pass on the chorizo stuffed dates, but next time it's a must. However, I learned my lesson that other reviews can't scare me anymore because they made me think I wouldn't like it. Don't forget that everyone has different looks on everything which was something you always have to keep in mind. sorry I was sidetracked! Great food, interesting atmosphere, good service, and really good food :)

Avec has amazing food, but it's the cramped dining conditions that make it tough for me to give this a higher rating.We went during a weeknight and even at 8:30pm we still had a short wait- they do NOT take reservations. But the wait wasn't too bad the hostess was very nice and helpful. When we were finally seated it was a tight space. I'm not a big person but it was tight and they are communal tables so you might need to move to let other people out. To eat here with more than one other person might be tough.We split a pizza to start and then split the pork shoulder as our entrée. The pizza was cooked perfectly. The cheese on the pizza was a little too rich but it was very tasty. The pork shoulder was so yummy. Again cooked just right and full of flavor. All of the dishes of our dining neighbors looked great as well. It just would have been nice to have a bit more space.It's a very small place and again they don't do reservations, so perhaps I would come back for lunch but dinner might be too much of a production for me.

I have to say I really enjoyed this place and even came two nights in a row! There are a few downsides although including a small crowded space that get increasingly louder the closer to peak dinner service you stay.  The chairs are extremely uncomfortable most without a back rest and simply hard wood.FOOD: I had the cauliflower tabbouleh both nights and it was a great blend of crunchy and smooth along with sweet and spicy.  It is unlike any other tabbouleh and I highly recommend it.  The seared trout was another great dish with a warm trout and chilled shrimp.  The gyro sausage was another hit and highly recommended.  We enjoyed the paella (although the bottom was more crispy the previous night) with sausage and head on shrimp.  As well as the pork shoulder with so much pork we couldn't finish it.  For dessert it is a must to get the nutter butters which are conveniently bite sized and curiously crunchy.  On the other hand another reason for the 4 stars is that i did not quite understand the apple dessert.  It came out hot and crispy on the outside but the apples on the inside were cold...very cold and I am not sure if that was there intention but I believe they did not realize when trying to quickly get it out to the table.  They also have nice teas, coffees, and cappuccinos!

Expensive, uncomfortable, loud, and just ok.This perhaps has been one of the biggest disappointments of my dining adventures in Chicago.This is my first time in Avec (will definitely be my last) and I had heard wonderful things about the place. What a disappointment our experience here was.Firstly, the restaurant is very small, doesn't take reservations, has shared tables and is EXTREMELY noisy! I could barely hear my fiancée and this made conversation difficult and uncomfortable. Furthermore, our table neighbors (seated in our same table and with which I constantly rubbed shoulders) were annoyingly loud.Food was just OK.We started by sharing the Serrano Ham platter and started with the wrong foot. Simple, uncreative, boring. No other way to describe it. We followed with the salmon starter and it was an improvement, still nothing impressive. We continued with a whole fish that was actually pretty good! But definitely not worth $42. For desert, we concluded with a cheesecake "with chocolate", which turned out to be a chocolate cheesecake (and I'm not a big fan of chocolate).Overall, our experience was only ok. I am disappointed because I had heard great things about Avec and there was nothing great about our dinner.The only "great" thing was the bill: UBER EXPENSIVE and totally not worth it  (and we didn't even order wine).

Avec had been on my list to try for a while so was pleasantly surprised to find no wait when I walked by on a cold and rainy Friday evening ( thanks crappy Chicago summer!).  The seating is a little claustrophobic, wouldn't be so bad if the wall side didn't require customers tapping fellow diners on the shoulder to let them in/outFood:- Had the medjool dates but forgot to ask for the half order (no indication on the menu that this is an option) but they were quite good so we *somehow* managed to finish the order (and wiped the bowl clean with the delicious warm bread)- the charred octopus was perfectly prepped and cooked, the beans and citrus added depth and lightness to the dish I really liked- the deluxe focaccia was delish, but super rich (ricotta+truffle oil+butter tends to do that) and large so probably better shared as an app with a group of 3-4- the tiramisu was good but nothing specialA little on the pricey side but has been added to the return list so I can continue making my way through the menu...
My favorite restaurant ever. Pretty much. This place is incredible, food is always top notch (chorizo dates, brandade) and solid wine list.

I finally had a chance to eat here last week after hearing many of my sister's rave reviews. It most definitely held up to the standards. The small seating area definitely makes you feel like you are in a metropolitan city, so if you don't like eating in crowded spaces, it might not be the place for you.We tried many of the current plates since there were five of us dining. Some of my favorites were the chorizo stuffed dates, the paella, the burrata, and the steak. The plates came out quickly even with a big crowd that night and no one went home hungry. Each of the dishes was well crafted and very tasty. The cafe avec espresso+brandy and the affogato were great ways to end a delicious meal. I hope to be back soon!

Overrated. Came here for brunch. Overpriced food, bad service.Pros:1. Pretty atmosphere, good locationCons:1. Instead of apologizing, our waitress gave attitude to my boyfriend when he asked about our bloody marys, which she had clearly forgotten about.2. The bloody marys, when they finally arrived, were small and way overpriced.3. We ordered the shakshuka, which was bland and came with regular bread (where's the pita?)4. We had the famed carbonara pizza, which was, again, overpriced, and just 'okay.' Most of the runny yolk ended up on the serving dish. The crust was the best part.We were really excited about trying this place, and sadly, won't be coming back. There are many more delicious places to eat in Chicago.

Im not sure if this is my favorite restaurant, but it does have my favorite dish.  The chorizo stuffed dates are just amazing.  They are better than any other date dish that I have ever had. They are stuffed with a ton of chorizo, wrapped in bacon and then covered on a tomato pepper sauce. They have  perfect amount of spice.  If I had to pick a last meal,  it may be a few orders of these...All the other food was great as well and I really enjoyed the burger they serve for lunch.  Overall great place to check out.

Had a terrific meal here last night! Arrived at 7:00 and was seated for two promptly. We both ordered the pollinator cocktail to start - very refreshing. To eat, we started with the smoked corn tabbouleh salad and the heirloom tomato and peach panzanella. Both were delicious. We also ordered the brandade which was very rich and creamy. The salmon was also cooked nicely, and my friend ordered the dates which she enjoyed. For dessert, we shared the lime and coconut gelato in strawberry soda, and the fruit tart. The fruit dessert was nothing particularly special, but I loved how unique and refreshing the gelato float was. Altogether, a great dining experience that I would highly recommend.My one criticism for the restaurant is that the booths at the communal tables don't work! My friend had to get up about 5 times throughout dinner to let someone in or out of the booth. Not functional!

Hands down, the best I've tried while visiting Chicago. Starting with my favorite of the night: Chicken Liver Crostini. This was absolutely outstanding. The smooth and creamy chicken liver pâté was to die for.. the stone fruit mostarda with fresh herbs to top the crostini..amazing play of creamy, crunchy, sweet, salty, fresh. I wish I could eat this every day.Chorizo Stuffed Medjool Dates. Another great one. Came in 4 pieces and again, the sweetness of the dates and saltiness of the chorizo and bacon were perfectly balanced. The tomato pepper sauce added a nice touch of acidity that really complimented the dates and made this dish different from other bacon wrapped dates I've tried. Definitely recommend!I also tried the Whole Roasted Branzino. Cooked and seasoned perfectly but since it is a mild tasting fish, I always found it a bit boring. They topped it with some wonderful colors which included carrots, parsley, cilantro, garbanzo beans (which were undercooked). It was good but I think the others items on the menu were better. The Pork Shoulder was also pretty good. Super tender with a generous portion. Loved the smoked yogurt that was on top. I would say give this one a try.Service lacked a bit but the food made up for it. If I visit again, I will definitely be back!

for the freeke  taboule salad with cauliflower  i wana give the kitchen a hugh mothafukinfive Good job guys keep it upLove the wood fired oven in the back kitchen i wish I would've sat by it but all seats were taken.. the host lady in front wasn't too happy to work on haloween.Smile you have a lot happy people excited to be in your restau..

I went recently as suggested by one of my companions, who is a repeat patron. We went on a Monday right when it opened and were seated right away. It got pretty busy within the hour. I heard the focaccia was a must, and it is. OMG. I really loved the kale salad as well. The mussels were so-so, but my companions loved them. I did like, however, how the pita was draped over the mussel cookware it was served in - you can tell it was baked fresh on top. Service was average. I like the minimalist interior, as it really shows how menu and cuisine focused they are. I didn't mind the communal seating, but we also were not hardcore packed in like sardines.

Food was delicious, wine recommendation was perfect and servers were very attentive and polite. Can't say the same for the hostess though, she was short and stand offish. On top of that I was charged incorrectly (correctly at restaurant, incorrect on my bank statement), no biggie just call and get it fixed right? I was starting to tell her what happened when she rudely cuts me off, acting as if what I'm telling her isn't important to her...Sure, it isn't your job and you'll have someone call me fine, but don't belittle your customers!!! Specially when the place you work at has made a mistake. 1st person you interact with entering and last person leaving a restaurant are the hostesses, choose wisely!

This place was great but I think I had higher expectations based on reviews.  Of course I had the bacon wrapped dates, but I would have to say that it was a little to spicy and little too sweet for my liking.  It was still incredible, but I think I was just expecting a little bit more.  The patatas bravas were excellent.  I liked that even more.

Its been a few years since we went here, but its still in my Top 10 all time meals so, while planning for a cross country trip, I felt compelled to drop in and write a review.We ordered the dates, a spin on a nicoise salad, the whole Branzino, and the nutter butter thinggies.   Every single thing we had was top notch, but Yelpers at the time stated that if the Branzino was on the menu ORDER it.  They could not have been more correct.  It was so simple and understated but I swear to god it was the best fish Ive ever eaten.  Deboned while keeping the body in tact and head on, stuffed with copious amounts of butter and fresh herbs, pan seared to the point of crispy skinned perfection and then finished in the oven to absolute flaky nirvana.  I really can't use enough superlatives for that dish.  Just get it if its available.The only real drawbacks to this place were the lack of reservations(we waited about an hour) and the tight communal seating.  Or course, that depends on who's next to you...... In our case we were seated next to an extremely obnoxious lady who f'ing sucked so bad.  I had to do some serious zen to not let her ruin my meal since your neighbor is no more than 2 feet away.  Luckily that excellent food and service served as a strong distraction from her loud ass mouth.
Excellent food! The paella and the pork shoulder was amazing!! They also give good portions for the price.

Incredible. One of the best meals in all of Chicago.The bacon-wrapped, chorizo-stuffed dates and the taleggio focaccia are the stuff of dreams. The wait was about two hours on Friday night, which wasn't bad considering you drink somewhere else while waiting and they text you when your table is ready. The decor and atmosphere were simple and rustic. It was a wonderful night with friends and fabulous food.Go. You won't be disappointed.

As I review some of the other reviews I can't help but have some doubt about my own perception of this restaurant. It's likely me, not them. But, nonetheless, I will continue with my 3 (gasp!) star review.First impression: Casual atmosphere with foo-foo menu items with which I have absolutely no familiarity.Menu: the menu made the dishes out to be complex.  I didn't quite know what was in each dish as my mastery of culinary lingo is incredibly subpar.  Not totally a big deal as, from my experience, high quality restaurants like this usually deliver on taste.Food: Overall everything was tasty and good.  Nothing was ever at the level of 'omg this is to die for' and conversely nothing came close to being spat out.  Everything was just...good!Chorizo stuffed dates (of course we got them- every single Yelp tip and review mandated the ordering and consumption of these ahhhhmaaaazzzing dates):  My thoughts:  they were.......good.  Nothing more, def nothing less.  I'm not going to rave about them as, for me, they don't deserve all the attention.Brussels Sprouts Salad: Good. (That is all)Mussels: Buuuuttttter!  (Which allows this item to hover between good and pretty good.) Lima beans were a good addition.Atmosphere:  Pretty cool vibe.  Casual environment.  We were seated at an upscale picnic-style table (if there is such a thing) which  was backed up against the wood wall.  Loved it until 3 different groups rolled through at various times throughout our meal and conversation, requiring us to stand up and allow them through.  At one point, whilst mid-chew, we stood up allowing a group to sit down beside us. However, the area in which we were standing became quite congested with the waiter who was attempting to deliver drinks, the new patrons, another table of ~5 getting up to leave, and us.  All ten of us were jockeying for position in 2'x2' space.  Whilst being excused this way and excused that way I was able to finish chewing the chorizo stuffed date with bacon.  Folks, the bacon made this situation tolerable. Therefore, I think the bacon (and I suppose the chorizo stuffed date to which it was attached) is due an upgrade on its ranking to 'great'! Ha.Anywho.  Everything was good. Glad I ate here once.  Unfortunately, I do not have a desire to go back at this time.Pro-tip:  weekday 6:30 seating was easy peasy.  7:30-9 it was hopping- people were waiting.

Avec was our final meal before departing Chicago, a last hurrah to the city and snow before we headed back to O'Hara. It's one of many successful restaurants under Paul Kahan, a wine-focused dining space that first opened in 2003. Although the restaurant has received more praise for the eclectic, ever-changing menu that pulls from many different cuisines and genres, it's nonetheless yet another quintessential Chicago restaurant.We arrived on the early end of a weekend brunch, as Avec does not take reservations; thankfully, at the time, there were only a few other parties present, so we were quickly greeted and seated at a table. The dining room is bright, featuring light woodwork, and the single row of dining tables in addition to the bar seating can be deemed minimalistic. It's a clear counter to the diversity of dishes found on their menu, which are small(er) plates, and best when shared. Each is as tempting as the last, and it's not difficult to overorder; three dishes is a good starting point between two people, unless, of course, you have sizable appetites like the two of us.One of the must-order dishes at Avec is the Chorizo-stuffed Medjool Dates. Lovers of the combination of sweet and savory will instantly appreciate this pairing, which consists of plump medjool dates stuffed with diced chorizo and then wrapped in a strip of smoky bacon. The dish is served in a spicy-tart piquillo pepper-tomato sauce, a perfect foil to the flavors, and can thankfully be ordered in a small (2) or large (4) size. We weren't as impressed with the Poached Eggs, which were served on sourdough with 'nduja, a condiment made of spicy, soft pork sausage. Perhaps it was the preserved lemon hollandaise, which tread towards being too acidic, but the pairing of ingredients didn't seem as harmonious.There's also a dish listed as the "Deluxe" Focaccia, a dish that wound up being the equivalent of a flatbread pizza. The focaccia was a commendable texture, simultaneously crisp and doughy, and held a center layer of ricotta. There were a few herbs to add some freshness as well as the all-too familiar drizzle of truffle oil; while delicious, it became rather heavy towards the halfway point. In hindsight, it would be better to serve a smaller portion of it as an appetizer, as it would make a perfect starter for a group. We barely had room for the Slow Roasted Pork Shoulder, a hefty serving of tender pork served in a lentil stew with onions, brussels sprouts, raisins, and a few slices of apple. It was a delicious and well seasoned dish, and ideal for the colder months, especially as the pork shoulder had just the right ratio of lean to fatty meat.I have to commend Avec on delivering a strong dining experience, from the delicious and well-executed food to the thoughtful service. They were kind enough to let us linger after our meal as we tried to figure out our next course of action (limited in scope given the nature of Chicago winters), and if we hadn't had to board a plane that afternoon, I'd have been tempted to return that evening for dinner.
Undoubtedly my favorite restaurant in Chicago. Never disappoints. Food is excellent. Only area that I have found in multiple cities that serves Basque cuisine.

I went here for dinner last night. The atmosphere is cute but you'll be sitting at a long table with other customers while you dine. I started with a red wine recommended by the waitress, the wine was really good and came in a cute little carafe. We started with the chorizo stuffed, bacon wrapped dates. Those were the highlight of the evening. I wish that they had an all you can eat option for them! For the entree, we ordered and split the paella which was huge. The dish was ok... I did like that they gave you large shrimp with the heads still on.So the last time we saw our waitress that evening was after we ordered our meal. I saw her going to other tables to socialize with her friends dining there that evening but she did not come back to our table. The customers sitting next to us had a different waitress who was very attentive to them. The water guy saved the day for us. He was on top of making sure our water glasses were full and our eating space was clean. He even got us the check!

Fantastic service and food. Everything I ordered was great including a few Tom Collins. The concept may not be for everyone, it's loud and no reservations (you may have to wait 30 minutes as I did) are taken but if that sounds OK Avec is an ideal place to have exauisite food in a less formal setting.

We ended up here because girl and the goat was a 90 minute wait. It was the second choice but were were very happy with the food.A nice bottle of Spanish red, no domestic wines.We started with the bacon wrapped chorizo stuffed date, wow!  I wasn't expecting the flavor blast, spicy, sweet, crazy good. The order came with 4 so good to split with 1 other person - you can't have just 1.We then had the steak and humus. This was also good but it was such a mild flavor it did not compete with the dates. This dish should have been served first.We then had the pork shoulder/butt. Very tender and nice portion for two.The bread was fresh, chewy inside and crunchy outside. It was a nice compliment to each dish.The staff was nice and helpful.I might go higher on the rating but the place was too loud to really enjoy the company I was with. I don't mind the communal tables but the volume was too much for me.

Avec had an inspiring menu with amazing food!  You know when you feel like you're a decent cook and you go out to eat and leave feeling like you could've made that?  Not this place!  I wish I had even a quarter of the skills that this chef had.  Yum!

Came to Avec to celebrate my boo thang's birthday and upon arriving at 6:32pm we were told the wait would be about 47 minutes and we could go have a drink else where and they would text us when it was time to be seated.So seeing how I needed to get to my 10K step goal for the day we walked around and found a bar to drink (water for me) and wait at. About 30 minutes later we got the text that a spot at Avec's bar was awaiting us and we had 10 minutes to get back. Our hungry gave us that Carl Lewis speed we needed to walk/run back 4 blocks.We got back with 2 minutes to spare and was seated at the bar directly in front of the stove which was awesome because we got to interact with the staff and watch all the food be cooked.Everything we ate was truly amazing! Also, the staff was friendly, funny and offered up great recommendations. I will definitely be back coming back to Avec again. If you haven't dined here yet, well you need to ASAP.For our meal we decided to get*Cheese selection: I believe we got Montenebro from  Spain, Comte St. Antoine from France and  Robiola Rochetta from Italia. Each bite of these cheeses had this dairy lover on cloud 9.*Chorizo stuffed Medjool Dates blew my f'ing mind. These dates will good you food dreams that will have you drooling when you wake up. The spiciness of the chorizo paired with the sweetness of the Medjool Dates set my taste buds to dancing and the bacon wrapped around the dates just topped it off perfectly. These are must tries!*Charred octopus which was so fresh, so flavorful, so good!*Kibbeh Sausage which was pump and juicy.*Squid Ink Pasta with Sardines was the perfect way course to end our dining experience. I never had sardines before and I'll probably never eat them again...unless the chef at Avec is making them for me.

Came here for dinner on a Saturday night with my friend. We didn't have reservations but we got seated within ten minutes at the bar. We decided to go with the small plates and got the stuffed dates, glazed steak, and gyro sausage. The stuffed dates were really good. A perfect combo of sweet and savory. The steak was cooked perfectly and had a nice flavor. However neither one of us liked the gyro sausage. The spices and flavors were a bit too powerful for this plate. Overall a good experience however it does get really loud with the large groups.

Am I the only one that found every dish here way too salty? We ordered the dates, calamari, and pork shoulder, and all three dishes were way too salty to enjoy. This was my second time here, and I wanted to like it, but again, like the first time I came, the salt overpowered any other flavor.Service was fine but not overtly friendly. It's less busy when you come for an early dinner. Overall, I still don't get the hype of this place...

Avec is all about the dates, pork shoulder, and taleggio focaccia. The dates are exceptionally flavorful, a nice mix of sweet and savory with a hearty chorizo stuffing and bacon wrapping (thanks, Publican Quality Meats!) I would drink shots of the piquillo pepper sauce.The preparation of the pork shoulder varies, but it's always incredibly tender and a very large portion. The latest rendition I've tried, with smoked clams and arugula, was very, very salty - hopefully that was just a one-off occurrence.And man, I'm not a fan of truffle oil in most foods, but I think it actually pairs really well with the soft taleggio in the focaccia.I'd love to try Avec's other offerings...it's just hard to stray from the staples above. A bit pricey, but generally worth it.

First of all, wow.A friend of mine and I went to Avec as a part of our restaurant hopping trip in the west loop of Chicago, and this has now become my favorite place to eat.I had a couple of small plates like the Chicken liver patte, Steak w/ hummus & walnut, and lastly, their well-known chorizo-stuffed bacon-wrapped dates, all of which I HIGHLY recommend.We were also lucky enough to sit at the chef's table and talk to the chef as he was cooking, which was also fantastic. It's decently crowded as deserved, but the service is fantastic.Highly recommended!

Went to Avec for lunch today - it was absolutely delicious! I highly recommend the chorizo stuffed dates and the lamb burger. The portions were decent sized too. The one area for improvement would be how close together everyone was sitting - we felt like we were on top of each other. Thank goodness we didn't have to use the restroom mid-meal.

Avec: one of the most amazing places you'll ever eat, but the ambiance is what kills it for me. You'll either love it or hate it. I don't recommend going in a large group, the place is small, no reservations, and seating is cramped and it's a pain in the neck to get up to use the restroom. It's like sitting in an airplane (you're that close to total strangers, and you could be seated in the middle between them - the tables are large and not broken up). Someone is always having to get up and interrupt their meal to let someone else out to use the restroom. It can be awkward for this reason. Service is good. Sometime feels rushed. But the food and drinks... Phenomenal. You must get the pork shoulder & dates. Always go for dessert as well. Don't miss it. It's hard to go wrong here with anything on the menu. This place is high energy but it's got the 5 star reputation for a reason.

If you don't mind communal tables, then do take the chance and have a meal here. The food is superb!! Nothing super fancy but a very good interesting take on some dishes you know and you realise how could they can actually taste.For example, we have had the dates wrapped with bacon and the deluxe focaccia with truffle oil. Both are dishes that we had had before but we were amazed how great they tasted here in contrast to other places we had visited.The atmosphere is also laid back and the staff is really friendly and attentive. Without doubt amongst the best places in Chicago!
All of the dishes we've ordered were excellent!I highly recommend the chorizo-stuffed dates and chicken liver crostini.Service was good, the staff was very knowledgeable about the food/menus.

This was definitely one of the most disappointing dining experiences i've had this year. Everything I ate (with the exception of the bread, I felt I could have cooked better myself and for a fraction of the price. I also found the seating style to be obscene and obnoxious: we were seated in the middle and we finished eating before the party at the end, so two of the three of them had to stand up IN THE MIDDLE OF THEIR MEAL to let us out. I think communal seating can be okay when you're in the mood for it, but not like this...you should be able to get up without disrupting an entire table.Here's what we ate:Chicken Liver Crostini: This was the first thing they brought to the table. It took them 30 minutes (which was confusing because it's clear that they had the liver pate sitting in the fridge and just spooned it into the container they served it in...there's no reason it should have taken that long, especially considering that they brought the second dish out (a hot one) 5 minutes after we started eating that one. This was pretty good. If you like chicken liver you will appreciate this...but it wasn't exceptionalBrandade: This was the second dish that was served. This was decent but WAY too salty (they buttered the bread with salted butter and then generously seasoned the fish as well.Trout with shrimp:  The trout was cooked very well, but the shrimp were not good...the quality just did not seem good (maybe farmed and previously frozen).Pork Shoulder: This had to be the biggest culinary disappointment of the night. The conceptualization of this dish was ridiculous: Pork with clams in a salty broth covered in creamy yogurt sitting in "cracked wheat" that is soaking in the broth. WHY? I would definitely avoid this one.Amaretto Cake with Peaches:  This was okay, but it did not seam fresh...we agreed that it must have been sitting in the fridge for hours (not in a good way...like, maybe hours was actually days).The Alcoholic Ginger beer was excellent (it's bottled, not something they make in house); I thought the cucumber cocktail was not good, but my boyfriend liked it (I would only recommend it if you really really love artificial cucumber flavor).I've given this 3 stars because I think the technique was there, but the flavors, execution, and concept are are not great.P. S. they put a ton of raw parsley on EVERY DISH with the exception of the cake.

A place that doesn't take reservations is always hyped up. Expecting to wait, we came in and put our names down and then headed next door to Salero for some cocktails.We waited about 45-1hr and were seated at the end of one of the communal tables. I don't know that I like this way of dining, especially when it's a nicer spot and not say, a sandwich place.We had an unruly group of people next to us that were several cocktails in when we got there, and then still ordering drinks when we left. The whole time they were yelling, laughing at crazy volumes. I should state the men were the ooc ones, the ladies with them were well mannered.We order a mix of plates - we didn't the infamous dates - might have to grab em at some point. Since we love meat, we had the lamb, pork shoulder, steak and then a fish pate to get some variety. Also had a wine. Everything was good and the pork was outstanding. We had more than enough left and took some pork to go.We liked the food but I don't know that it's one is the best dining experiences I've had in Chicago. Still happy that we tried it as its right near our home. Worth a try and maybe you'll get a more tame group next to you!

AVEC ... So far I had a great pleasure to enjoy few lunches.The Vibe - I'm not a fan of communal tables, but their bar area is very comfortable and the people behind the bar are friendly and fun to chat.The Service -  excellent!The FOOD - I believe this in my #1 lunch spot. The menu is not big , but it has plenty of choices. You can go healthy or hearty , vegetarian or not :). I'm not a vegetarian , but I respect my company, and I value a lot a place where different personas can enjoy quality food without compromise or asking to substitute.When you go through the menu everything looks temptingly , and then when you finally make a choice and get your order ...
