Burgers are not just  patty of meat, they are flavorful and each burger has a distinct taste.Kuma's corner and Hot Doug' (closed now) are two places which I hold at very high regard in Chicago area. They are true to the hype and don't disappoint ever.If you have never visited the place, please make sure you try it once. Cheers!

Kuma's offers BIG food for burger lovers. You won't find such juiciness elsewhere.Visiting Chicago, I did my research on Yelp on some of the best eats. Of course I saw Kuma's with it's 4,000+ reviews. Thousands of reviews can only mean that it's popular among Chicago citizens. Furthermore, a good friend of mine raves about this place saying he could eat it every single day if he had enough to afford it.This was the first meal I had in Chicago and I was shocked by the portion size. You better come ravenous cause there is going to be a lot of food. Since it was my first time, my friend agreed to split a burger and mac-n-cheese with me. You build your own mac-n-cheese here by choosing two toppings. You can choose additional toppings for an additional cost. We decided to go with the chicken and the sweet corn. For the burger, we shared a Mastadon which had BBQ sauce, bacon, sharp cheddar and frizzled onions. The burgers are recommended to be medium although they will do the wellness to your preference. I was very pleased that they will give you exactly what you ask for. Medium is medium and you can see the pink and juices on the inside. Cutting the burger in half felt like a sin but it needed to be done so I could have my half! The meat patty is so meaty and thick. The BBQ sauce is slathered everywhere and I love the texture of the frizzled onions. It adds that hint of onion slice you would get on a normal burger but in it's own fried way. The bun is a good vessel but I do find that it gets a little soggy. Each burger comes with fries. They are so dark that I almost that they were sweet potato fries. The fries are pretty average in my opinion, nothing too special.The mac-n-cheese was delicious! The bowl and portion is giant. I have never seen so much mac-n-cheese in my life. Between my friend and I we only got through half the thing. It's perfectly cheesy in every way possible. I never thought of putting chicken in mac-n-cheese but I really liked the combination with the corn. Each piece of chicken was small enough to be present in each bite, without feeling like you were just eating slices of chicken. I love how the sweet corn added some texture and pop of sweetness to the rich and salty cheese. I would recommend sharing the mac-n-cheese with someone!Service was great. Our waitress was witty and had some humor. Food came out promptly and we were checked up on at the right times.There is just something really comforting about eating such fatty burgers and ridiculously giant mac-n-cheese. I can see why my friend loves this place and hopefully I can come back to eat it with him again.

It was good. Not crazy about the pulled pork fries but the burgers were delicious. Big selection of beer. Nice little outside area. Serving was excellent! Our waitress was very attentive and super nice. Definitely will come back.

This nice little cafe is in the Museum Campus area, very close to my friend Kevin's condo, so it is convenient when we go visit.The star of the show is the beautiful and mostly shaded outdoor patio.   When the weather is nice, you see people enjoying their food in this nice setting...dog and child friendly, you also see many of them at this eatery.The food is very good, but it can be a bit on the pricey side.    The breakfast tradition is a plate with eggs, bacon and home fries.   Very good !They also have an inside section that has big windows and it overlooks the corner of Indiana and 18th.Super friendly and super hip.

I really want to love this place. Instead, each time I've gone, I leave feeling whelmed (not totally overwhelmed, not totally underwhelmed).Big shoutout to the 63 degree egg. That thing is a custardy, velvety, poached egg of my dreams. I love it. But it is $12 bucks for a breakfast that comes with that, some potatoes and 1 piece of dry sausage. I really appreciate that it is handmade, and feels super fresh, but it is not that much food at all. And it is served on a pretty big plate, making it seem a bit sad. (there is toast, so that makes a different for a lot of people. But I can't eat gluten, so that went to a friend).My three stars were almost 4, but not quite.

We tried it again cuz the patio was so appealing, which we realized is the only draw to this place. My wife got the chicken sandwich and it looked like a 4-year-old put it together. It was like big chunks of chicken with some mayo between two untoasted pieces of bread.I got the pasta carbonara and my wife got the double cheeseburger. Both were surprisingly good, but the portion sizes were too small for the price. We left a little bugged that we were still hungry after spending a good amount for a cafe.

Food is disgusting, unfriendly service. But they have a nice patio space.We ordered a carbonara and a rib. The carbonara is the worst I've ever had. The spaghetti was overcooked. The carbonara sauce is burnt. I asked the server and he said it was suppose to be like that because it was garlic, and didn't do anything to fix the problem. The rib was a bit better. It was edible, but the rib is still overcooked.The owner said the black burnt particles are "frico" (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fr…). I admitted that I'm not familiar with that, but I still stand by my review that they tasted burnt.The only good part of this restaurant is the outdoor patio space.
Owners are the nicest people ever! Happy to be hosting my birthday their again for the 2nd year in a row! XO

Felt like doing a chillax Sunday brunch this morning where I would be able to bring dogs.  I have mine plus a friends that I'm watching for the week.  The spot was found on Yelp as offering brunch and allowing dogs.  Nice large courtyard, with plenty of tables.  There is some street parking, but be careful not to park in a permit only zone.  That would make for a no funday Sunday.  The server was friendly and brought us water bowls.  You have to go inside to place your order and pay, but then food is brought out.  It actually only 13 minutes from the time we ordered until the time we received our food.  Realistically the best thing about this place is the large outdoor courtyard with shade of a big tree.I ordered the quinoa porridge with quinoa puffs, scallions, egg, and pecorino cheese.  I also ordered a side of the grits.  He ordered the pancakes with bacon jam, whiskey butter, maple and bourbon syrup.  To be honest (and I love the feel of porridge), it was too watery for my liking, and maybe making it a bit bland, not starchy enough.  The egg I was told was cooked in a circulator, and the reason it was barely cooked looking.  Sous vide to be PC.  Held to a temperature of 140°F, will become firmly set enough to hold their basic shape, though the slightest provocation will cause them to crack and split. Loose white...watery and loose, and the yolk was indistinguishable from raw. I think I would prefer it slightly cooked more, poached even, for texture anyway.  I sent it back, and then it came back completely opposite.  Dry quinoa, and the chef suggested over medium (edges slightly browned).  It lacked salt, so, I was....well...I lost my appetite for it.  The grits were tasty enough, and I enjoyed the cheese, however, someone was very heavy handed with the black pepper.  Whoa!  Kinda can't taste my own own taste buds.  The pancakes were a good sized portion, but a wee bit dry.  The syrup (said to be a bourbon maple), sure had the bourbon in it, but very hard for me to distinguish if it was actually maple or more like pancake syrup with bourbon, Hmmmm... The bacon jam was spot on!  The whiskey butter to moisten the pancakes would have been amazing had it not been for the scallions/chives in it.  The bitterness completely threw the whole thing off whack.  Not a lack of execution, but definitely a lack of formulation.As for the pastries inside, some were underneath glass domes and fresh, and the others (I had read that people were upset they were wrapped in cellophane) looked fresh, but because you have to keep baked goods covered (health regulations), I fully understand why they are wrapped.I don't think we'll be back, but its off my list to try.

Just Disappointing... I can totally appreciate the fact that it takes a few minutes to make a good cup of coffee or espresso and would never complain about a short necessary wait. However, this morning my wife and I waited about 30 min for two "Americanos" as I watched 5-6 people behind me in line ordering and receiving their food and drinks. Upon enquiring about our order I was told it was up next. The barista gave his apologies all around and I asked how others received their order before me. He said "we're not really an in & out coffee shop, plus our orders are just piled up on the counter and they get mixed up and some people are just like I gotta get outta here so we try to get them taken care of"... Then I asked the cashier/barista if the orders were numbered and she said "yes they are, but i did tell you there was gonna be a wait right"? No, she did not. In fact, I felt like I was lucky walking in just before they got busy. Little did I know I would be waiting longer than anyone else in there, literally. I'm ver sorry but we won't be returning, especially since it's not an in & out coffee shop which is what we regular patrons go for.

Food was okay, nothing amazing. The latte was good, nice and strong. The homemade ketchup was delicious.My friend got a sausage that was raw in the middle. Wouldn't go back for food, but I would stop by for coffee.

Was staying close by at the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place, and wanted to go somewhere for breakfast we could walk to. EVERYTHING was delicious. As another reviewer mentioned, the patio area is beautiful and large, with plenty of available seating. As it was quite breezy when we arrived, we opted to sit inside, where there is also a great amount of seating and is super lovely. The breakfast sandwich is BOMB! One of the most perfect sunny-side-up eggs I have ever had with the tastiest spicy mayo and smoky ham! Not normally a fan of spicy mayo, but decided to throw caution to the wind -- it was not super spicy and was almost a little more tangy than spicy -- so delish! My dad got their traditional breakfast with rye bread -- AMAZING! Some of the best rye bread we have ever had. As my dad was born and raised in New York City, he has some high standards for rye bread. Service was quick, fantastic, and friendly. All in all, it was an incredible breakfast that we were not expecting and started our day off on a good foot!

You know those beautiful, late(ish) Spring days you get every so often in Chicago?  You know the one where you sit in the sun and have a beer at the perfect place?  Well that was Saturday and the place was Spoke & Bird...My wife and I had just finished helping out at the Anti-Cruelty Society's "Bark-in-the-Park" fund raiser south of Soldier Field.  We fired up Yelp and found that Spoke & Bird was just about due west of our location and off we went...First and foremost, their outside area is quite nice.  There are sunny areas (when the weather cooperates) and shady areas and the whole space is quite large.  So large in fact that the tables turn fairly quickly which is nice.  (Note: The inside dining looked great too)   We got in line, ordered our food, and got a number.  Personally, I like this approach.  I feel like it enables them to focus on the food.  Also, were told, in advance, that the food may take some extra time which was also nice to know.My wife ordered the Mac & Cheese and I had the BLT (s&blt?)  I gave her meal a taste and it was quite good but I really focused on the BLT.  The bacon was amazing and the tomatoes (I am not normally a sliced tomato fan) where perfect.  Both came with homemade potato salad, which was quite good as well.  The portions are big enough to want stop and take some home which we both did.The overall value is quite good.  Even their beer prices are decent.  All in all I have to say 4 stars with an addition star for allowing me to dine with Al Fresco.   I am glad Yelp! led us to Spoke & Bird.

Recommend for a nice breakfast spot. Lovely outdoor patio where you can enjoy a morning up of coffee and eggs. The interior certainly has your "coffee bar" kind of vibe so wasn't too sure how the food quality would be due to kitchen size, etc. I was pleasantly surprised to receive a nice "home cooked" style breakfast sandwich on a nice whole wheat English muffin, freshly cooked egg, and a good portion of ham plus some great tasting hashbrowns with homemade ketchup! Quality of the coffee is high and enjoyably flavorful.One of the previous comments chimed in on price... that would be the only thing I would negatively critique on my breakfast as well. It was good, but at just north of $20 don't feel it was the best value for money. Nevertheless, the chirping birds and lovely weather on the patio makes it easier to forget the price.

I walked over from my office for lunch on a Friday. My pasta carbonara was filling, but did not have a farm egg and was loaded with cracked pepper to the point that it dominated the dish. The service was pretty good though and the patio is a really nice and peaceful place to sit outside and enjoy your lunch. Not sure if I would be back though for the food.Updated: Came back a second time hoping for better results. No dice. Again, lovely patio and I did enjoy sitting in the nice fall breeze, but not enough to raise my previous star rating. I order the $13.50 Lambecue Sandwich and was grossly underwhelmed.  The potato salad that came on the side was ridiculously over-salted. The 'lamb' came on Texas toast knifed with a dollop of mayo; basically it was the two fattiest pieces of meat you could possibly find slid between two pieces of read. If I had Thanksgiving leftovers and was wasted off my ass I could have probably assembled a better tasting concoction myself.

I am incredibly sad to see how the quality and quantity of the dishes is reducing  every time I come to this place.The ambiance is what makes me give a 3 star.I live in the neighborhood, and the owners are the most honest, and friendly people.Great place to work!

It was a nice day out and we were out in South Loop. We went here to get dinner, but it's more of a casual breakfast/brunch/lunch place. You order inside and then you can sit down outside at the tables. Food was okay. Like I said, more of a lunch place.Nothing wrong with this place, but it doesn't stand out in my opinion.
Literary cafè ,I like the daisy, the Mac & CheeseEverything here just right~Comfortable and relax, especially the rainy day, even more poetic

I'm very happy I came across this place just a short walk from my hotel.Spoke & Bird is very "cute" - very nicely decorated in a simplistic way. Outdoor seating is very quaint and relaxing. There is also plenty of indoor seating for those cooler days.The first time I ate here, I was somewhat unimpressed with the food. I had the kids scrambled eggs and toast which were kind of bland and just plain forgettable. However, I gave Spoke & Bird a second try and ordered the egg sandwich with ham....YUM! It was full of flavor and downright delicious.I also had hot chocolate which was very rich and delicious! It hit the spot just right.This is a great place with a great vibe and for the most part, great food. Definitely worth giving a try!
Spoke & Bird is a neighborhood gem! The outdoor space is generous for outdoor dining. Great spot for just a coffee, breakfast, lunch or early dinner. Dog friendly patio! I love it!

Really cute little space with a lot of outdoor seating.  Pretty good beer selections, and a nice spot to stop into for a quick bite to eat.  I had the BLT, which didn't blow me away, but was pretty good.  Nice tomatoes, toasted bread, nice bacon.  So I was happy with it.  I wasn't a huge fan of the potato salad.  Otherwise, a really solid casual place.

Yes to beverages. It's a good spot to get coffee and sit outside (which is the reason why I go here).  The seating area has a lot of shade and is in a nice location near the Woman's Park.Food is meh. Ordered Mac and cheese and noticed the taste of black pepper more than cheese.  I visited another time and ordered the jam burger with home fries.  The fries had a ridiculous amount of pepper on it again, but no salt. Someone cooking these dishes loves their pepper. On the plus side, staff is always friendly. Not thrilled with their food, but coffee is decent enough to come back for the nice patio area.

Rode past this place a few times and finally decided to stop in. Nice ambiance and wonderful patio.Unfortunately, the food bombed pretty bad. I ordered a burger with some home fries. The burger was unexpectedly tiny for the steep price. The weird thing was that the patties were ridiculously salty - and this is coming from someone who loves salt. The rest of the toppings were alright. The home fries were barely salted at all and were also nothing special.On a positive note - their ketchup is really good.I wish I had read some of these reviews before I came by. Pretty expensive for meh food. I'd probably go back to have a drink on that patio, though.

It's a great little coffee shop to meet up at. The seating and the setting was cozy. The chai latte was pretty good but it was served slightly warm...it wasn't hot enough. I was able to drink it quickly. The boy didn't seen to care for the latte he had. We didn't get to try the food but it looked good as we some plates pass by. We just ordered some scones and muffins which were pretty good.

Two stars because the guy behind the counter making the burger patties was very pleasant to have a conversation with before getting served.  We got two coffees and a bowl of "cheesy grits".  Two stars on the coffee---description said it had "Cramel" flavor---we laughed.  Negative two stars on the grits.I lived in South Carolina for 15 years and love grits.  These grits were awful.  There were purplish colored flecks in the grits, it was loaded with too much butter, and it had some unknown, not good cheese.  Then the texture of the grits was weird---it was a cross between instant grits mixed with stone grounds grits and not in a good way at all.  It was almost like they put the instant and stone ground grits in the microwave together at the same time and hit go.  My wife and I deemed them the worst grits ever made!  Grits are simple and you have to work to screw them up.Revamp your recipe: Stone grounds grits, bring to boil, then simmer, add salt, a little pepper, a spat of butter, then add an ok amount of cheddar cheese---just enough to add flavor and bind the grits a bit but too much and you have lost it.  Serve it with a buttermilk biscuit and you will have a home run!  Please work on it and let me know when I can come back.Owner's comments:Comment from Alicia B. of The Spoke & BirdBusiness Owner6/4/2016  Matthew,That wacky "Cramel flavor" gets em every time. We thought we'd reach out before we share your review with the staff. Two stars - for an entire restaurant because you didn't like the grits?We'll make sure to "work on it" and after we do... just wait for us to call, you know, so you know it's safe to come back.All the bestResponse:Alicia:I gave Spoke & Bird a bad review for the awful grits.  You then decide to post snide remarks, instead of owning up the shortcomings in making grits.  When I took my dish back into the restaurant, I asked the staff where should I put my bowl.  A kind staffer said she would take it and clearly saw that the bowl was still full.  I got a weird look from her and thought normally someone would ask if I didn't like the item.   Instead she took it and walked away.  I now presume that she is used to people returning the grits.  She did not even offer to refund me the $5.00 that I paid for that abomination of a southern staple.Now, I see that you are upset---as I can tell in your passive aggressive tone---that Spoke & Bid only got two stars.  Actually, my written review gave you negative two stars for the grits, which is now updated for one star due to you.  I have only visited your place once---in most instances you may have only one shot with a customer.  I made an food ordered, which you represented as edible, and your establishment took my money.  I was served something that was inedible and I will always believe that those were the worst grits ever served.  That was, and will be, the basis of my experience with your place---nothing more, nothing less.  I have zero desire---after my first experience coupled with your response---to really try anything else on your menu.I noticed that in one of your reviews you thanked someone for their positive review and you said you were glad that everything was good.  However, I notice that when the review is not so good, you go after the reviewer.  It is not my fault that you cannot make proper grits or failed at making grits.  So instead of me waiting on you to "work on it" or for you to "call me" when it is "safe to come back," I'll just take my money and go elsewhere, never to return to your business.Matthew06/07/2016:So now it seems I am to blame because you "employee [sic] a lot of college student[s]" and haven't trained them.  That is somehow my fault and not yours as the business owner.And you impugn my ethics and morals because you have made the worst grits ever served?  I am pretty sure you cannot find worse grits than yours!Matthew

The only thing this place has going for it - is the beautiful outdoor seating. I live in the neighborhood and decided to give this a try for a Sunday brunch.You have to order and pay at the counter, then the food is brought out to you at the table. The ordering place is tiny and awkward if there are more than a few people in line. Hubby ordered the strata and I ordered the mushroom omelette entree - I requested for less chees and only for egg whites. We sat outside - which is great for summer. There are a lot of families with dogs (dogs are allowed) and the atmosphere is very nice. The downer is the food. FOr the kind of prices that they charge, I expect the food to be very good. The strata was two small pieces with a side salad. It was practically burnt. Not on the inside, but the outside crust was black with a few spots of non-black surface. Very bad!!! My omelette was ok - greasy but they made the substitutions that I had requested for. There is a surcharge for only egg whites. So I paid upwards of 11$ for an egg white omelette - which came with nothing else. Not even a piece of toast. Its a total rip off for the quality of the food served. I still give it two stars - and that is only for their outdoor seating, 'cos its very charming.

Spoke and Bird is a wonderful addition to the South Loop.  Some notes:1. Best damn home potatoes I've ever eaten. For reals. Disagree? I'll refund your money. And never speak to you again2. The care the kitchen puts into all its food. Take a few moments and watch how much time they spend preparing a humble beet. The eggs are always perfectly prepared. This is not your usual north side 10 pound omelet. This is fresh local ingredients, perfectly prepared each time.3. The best damn patio in the city. Ok, outside of the lake or river. Big patio next to Woman's Park, but far enough from Michigan Ave to enjoy a conversation.Why only four stars? I'm obsessed with iced mochas, and they are still fine tuning the chocolate.

This is a nice independent coffee shop, with a beautiful outdoor seating area for the summer. They use local farm products and has a somewhat hipster vibe.Unfortunately their food is a disaster. I'll never forget the day they had a meatball over dirty rice special. I thought that could not be bad. It was roughly 90% pork fat.

Came to Spoke and Bird for the first time to check out the Pints of Science presentation going on that evening.  First impressions were great.  Ordering at the counter was easy, menu sounded appetizing, staff was pleasant, and the patio was huge and inviting.  We ordered two beers, two jamburgers, a side of potatoes and mixed salad.  The beer was reasonably priced, we got a seat out on the patio, and then the disappointment started.  The food took over an hour to get out to our table, when it did come out the food was cold.  I understand being busy, but why was the food delivered cold?  That means the food had to be sitting out for at least 15 minutes before it got to us.  The Jamburger was decent, but it sounds much better on the menu than it tastes.  Five Guys is arguably a better burger.  The potatoes were terrible, they were burnt, cold, and clearly had been sitting out for some time.  The small side salad was good, but I think it takes a special type of person to really mess up a salad.  So why am I giving this place 3 stars? Because the patio is awesome.  The breakfast menu sounds good, so I'm going to come back and give it another shot.  If breakfast sucks too, then I'm done with this place.

The place/ambience looks decent from outside. Decided to give it a try despite the rather low reviews since I live in the area any way. The setup is a little strange where you go order on one side of the building and then go find a seat in the hallway or in the room on the other side. Kinda like corner bakery system.The food took about 40 minutes to come out. Portions were extremely small for the price tag. Not particular good either. We got the carbonara and bird burger. The pasta was about a 5 oz portion with sprinkles of bacon bits. The burger is a size of a white castle slider with bigger meat patties.Coffees were ok, not great. If you're here for the atmosphere, maybe itz ok. I would pass for the food.We also noticed there were cases of milk just left out there in the hallway the entire time we were there. Not sure how long milk can stay good without being refridgerated.With all that said, i would pass on this place and go visit a starbucks instead.

I came here a couple times while traveling on business and staying close by. I was there on a Mon and Tues and everything was great. The coffee was really good. It's a strong flavor, nutty espresso like great ones I've had at many other independent coffee shops. The breakfast was really good. I tried the classic and the eggs and beans the other day. This is not a traditional place but a place for those wanting quality product with a unique taste.  It's not cheap but neither is Starbucks.

All local food, everything I have eaten here is delicious. Grilled cheese, egg sandwich, pup, mushroom sandwich, pancakes, oatmeal, muffins, you name it and it was amazing. The service is quick for such interesting dishes, oh and the grits! They are to die for!

Sometimes restarants just try too hard to be original. I hate it when I end up wasting money on places like this one.My wife and I live in the neighborhood and she had been wanting to check it out. Like previous comments, the location is rather intelligent and the outdoor seating is great (minus the red bugs crawling all over the place).The ordering area is like a 7-eleven...rather awkward as people sometimes have to cross in front of you to get to the indoor seating or to pickup the beverages in their open cooler. Needless to say, the prices being so high led me to believe that the serving size would be fairly sizable and the the taste, excellent.Not so much...Food was not good. The horseradish or mustard on my brisket nearly choked me everytime I took a bite. The sides were not that great. My wife's turkey burger was very dry and like ground turkey. The portions were not large either. AND... No bbq sauce. I didn't find that out until we got the food. The sauce they gave me was absolutely horrid.Great concept and location. The name will get you in. The food, however, will take you and keep you out and away from this place.

My wife and I just moved to the neighborhood after 10yrs in Lakeview, and were very excited to try a neighborhood place. We were very impressed.On April 1, we stopped in for a lunch. The ordering is funky as you walk in and see the cashier off to the left, but the quirkiness is endearing. You figure it out pretty quick. I ordered a smoked hotdog sandwich, a Lagunitas Little Sumpin Sumpin and my wife had a BLT.Prices are above average, but so is the food quality. Everything was incredibly fresh- my smoked dog could have been plucked from a perfect July cookout, and the bacon on my wife's dish was perfectly thick and crispy. We waited about 15mins for food to arrive and we devoured everything. It is worth the wait and pricing; they set an expectation and met it.In fact, we were motivated to stop in on Sunday April 3rd in the afternoon- their gorgeous, tree-covered patio outback was open, so we ordered a PBR and enjoyed the 70 degree weather.This was a well-above average lunch with great beer selections to boot. The patio is a treasure. You are missing out if you're a South Looper and don't stop by.

My parents, husband, and I visited the Spoke & Bird cafe for the first time a few weeks ago for Sunday lunch and had such a lovely meal in the indoor dining room. Altogether we ordered the chicken sandwich, jamburger, mac n cheese, brisket sandwich, sweet potato soup, and Bavarian pretzel. Everything came out perfect and my mom and I especially loved the unique pottery the dishes are served in. Every item seemed to include a little extra something to make it special, be it a housemade bun, seasonal side, or delicious sauce/spread. (Don't miss out on their housemade ketchup with the home fries!) We found free parking on Indiana and took a walk through the adjacent garden afterwards. All around great spot!

I don't write reviews often, but The Spoke & Bird truly warrants one as a casual spot that really makes a neighborhood great. The south loop is full of fancy, rather impersonal condos, but this place and its staff exude character and personality. Food and drinks are very reasonably priced and the perfect complement to a shady seat on their outdoor patio or inside. Also, their involvement with--and support of--many local non-profit organizations is tremendous and worthy of significant recognition.Long story short, The Spoke & Bird is one of just a few places that makes Chicago home.

I don't write one-star reviews lightly. This place really deserves it.I came here for brunch with my girlfriend around 10:30. There was a line and the place was pretty full. Seemed like a good sign. But the food took an hour to arrive at our table. I checked with the cashier after about 25 minutes and was told that it takes 30 minutes for food, but it would be about 10 more minutes.20 minutes later, my girlfriend checked again and a server told her she should ask the kitchen staff directly. Weird. But she asked and they explained to her there was a fire in the kitchen, which delayed all the orders. They said it would be about 10 more minutes.15 minutes later, the food comes out. My "classic" breakfast was subpar. Small portions. The eggs (over easy) were cold, and covered in pepper. Home fries and sausage were lukewarm. If there was a fire in the kitchen that delayed the food prep, why wasn't the food hot?Girlfriend had the carbonara, which was also lukewarm and nearly flavorless. Her coffee was full of coffee grounds. Probably the only thing I liked about the whole meal was the jam on the toast. Even there they only give you about a half a teaspoon worth. The sausage was all right too, but would've been better hot. We ended up going to get a pizza after leaving here starving.Great concept, but extremely poor execution. We won't be back.

Burger. Whoooaaa.Aggressively made. Super delicious.Unless you're just down for a snack they recommend getting at least a Double.  I opted for the *asterisk*, which indicated a complementary fried egg that comes on the Triple upon request.  Well, saddle me one up!The freshly made bun was key.  The tomato jam had a ton of flavor. And the egg just blended all the flavors together in gooey goodness.It was honestly a killer burg and totally worth it.  Dare you to try the Quad!

Food was ok, nothing special. My iced mocha was well made, real chocolate.Also had a black coffee, but it didn't taste very good, very tart.Too hot in the back room. There wasn't any Wifi and they were blaring very bad jazz.

The coffee here is amazing. Not the espresso but the drip coffee. Espresso beverages are a little lacking, unfortunately. The staff is very friendly and personable so I really love coming here for my morning cup of coffee.The food is really very overpriced given the neighborhood and the portion sizes. I think I've actually gotten a meal here once because of how off putting the prices are. $5 for a muffin that is on the small side? What? No thank you.I did get the brownie once and it was divine.The maple bourbon pancakes were good but the butter wasn't as described and it didn't go with the flavor of the pancakes which was a disappointment because I really love butter. Felt like I wasted my money a bit.My partner loves their breakfast sandwiches and the potatoes are pretty good. This item is actually reasonably priced so we order it pretty regularly.

This location is near a very beautiful park. As soon as I went in I knew I was in for some good homemade breakfast. Everything seemed so original and every detail perfected. I ordered a kid's menu $4 double pancake, then some hot chocolate. The pancakes were whole wheat, or sort of brownish, which probably means they're healthy. The hot chocolate was delicious to say the least. They have home-made ketchup sauce, is that cool or what?I thing I wished to have seen would be either colder water or ice for my water, but everything else was so perfect that I quickly forgave them for it. Come in and dine with your family or group of friends. Enjoy the cozy inside sitting area or the open-air seating in the back. This sure is a cute place to come with my girlfriend ;)

Cure little coffee shop. Feels cozy and warm being in there. I've had the mocha, and just regular coffee and I think I prefer the regular hot coffee over the mocha. Both delicious, however very pricey. The chocolate chip cookie was amazing too! Love this place!

I just finished the brisket sandwich on rye which was pared perfectly with a homemade potato salad. I also had home fries drizzled with homemade ketchup. Everything was outstanding. Perfect meal before the Bear's game. I will be back.

Very good, but not great. The reason I give it only four stars is that the food is far over-priced for the uniqueness. The basic premise is American standard fare with upscale twists (organic, cage-free turkey burger with artisan bacon jam). The biggest upside to this place is the location - right next to the park in the south loop area otherwise bereft of decent restaurants. If you're looking for a spot near the park with a super outdoor area for snacks, a beer, a coffee, and maybe a light meal - look no further. If you're looking for culinary fireworks, keep searching.

I've only ever gotten coffee here, but today I went to get breakfast with my dog. I've seen a lot of people on the patio eating with their animals I thought it would be a fun dog friendly thing to do. The problem is, you have to order at the register but you're not allowed to bring your dog inside. I stood outside for a minute and nobody helped me so I went inside to grab a menu and order and after about three minutes the manager, I'm assuming, told me I can't have the dog inside. So I asked how do I order and he said I don't know but you can't have the dog inside. I understand why you can't have dogs inside, but they don't give you an alternative. I guess I'll be going to Waffles from now on.

Very meh.Came here before Da Bears game last week for breakfast and ordered the traditional breakfast. Eggs were tiny, sausage was not good at all too herby for me and did not look appealing at all. Barely gave you any potatoes. However the bacon was awesome along with the toast & jam. Coffee was weak too it was just ok esp for $15

My boyfriend and I went to breakfast last weekend around 10:40. When we arrived, we were told the wait would be about 30-35 minutes. It was a beautiful Sunday morning, so we were fine with that and were lucky enough to snag a table outside pretty quickly.We ordered coffee, which we received right away. We also ordered two meals, so we were given a number to place on our table. After about 30 minutes, we noticed that the 3 groups that had been ahead of us in line still had not received their orders. This was still the case 15 minutes later.At this point, we'd overheard one of the waitresses explaining to the group nearby that there was some kind of hold up in the kitchen. We were never given any information, nor did any of the servers check in with us. Our coffee was long gone, so we ordered beers - hoping our food would arrive soon.About 75 minutes after we'd ordered, we finally got a server's attention and asked what the wait was about. She explained that they had new cooks and that they had run out of home fries, and offered a timid apology. We asked if we could have some compensation for our time (the beers, for example - which we would not have ordered if we hadn't waited so long). She said she wasn't able to do that...and offered us a cookie instead. Fortunately, our food arrived at that moment - over an HOUR after we'd ordered. (Also - the server that brought us our food did not apologize or offer any explanation.)Although the food was great, I have no interest in going back to this place because of the poor service. I completely understand extenuating circumstances - but the one thing I do expect is communication.
Cute place!  The bacon jam on the pancakes were awkward and the water tasted funny. But cute place!

How long does it take to make oatmeal? At my place about 2 minutes. At Spoke and Bird - about 20 minutes.How warm should oatmeal be? At my place, pretty dam hot. It's breakfast. At Spoke and Bird - about 37.5 degrees Fahrenheit.How much should oatmeal cost? At my place, a couple of bucks considering I source local too. At Spoke and Bird - $9.Guys, I get it. You want to keep it hip and local, and I am happy to pay when quality is top notch. But seriously, get your act together.  I stumbled over considering how close I live, wanted something healthy and wanted to try this place for myself despite the mixed review and the owner's arguments (which honestly is a major turn off). Man was I disappointed.Good luck on fixing this up. I'll give you guys a shot in one year. Till then - no soup for you.

Charming and surprising gem in the south loop. The matcha latte is quite lovely and the patio in the back is big and sunny.Pecorino mushroom omelette is simple and flavorful. Every hot beverage is served with the tiniest square of cardamom shortbread...darlingOther highlights and interests: thick cut bacon, bacon jam served with pancakes, toasted English muffin, toothsome oatmeal with berries.

Felt the need to update review. I took along time off and recently went back. The concept is better executed this time and the patio is very kid friendly to have a beer with your stroller.  I've come to realize that the prices reflect creative food. Before the food didn't live up to that. Now I get it since the food improved. Plus they have a small but really impressive and hard to find beer list.

I've been here a few times since it opened as I live very close, and finally thought to review it once a few of my neighbors asked about it.  (I'm sure I'll get a scathing reply from the owner like many of the Yelp reviews on here! Hah!)Coffee - they brew fancy stuff and it's typically good.  However, if you just want a coffee, you have to wait in the same line as people ordering food - they only have one register.Food - Mediocre and expensive for a "cafe." Portions are tiny.  I once paid $10 for an egg mcmuffin with a few dried out home fries on the side.  My girlfriend had the porridge (also around $10 for a cup or less of it) and thought it was quite bland.  Food is never hot, always kind of warm to lukewarm.Wait time - Common them on here, I'm not surprised.  You have to wait in line to order and pay, and then wait for your food.  Rarely enough seating.  Up to an hour total on weekends, sometimes more!  Ridiculous for the quality of food.Staff - Cashiers are mostly friendly.  I was in there once and heard the cooks swearing at each other loudly and complaining about the orders (which I get that cooks do, but maybe not in a building shared by a children's day camp??).  Servers are young kids who look like they're in a state of panic at all times.  I've seen the owners (managers?) on weekends standing by the door and yelling at their staff to work faster and looking generally pissed off to be there, awkward when you're standing in line behind them.  Customers seem like an inconvenience to them, god forbid you don't know what pecornio is or have a food allergy.  I don't know, bad vibes from the kitchen area in a way I can't really place.Tipping - I'm really turned off by their tipping system.  If you pay with a card, you get an option on the screen to add a tip ahead of time, and it's awkward because the cashier is standing right there.  What are you tipping for?  The interaction with the cashier? The food runner?  The coffee refill I have to get myself?This place gets business because they have no competition in the area.  I admire what they are trying to do, but the execution is lacking.
FYI, I'm not at all associated with the restaurant, but thank you random Yelp user who messaged me rather unkindly and suggested so.It's good - check it out - 'nuff said.  :)

Came here to study on a weekday morning.  Quaint little Shop with great selection of tea and breakfast.  Had the classic breakfast.  The sausage is amazingand homemade.  It wasn't too crowded and a nice place to get some work done.

AVOID!!! They were crappy when it was cafe society. They are crappy now. Only thing they have going is the beer garden.Forced 15-20% tip at a self service restaurant.Portion fit for birds.Over-cooked food.Rude and elitist staff.Our tab came out to be close to $15-20 per person. All walked away hungry. Locally sourced is not a license to overcharge. It may be okay to let customers leave a little hungry if it's dinner. No one likes leaving hungry after breakfast. Come on!** edit **He tried to get Yelp to remove the review. Then reached out to me asking what the issue was. Just read my review and several others'. And spend the same amount of time you're spending here arguing with people and trying to prevent negative reviews... fix the source of the problem. That'll be infinitely more efficient.

I've been here twice. Once on a weekday for breakfast and everything was perfect! On a Sunday, different story. We were told a 30 min wait after ordering a classic breakfast, others said they were told 30 but waited 75. The chef was yelling in the kitchen at the service staff, leading to more frustration and disorganization of the staff. Great food, great weekday experience, but I will not come here on the weekend again.

This is my morning coffee place. A remodeled face over the old Cafe Society where I always come to relax and breathe some fresh air.. It features locally grown foods and a much cleaner look. The food is great, the people are friendly, amd if you love to sit outside during the fall and summer, you can" people and dog watch". It's tucked in the Southeast  corner of 18th and Indiana next to Women's Park. It also happens to be the last place you can get a water or beer before you enter the bike trail.

Never, ever, wrap fresh-baked anything in cellophane. One reviewer is absolutely correct: Wrapped pastries are for gas stations and 7/11s. I assume you aspire to something higher than that? Please consult the rule book and let your pastries breathe!

I thought the food here was very good. It is a little confusing so if you are a first timer, you order and pay in one room (also get drinks there), then take a table number to one of two OTHER rooms, and then wait for your food there. The one drawback was maybe the price, it was pretty high for the very small portions.

My husband and I went here for lunch. It was absolutely delicious! Their grilled cheese sandwich is probably one of the best I've ever had.It looks like they may be opening a new location in Pilsen, which I can't wait for since that's the neighborhood I live in. Hopefully it will be open soon, but in the mean time, I don't mind traveling to the South Loop for their yummy food.

A friend recommended I try Spoke and Bird for breakfast while I was in town. It's tucked away in the South Loop but not far from downtown. They have a full breakfast menu, coffee, tea and lunch as well. I got the classic breakfast of bacon, eggs, toast and potatoes. It was excellent, eggs cooked just as I asked, bacon was perfectly crispy, and the house made jam topped off the toast. It's a little pricey, I thought $11 for my order was fine, but I can't see the oatmeal being worth $11 too. This was a perfect way to wrap up a visit to Chicago.

Super cute place! But YIKES I spent 20 dollars on 2 eggs and grapefruit juice basically. I ordered 2 eggs, cheese grits and pancakes. It took 35 minutes to be served that.  My pancakes came burnt and dry. the grits where way way salty.  I asked for lighter pancakes that took another 35 minutes.  The kicker: they came back just as burnt. I just left. I couldn't even eat it. They need better service and a better cook.  The eggs were delicious however and fresh juice.

Great place.  We were in need of a good coffee/beer garden in south loop.   Their coffee tastes great. I'm back for seconds within 14 hrs.  (I guess I'm addicted to coffee).   The decor is awesome -they did this great design above the bar/dining room that includes cycle gears.   I can't review the food as I have not tried it yet. We will be back to try it very soon and will update my review.   Also, they have this huge patio that has to be a blast in the summer, I can't wait.Scott and Alicia went for something different ( sourcing all their food locally) nothing comes easy, and when it comes to restaurants, we all know it's not the easiest business to get into.  I know that they will figure everything out quickly so let's give this place a try and help it succeed.Design/decor 5 starsFriendly employees - 5 starsFood  - I haven't tried it yet :( will update soon.
Place is great for a cup of joe or a fancy breakfast.

Read mixed reviews but since it's in the neighborhood we decided to check it out. Thought it would be fun since it's a beautiful day and they have a nice outdoor patio.The short version: we left before our food was ready. There was only one person cooking and he was yelling at everyone, which was uncomfortable. We had waited for an hour after ordering before we decided to call it quits.Lastly, what we were able to try-- the coffee and a muffin-- tasted terrible (coffee was burned, muffin was excessively salty). Would not recommend this place. Plenty of other much better options in Chicago.
Classic breakfast is fresh home made like mom makes.  Hard to find options in this part of town. Glad to get Yelp directions to Spoke & Bird.

I've given this place enough chances - I'm done.I just asked for a decaf iced coffee and was told they didn't have any decaf right now and would have some in a few days .....OVERFLOW or STARBUCKS it is then ...

Incredible menu and tasty food. Good vegetarian options. I live in South Loop and am happy this place exists.That said, I can't get over waiting 42 minutes for pancakes, two sandwiches, and a side English muffin on Sunday. The restaurant was not full. Multiple servers seemed to be frequently checking in on the room without bringing food or checking in on us. I had brought my father from out of town and was sad we had to spend much of our time together hungry on a hard seats, waiting.

I had high expectations for this place, but after two visits, I'm stuck on meh.The Good:  Beer garden / patio in the back is spacious and great on a sunny day.  Nice selection of local beers - I enjoyed the Pistachio Stout from South Loop Brewing Co. in the winterThe Bad:  Food is average and over-priced

The first thing with reviewing a place to eat should be the food and the food was very mediocre. The eggs were meh like they were cooked in a hospital cafeteria or something. Lumpy and barely warm. The sausage was some odd lamb beef thing that was very gamey. It was also Luke warm. Portion sizes are very small as if every bite was so good or savory you wouldn't need more but that's not remotely the case.Oh and the price is way to high for quality or quantity of food. Go to yolk for quantity and better quality. Go to little goat or bongo room or eleven city diner etc. It's a place that looks like it's gonna be a great little neighborhood place except the food is awful haha.The cappuccino was good the service was good and the location was nice with the outdoor patio. None of that can make up for food that was terrible. So if you want a place to sit and drink coffee this is fine but for food this is a no go.

Decided to give it a try since I live nearby. I tried to give it a visits to be objective, but I am done. The only good thing I can say is it was relatively clean and nice ambiance, hence at least 1 star.   You need to change the price rating on this to $$$$;Now for the rest. I think these folks are abusing the farm to table concept, which is supposed to make it cheaper. beyond that, you are in a park building, so rent is usually lower. it's as if someone looked at what others are charging, looked at the money in the neighborhood, and just charged 25% more than everyone else. I will pay for great service and great product, but this does not reach that threshold.So first I tried Yogurt that is not really that good. $8 for Yogurt? 3 bites, tossed it.So I thought, ok, bad luck, I gave it a second chance and I tried the Mac & Cheese - underwhelming, cold; Mac & Cheese with a drink that came out for almost $20? Are you crazy? And you want me to tip at the order point of service?  When I tried to tell them it was cold after waiting for 20 minutes, I got the run around from some bearded guy.Fool me once, twice, I thought, we will give them another chance, local joint needs to succeed, etc. 35 minutes, unbelievable. Me and my girlfriend ended up spending almost $40 with coffee and tip for 2.

I've had breakfast and lunch here.  I had a turkey burger with home fries for lunch and egg sandwich with home fries were breakfast.  Both were average in taste and quality.  My feeling is they are charging a premium for high quality food but delivering average quality food.  The service is just ok.  My favorite thing so far was the cappuccino.  My star reduction is based on the following-1 cost-1 quality of food based on cost-1 wait time for foodI will give this place some more time to develop since they're fairly new and go back to see if there is any improvement.

First of all, let me say that I *really* want to like this place: it's close by where I live, it's got a very cool vibe, local beer on tap, an awesome courtyard, is dog-friendly, uses locally sourced ingredients, has an interesting menu, excellent presentation, etc. etc. etc.However, I've come here three times so far, and it's just not working out for me:* The food is routinely oversalted & overcooked (e.g. *vert* crispy bacon & *very* crispy home fries)* Overall, nothing I have eaten here has really been that great* It's overpriced* It takes forever to order at the counter* It takes forever for your food to arrive at the tableI'm really sorry to say that I probably won't be coming back. Next time I want to eat breakfast out, I'll go to Lyfe Kitchen: better food that's cheaper, faster to order, and faster to get to my table.My suggestions to the proprietor:* Salt less* Stop overcooking the food* I get that the kitchen is small, so it's hard to speed up food preparation, but at least deal with the ordering bottleneck (e.g. it's crazy that if I want to order a muffin, I have to wait 20 minutes in line). I see that you can order with GrubHub, but apparently you still need to stand in the forever queue to pay.* Lower the price a bitThese are all fairly straightforward to implement, and would prompt me to bump my review by two stars.Good luck.

I have to start this post off by saying Spoke & Bird is an adorable place and has a great patio/beer garden.  Wonderful lattes and breakfast.  Very nice owners. However, was bummed today when I had my husband pick me up the 'kale salad with roasted vegetables' I have been dying to try.  Knowing they use fresh ingredients I knew it had to be a winner.  He brought it home and I could believe my eyes.  A handful or some spring greens and some kale. There are about 5 pieces of butternut squash and some shallots.  That's it.  For a $10 price point I just feel there should be more salad and roasted veggies in this box.
Just had a great experience! Friendly staff, fun space, and the bacon jam and savory butter were nice additions to the pancakes.

I agree 100% with all the lower star reviews.  We Get it-30 local farms. Good for you. Drop the almighty yelp review act. It actually makes it worse.Newsflash. Customer service is key.The strategy of requesting a tip BEFORE receiving the staff's half-hearted -more like cold-hearted service is not fooling anyone.Customers- I advise you to tip AFTER your meal.Train the untrained staffDrop the pompous attitudeAcquire customer service skillsGain customer loyaltyListen to customersMaybe phone the previous friendly owner of Cafe Society and ask how to treat customers.Staff and customers are just a revolving door.Once you lose customer loyalty-you lose your business.You lost me for sure. I tried. I gave  3 chances.   Adios!

Hey South Loopers!  This is the crown jewel you've been waiting for!  And calling all other Chicagoans, this is a super cool spot located in a super cool neighborhood that you did not know existed.Great coffee, great inspired food menu, great rotating beer selections, awesomely friendly staff.  This is the rare place where you can swing by on the way to work for coffee and a quick breakfast to take to work, stop by for a quick, healthy lunch during the day, drop in for a beer on the way home from work, and then come out in the evening with friends to enjoy the nice shady outdoor patio along with beer, tea, coffee and espresso, great food and desserts - something for everyone, anytime.Also worth checking out is the nearby hidden park - beautiful and quiet, nice for a post-coffee stroll...

Like other reviewers I live nearby, and was very excited about the prospect of a real dining experience in the neighborhood.My first visit probably won't be my last, but I'm giving it awhile before I go back. I went after an event at Soldier Field- so the place was BUSY. From the time I walked in the door and received my food it took 45 minutes.Their kitchen is small, and they have NO system in place to differentiate dine in vs take out orders.So I finally get my food, high tail it home, only to be devastated. The portions vs what you pay is just laughable. I ordered a side of sausage the root veggie salad and a bacon cheddar biscuit. A side of sausage was one small link, AND they forgot my biscuit.I had high hopes for this place and I still kind of do. But there are legitimately some things that need to be addressed to keep this place afloat, as it stands right now I'm fine walking past this to place to a place that offers more consistent food, and service.

I am not used to seeing new ways of preparing French toast but the spoke & birds French toast is like no other French toast I have ever had. This is incredible. I think it's safe to say it's the best French toast I have ever had. I think I will be back tomorrow for more.

This place has it dialed in. Portion sizes are perfect, unless you're used to eating at Old Country Buffet. Our wait time was 20 minutes on a PACKED Sunday, but that was communicated (they actually estimated 25 minutes) before we ordered. The staff is super friendly...I think they actually enjoy their jobs....and the food..... ah-mazing!Ambiance is important. The outdoor patio is perfection, yet the indoor dining space is perfect for the winter months. The moment you walk in, you can tell there was a lot of heart and soul poured into the decor and set-up of Spoke & Bird.A much needed secret treasure in Chi-town. We will definitely be back again....and again.... and again!

I'm a 2 min walk from here and was excited that there is a real restaurant next door to my home. The first visit was a week after they opened. I had a coffee and chatted with the staff and reviewed the menu. Coffee was great (counter culture), staff were really nice, and menu looked diverse, fresh, local, and progressive.Went back today to eat, after 2 months. Ordered the breakfast sandwich, cappuccino, and spinach salad with a side of bacon.Cappuccino: perfect. Little delicious cookie bite to boot.Breakfast sandwich: 2 of these, one for each of us. I  feel this is an item that will showcase if a restaurant has it together. It's a simple dish that and easy to perfect with some attention. Egg was sunny side up and cooked very well. The ham was lost in there by the hot sauce/mayo mix. The English muffin was soft and not toasted. The whole thing lacked texture. It was soft, sloppy, and messy. Flavor came together, but much to be desired. And so easy to fix. For $8, I felt cheated by this sandwich.Spinach salad: pecorino, ramps, pecans, blueberry vinegarette. SAND IN MY SALAD. I asked my sister about it and we tried to figure... Was it blueberry seed? Was it cracked pepper? Nope. Spinach was not washed well and it was sandy. Pecans were not seasoned or toasted and threw the salad off. Blueberry dressing tasted horrible with the ramps. Pecorino was sparse. $10 for a disastrous plate.Side of bacon: not cooked to order. Dry and chewy.Service. Very good.Overall, $40 with tip for two people. That's enough to buy my groceries for the entire week. And I blew it on a terrible brunch. And though I'm salty that I wanted this place to be great bc it's next door and our neighborhood needs this, I have to be honest in my review.I really hope they read this. I will try it out for dinner and give it one more chance. Otherwise it will be only for coffee.

Bed service. When I asked if I can add tomatoes to my dish I've been told "I don't think I can make this happen", I ordered just omelette and a salad and had to wait 15-20 minutes and still didn't got my food.When I ask what's going on they told me that they make each dish separate, order by order, and they still haven't started to make my food.  Of course I asked my money back because they just kept giving me stupid answers.------I don't know how I can answer to all the lies that you wrote in the comment below, but i'm sorry for you that you need to laugh about bad English.Everything you wrote is just lies. nobody told me it's going to take 40 minutes, how can you even know that ?! You don't know who I am!!! I never threaded with a bad review! and the way that I've been told "I don't think I can make that happen" was rude, and than I asked him clearly "do you have tomatoes in this place?" he said "yes"!!!I asked "so why you think that you can make that Happened?" Very nicely.I never yelled, never asked for any favors, and of course that you are SO confusing me with someone else or just trying to embarrass me and claim that I'm a B***h.Every single word that you wrote is a lie. I am not this type of person and if you're making fun of others you shouldn't be running a restaurant or do customer service. good luck

What a treat it was to find this south loop gem. Walking to soldier field, you might walk right by this unsuspecting spot. With a huge outdoor patio and a detached indoor seating area, it can be a bit hard to figure out. But boy oh boy is the food worth it. The classic breakfast was filling and made perfectly. On top of that delicious glass of iced coffee made the meal perfect. Looking forward to coming back again and again.
Amazing coffee!!!! I had the root veggie muffin and I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious it was!! Love this place!

I've come here twice, both times for lunch this summer. The staff is all extremely friendly and I love bringing my dog because they gave her treats and they have a huge patio in a really nice and calm area. I've definitely been looking for a place like this in the South Loop. I'm pretty sure that their food and drink is local, which is very cool but on the downside, makes it more expensive. Their portions also are pretty small for the price.I haven't yet tried the breakfast food but I really loved the jam burger and potato salad. The burger itself if you get a single patty is a good portion size and you don't walk away feeling stuffed, but satisfied. And the jam is extremely tasty.Not so good: the mac and cheese. It was extremely small and dry. There was hardly and cheese sauce on it and to give it some flavor, sriracha had to be added.All in all, this was a great find and I'll definitely be coming back. They have a wide selection of food and beer, and the patio makes it all worth it.
Cute place. Their lambeque sandwich is pretty great. Super spacious patio right next to the park!
The food was good, but overpriced. The patio was gorgeous, and I'd go back to drink outside, but I wouldn't pay the food prices again.

Went for a really late brunch and was very disappointed. It was a little pricey compared to other good brunch places but I just ordered and sat down outside in their large garden area thinking the food would be worth it. I was happy that they knew to bring the food out to us and we're really attentive about refilling water. The food however was another story. They had huge fancy plates but the portions were tiny! The flavors were very unique in my chicken sandwich at least and not in a great way. The fries were pretty good but not worth the price and not worth the trip since they also got a little dry towards the end. The location is not near any train stations but it is BYOB. Will probably not return just because the south loops has so many great brunch spots to offer and I like big portions!

We had been anticipating this place opening up and with the advent of the patio it really take you to another place.This hidden gem in the south loop boasts locally and regionally sourced ingredients, coffees and beers.We typically avoid the early morning rush and enjoy our brunch on weekends after 1:00 pm.  Weekdays are no problems.Price points are either hit or miss depending on your choice and affinity for locally or regionally sourced items.We have enjoyed both burgers with the turkey burger being our favorite.Omelette was excellent and at a great price point and French toast delicious but a little pricey.The owners are local residents who turned this space into something the area has needed for a while with the redecorated dining area and of course the wonderful large patio space that invokes a European cafe feel.All in all we really love Spoke and Bird and will stick with and support them through any growing pains.  We will be back for not only for lunch but also the patio for coffee and the ambiance.
I LOVE this place! It's great. The food is great, the service is amazing.  The prices are a little high but this place is worth the visit.

Words alone do this location no justice. The staff are friendly, the food is not only delicious and unique but is also locally sourced. The beers on tap are always varied and excellent. The lattes are better than any other I've had, and I've had lattes from most of the craft coffee sources in the city (no offense Bridgeport or Bow Truss).They really love what they are doing and they won't disappoint, give it a try! Plus the decor is great.

I really liked the ambiance. The tea & snack I had were delicious. The guy behind the counter was really patient & helpful as I chose my drink. He and the rest of the staff were very helpful & polite. I'd recommend it for sure!
Quality of food continues to be ok for a bite to eat in the neighborhood. I prefer the breakfast options and the service continues to be average.

Despite an excellent location and good coffee, I am not sure some of the issues are attributable to opening week  45 minutes for a cold burger and a disassembled "pot pie" are possibly due to opening week.  However, out-of-whack pricing ($15 for 2 blueberry muffins and 2 small coffees and $10 for an egg sandwhich), over-seasoning, and a bad attitude towards consumer feedback are not.  I appreciate that the owners are new to the restaurant business and am always willing to give places a second chance, but negative feedback shouldn't be  met with snarky yelp replies and defensive excuses, but instead with a willingness to at least look into the issues causing the discontent.Although I appreciate the effort to revamp a tired neighborhood staple, I fear that they are trying to do too much with their food while passing for a laid-back cafe.  The neighborhood is not so devoid of options that I'm going to pay these prices for oversalted, overseasoned food.  Locally sourced food is great and I applaud them for their effort...but it has to present value for the price.  Getting blueberries from your neighbors yard doesn't make average-size muffin worth $52 stars for decor and for the coffee...
Long wait to order. Long wait for food. Bees attacked us as we ate. My pancakes were raw. All and all not the best experience.

portions goodI've been wanting to try this since it opened and finally made it over for lunch.  I do plan to return and hopefully make my review more accurate and robust since I live close by.  A few interesting tidbits.  The set up is just plain strange, to be honest.  You walk in by the patio (which looks awesome, btw) and it's sorta like a little order counter but it's not marked and there is no menu hanging other than coffee so you almost wonder if you entered the wrong way.  They do have menus if you ask but it would make more sense to have a board.  The ambiance reminds me a bit of Antique Taco but they have a menu you can view in line.  Also, the beers don't have a menu.  So if you ask they'll say they have a few on tap and a few bottles but there are no explanations of what they are.  It would be better if on the back of the menu or something they had a beer list and just described the beers a little as many of them are from smaller, local breweries (which is good) and the average person might not know much about them.  The guy at the register was very friendly.  I walked through the park district type of room (super weird) and into the dining room and sat down with my number.  After about 10 minutes, they brought my pasta carbonara.  The wait was not long.  I thought the portion size was perfect.  It was not too heavy and not too large.  The in house pancetta was very smoky.  I actually thought the pasta was really well done.  The dough was tasty and perfectly audente.  The sauce was not as heavy as a normal carbonara.  Overall I thought it was a bit quirky but the food was legit.
There was a long line, but the food definitely made it worth the wait. Everything was well-cooked, well-seasoned, and fresh! Even the staff was courteous and provided excellent service.

I found this place very rude to customers. 1st time there I saw some sandwiches ask them what kind of sandwich is it they just ignore me, fine took my coffee and leave. 2nd time there the old guy ask me "what you you want" like I'm lost walk into some ones back porch. Bad place for the naborhood : (

We've already been back several times if that tells you how great this place is.Make your own pho, reasonable prices, very decent portions, fresh ingredients every time we're there, this place hasn't done us wrong. It's usually just staffed by one employee who makes your pho and takes your payment, but we never had to wait while we're there. Really, the food here is so delicious and fresh, check it out! Also - unlimited toppings. Do you need any more reasons?

Daily affordable neighborhood meal.  No trek necessary.  Thank you Marie K for the Yelp recommendation.TRADITIONAL PHO ($8.95) is a better option than the one on Belmont.Noodle Width -- size matters for slurping.  Current width and al dente done-ness are meant for salads.  Just the right amount.Beef Broth -- clean, slight sweet, ordinary.Rare Beef -- one of the best!  (+1 star) Significantly better than it's original counterpart.  Perfect amount.COUNTER SERVICE.  Not quite FU-POTLE Danny W as 15% tip is first than No Tip.  Since we are encouraged to separate used containers, that TIP should rightfully be eliminated.FIVE STAR rewards program.Wear and Tear shows up with greasy floor in women's bathroom.

The concept of FUH is basically a chipotle-subway Pho restaurant!YES - fast lines/ serviceYES - Reasonable pricesYES - staff is awesomeYES - pho is deliciousYES - Vegetarian options*YES - deliverYES - credit card acceptedI had the SAIGON SLAW (5/5) I loved it! Their vinaigrette is delicious & tastes authentic!They have an assortment of S A U C E S!Will return! YOU GET YOUR BANG FOR YOUR BUCK!

This place is fantastic. I seem to stroll in on Saturday afternoons after long Friday nights. It hits the spot every time I go.I love the concept of the place with the Chipotle style setup. You walk in and choose whether you want rice noodles and I believe the other option is cabbage. Then you choose your protein or a veggie/vegan option. My personal favorite are the beef balls. They're not made up of questionable meat like the ones you would find at your typical Pho hole in the walls. Their toppings include cabbage, bean sprouts, fried garlic, green onion, white onion, mint, basil, lime and more! Then they have this fantastic pineapple habanero sauce that I can't get enough of. They should consider selling bottles separately if they don't already.I recently tried their Vietnamese iced coffee and man oh man...it's strong and super delicious!It's nice knowing that I still have a piece of home close to my new home. Excited for the comfort come winter.
Solid choice for a quick meal if you're in the area. I ordered through Yelp Eats and it was ready in no time, and the staff was great. I'm sure I'll be back on those cold, Chicago nights.

Huh?  Fuh?  I guess I've got hooked by "Fuh" because of their pho.Get your pho made like a "Subway style."  Vegetarians and vegans also can enjoy a bowl with tofu in vegan broth.  Hubby and I were hunting Pokemon in Lincoln Park this evening.  We stopped in here for dinner, and this certainly wouldn't be our last time.Some people have shared how this works in their reviews.  I won't repeat but will briefly summarize this assembly line for you:1) Pick a base (rice noodles or mixed cabbage)2) Add protein (beef, chicken, and tofu varieties)3) Complete the bowl with the ingredients of your choice (bean sprouts, arugula, carrots, jalapeños, onions, green onions, basils, cilantros, mint, roasted garlic, roasted peanuts, and one or two other ingredients I failed to mention)4) Finish off the bowl with broth (beef, chicken, or vegan)If your want to make your pho "spicy," don't forget to ask for jalapeños and the grab the hot sauce from the self-serve condiment area.  Every single ingredient tasted fresh and delicious.  Economically, two (2) bowls of belly-warming pho cost us $20, with quick service, laid-back ambiance, and more time to spend strolling at the nearby Oz Park.They offer frequent diner punch card, buy nine (9) bowls get the 10th. one free!

This is my favorite pho place in Chicago so far!! Oh my god, BEEF BROTH was spectacular!!!!!! Worth trying it.Whether you are with friends or alone, this is a place to eat! Modern and edgy atmosphere inside out. Staff was very friendly, too.I don't have much to say because it's just perfect!! I wish I could make beef broth like this at home. Miss it!! Definitely come back.

While on the 74 bus from Fullerton & Lawndale to the Lincoln Park Zoo area, I looked up restaurants near there so my friend and I can grab a bite first. FUH was one of the top restaurants that popped up and had great reviews. I showed my friend the photos and she was instantly excited. We've never been to a restaurant that allows you to pick your own ingredients for pho.We got off at Lincoln and Webster stop and walked across the street. The restaurant was not busy, which was great, so we didn't have to wait. The staff member, Molly, helped us with our order. She instantly greeted us nicely and told us about how ordering works.I decided to get:- Half of rice noodles and half of cabbage- Pulled beef- A lot of fresh veggies- Peanuts and Fried onions- Beef BrothThe result was a HUUUUGE bowl of yummy beautiful aromatic pho placed on a plate with chopsticks and spoon. I used my FIU student ID for the student discount (awesome!!!), and made sure to tip Molly. She automatically gave me a cup of water and treated my friend really nicely as well.The pho was AMAZING! Beef was really tender, everything tasted well. We were SO HAPPY with the pho that we wished they would open a location in Miami. There's no place in Miami so far that allows customers to pick what ingredients they want. Genius idea! My friend's pho (beef broth, rice noodles, chicken/beef/tenderloin, veggies) was delicious as well. We both couldn't finish our bowls because there was so much food. You really get your money's worth!THIS RESTAURANT IS DEFINITELY A MUST TO TRY if you live in or you are visiting Chicago. Service is great, food is delicious, and price is awesome. I really hope FUH opens a location in Miami :-). You guys are awesome! Thank you again Molly!!!!

Read reviews on how good this place was but was skeptical at first so decided to try it for myself. The broth was seriously killer and my only thing that I would change is the default noodles to be the classic Thai thin noodles. Other than that, everything was on point. I love the customization! I love bean sprouts and the lady piled them on! Definitely will recommend to friends, better than most Thai pho places in Argyle!!

Awesome pho place! First time here and the staff is super helpful on laying out how the build your own pho works and helping with all the options. We live outside the city but I would come in for this pho

Good stuff.  Massive portions.  Love the build-your-own-pho concept.  Lots of choices to make it your own as well as a "hit list" to order from if you're not in a creative, adventurous vein.  Nothing like a good soup to comfort the soul -- especially on a gray, drizzly, fall day.  I like spicy and the only thing I would note is that I did wind up hitting my broth with a bit more fish sauce and sriracha to pump up the heat and brightness.  But my friend loved hers as it was presented.

I guess since I'm a big fan of the Argyle neighborhood I might be a bit biased. If you know what's good with fuh, you should definitely make the trip more north for that good good. The ingredients here all tasted relatively fresh, they just lacked any flavor. The broth specifically actually tasted like hot water.The dude at the counter prepared me his favorite fuh, I forgot which one it was. He was mildly kind, terribly apethetic about what he was serving and described their ordering concept as "Chipotle style"  which probably wasn't the best choice of words especially after their E. Coli crisis.The shrimp chips were decent.

3.5Tasty especially on a cold winter day... or rainy day..It is like pho "chiptole style" (meaning you get to choose your soup, meat, and toppings). Very simple! I like the concept, but it tasted more like fast food pho...can't really compare to pho restaurants.Costs-average..expect to spend at least $10...soup bowl with beef was $9.78 (tax included)..Meat-options range from chicken to rare beef. (They dont give you that much)Broth-options are vegan, chicken, beef...broth wasn't steaming hot, but warm enough.Vegetable toppings- the basics that go into pho (bean sprouts, jalapeno etc)Sauces-more of a variety than just hoisin sauce & hot sauce which is nice to have...Portions-decent, filling for me... but maybe not too much for others..Restrooms-one per gender.. clean.. but no mirror in the woman's restroom for now (instead there is a nice message for you to read)..hope you dont have snout dripping or mascara running from hot soup..:)Location-street parking available and many stores/restaurants nearby if you need something to do before/afterI would come here again if the pho restaurants in Broadway area were closed or if i was in the area just craving pho.

The best way I can describe Fuh is by comparing it to Subway where the soup bowl is your 'bread' and the ingredients are placed in front of you in containers and you just point at what you want and they put it in for you. You have a choice of building your own pho bowl or picking a preset one with predetermined ingredients. I would consider Fuh a fast food joint.For my first visit, I chose to build my own pho bowl as it was an unique concept that I definitely wanted to try! It was interesting designing our own pho bowl as Fuh also had some non-traditional ingredients like carrots and arugula. While the pho was decent, I didn't think it was amazing enough to warrant a trip to try it. Fuh doesn't taste like authentic Vietnamese pho (more like westernized Asian fusion) and the beef broth was quite salty. Also, I was a little disappointed I only got 2 pieces of rare steak (which is quite small after its cooked in the broth). I did like the noodles though.One thing of note was that the service was quite friendly and very prompt.I would recommend only trying Fuh if you were in the area and looking for some hot soup noodles to warm you up in the winter.
The veggie broth is amazing, and the price point is solid considering how good the fuh is. The pineapple habanero sauce is really good too, it's a must when you get fuh here

Perfect for a rainy day in Lincoln Park, or a quick lunch while running errands. But if you can get to Uptown relatively conveniently, I would not use this as a replacement pho for those cravings.The broth... I mean, it tastes like pho broth. It's pretty satisfying. While I don't like cabbage and carrots in my pho it's nice to have the option to get extra vegetables into your meal and a nice little crunch.But I want real Thai basil! And more than just 3 slices of rare beef or 5 halves of beef balls for $9 with my broth. It's really actually overpriced for the quality of the pho when you can go to a more traditional place for a more soulful broth and a giant bowl full of everything for ...$7.95.The chicken spring rolls lacked herbs for me and the chicken was unseasoned and dry. I did love the little turd-like piping of the peanut-hoisin sauce. Pretty funny!Kinda seems like they're trying to appeal to more people by making everything a little less bold and a bit more generic and leave it up to us to customize the taste via sauces. I was also totally missing just good old Vietnamese dipping fish sauce.
