A friend wanted to go to Thai Bowl but we decided to check out Golden Thai to change things up.  We had the red curry with beef and chicken pad thai.  The curry was very flavorful (requested spicy) but there was not enough beef in it to justify the $9 price tag.  Same with the pad thai - great flavor but not enough protein in it either.  I think the freshness and quality is a step above Thai Bowl (as is the atmosphere), just not a very good value considering all the competition on Taylor.

Probably one of the worst papaya salads I've had, and I order papaya salads all the time in Thai restaurants.  The complimentary veggie egg rolls are a nice touch, but not enough incentive for me to ever order their papaya salad ever again. Regardless, I'll probably come back because it's walking distance from IMD. I'll try ordering their pad thai or pad see ew next time.
Tasty noodles with fresh vegetables for a low price. Nice people working there. You will have to convince them that you really do want it spicy if you want it spicy, though.

I really love Thai food. I was very impressed with the Thai food that I got from this restaurant. I'm very happy that they tailor to my dietary restrictions. The service was excellent and the food was very fast. I will definitely recommend this restaurant to all my friends.

Tried this place for the first time a couple of weeks ago. I got the garlic chicken noodles and it was really good. Went back today and got the same thing and it was soooo sweet. Plus the cashier screwed up my order and I didn't realize it until I got to my car. I ordered chicken noodles again and got a container full of just meat. I only took the container back in (not because I wanted to keep the rice but I was just being lazy and didn't feel like repackaging everything lol) the cashier said she would fix it and told me to go get the rice and bring it back and I'm pretty sure she didn't throw it away. Pretty unsanitary.

My husband and I were craving curry so we got take-out from Golden Thai this weekend. The food was excellent overall - the flavors were great, the prices were fair and the service was friendly. However, the food has FAR too much sodium. They could cut it by half and it would be equivalent to other restaurant food. If they cut back on the sodium (green curry, red curry, and especially the Tom Kar Soup), I would be a frequent customer.

This place is a never fail place. I love their Singapore noodles and pad Thai. The food comes pretty fast and decently priced. It's a small place, almost hidden in Taylor St but once you find it, you will feel like going back again and again!

My favorite Thai restaurant for the last 4-5 years.  My wife and I have made this place our little get away.  BYOB some we always bring a nice bottle of wine. Preferably a white wine to go along with our meal.The service is always great, the food is always delicious.  And we love the mom and pop feel.

This is a true 3.5 review.  This is my go-to for Thai in the neighborhood.  Very friendly staff and reasonable prices.  I wish the portions were a tad bigger, but hey, it's still decent.I usually do take out or delivery since the place is small and I usually order when I'm not in the mood to cook.  And they have CRISPY pad see eew, which is a treat every once in awhile!The food is good and does the job when I'm either craving, lazy or both.  :)

This place has the best Thai food. It's delicious, the service is fast, and the prices are reasonable. I have never had anything here that wasn't extremely tasty. I used to live around the area, and of all the restaurants on Taylor Street, this is by far the best one. I haven't been here in awhile, but I was thinking the other day about how much I miss this place. So good!

Golden Thai was good! I only tried one dish - the Yellow Curry - but no complaints. It's really more of a 3.5 star review, but I couldn't really think of any major down sides to knock it down to a 3. Technically I've had better yellow curries, but this one was definitely good. Prices are reasonable - every dish my group had was $6.95. We dined in, and the atmosphere is pretty standard for a Thai place. I guess my one complaint would be that there's no lunch specials - just the regular menu. Portion size was good and I definitely have enough for leftovers for lunch today. Success.

This is the 3rd time we've carried-out from Golden Thai---we've always been satisfied with the food (quality, portion, etc).We had the spring rolls and since our order was over $20, we got the vegetable egg rolls complimentary. My bf had the tom yum noodles with chicken (no soup broth) and I had the Bami haeng ped (with tofu).  We also ordered vegetable fried rice.Since we were carrying-out, we ordered at the counter and waited about 10 minutes for our food.  The portions are large and our entire meal came out to be $26. Apparently it's byob too, even though it's not advertised as such. (I asked the man who took our order) ;)The place is always clean and very casual, and we've always liked what we've ordered....there are about 10 tables in the place and there's a large flat screen tv on the back wall which always seems to have sports on.I've eaten at Thai Bowl and Yummy Thai (both on Taylor) which are great places, but this place seems to be a bit less expensive and I've found the portion size to be larger. If you're looking for a casual byob thai place on Taylor, I recommend Golden Thai over 'Yummy Thai' and 'Thai Bowl'.

I visited this place with a couple of co-workers.  I travel a lot and love the local mom and pops.  Their cashew chicken was delicious.  My favorite part of ordering was being asked if I wanted mild, med, or spicy.  The med is spicy compared to most.  We all ordered different menu items and everyone agreed their dish was very good.  The prices are very reasonable.  Don't expect white table cloths or fancy decor, just a neighborly proprietor who waves a passers by during lulls.

The 3 Thai restaurants on Taylor Street that I've been to, this one is positioned at the bottom. The food was sub-par and the last time I was there, I think the bathroom was broken because all we smelled was poo. Imagine eating next to a piece of crap. Can't be a good experience. Hopefully, it's been fixed. Unfortunately, it's left such a bad taste in my mouth, it's safe to say that I would never go back.I hate the smell of poo.

nice portions for the prize. food not overly sauced or seasoned, but at the same time it didn't lack flavor. service was ok. we had the crab rangoon, the shrimp fried rice and the thin rice noodles with beef. it was clean, the chairs can be a little more comfortable. and i assume this place has more pick-up business than dine in since during our visit we were the only table but lots of people came in and picked up food
This place is wonderful! ! Golden Thai rolls and Panang Curry with rice noodles are recommended. Service is sweet!
Best Thai food on Taylor st!

I don't know squat about food. But I do know squat about music. Perhaps even more than squat, and for that reason I am not listening whatsoever.That is to say, I have engaged my talent for selective listening. In my line of work, it is important to be able to listen to multiple sounds at a time. It is equally important to be able to tune out certain sounds when they are unimportant or distracting.This talent of mine that I have developed over many years does not have much application in my daily life. The few times I get to flex my multi-listening abilities are rush hour at the airport or unobtrusively eavesdropping at restaurants or simply listening to the elevator music while having a conversation simultaneously. Virtually no one ever even realizes that I am doing it unless I burst out laughing after hearing "Hungry Like The Wolf" recorded as a pan flute orchestra.That's not a joke. I think restaurants like to play songs with "hungry" in the title or lyrics as kind of a subliminal message auto-suggestion hypnosis. They think most people don't even hear it.But I do.I would normally gladly enjoy the conversation and background music simultaneously. Here at Golden Thai, I have chosen to turn the conversation off altogether for two reasons:A. The conversation is not worth participating in.B. The music here is pretty good actually."...men can NOT be trusted for any reason whatsoever, and I'll tell you..."DEFINITELY not worth participating in. Fortunately, my participation is unwanted anyway, and I set my head oscillating at regular intervals to complete the illusion of an audience member.The music being played is nothing I recognize. I would gather these artists are likely Thai or something from that region of the world, but as I said, the music is actually pretty good.Sitting back I stretch my ears out, my head and tongue on autopilot, wagging at appropriate moments, listening only to Thailand's finest.And I dig it.After the CD changer's latest grind, I really dig it! Whoever this guy is, he is really good, and his voice is sweet! I envision a giant crooning stick of butter."...when I was traveling the astral plane..."It's going to be awhile. It's just you and me, Butterstick! If there were a reanimated amalgamation of the corpses of Sinatra and Elvis, it would be jealous of this man's talents."...the Salvation Army Store wouldn't take back the scarf! I was out $1.50..."Latin rhythms? This guy is out of control!"...visited by three spirits that wanted to deliver a message..."Oh dear, we're back in the Shadow Realm again. As long as this CD doesn't run out, I'll be alright.The melodic structure is totally different than typical western tastes, and the vocal harmonies totally blow my mind. I need this CD!The completion of the meal was my reprieve from accidentally hearing any more of the conversation. I went up and asked the lady behind the counter who the artist was. When she handed me the CD case, it looked like a microscope slide of squiggly bacteria with a handsome asian man, acoustic guitar in hand, smiling through it. Whatever language it was, I certainly couldn't read it.I asked her to write the name of the artist down for me and she obligingly handed me a piece of paper that read:---theta - theta - backwards "L" - jesus fish - N------K - jesus fish - jesus fish - N - O - R - backwards "L" - sigma---Oh well. I guess I'll just have to come back for my Sonic Butterstick Fix.Fortunately, the beef fried rice here is reasonably priced and made just how I like it. Tender beef, lots of egg, flavorful rice and no weird stuff like peas or corn. You'll have to ask someone else about its authenticity. See my previous comment re: "squat".I'd come here more often if this place weren't in a weird part of town that is a major pain to park in. The staff is really friendly. The bathroom definitely needs a remodel.All things considered, Golden Thai is a great place to not listen to somebody. Instead, just float away on a buttery cloud while Elvisnatra shakes its decaying fist.

Giving this restaurant 1 star is quite generous in my view.  We were craving for something different menu-wise and that could be ready quickly.  Since we were not too far from the place, we decided to go there.  Ordered 5 dishes, one of which was a dessert.  We stood and waited by the cashier's station and worked up an appetite just watching the scrumptious images scrolling through the computer screen and the food that was coming out of the kitchen.  The smells wafting our way made us more hungrier.  We stood there for 15 minutes -- no food, 20 minutes still nothing.  The person who took our order ignored us, wouldn't make eye contact.  Finally the owner came and announced that the food should be ready in 5 minutes.  Total wait time-- 30 minutes while other customers who came way after us got their food and were halfway through their meal.  No one bothered to apologize when we finally got our food.Got back to the office, opened all the containers.  What!!!!!!  The portion sizes were puny compared to the ones served at the restaurant (probably 1/4 of the portions we saw at the restaurant for dine in customers).  The food looked like it was made by a different set of cooks.  Nothing like what we saw in the photos or in person at the restaurant.  Needless to say, we were all still hungry after the meal.Probably not going there for take out again.  Lesson of the day -- eat in rather than take away.

Yep, this place is still good.In addition to my previous review I would like to highlight the following:Appetizers:-CHICKEN SATAY is AMAZING!!!!!!-Shrimp roll is ok-Fried tofu is pretty good if a little bland. Comes with dipping sauce.Entrees:-Pad woon sen is pretty good, if a little less filling than other dishes due to higher veggie content-Lad nar was good but the noodle flavoring had a hint of organ meat flavor which isn't one of my favorite tastes. Still good.

Kudos to Golden Thai for grossing me out every single time! I tried their fried rices and noodles (mostly others' treats, thankfully), and everyone tasted like a horror show. Rice was never fresh; noodles were generally overcooked. I won't even guess what their entrées taste like, 'cause this place cannot properly handle rice and noodles to begin with.Go to either Yummy Thai or Thai Bowl on the same street. You deserve better.

So this was once my spot for nice thai, great thai iced coffee and just really great pad thai. I don't know maybe it's me but a small quant little spot is just what is needed at times. Incredible spring rolls and just a delight to talk to someone over lunch when, although busy still a world away from the everyday drudgery of daily drama. If you can find parking, you will have to experience this first hand.
Never had Thai food before but the drunken noodles were pretty yummy. I would go back to try the other food.

I come here every few weeks for lunch.... it's great.  Not overpriced, always delicious.  I've never had issues with weird smells/bad conversation or anything else people have complained about here.  This place definitely tops Yummy Thai... talk about bad smell for THAT place, but that's for another review.Bottom line, I'll keep coming back!
This place is for those who like homely atmosphere and enjoy exquisite Thai food... The stir-fry dishes are great... with rich flavors...Try "Basil Chicken" ... It's great...

It was good. I had a jubarito and husband has breakfast. I don't give it five start because breakfast was expensive for the amount they give. I would just go for lunch. Service was great. They make you feel welcome. Very nice place .

They were out of chicharrón,  fruit was not fresh at all,  water poured all over,  dry omelet, and sword their orange juice was freshly squeezed when it obviously was not.  It's sad to see how this place has changed.The oatmeal continues to be delicious.

Worst service I've had in a long time, we went for brunch as a pretty large group - 6 of us, but the staff said they could accommodate us which we were excited about so we didn't mind waiting some.   Little did we know the hell we were about to endure.  They told us a 15 minute wait, it was a 35 minute wait.  We sat down for breakfast and a waitress wasn't with us for 20 minutes. Half of our party got the buffet, the other half of us ordered directly from the menu.  For those of us who ordered food - it took us 50 minutes to get our food.  WE spent over two hours at this godforsaken hell hole.  The food was pretty good, but the service didn't even make it worth it.God bless you if you try to eat here.
Fist time and ansolutely loved it. The food is amazing. Everything coming out of the kitchen looked yummy. Ran into a grammer school friend there. Love the old neighborhood!

We stopped here for Saturday brunch and had a fantastic meal. My fiance got the brunch buffet, and I got the pork jibarito. I have been dreaming about that jibarito ever since! Perfect plantain sandwich with juicy pork inside and a great sauce. YUM. Very reasonably priced, too. We will be back!

Nellie's has been on my bookmark for over a year now.  Humboldt Park is going through some sort of transformation and diversity is gradually implanted in this area of town.  Rosa J. has explored and visited many places and neighborhoods in Chi-town, yet she hasn't had lots of footprints in Humboldt Park.  Perhaps she needs get on that CTA #70 bus more frequently.Hubby and I came for their AYCE breakfast/brunch.  For $15.99 per person (as of 12/13/2015), you can sample an assortment of Puerto Rican yumminess.  Yes, my understanding of anything Puerto Rican is "Zero," with a capital "Z."  However, I am still "livin' la Vida Loca" with all the good food I can find in town.There were several highlights in my AYCE brunch date with Ms. Nellie:- pastelon: it is "sweet plantain lasagna" in English.  I couldn't tell what it was with the first glance, but it didn't bother me since I take chances on everything I do in my life.  It was more savory than sweet, so it's appropriate for being a breakfast/brunch item since my tolerance for sugar is higher before 1200 hour.- potatoes: they had a unique seasoning, which I couldn't precisely pin-point what it was.  I was quite diggin' those sautéed potatoes though!- coconut cinnamon oatmeal: oatmeal and I are usually strangers and we don't converse.  Nevertheless, coconut and cinnamon were the catalysts that helped me take a second look at that gooey oatmeal.  Ummm...maybe he's just as attractive as an Italian supermodel.  He just doesn't dress fashionably like other dishes on the buffet table.-made-to-order omelet: a friendly older gentleman was in charge of this station.  He could oversee four (4) omelets at a time.  I'm a sucker for omelets.  I had mine customized with feta, spinach, onion, mushroom, and green peppers.The "youngest" young man was attentive.  He was so cute when he filled our orange juice ALL the way to the top of glass.  We didn't ask for more coffee because I was afraid that our coffee would be too full to have room for the creamer (jk).I will definitely come back again.  Be sure to dress in layers so you can remove the sweater or cardigan since the venue is toasty warm, especially when you step into the buffet bar in the back room.

Of course it was a must try knowing that this place is famous for their Coconut Oatmeal.  Puerto Rico is in the house......my goodness this food will put you in food coma. I decided to come here for breakfast and boy am I happy that I did. The atmosphere is surrounded with beautiful artistry.My lovely breakfast choice was the Nellie's Breakfast Special. The breakfast special is enormous and delicious. This lovely meal includes an omelette with cheese, tomatoes, onions, green peppers, onions, sausage and sweet plantains. The meal comes with a side of garlic bread and cup of the most delicious coconut oatmeal you will ever have in your life. Nostalgia was present as I tasted each bite of this savory oatmeal it reminded me of the oatmeal my grand mother used to make growing up. I could not even finish my whole meal it was so filling.You honestly can not go wrong by ordering this special or just coming to this place period. The staff was super friendly and the food came out extremely fast. Overall, I had a tremendous experience!
My first time, cocunut oatmeal, the best ive ever tasted. Service is amazing and on point.
Great Puerto Rican food.  Simple and humble in the inside. Great food: avena con coco, rice and beans, bistec, coquí sandwish, cafe con leche, jibaritos, and etc.

So we arrived her at 12:00pm and were seated at around 12:15pm party of four.Four minutes after being seated we ordered our food. No beverages just water. We ordered 3 sandwiches and mofongo.It's now 1:00pm and we still haven't received the food. Our server hasn't came to us to let us know about the delay. She had to be tracked down. The Resturant is full, but the majority of the people are eating at the breakfast buffet.Also, the electricity in the building is flickering and seems unsafe.Food arrived at 1:03pmEveryone received their food and I'm still missingThe rice is good but not excellentThe French fries are greasy and appear as though they have been refrained or that the oil was not hot enough and the fries sat in the oil for a period of time.El boricua steak sandwich is alright it's lacking salt though, however had potential of being a delicious sandwich.

Went here with my sis and hubby for lunch and everything we had was pretty good. Sopa de salchichon, bistek encebollado, arroz con Gandules, pork sandwich- all pretty good. Wish I hadn't eaten breakfast to try the coconut oatmeal. I don't like coconut (unless it's a raspado de coco) and don't eat oatmeal often but Chicagos Best gave it excellent reviews and so did the table next to us lol. Service was good too so I would recommend this small corner joint. They also have a brunch buffet if you like that but I'd rather be able to take my leftovers home. Be warned though - the coffee was quite strong lol.

Their Chicharrón de Pollo aka fried chicken thighs, are not to be messed with. Some of the best fried chicken you'll ever find and alone are a reason to drop $15 on their w/e brunch buffet....where they are included along with an Omelette station, sausage/bacon, lasagna, coconut oatmeal, pancakes/french toast, fruit, desserts, and more.  For kids a steal at $7, all you can drink juice and coffee included.For the lesser appetite you can forgo the brunch buffet and still do yourself right with the regular sandwich menu which is great....the Coqui breakfast sandwich and any of their Jibaritos are the standouts.You'll find Nellie's on that non descript corner of Division about halfway between those Iron Flags of glory and across the street from the best bike shop on the West side.  Check it out.

This was such a great experience from start to finish. From placing a reservation online to getting set quickly upon arrival. The server's were all so attentive and the food was TOP NOTCH. What really made the experience memorable was when Cynthia can't by to ensure we enjoyed our meal and had a great conversation with my friend who is also from Puerto Rico. This was so personable and such good food that it will now be a regular brunch spot that I'll introduce folks to when I'm visiting Chicago. YUM!!!

Nellie's is a warm neighborhood restaurant with a delicious and different coconut oatmeal and interesting art on the walls. I enjoyed the generous Nellie's Breakfast Special with a fluffy omelet and garlicky toast while my friend had thick slices of French Toast and a heaping side dish of bacon. The woman who took our orders was very competent but be prepared for somewhat young and inexperienced bus boys.
Good service, the food is fresh, I will definitely come back. Loved that oatmeal with canela, and veggie omelette.

I am someone who can be very frugal with my money so $16 for one meal has to be worth it. Well, the brunch buffet is definitely worth it! It's probably the best brunch buffet I've ever had. Whenever I have someone visiting from out of town, I always suggest this place.The brunch includes:An omelette stationPastelon de huevoAvena de coco (coconut oatmeal)French toastPancakesBaconSausageSeasoned breakfast potatoesToastSeasonal fresh fruitCoffee and orange juiceMake sure you try the avena de coco

I enjoyed th coqui sandwhich. Great neighborhood joint. My only complaint was the slow service, took nearly an hour to get our food. Plus paying was a complete disaster. I liked that its BYOB so take full advantage and don't goto if you're in a hurry.

AVENA DE COCO... That is, if you happen to be in like or in love & absolutely obsessed with the warm, stick to your stomach, full of flavor (that scream "Caribbean") coconut infused absolutely AH-mazing oatmeal, then THIS my Yelp! Friends is your place to go. And mine to say the least.P.S. Go for the Avena but visit the buffet while you are here, you will not be disappointed.
Love the brunch. Friendly service. You have to try the oatmeal, it's to die for.

I ate breakfast here this morning. My friends' brother-in-law (A Chi-town native) suggested we try it out based on word-of-mouth suggestion from his co-workers.Our party of four all had the breakfast buffet. We were all blown away by the customer service. Most of the servers/people attending to the tables were very young adults and at least two of them had to be less than 18 year old teenagers. They were absolutely fantastic! They were very courteous, pleasant and were always buzzing by to re-fill the drinks and to remove plates. My friend was so impressed he left a $20 tip...The food was fantastic as well. A lot of others reviewing Nellie's already summed up the buffet so I won't dive too much into it but I was for seconds on the Pastelon de huevo. The Coco Oatmeal was very unique and tasty, especially when I added the fried plantains to it. The one thing we all raved about was the omelette. The man making them must have seasoned them with something special because we could taste something a little extra in there--but it was a good thing ;) I had mine with feta and all veggies and would of went again had I not doubled up on the other items!I don't live in Chicago but if I ever come back I will be returning here.

Not all hyped up the way I expected. I tried the buffet. A lot of options, but it was not as tasty or fresh as i expected. The service was very good. All very sweet staff. And the omelette station was superb, but  the buffet was not worth it. I didn't try any food off the menu, but you may be better off since it will be served fresh.

LOVE THEIR FOOD!!!! However, the amount of time it takes to get an order really needs to be adjusted some how, because a hungry, Puerto Rican woman in a rush is def a lethal combination. The buffet on the weekends are AWESOME!!!!..

Today was my first visit. 12:00 noon on Thursday. Although the restaurant was not "packed", I noticed there were quite a few large carry out orders. It did take them a reasonable amount of time to bring the food. Not fast but not slow and expected for a restaurant that serves delicious food at lunch time.The ambiance reminded me of the Dominican Republic. Loved it. Simple. The food was Delicious! Served quickly after preparing. I had their special Tortilla Boricua which is an open faced omlet. I asked to substitute toast and was offered a delicious bowl of fruit. The service was great. If you need something, ask for it with a smile. This is a lesson in life that well take you a long way. Relax! Also, consider avoiding the weekend lunch buffet if you do not like crowded, busy, delicious restaurants!THE OATMEAL....... ! I'm definitely coming back for the Mofongo!

Avena de coco is delicious!Ordered the Nellies Special which was great, the sweet plantain was different, but good!I also took a few bites of The El Coqui sandwich which was also great...no complaints on my end.  Will definitely be coming back to try out the brunch buffet they have on the weekends!

Delicious, clean, easy street pay box parking. Courteous service. Went in for breakfast and the coconut avena (oatmeal) is so delicious it's a must! The coqui breakfast sandwich, amazing and oh so filling also a must! My kids had pancakes and the other had the standard eggs, bacon, potatoes. They loved it. Standard breakfast prices. Wepa! Check it out....

Six of us enjoyed brunch at Nellie's on a recent Saturday a little before noon. We got the buffet. The food was incredibly delicious. The magic oatmeal (it tastes sort of like horchata) is beyond ... the omelets were delicious -- delicately cooked and mine was seriously amped by the addition of a pinch of adobo. They have adobo and oregano as options as well as diced onion, mushroom, tomato, spinach (and maybe peppers?) and cheese and sausage. The yellow rice with pigeon peas is  addictive and their potatoes are deceptively simple: sliced up and cooked with salt and pepper. Not greasy, not soggy, a little fluffy almost. Just seriously potato-y. They also have beautiful cut-up fresh melon and pineapple. The place is also very cute and the staff is lovely--warm, kind and helpful. It is so close to getting 5 stars. I won't like, most of us went back for seconds on things--I got a little more oatmeal, rice and chicken--even though I was already full. They were that good. The only small hiccup: the delicious small pieces of fried chicken leg on the buffet were a bit dried out. Note to tea drinkers; it seems that they don't serve hot black ("regular) tea, though they have hot green tea and two lovely herbals. They do serve regular (black) unsweetened iced tea.

Food was amazing but the service was terrible. We were never even acknowledged after 15minutes of just sitting there...finally we had to request a waitress. The place was not even that busy so there is no excuse for the negligent service. We were never offered water or checked up on even after receiving our meal. I really loved the food but the service was a deal breaker. Jibarito, coconut oat meal is a must though!

Great food and even on the weekends it is rare to encounter a wait time of more than 15 minutes (usually there is no wait at all). Has a pretty good buffet for inpatient consumers; however, the service is rarely as good as the food and identifying your actual server/paying for the bill can be frustrating at times.

The food at this place is phenomenal. The coconut oatmeal is just as delicious as everyone says it is - portions are big and prices are very cheap. You have to be prepared to deal with a loud, chaotic environment in there, and the service is slow and lacking in charm - probably not somewhere to bring your grandma visiting from out of town. If you're good with dealing with all of that though, you're in for a great meal. Get there early or make a reservation. We got there at about noon on a Sunday and fortunately had a reservation, because the wait time was an hour and a half.

I came in here with four friends for a basic brunch.The service was awful. We had about 4 different "servers" erratically checking up on us, sometimes 4 within a couple minutes, sometimes no one would come by for 20 minutes.No one knew what the heck they were doing. Two of our "servers" would ask if we wanted coffee, and they brought it to us 30 minutes later.One of the servers kept sticking his arms over our table to grab plates that still had food on them. He repeatedly asked if we liked the house-made hot sauce and if we wanted to buy some.We waited 30 minutes for a check, and we finally went up to the cash register to get it. The cashier ran the wrong ticket, and then he finally ran our ticket, but grabbed it and walked away for a few minutes. He came back, and they ADDED A 20% AUTOMATIC GRATUITY.This is shameful! We only had a party of five - we weren't told there would be an auto-gratuity and 20% GRATUITY IS FAR TOO MUCH. The service was horrible.The food was bland.To top it off, I got FOOD POISONING later that evening from eating their bland, watery omelets and cold, flavorless ham jibarrito.

The food and service is good, we got there on a Sunday and they had just opened. There was no where for us to sit. They where waiting for people to come in that had a reservation. So we were forced to leave or sit at the bar. The buffet is $16.00 to much for an ok breakfast.

I went here twice for breakfast and lunch in one day. That's how much I love Nellie's. I called in my lunch order and they were efficient and courteous on the phone. A big plus for me.  I had that yummy coconut-cinnamon oatmeal for breakfast.  For the larger size, it is way too small and overpriced.  I could have easily eaten 2 but I'm not spending $9 for oatmeal.  For lunch I had the knock my socks off chicken jibarito and maduros.  They give you SO much rice/beans to go with it.  What a filling, worth every penny meal. I have had the mofongo on another occasion and it was just OK.  Unimpressive.

Came for the brunch buffet. The Avena de coco (coconut oatmeal) was clearly the best part, especially on a very cold day. The service was ridiculously on point! We had about 5 waiters helping us. The made to order omelette guy was outstanding; he pointed out what to try in the buffet. The lasagna was savory, sweet, and terrific.
Great buffet option for breakfast! Not the flashiest place in town, but a super nice and attentive staff. I would definitely g

Great authentic Puerto Rican food and American breakfast options taken up a notch. You HAVE to try their buffet and they're BYOB! Best place in Humboldt park West Town for breakfast and brunch. Not to mention the best Puerto Rican food on paseo Boricua weekdays for lunch.

If I could give this place 6 stars, I would. Delicious food and awesome customer service at Nellie's. El Coqui sandwhich is amazing and I also tried and loved the coconut oatmeal. I would highly recommend eating here to anyone staying in or visiting the area. The coffee is also really good!

Very good breakfast sandwich at Nellies. Try the Coqui sandwich with eggs, avocado, and veggies in a grilled bun. Very tasty. Next is the delishes pancakes - man, super good. If you have kiddos they will love. Also try the avena con canela was good too.We ordered out the time I was there because the wait time was too long but would come back to eat there and try other dishes.

Came in on a Sunday morning and was tremendously pleased with everything! Our waiter was funny, quick and gave my friend and I avena de coco on the house. Wouldn't have spent my morning any other way.
Fantastic brunch when your in the mood for a Puerto Rican breakfast! Pastelon was scrumptious, made to order omelettes were hot and fresh. Avena de coco is so creamy, I highly recommend trying it!
Great breakfast! I gotta go back n check out their brunch buffet. Can't go wrong with the Nellie's special. Da avena de coco is da shiet!
Coconut oatmeal and jibaritos de lechon are my favorites but anything you order from nellies is delish!
Fresh, hot and ready! Love the brunch buffet! And the fresh omelet with sofrito....Mmmm...like no other! Super clean and beautiful art work! Definitely will be back!

HOLY MOTHER OF BREAKFAST SANDWICHES!  Get the El Coqui with a cup of coconut oatmeal.  Thank me later.  I think I may defect to Puerto Rico - oh wait - they are practically American so that probably won't work.The vehicle for the eggy goodness was the most delicious Cuban type bread which was lightly garlic buttered and toasted.  I'm starting to drool just writing this.  We originally planned to go to Bongo Room but it was a crazy 40 minute wait.  So we Yelped 'nearbys' and Nellie's came up.  You Yelpers are sooooo AWESOME!Great parking, cute place, good coffee which our server kept flowing almost non-stop.  The buffet looked amazing and is dedicated to an entire room with a made to order omelet station.One of my favorite breakfasts in Chicago.

I was so tempted to stay in the area so I could order off the lunch menu later in the day. That's how much I loved the breakfast at Nellie's.A group of us came in for breakfast on a Sunday. They were almost empty when we arrived at 930 (yeah we like to start the day early on Sundays sometimes) but by the time we left, the restaurant was full with a line of folks waiting to be seated.My husband and I went with the Breakfast Buffet--it was the best way to sample some things on the menu and plus, kids under 3 eat for free!  The two others in our group went with the breakfast special and omelet and both looked really good.There is quite a lot to choose from in their buffet--Pastelone de Huevos (which is like an egg strata, with a layer of ground beef and plantains) breakfast potatoes, bacon, sausage links, pancakes, french toast, an omelet station, Maduros (sweet plantains), fresh fruit and the Avena de Coco (the famous coconut oatmeal dusted with cinnamon). There's also fried chicken and arroz con gandules.My husband and I split an omelet we had made at the omelet station. We ordered what was basically the omelet in the breakfast special. An open faced omelet seasoned with sofrito, cheese, tomatoes, onions, green peppers, salchion sausage and maduros. It was fantastic. Very flavorful and well-made.The oatmeal was not like any other oatmeal I've had, it was very creamy and filling. The coconut milk adds so much richness and flavor. Perfect comfort food.My other favorites of the buffet include the little pieces of fried chicken. So crispy on the outside but very tender on the inside. And the plantains--a bit sticky from the carmelization, not overly sweet either. And they use fresh ripe plantains so no hint of bland/bitterness.Service was so friendly and anticipated our needs. Our server was funny and kept us entertained by his jokes and friendly banter.  Our coffee cups never went empty and water glasses were always filled.

This review is based solely on the weekend brunch. Without a doubt the food is 4-5 stars. The gentleman they have makes the best omelettes to order.  However the service is horrible. The service is nonexistent. I have gone 3 times in 3 years and each time it is the same thing. Nobody comes to check on you. Nobody refills coffee or water. I went Sunday Feb 8 and I am still waiting on my glass of orange juice.Do not get me wrong, everyone is cordial and nice. However you need to tackle someone to get any attention. The only reasons I keep going is because I want to see a Puerto Rican place do well and I hope their service gets better. Every time I have gone, it was to take non-Puerto Rican out of town guests and introduce them to something different. They loved the food but hated the service.
I had El Coqui scrambled eggs and it was wonderful! The restaurant atmosphere is really cute and service was very nice and attentive. Great place for breakfast :)
This restaurant had great overall service from the get go. Not to mention the food was great as well.

$14.95 for the all you can eat breakfast buffet available on Saturday and Sunday.Overall the buffet was pretty good. The coconut oatmeal was available, and my husband went back for 3rds. I had to abstain due to an allergy but it smelled amazing.The omelets they make for you are good, but they use eggbeaters unless you request fresh eggs, something I wish I had known about before starting.Nice selection of fresh fruit, and they also offered fried plantains. I got them two separate ways. The first time they were kind of old and therefore not terribly appetizing. The second time, I got them as they were being put out and they were simply divine.A word of caution. The orange juice is listed as "fresh squeezed" but we watched them pour it from a store bought jug.Be prepared to wait at least 30 minutes to get sat as they're pretty popular. We opted to sit at the bar so we got served much faster than others.We will definitely consider going back, even if it is a bit of a trek from where we live.
What can I say.. this place is great... Ask for the Coqui scrammble . You won't be disappointed.

Whoa, Nellie's! Breakfast in Humboldt has no equal. For starters, get the coconut oatmeal- it is heaven. Served with a sprinkling of cinnamon, I kind of giggled, thinking of being a kid again. (I promise never to giggle again- it's not a good quality in a man).The oatmeal was part of my Puerto Rican Special- an omelette as big as a plate, with onions, peppers, and topped with plantains. Very tasty! Coffee was good, not weak, and service was great.On a weekday morning, not many people at Nellie's, but it started to fill up. Conversations around us started to percolate, and we met a man who was part of the 1966 Division Street Riots. So great to meet a living part of history, and Nellie's is kind of a nice reminder that douchebag expansion stays east of Western.Nellie's and breakfast- Keepin' it real in Humboldt!

I had to go try Nellie's after reading the yelp reviews.  This was a day I wanted to eat semi-healthy, but I ended up having the buffet.  The only healthy thing was the fruit.  If you like to eat and can eat a lot, then the buffet option is for you!  They have omelettes, waffles, pancakes, bacon, sausage, french toast, pancakes, Puerto Rican lasagna (yummy - would order this by itself), coconut oatmeal and many other food items.  I would say everything was good, but what stands out is the lasagna and the oatmeal (more authentic).   My husband had the Nellie's breakfast special and said he would definitely go back for it.  I had a bite and would definitely go back for it (I liked the plantains on top).  The oatmeal was good, but nothing I would go back for.Customer Service:  The girl we had should stay at the cash register.  She couldn't put down her phone long enough to take our order (kept on texting).  I'm amazed by people's customer service skills.  I hope our tip went to the other hard workers there  (the busser was acting more like our server).  I'm taking 1/2 a star off for this.It's definitely a place to visit to see if it's the right fit for you.  They have good food and the price is right.

The way they do the seating for the Sunday brunch isn't fair or consistent. You can have a party of 2 waiting for 45 minutes and then a party of 6 walks up and they seat them right away. Finally it was our turn, or so we thought. Then they seated 2 adults and a child that came in after us. Their answer was that they need to sit at least 3 people to a 4 person table.  And no apologies were offered.

I'll take Nellie's over any of the nearby overpriced, overrated brunch places. The authentic Puerto Rican breakfast is something you won't find anywhere else in the city. Having a Groupon all the time (with the ability to take out!) doesn't hurt either! Some of my favorite features include the special Puerto Rican omlette with plantains cooked inside, the plaintains themselves, the El Coqui breakfast sandwich (massive), and of course, the coconut oatmeal! It's a bit out of the way for some, but close enough to Wicker Park & Ukrainian Village for those who don't know about it. This place is definitely worth going West of Western for.

Great, authentic, Puerto Rican cuisine. Puerto Rican art you want to take home. Famous for Avena De Coco and for good reason. The best oatmeal in the city.Caveats:-Do not dare touch food from a person's buffet plate. I nearly was kicked out for trying a sausage from my boyfriends plate.-bill can only be split twice.

oye latinos!  oye puerto rico!the other Sunday I straight up passed on sex, for brunch at Nellies.do yourself a solid papa, take on the breakfast buffet or Nellies special. try not to cry tears of golden unicorns when you taste the avena de coco; you can cry, just do it silently."who needs to sit hungrily for 2 hours for brunch in a bar that your roommates were puking in just hours earlier...f*ckin really tho"-cham

Came here to try the breakfast buffet.  Fill up on the Puerto Rican stuff, and skip the American stuff.  You'll thank me.  They switch weekends between two chicken dishes (one is fried, and one is braised).  We were lucky enough to try the braised chicken w/ rice.  IT IS SO DELICIOUS. Like, what you'd eat at your grandma's house after school delicious.  Also delicious,  the casserole layered with plantains, tomatoes, and beef.The oatmeal is coconutty and cinnamonny, and has a consistency almost like snot, but in the best way possible? I'm good at selling food, no?Service is super friendly here, which I always appreciate.

I am about to feel so horrible with this review, but when I became ELITE I said I would always be honest and not read anyone else's review until after. I am SO DISAPPOINTED!No one sat us down (but than again no one was to be seen for over 10 minutes and I could of been a theif in the temple and no one would ever be wise),  We ended up seating ourselves although the sign clearly says "WAIT TO BE SEATED". No utensils (I got up to get mine even after the waitress saw us). I was really hoping for a beautiful experience but unfortunately it wasn't. Thus far its been over 25 minutes since our order and we are on lunch break hello. The food took another 25 minutes to get here and so basically almost a whole 50 minutes has passed and its time to go. My co worker of course was really PO'ed since we are very funny with our lunch breaks! I asked the waiter and waitress for some water and some utensil's while I looked at my food. I just order the Nellies Special which consisted of Coconut Oatmeal (ummmm I didn't get the big deal to be honest) and eggs with red/green peppers and onions (typical omelet) except this one had plantains nestled in the omelet, again nothing really popped to me as special.I think that although it was 11:30 and only 2 other couples sitting, this place just  seems extremely unorganized.Now we just over heard that there is no breaded steak? And this person ordered it over 20 minutes ago and they are just telling him no breaded steak? WHAT! The very idea that a restaurant can tell someone twenty minutes after they ordered that there is no breaded steak? Come on now, this is unimaginable. I am utterly shocked.Well the hour is almost up so I took two bites of the omelet (and it was cold when they brought it out) and I had to ask for a take out. This has been the worse lunch experience in a long time, and you all know that I don't like to bad mouth a business, and I am trying not too. I think that the waiter and waitress should get some kind of herbal tonic because they seemed to of been very unorganized and forgetful. This is definitely going down in my archives as really weird service.Sorry, but if you want better food and excellent service, I have to send you down the block to La Bruquenia since they are really into great service.

We came here for lunch on a weekday and I was really excited to try Puerto Rican food since I've never had it before. My friend and I split the Steak Jibarito and the Stuffed Mofongo with steak. I thought the jibarito was amazing! It's basically a sandwich that uses two large plantain pieces to hold the sandwich together instead of using bread. With the entree we also got the Puerto Rican yellow rice with pigeon peas which was delicious and full of flavor. The stuffed mofongo was a bit dry for my taste. The steak wasn't as juicy and the whole thing lacked the kick I was looking for. However, the soup that the mofongo came with was absolutely addictive. I kept finding myself sneaking a sip!It seems like the breakfast/brunch has good reviews so if I happen to come back it'll most likely be for that!

The weekend brunch is amazing with all the Puerto Rican favs and traditional American breakfast foods. It's $15.00 a person with unlimited coffee and OJ. The coffee is not good but if you want good coffee go to Cafe Colao right down the street. I think they are owned by the same people. The OJ is great! The  Avena De Coco is the best I ever had (sorry abuela). Great place to take people from out of town. Be prepared to wait if you go during peak hours but it's worth it!!

Nellie's is a quiet place where to have a brunch in the Portorican neighborhood.Nothing fancy, but the French toast combo (eggs and bacon) was as good as expected. Friendly service and a good experience overall.

This is truely a diamond in the rough. The food is fresh, authentic and all around delicious! The customer service is beyond comparing. I felt like I was at home with how approachable everyone was. One thing that you must try is their homemade oatmeal! Once you get a taste of this treat, your world will never be the same.If you are near or far and want to try a real authentic Puerto Rican meal, nellies is your destination! Besides, nellies is in the heart of Chicagos greatest Puerto Rican cultured neighborhood.

This place is horrible, awful, whatever you do-DO NOT EAT HERE!Oh yeah?? Still reading.  FINE!  SUFFER THE CONSEQUENCES!! ALL OF THEM.YUP,  I MEAN IT!!  I am not just randomly yelling at you! SERIOUSLY!OK, wear some elastic waist pants.  You are going to want them.  No need to be coy.  We are past that. Come on folks.  You hipsters, you.  You can deal with it.  Or not. Have a seat. If you are out of your depth, my friends and I will eat your portion.You see, the $14.95 all you can eat breakfast bar is more than some of us can take.  It pushes us past the breaking point of our willpower, if we had any. We do like to pretend, at times.  Nellie's strips us to our bare essence, turning us into slavering, greedy, food mashing, eating machines with one goal- EAT ALL THE FOODS.And my goodness.  You will NOT regret it here.  Well, the uncomfortable fullness you might, but the food, nah, no way!!Ah, today!  I am still satiated from this morning.  To give you a hint, I ate brunch at around 11:30 am.  It is now 8:30 pm and food does not sound like anything I need. Puerto Rican Breakfast floats my boat!  We ate, oh boy did we eat!Avena de Coco- this delightful oatmeal that is coconut and slightly cinnamon infused  is SPECTACULAR!!Egg Casserole- Plantains, eggs, meat and totally different than what is usual!Plantains galore!!Bacon!They also offer sausage, an omelette stand, pancakes, french toast, and dessert .HELLO!!! Is this not enough food?? This place is amazing!  Seriously.  STAY AWAY!!!  Your pants may not fit.

Went there for brunch because my Latina side was kind of screaming for food this morning.I really don't have that much to say.  Staff was polite, but not remarkable.  Food was good, but nothing I couldn't cook at home and it wasn't "WOW" food, it was more like "eh" food.But it's ok. Price is reasonable.The two things I liked the most were the coconut oatmeal and the plantain/beef casserole.

An amazing place for breakfast and lunch! My wife and I went to Nellie's on a Sunday afternoon to have brunch with a couple of friends. The buffet was amazing! It has sausages, bacon, fried plantains, breakfast casserole, fried chicken, oatmeal and omelettes made to order. If you don't want the buffet you have to try the Beef Jibarito!Yumm!!

Try the breakfast buffet on the weekends!  Try everything else all the time!  The service and food have been outstanding each time, which is why after just one visit  this became our go-to for weekend brunch.  Affordable deliciousness is always good.Reasons for the buffet?1.  Build-your-own omelettes cooked to order.2.  Options for even the pickiest eaters.3. The oatmeal should be illegal.  I mean seriously, who's ever heard of oatmeal that is so ridiculously tasty that people rave about it?Tip: Get that infamous oatmeal!  I don't even like cinnamon that much, my husband isn't a fan of coconut, and we still fought over who got to finish the oatmeal the first time we went to Nellie's.

Puerto Rican Breakfast!Avena de Coco: Coconut infused oatmeal/porridge. Definitely on the runnier side (which is good!) and oh-so-sweetly-satisifying. It'll stick to your ribs, but with shiz like this...you want it stickin'!Puerto Rican Omelette: Holy heavens, one of the bestest omelettes in all the land, and it hails west of Western, folks. A whole lotta eggs, veggies...and soft, soaked plantains baked into the top.Served with what I'll call "PR toast points." Basically, french bread slices, toasted with aromatic punch that'll wake you up, STAT.All of this? $8.95. Yeah, less than a tenner. Go for it.*Closed Mondays/Tuesdays*Only open breakfast/lunch*Avoid the brunch waits in nearby blue line 'hoods, go to Nellie's.*pretty good coffee.*GREAT/friendly/fast service*inexpensive*huge portions*super easy parkingPuerto Ricans apparently do breakfast/brunch extremely well. Proof in the avena de coco, yo.

In the "corazon" of Humboldt Park sits Nellies, a patriotic brunch cafecito that boasts to have the only Puerto Rican breakfast buffet in the city.  Step through the colonial-looking door into your abuelas home with art of national heros, countryside and family back in la patria (the homeland). I wasn't hungry enough to get the $15 All You Can Eat Buffet but Nellie has got my back with the, you guessed it, Nellie's Breakfast Special.  You get a taste of all the good stuff: The infamous avena de coco (coconut oatmeal), pan tostada (toasted bread), tortilla boricua (Puerto Rican omelet) and maduros (ripe fried plantains). Mmm mmm like coffee time at abuelitas.  My boyfriend had the $4 ham, egg and cheese sandwich which was a bargain.  The huuuge sandwich on fresh artisan bread with the additional side of avocado plopped on top made it perfection.I will warn you that even though the waitress was far from being a grandmother in age, she was slower than one!  With the delicious island cuisine comes with its cultural additions.  Come here with plenty of time to chill out with some fresh drip coffee and patience (the free, unprotected WiFi helps!).  Yet, Nellie's is the perfect place to begin a Humboldt Park neighborhood exploration or sports day.
This is temporarily closed.  We tried calling and phone wasn't working.  Usually the Avena de coco and Maduros are super yummy!

Based on a negative review I read from some lady with a ridiculous name, who only seems to leave negative reviews in her trail,  I thought I'd come to try the breakfast buffet!WOW! I'm in love! I like spicy foods but I'm not sure I've ever had traditional Puerto Rican food. The eggs were fluffy and fresh, the meat was juicy (also indicative of freshness) and the staff was polite.I'd def. recommend this place during sun-up hours!

We redeemed my Groupon here for a Friday lunch. It was a pretty cool day, and I was surprised that they wouldn't turn up the heat a bit more considering my sister and a couple other people left their coats on. I felt rather cool myself without my coat and was rubbing my arms to keep warm. We placed our order and didn't get our food until 45 minute later, which was very surprising to have the waitress come back to tell me that they were out of the yellow rice with Pigeon peas. I have to wonder how they decided who got to have the remaining, since I did give her my order before my sister and this guy that came in after us also got to have the yellow rice and his meal before us while I had to accept getting the white rice and beans unless I wanted to wait for them to cook more. This is quite ridiculous considering we got here for lunch at 12:20pm, how do you run out of a main staple item at a prime lunch time hour...? I can't believe it would also take so long to tell your customer that you ran out. The pork jibarito I had was quite small in terms of portion, and probably the smallest of all the Latin restaurants I have been to. Some bits of my pork were dry and crispy/sharp. I'd probably cross the street if I have another craving for a jibarito.

I wanna give this place a better review because their food is great and the gentleman that makes their omelettes is cool and funny, but their table service SUCKS. Their waiters are consistently neglect my table. The male waiters only come by when I'm with a woman, otherwise they don't come by at all. I have never had a refill on water, coffee, juice, etc without having to ask several times. Idk why, and I genuinely love this place, but like many locally owned establishments in Humboldt Park, if you don't know someone who is friends with the staff, prepare to be neglected and have the slowest service possible.

Although it took some time to gather our meal, they forgot bacon, oatmeal, toast and catchup, once we got it, the food was excellent and very generous portions.Oatmeal is worth raving about, delish, not thick, nice gentle texture and amazing flavor, aromatic almost.We sat next to a large table and acoustics in this place is so terrible that we couldn't hear each other at all. Once most people left the place we could resume the conversation. I'm still not reducing the stars in this review because our breakfast was worth it.They had buffet on Saturday too but we found ordering off the menu is plenty food.

Avena de Coco!!!I'm the type of person who prefers hot chocolate with milk, oatmeal with milk, everything with milk. I like it creamy. Add coconut milk to this oatmeal/porridge of sorts and it's a win-win situation. Honestly, I ate the cup so quickly it made me hungry for more. I ordered the first thing on the menu...  Nellie's special or something like that. It pretty much encompassed everything you would want from the buffet for $9.50 instead of $15. It was a huge omelet with plantain, came with the coconut oatmeal, etc. The best part about the meal was the oatmeal though. Don't get me wrong, I ate the omelet but it didn't wow me. I love plantain so that was an exciting addition that I've never seen done before. Overall though, I'd only go back for the oatmeal! But that's not enough for me to rate it above a 3 sadly.

Yes yes yes yes yes. Gimme all that delicious Puerto Rican food. I had been to Nellie's once before for and event where they did the catered style food and was impressed, but when I went yesterday for breakfast my mind was blown. I ordered the El Coqui Sandwich and it was easily two meals - that bad boy is HUGE. And amazing. And the ingredients are super fresh. My friends got the coconut oatmeal (avena de coco), the veggie omelet, and the pancakes, and we were all stuffed and happy when we left. I have heard wonderful things about their brunch and will need to go back one of these weekend.

This has got to be the most underrated breakfast in all of ChicagoBest groupon deal we purchased in all of 2012.Who can beat omelette station, Puerto Rican fried chicken AND coconut cinnamon oatmeal! No one. Crispy fried bacon, sausage, French toast. Oh, and BYOB for your own mixed bellinis and screwdrivers. The staff there are very accommodating, situating customers at the bar till one of the tables are open.Highly recommend for a tasty family breakfast or even a girls' Sunday brunch!
Amazing local joint in the hood. The breakfast sammies are HUGE, and they are only 6 bucks. Great spot. If you're near WIcker Park hit this place up. The workers are always really nice too.

I had to go and see for my self with all great reviews , to start walked in there is assign stating to wait to be seated not really a female at the end of the bar looking at you . I walked over she asked may I help you is not welcome to Nellie's,   I told her table for one she replied table for one got my table she offer coffee it as a while before she got the coffee but gave it to another 'waitress '  I ordered the nellies special I got my oatmeal it was good when I finished got my omelet really fluffy and hot but looks like all the ingredients were finely shredded not having flavor at all and they never come by the table    to offer more coffee or to see how is everything also overpriced 15.00 for just that I don't have a problem paying for good breakfast ,but service ,quality, and price no go usually give a second try but  not on this time

Super rico de Puerto Rico!  Breakfast here is fantastic.  I had the El Coqui sandwich which was eggs, tomatoes, cheese, onions and mayo on garlicky french bread.  The eggs were nice and fluffy, and all fresh.  A side of fried bananas (maduros) was also delicious: naturally sweet and lightly browned.  You must try them! My cousin had a roast pork jibarito, which is a sandwich made with crispy plantains instead of bread.  She also adored hers.The service was friendly, and the restaurant was clean with nice Puerto Rican art all around.  The waiter accidentally spilled our milk, and got some on my cousin.  He apologized many times, and then brought us complimentary coconut oatmeal.  This was super tasty, if a bit liquidy for my taste.  But, a very nice gesture.Lastly, if all of the above doesn't convince you, just go to check out the bathroom.  It was reminiscent of some chambers in an old Spanish castle, and you could wash your hands while sitting on the toilet if you so chose.  This was entertaining to me.

I have walked past this place several times and wondered what was going on in here. Today I walked over and was pleased I took the chance and opened the heavy Gothic door and walked inside. I think this must have been a Scottish pub years ago since the same heavy doors are used for the men's and women's bathrooms!Anyhow, the food:I took a pass on the $14.95 all you can eat breakfast buffet, but it looked wonderful and had a mix of Puerto Rican and American style favorites. I opted for the eggs, sausage, and sweet plantains with multigrain toast (two pieces of real toast, not the single piece in two!). Everything was perfect, and the plantains were fresh and mind-blowingly perfect! Yum in the tum!The menu had sandwiches from about $3 and most everything was under $10. My breakfast with coffee was under $7.They only seem to have regular drip coffee, which is a shame because Puerto Rican cafe is pretty darned good. I had a couple cups off the diner-style coffee and was happy, but thought that I might like an espresso or a cafe-con-leche next time.Now, I sat down then realized that depending on the waitstaff you might have to go up to the register to order. Since it was my first time, I got up after sitting for a few minutes and ordered. The place is very chilled out, and unrushed, so, take this into consideration.The place is run by a family and the kids came in to visit the parents, and there was a big table of people with strollers, so if you can get your stroller past the big heavy door, this place seems to welcome kids.They have free wi-fi and since it was a bar, the long bar might be a place to sit and drink a few cups of drip coffee and surf the net. There are tons of tasteful framed photos of Puerto Rico, and some very cool Puerto Rican national paintings on the wall.I could see myself skipping the places further East on Division and going here instead to try everything on the menu!They are open Wed-Sun.

I would love to give this place four stars! Come on its Puerto Rican breakfast! Sadly it only gets one star based on service. I have been to Nellies a good amount of times but have decided based on my last visit to never return. The service is terrible and there is a certain guy who works there who has made me very uncomfortable every time I've been there. I am actually saddened to walk in and see he is still employed by you guys. He is above all very rude and makes comments that have made various people who have accompanied me on separate occasions feel very uncomfortable. I love the food here and the oatmeal is to die for but it's just not worth the hassle!

Sunday, November 11th at 10:00AMDavid (my boyfriend): I have a surprise for you.Me: OH really? *shifty eyes*David: I got a Groupon for Nellie's. Let's go to get brunch!Me: Oh, okay...I thought it wasn't much of a surprise. Going out to eat is a regular weekend activity for us. Plus, brunch is just eggs and carbs. I wasn't expecting much at Nellie's, a casual Puerto Rican restaurant in Humboldt Park. It must be average.I was COMPLETELY wrong. Like, 1 + 1 = Zebra wrong.We arrived at 11:00AM. The wait was 30 minutes. Yikes. This was the result of the Groupon. The neighborhood is desolate, so there's nothing we could do but wait. The hostess was very sweet though; she is the daughter of the owner. When we were finally seated, I saw that the waitstaff used the cool iPhone ordering system to take our orders. I have never seen those in a restaurant in Chicago (only on Gordon Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares)! That is pretty damn nifty.I ordered the El Coqui Scrambled Eggs ($8.50) and side of Plantains ($2.75) and David had the Breakfast Buffet ($14.99). The menu is pretty vegetarian-friendly. Anyway, I didn't see the buffet area in the back, but David told me it is impressive. Some Yelper mentioned that it was small, but it is not. For a buffet, you get a good selection: sausage, bacon, pancakes, french toast, omelettes (you can choose the fillings), fresh fruit, and ...Avena de Coco. Coconut Oatmeal.I had only one spoonful of it. My boyfriend is a stickler to rules and didn't want me to "mooch" off his cup of oatmeal and cheat the restaurant, even though I just wanted to have ONE more spoonful to determine whether or not I like it. (He's difficult like that.) I think my opinion on the oatmeal are fuzzy, since I only had about a teaspoon of it. It's good, although a little watery. It needed more oatmeal. I'm not sure what's all the big fuss is about with this oatmeal. It's good, but not THAT GOOD.David ordered orange juice (fresh squeezed), and it was also taking a very, very long time to come out. As I watched David eat his food, I started to wonder what was taking so long for his orange juice.Me: Maybe they are HAND-squeezing your orange juice specially for you, David!*some time later*Me: Maybe they are importing the oranges from Brazil JUST for you, David!*some more time later*Me: Maybe they are growing the oranges JUST for you, David!It turns out that the orange juice was freshly squeeze as they didn't start serving it to everyone until later. I assume that there was a delay in the orange juice because someone had to squeeze the oranges.My food also took forever to come out. I also started to believe that they went to get the eggs from the grocery store, then the farm, then actually raising the chickens. It was taking a very, very long time for my food.You'd be surprised that I didn't mind it one bit. You gotta be understand the circumstance they're in. (I wasn't that hungry anyway.)When my food finally arrived, I was extremely pleased with what I received:- Breakfast potatoes: Mashed baked potatoes with skin still on. SO GOOD!!- Wheat toast: Thick slices of multigrain bread. Not the cheap crap!- Plantains: Caramelized and sliced.- Scrambled eggs: Fluffy and PERFECTLY cooked with slightly mashed slices of avocado on top. I actually prefer this over the pretty slices of avocado. It's easier to mix the avocado in with the eggs.I was so happy. I had the eggs with Nellie's hot sauce, which is pretty damn spicy. Word of caution: It's very watery, so it'll pour right out of the bottle. Be careful.Our brunch was a very long brunch, but it was the best brunch I had in a long time. I have paid more money for mediocre dishes with lower quality ingredients elsewhere. Nellie's is extremely reasonably-priced for the quality and quantity you get, and everyone there was friendly. The artwork was impressive as well. Again, we didn't care about the wait at all. We had a good time regardless!Nellie's really took me by surprise. I am very happy to discover such a wonderful, charming place. This place is full of win and 5-stars.PS: Parking is free on Sundays until 4pm!

OMG. Puerto Rican brunch! Woooooooo!I got the coconut oatmeal, fruit, pancakes, a made-to-order omelette, rice and beans and something else I'm forgetting. I was so full it was hard to continue living afterwards.The bottom line is that the food is so good you might want to die afterwards to avoid ever having to eat a lesser (read: all) meal ever again.Nom Nom Nom. Saturday! Come on Saturday!OH! My friends go the plantain sandwich thingy. That is also super delish apparently. Just, get on it folks.

4 stars for service - on a Sunday at 11 AM, it was attentive and quick (which was a surprise after reading other reviews)2 stars for the food.  The crunchy french toast was not sweet, which is fine because we had syrup, but then some of the slices tasted like GARLIC.  Did they cook it in the same pan as the garlic toast that they serve with the Nellie's special????  It also was like Jewel wheat bread slices MAYBE dipped in an egg wash with a few sprinkles of corn flakes  -therefore not crunchy.   To be fair, this is a diner but at least use more corn flakes and a different pan!The avena de coco had a mild coconut flavor and was served at room temperature.  It was normal oatmeal, don't go out of your way to eat oatmeal here - make it yourself.The Nellie's special (the omelette) was fine.  The maduros saved the dish.If you want to come here, use a Groupon so you don't feel like you got ripped off

The owner/person in charge is on a power trip where he thinks he should make ppl wait. I sat there for 35 min at lunch time about 1:00 PM, I saw the servers point us out to the person in charge but I was still waiting while I could see 5 0r 6 empty tables through out the restaurant and that is what I could see, there could have been MORE empty tables.So I was thinking to myself, IF THIS IS WHAT HAPPENS IN FRONT OF YOUR FACE, WHAT HAPPENS BEHIND CLOSED DOORS IN THE KITCHEN??  I finally left without eating.
Nellie's is a great place for breakfast.  The coconut oatmeal is stupid good.  Can't wait to come back.

You have to be careful around Nelly's/Nellie's; they can disappoint. For example, Nelly Furtado hasn't come out with a solid album since Folklore. Being called 'nelly' is an insult. The Lou's Nelly's teeth are so jacked, I see them in the deepest, darkest recesses of my mind. And, Nellie Oleson still reigns as one of TVs biggest b!tches. Ever. Not a good track record.It takes a boricua to break the cycle.This spot on Division is serving up breakfast specials in a big way. For starters, you gotta go with the oatmeal. I am not an oatmeal kinda guy (unless it's in a cookie). I was dubious. I tapped that isht. So.good. The oatmeal comes out topped with cinnamon and all coconuty and Caribbean-y and taunting me to shuck it all to move to the islands and live a life of music, food and booty-y. Very tasty way to start your meal. Follow that bowl of goodness up with a Rican omelet: plate-sized egg goodness, filled with peppers, cheese, tomato, onion, ham, AND TOPPED WITH PLANTAINS. Dye your hair platinum, cut it into a crew and scream into the void, "Stop the insanity!" Delicious.Now, improve upon your meal by ordering orange juice or coffee. I ordered the lemonade and while i appreciated the free refills, it was pretty watery and I didn't 'get' it. Stick with breakfast standards. If you're a bread person, you'll like the slightly garlicky crunchy bread that comes with the meal. It's not a deal-breaker or game-changer. It's just there.Stretch out. Relax. Stay a while. The joint is a lot bigger on the inside than what it looks like from the street. This is summer in the city. You gotta do it.

Food gets an A+, Service gets an F-Other reviews describe the food which is just fine. I am going to rant about the employees and management.We made a reservation for Sunday Brunch and showed up on the dot. They had no record of the reservation. However they said they could seat us in 15 minutes. Twenty minutes later a different employee came over and asked if we had a reservation. She had no communication with the previous person.  We told her our story. She said she would seat us in 15 minutes. We finally got seated.We had a group of six people. Four of us ordered the buffet. The other two ordered off the menu.Wait staff were very negligent about refilling coffee and orange juice.We got the check. Like most places they added a tip because we were a group. However the tip was outrageous. They put on a 20% tip. Most places will put on 18% if they do full service. This was mostly buffet! The proper tip for buffet service is 10%.I feel we were ripped off.At this place the food comes with a generous side order of abuse. I will never go back.The good food is not worth taking the abuse.

The main reason why I drop $15 for their all-you-can-eat brunch buffet is for their pastelone de huevos.  Seriously delicious pan of eggs mixed with a somewhat odd assortment of various vegetables and ground beef.Super simple dish that is a perfect mixture of sweet and savory.  Sweetness mainly coming from the maduros (sweet plantains) which makes this better than pretty much any other egg casserole out there.There are other things on the buffet, such as your standardized American pancakes and french toast, but I stay away from that and stick with huge helpings of the above mentioned dish, the avena de coco (coconut oatmeal), the Puerto Rican style fried chicken (chopped, bone and all, into small pieces and fried crispy), and maduros.Stick with the Puerto Rican food here.  It really is very good.If the pastelone de huevos really isn't satisfying your egginess enough, saddle on up to the omelet maker and have him cook up a made-to-order omelet for you.About the only thing that I really missed having the chance to eat on the brunch line to complete my Puerto Rican feast would be a nice helping of mofongo.While you're at it, check out the art on the walls.  My favorite piece: Buddy Jesus and his Harley Davidson (not sure if that is the real name of it).
Tasty, hearty breakfast.

I'm not a breakfast person, but this meal made me a believer.The proof? It's in the pudding... er, oatmeal!The deets on Nellie's Breakfast Special:Cup of coconut oatmeal sprinkled with cinnamon. Aka 'heaven in a bowl'.A huge, fluffy omelet bursting with goodies such as peppers, onions, cheese, and ham. AND it's topped with sliced plantains, and served with garlicky toasted bread.All of this? Less than $9. Parking is easy, the service is swell and the coffee is a-ok.Can't wait to come back for the Puerto Rican buffet... worth every last calorie I'm sure!

Hello Nellie's!! I wanted to try something new so my breakfast buddy and hooked up and went to this quaint little place. We read there was some big wait times but we go there about 11ish so the wait was next to nothing. Im guess because Sunday mass was still in across the street. I was also intrigued because of the strange hours of operations (Wed-Sun 9am-3pm)  We went with the buffet ($16.00 all you can eat) They had an awesome elderly gentleman there hooking up the freshly made omelets right in front of you all while telling great stories of his days as a young man in Puerto Rico. He made everything with fresh veggies and a special seasoning that he could/would not reveal the secret to. Hmmm They also had French toast, Pancakes, Chicken, Rice and the famous Coconut Oatmeal. Yes. I did have seconds of that. Another awesome bonus was all available juice was included in the buffet! This was quite a good choice and I will be back. If you're in Humbolt Park make a stop at this neat little place.

A fantastic breakfast and lunch place right on the corner of our street. We've never been disappointed with Nellie's and take all our out of town guests there. The breakfast buffet is the way to go, seriously- because if you order stuff separately (like I always want a breakfast casserole, the oatmeal and an OJ), your bill is already about $13- so why not get an omelette you can custom order, all the coconut oatmeal you can eat, and any other specialities they happen to make that day? Be prepared to nap though...seriously....nap....mmmmm.

The only reason I am not giving 5 stars is because of the disorganized table service. Maybe if we had had the buffet we would have fared (pun) better. But seriously, the coconut oatmeal is SO good. I had a chorizo and egg breakfast which was outstanding as well. The side order of "one egg" for our daughter had to have been like 4 scrambled eggs and the hot chocolate they brought her was creamy and delicious. We loved the coffee, but didn't like that we had to wait for refills. Everything we needed we literally had to flag down someone to help us:  napkins (there's a 5 year old at the table--a waiter should just set those down first thing!), a place setting for all three of us (until our food was served there were only 2), actual milk or cream instead of those homogenized plastic packet thingys would have been preferred. But the food on the plate itself? I will certainly be back someday for that. So wonderful and worth the spotty table service.

Horrible service with an attitude. Arrived at 1 ordered the buffet to discover that there was very little left and it was lukewarm. When I asked the waitress to cancel my order, she began to argue with me. The owner then came out and apologized that the food was low and offered to make me a fresh plate. At that point my hunger had surpassed and I was upset and list me appetite. I want to support restaurants that work hard at providing good food and service but I'm sorry to say this one has missed that goal completely. I will never come back here and don't recommend it.

This is truly a hidden gem ! I have gone here quite a few times and it just gets better each time. Best deal is the buffet brunch. Food is great and service was outstanding. Shout out to the servers Ashley and Eddie always know what I'm going to order.
Excellent foodExcellent serviceExcellent ambianceDid I mention excellent food and service???

This will be a long one but I've never experienced such rude service.Extremely disappointed with this place. I ordered a pizza on a Friday night and knew the wait would be long but I never expected a 1 hr 45 min wait for a small stuffed. The girl on the phone seemed to not know what she was doing, told me my card was declined, and then said never mind it went through.When the pizza finally arrived I gave the delivery driver a really nice tip EVEN though it had taken so long. I kept hearing my phone going off in the next room and when I finally answered it was the manager saying quite rudely and loudly that if I didn't pay for the pizza NOW she was going to call the cops. That the driver had been knocking and no one had paid! I tried explaining to her that the girl on the phone said it had gone through just fine but was cut off.One we never heard knocking at the door. Two there was no need for her to act up the way she did when it was a simple misunderstanding. And then she hung up as soon as I gave her my card information. I was pissed off. Never have I ever been spoken to like that by a "manager". AND the pizza wasn't even good. Barely any sauce. I'm NEVER ordering from this giordanos again.

Food was a 4 but what happened when we paid is another story that left a very bad taste in my mouth.Got deep dish pizza, good ingredient, great taste, made to order. Way less greasy than I anticipated, which is great.However, upon paying, waitress took our credit cards and then came back to ask for ID stating that her manager would need to see the ID's. Didn't think twice and handed the waitress our ID's. She took them to her manager.This is when I thought it was highly strange and irregular that they had to take our ID's out of our sight. So I went back to the cash register where the apparently appointed  manager was running credit cards, I told her I thought it was entirely inappropriate to have our ID's taken to her and I needed my ID right there.This is highly inappropriate and now I wonder if they are running a scheme. There is absolutely no need for this, the waitress can ID customers without taking their cards where God knows what they can do with them (scanning machine, copies, etc)Very disappointing end to what could have been an ok meal. Now, I am wondering if I will be the victim of credit fraud.I am alerting my credit cards and mentioning them as a potential source of future problems.Oh, and the "manager" acted surprise when i told her I need my ID CARD back. Unbelievable bad commercial manners, what a witch! Will not return in the future.

The best pizza pie in Chicago! I came here for the first time and will most certainly be back. Giordano's was recommended to me from a friend and he was not wrong! We sat at the bar and Debbie took care of us. She was friendly and very helpful.I ordered one of the pies, it takes 45 minutes once you order it, but it's well worth the wait. That's what a pitcher of beer is for anyway, right? My friend ordered a thin crust and loved his as well.
